column2: Useful in its day, the General Mining Law of 1872 is a disaster now.
Could it be that something as abstract and elemental as fun has been so commodified and consumerized that cutthroat manufacturers in China could cast doubt on whether our children will have any?
We will never know just how much better the fight in Afghanistan might be going if it had been managed more competently over the past six years.
More than 60 people were killed when the Church of San Clemente in Pisco, Peru, collapsed during an earthquake, but some have drawn faith from what they see as small miracles.
Americans who have lost their homes may be subject to income taxes on their canceled debt.
A damaged valve may have sent tons of water into the basement of the Deutsche Bank tower, keeping it from air-starved firefighters battling the blaze above.

Alexander Vinokourov has accused cycling authorities of violating human rights and vowed to clear his name after failing a doping test last month at the Tour de France.Vinokourov, 33, in his native Kazakhstan for the first time since his expulsion from the Tour, said riders were being subjected to doping controls beyond those of other sports.“In cycling, nobody respects human rights,” Vinokourov said.Vinokourov, a prerace favorite at the Tour, tested positive for doping after winning a time trial July 21. He was fired by his Astana team, which has been banned from next month’s Tour of Spain.

Alabama cornerback Simeon Castille was arrested early yesterday on a disorderly conduct charge.A Tuscaloosa, Ala., police spokesman, Capt. Greg Kosloff, said Castille was arrested in an entertainment district near campus. The police declined to release details of the incident.Castille was one of the top defensive backs in the Southeastern Conference last season. He is the fourth Alabama player to be arrested in the last two months.
Shameka Christon hit a crucial 3-pointer with 23.9 seconds remaining, capping a 9-2 run that the Liberty used to finish off the Sky at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.

Sevilla got its season off to a glittering start by winning its fifth trophy in a little more than a year with a 5-3 victory against Real Madrid in the second leg of the Spanish Supercup. Frederic Kanouté scored three goals and Renato two, making Sevilla the winner by a 6-3 aggregate.

Roma defeated Inter Milan, 1-0, to win only its second Supercup, Italy’s traditional season opener.Daniele De Rossi converted a penalty in the 78th minute after Francesco Totti was fouled by Inter defender Nicolas Burdisso.The Serie A season kicks off Saturday.

Manchester City defeated the defending champion, Manchester United, 1-0, yesterday, giving Sven-Goran Eriksson his third shutout in three games as a manager in the English Premier League. Geovanni, one of Eriksson’s eight preseason signings, scored the winning goal in the 31st minute. City leads the league with 9 points, 2 more than Chelsea.

One motorcyclist was killed and another injured yesterday when they were struck by a car after pulling to the side of the road on the Jackie Robinson Parkway, the police said. The motorcyclists had stopped on the parkway’s narrow eastbound shoulder, near the Metropolitan Avenue exit in Kew Gardens, to wait for a third rider when they were hit by a black 2001 Acura, whose driver remained at the scene, a police spokesman said. One of the motorcyclists, Leon Vanhatten, 47, was pronounced dead at the scene, while the other, who was not identified, was taken in stable condition to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, according to the spokesman. As of last night, the authorities had not filed charges against the Acura driver.
It is becoming increasingly clear that New York needs a state pension board whose members are chosen very publicly and for their financial expertise, not their political connections.

A gunman fired at least five shots into a car stopped at a traffic light in Mott Haven yesterday, killing its driver and injuring a front-seat passenger, the police said. The shooting happened at 5 a.m. at the corner of East 138th Street and the Grand Concourse, near the access ramp to the Madison Avenue Bridge, the police said. A second passenger, who was seated in the rear and was not injured in the shooting, jumped to the driver’s seat and rushed the men to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. The driver, Francisco de la Cruz, 27, was pronounced dead shortly after 7:30 a.m., according to a police spokesman. The injured passenger, also 27, whose name was not released, was listed in critical condition last night. The three men had left a nightclub in the neighborhood and were westbound on East 138th Street when they came under fire, the police said. It was unclear last night what led to the shooting, and there were no arrests.
In its first year as a living entity, the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup points race has been embraced and embellished, mocked and misunderstood.

A woman, whom the police identified yesterday as Shirley Kelly, 56, was killed in an apartment fire in Brownsville on Saturday evening. The fire was reported in her apartment on Mother Gaston Boulevard about 7 p.m., the police said. Ms. Kelly was pronounced dead at the scene. The cause of the fire was under investigation, the police said.

A booming real estate market, combined with a 120-year-old state law that allocates a fixed portion of local taxes to libraries, has created a surplus that has reached into the millions of dollars for some libraries in towns on the Jersey Shore. In Avalon, where the valuation of taxable real estate has tripled since 2004, $2.3 million will go to the town library this year. In Ocean City, officials expect a library surplus of more than $4 million. Advocates say the law protects libraries from budget cuts, but some town officials want the law changed to allow them discretion in spending some of the money. “Some of these towns, their library systems cannot possibly spend the amount of money they are collecting,” said William Dressel Jr., the executive director of the State League of Municipalities, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Rookie Brian Leonard is getting a lot of playing time for the Rams, as the team conserves starter Steven Jackson.
The six men trapped in a collapsed mine nearly two weeks ago may never be found, mining officials said.
As legions of workers across the globe face new barriers to migration, professionals find more welcome mats.
A rapid river current swept away 15 members of a religious group in western Mexico on Sunday, drowning at least nine.
Monday night, Colts quarterback Jim Sorgi and the other backups will take center stage in a rematch of the Super Bowl competitors in Indianapolis.
Police described an 18-year-old man arrested on Sunday as the final suspect in a triple murder that has rocked Newark.
A former assistant treasurer of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland is to go on trial for taking part in looting of church funds.
As students return to classes at Virginia Tech, the campus is walking a fine line between remembering and moving on.
A New Jersey couple is charged with animal cruelty after more than 100 neglected cats and dogs were found living in squalid conditions in their $2.4 million home.
Hurricane Dean left a trail of destruction as it surged across the Caribbean on Sunday, toppling buildings on islands along its periphery and taking at least eight lives.
Zane Ancell hit a home run and struck out 11 to lead undefeated Lubbock, Tex., to a 5-1 victory against Chandler, Ariz., at the Little League World Series on Sunday.

Johan Santana set a franchise record with 17 strikeouts in eight innings yesterday to lead the host Minnesota Twins past the Texas Rangers, 1-0. The Twins have scored only four runs in their past five games at the Metrodome, three of them wins.
Pakistan’s prime minister said American involvement in negotiations between the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and the opposition politician Benazir Bhutto could hurt the parties involved.
Darrelle Revis’s fresh legs may have been the only advantage he had over his teammates as he took his first steps toward assimilating into the secondary and making up for lost downs.
Lorena Ochoa posted her second consecutive victory and fifth of the season, closing with a two-under-par 69 Sunday for a three-stroke victory at the Canadian Open in Edmonton, Alberta.
Joybubbles was a blind genius with perfect pitch who played a pivotal role in the 1970s subculture of “phone phreaks.”
After receiving treatment Sunday morning for inflammation in her right shoulder, Justine Henin defeated Jelena Jankovic for her second career Rogers Cup title.

ABOUT THE SERIES — They are the leading causes of illness and death in the United States today: heart disease, cancer, stroke, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s disease, in that order. And they have a lot in common.
Mark Teixeira drove in four runs with two home runs yesterday and John Smoltz became the Braves’ strikeout leader as Atlanta beat the Arizona Diamondbacks, 6-2, at home.
The German woman was kidnapped Saturday in Kabul and freed early Monday in a joint raid by Afghan intelligence services and the police.
The visit by the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, was the highest level visit by a French official to Iraq since the 2003 invasion.

MASON, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) — Top-ranked Roger Federer reached another measure of tennis greatness Sunday, winning his 50th tournament title by defeating James Blake, 6-1, 6-4, in the Western & Southern Financial Group Masters.
A steady rain on Sunday forced NASCAR to postpone the 3M Performance 400 Nextel Cup race until Monday.
On a tour through Iowa farming communities, Rudolph W. Giuliani endured the test of making small talk.
Israeli human rights groups condemned the deportation of the migrants, many of whom were said to be Sudanese refugees.
Here are five things that Dr. John Buse, director of the Diabetes Care Center at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, says everyone with diabetes should know.
It may just be that more people are learning they have diabetes, not that the number of those with it is increasing.
On Staten Island, about 40 riders took part in an “alleycat” -- a race designed to replicate the daily work of a bicycle messenger.
President Nursultan Nazarbayev’s governing party won all of the 98 contested seats in an election that drew criticism from international observers.
Amid a temporary ban, a battle over fishing rights pits a French village against an industrial Spanish fleet in the Bay of Biscay.
The body of a man missing since a highway bridge collapsed into the Mississippi River was recovered, bringing the confirmed death toll to 12.
The six men trapped in a violent collapse deep within a mountain mine nearly two weeks ago may never be found, grim-faced mining officials said Sunday.
Voters in Thailand approved a new constitution in a referendum on Sunday, taking a step toward ending nearly a year of military rule.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,694 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
A Red Sox fan goes on a first date, a woman eating ice cream falls over and a dog wears glasses.

EYE ON THE ECONOMY Wall Street will be looking for signs of whether the recent volatility in the credit and stock markets could spread to the broader economy. The Conference Board will issue its index of leading economic indicators for July (Monday), and there will be reports on durable goods for July and new home sales for July (Friday).
F. Murray Abraham is to star in a double bill of one-acts by Edward Albee in the spring.
Joba Chamberlain retired the side with two strikeouts in the seventh inning and Edwar Ramirez followed with two perfect innings to close out the victory for the Yankees.
Carlos Beltrán hit a two-run homer in the ninth, his second of the game, to finish off the Mets’ scoring and make Orlando Hernández a winner for the first time since July 28.
Europe’s top appeals court will announce its decision Sept. 17 on Microsoft’s appeal of Europe’s largest antitrust case ever.
“Countdown With Keith Olbermann” will be shown on network television, “Superbad” scored at the weekend movie box office and more culture news.

My Chemical Romance, Big & Rich, Gretchen Wilson, Daughtry and the All-American Rejects will each have two chances to be the opening act for Bon Jovi when these New Jersey rockers perform a 10-concert series to mark the grand opening of the $375 million Prudential Center in Newark.
An “ultimate Elvis tribute artist” is named, and Hunter Foster will appear in “Frankenstein.”
The Sunday Times of London reported that J. K. Rowling is working on a new book, a detective novel, and has been spotted in action at an Edinburgh cafe.
The National Theater of Greece and the Pennsylvania Ballet will appear at City Center in the fall.
A haunted house inspired by actual paranormal experiences will take over the Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center.

“Countdown With Keith Olbermann” the highly rated cable news program, will be shown on network television on Sunday before a preseason NBC football game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers.
The teenage sex comedy “Superbad,” from Sony Pictures, scored at the box office over the weekend.
“Invisible Wings,” a work being revived at the Jacob’s Pillow dance festival, weaves movement with African-American storytelling and 19th-century slave songs.
The news marks a surprising turn in the tax-shelter case against former KPMG employees and two executives.
There is something slightly unnerving about the kind of attention R. Kelly’s audiovisual opus, “Trapped in the Closet,” has received.
When shareholders gather to approve an $8.2 billion plan to take Tribune private, an uncomfortable question is sure to be on many of their minds: Will this deal fall apart?
As problems in subprime mortgage lending have expanded into the broader markets, hedge funds have come face to face with the ghost of past financial crises.
Ben S. Bernanke, grappling with his first major predicament as Fed chairman, is being intently watched to see how he handles the reins of the economy.
A precipitous slowdown in advertising growth has raised new questions about AOL’s transformation plans.
Fans of The Simpsons TV series have been bidding up Kwik-E-Mart mementos for sale on eBay that are left over from a promotion for “The Simpsons Movie.”

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) — Members of a union representing about 2,000 hourly workers of the Delphi Corporation, the auto parts supplier, voted to ratify a new four-year contract with Delphi, the union said.
The company said its Internet phone service had returned to normal after a software problem left many users unable to log on for two days.
A new research paper co-written by the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve says that consumer debt soared over the last six years mainly because of the rapid increase in housing prices.
Greeting card companies hope to promote the idea that cards can be sent anytime, not just on holidays and special occasions.
Lincoln Center seems to be taking a proactive approach to adding new works to the repertory, using Osvaldo Golijov’s “Pasión Según San Marcos” as its test case.
The message of this latest “Grease” is that anyone, famous or not, can star in a Broadway musical.
In a program presented by his company, Nicholas Andre Dance Theater, Nick Seligson-Ross’s attraction to athletic prowess was on vigorous display.
“Away” is a modest name for a book as gloriously transporting as Amy Bloom’s new novel.
Ever since the Atlantic Monthly’s crossword puzzle disappeared from the print magazine over a year ago, its fans have been complaining loudly.
Hoping to alleviate a frustration of mobile computing, Hewlett-Packard has introduced a free service designed to make it possible to print documents on any printer almost anywhere in the world.
The Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation is bringing back for a second year a multimedia campaign called 30 Days of Fashion.
This month, 10 of Time Inc.’s magazines are running articles about New Orleans, the result of editor in chief John Huey’s  decision to take 12 editors on a two-day tour of the struggling city.
New releases from Rilo Kiley, Hurricane Chris, Floratone and the Mekons.
The domination of two legal research services over the publication of federal and state court decisions is being challenged by an Internet gadfly.
In this show, the latest televised attempt to make Americans look like extraterrestrials, a guy named Leon Logothetis makes his way from sea to shining sea on $5 a day.
Last week, Fox decided not to renew “1/2 Hour News Hour,” the network’s answer to left-wing news parodies, saying it was too expensive to produce.
While Americans may feel bombarded by media information, we seem to be consuming less of it.
Accounts.
Among Internet businesses, perhaps only VistaPrint has managed to reach a market value of more than $1 billion by getting customers to hand out millions of promotional messages for it.
The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.
In the second quarter of the year, the news media paid increased attention to the presidential campaign and the immigration debate.
Mike Godwin’s job is to defend an online encyclopedia created by tens of thousands of (often anonymous) contributors who comment freely on living people and businesses.
Pair events can make players take unwise actions as they try to outscore the players holding the same cards at the other tables.

8 P.M. (BBC America) TOP GEAR This popular British automobile series, which uses stunts, time trials and road tests to assess the performance of the most lusted-after cars on the planet, makes its United States debut with back-to-back episodes. First up: Richard Hammond, above, Jeremy Clarkson and James May, the show’s hosts, attempt to turn a minivan into a convertible by putting a retractable roof on a Renault Espace. The result? It’s a bit like trying to cut your own hair; you could, but you probably shouldn’t. Then the men try out new models, during which Mr. Clarkson gets excited by the Koenigsegg CCX, Mr. May finds the Honda Civic newfangled enough to want to drive it again, and Mr. Hammond doesn’t like the Micra C+C one little bit. In Episode 2 the team takes a road trip to Iceland and meets up with the chef Gordon Ramsay, who sets a track record for — yep — swearing.

The top 40 people cited in the world’s 56 million blogs, as tracked on BlogPulse.com, tend to be political figures like Rudolph W. Giuliani, above, and celebrities like Britney Spears. Four presidential candidates made the top 10 list on Friday. Hillary Rodham Clinton was No. 11 that day: since July 20, she has otherwise fallen from the top 10 on Aug. 12, the day Merv Griffin died and the day after the Iowa straw poll, and on July 22, when Harry Potter characters took six of the top 10 slots.
Until a suitable alternative is found, DDT remains the cheapest and most effective long-term malaria fighter we have.
I sweat. I am a sweater.
“I’m really shy or introverted,” many readers say. “How can I make my accomplishments known?”
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Webdenda.
Death penalty cases can take a long time. Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales wants to move things along.
Did you hear the one about the punter who prosecuted the punter who knifed the punter? It’s no joke and may be the most warped example of bad sports, the furthest case of all from funny.

Once again yesterday, officials trying to assess the damage walked down the block across from ground zero, past the former Deutsche Bank building, partly dismantled and now charred, but still there. And once again, people who live in the neighborhood were uneasy.
Once a 41-story skyscraper, 130 Liberty Street has seemed foredoomed since the days immediately after 9/11 and almost jinxed in the years since then.
Researchers are struggling with a fundamental question. Why does high blood sugar lead to any of the diabetes's complications - heart disease, stroke, nerve damage?
The death of a firefighter has become a familiar event at the firehouse of Engine 24 and Ladder 5 in SoHo.
Jennings Lilly has been turning again and again to the television news reports, his thoughts flashing back to the time when he was trapped for 10 days in a mine.
At least 20 separate mayday calls -- the most desperate call for help a firefighter can register -- were made during Saturday’s blaze at the Deutsche Bank building.
Doubleday will publish Vanity Fair writer Michael Wolff’s biography of Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation.
Imprisoned for tax evasion and fraud, she was widely regarded as a 1980s symbol of arrogance and greed.
In a television tour of three shows, Karl Rove, President Bush’s chief political adviser, complained that Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill were pursuing him relentlessly.
As Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton disagreed, contenders who had been toiling with less fanfare reminded voters not to forget the alternatives.
Dick Cheney once scoffed that energy conservation can be a “personal virtue” but is no basis for an energy policy. Growing evidence suggests he had it exactly wrong.
New-fashioned bank runs are at the heart of the current financial crisis.

RELIN--Roslyn. On August 16, 2007. Cherished aunt of Neil Relin, and Margaret Relin Judge; adoring great-aunt of Banjamin Wade Judge; beloved friend and mother to the world. A memorial service will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, please donate in Roz's name to your children's charity of choice. For a future album, please send testimonials and/or stories to Margaret Judge, 3341 Rittenhouse Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20015.
INTERNATIONALA3-7 Hurricane Hits Caribbean, 8 Die Amid Destruction

SULLIVAN--Cornelius F., Jr. , of Scarsdale on August 17, 2007. Husband of the late Irene, father of Corey Sullivan, Mark Sullivan and Erin Anderson, grandfather of Aimee Sullivan and Anthony Hill, uncle of Peter, Michael and Debbie Sullivan. Mr. Sullivan was an attorney since 1950, graduate of Fordham University and Harvard Law School, former Associate Vice President of Business Affairs for Children's Television Workshop. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 pm, Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale on Wednesday, August 22 at 10:30 am.

WEGNER--Walter , 87, passed away on August 16 in Port Washington, NY. Devoted husband of Patricia, beloved father of Karen Pilant and Wendy Wegner. A retired big band and Broadway musician. He will be remembered for his sense of humor, courtly manner and kindness.

KORMAN--Sinclair , of Redding, CT, died August 8, 2007. He was a U.S. Navy veteran of WWII, leaving the service with the rank of Lt. Commander. In 1983, he retired as C.E.O. of Marshall Sinclair, Ltd. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Martha; his daughter Gail Samuelson (John); his sons Jeffrey (Keshia) and David Korman; his grandchildren, Ariel Samuelson Winn (Adam), Jake and Jessie Samuelson and Noah and Maia Korman; and his sister, Florence Barrack. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Mark Twain Library, P.O. Box 1009, Redding, CT 06875.

PERRY--Florence Louise , died August 17 in her 90th year. Retired Chase employee, passionate traveler, lover of performing and all arts, dedicated volunteer to Lincoln Center, NYU Hospital and New York City children. Devoted to her family, Florence was a beloved daughter, sister, sister-in-law, aunt, grandaunt and friend. Services at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue at 29th Street, on Monday, August 20 at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in her name may be made to Marble Collegiate Church or the New York City Ballet.

DEAVER--Michael K. Our 3,000 staff members worldwide join in grieving the passing of Michael K. Deaver. He brought his communications skills to our firm and for 15 years served as teacher and guiding spirit for all of us. He was truly beloved and in his final comments to our group at a recent meeting in San Francisco, he expressed his love for our firm and its leadership. Farewell good friend. Rest in peace. Daniel J. Edelman, Inc. Dan Edelman, Founder and Chairman. Richard Edelman, President and CEO. Pam Talbot, President U.S. Rob Regh, General Manager, D.C. office.

WARMBOLD--Herman P. , entered an eternal sleep on August 16, 2007. Born in Berlin, Germany in 1927; Herman was deprived of much of his childhood having been appointed to be a German antiaircraft gunner, at the age of fifteen, a crew member of a German PT boat at seventeen and a POW of the US Army at age eighteen. In 1947 Herman and his family relocated to Chile. At the age of 27 he immigrated to the United States via New York City where he received a B.S. degree in Economics and a Masters in Business Administration from NYU. In 1963 he began a new chapter of his life by marrying Grace Staub. Herman and Grace were living in New York City when he co-founded the executive search firm Staub Warmbold & Associates. In 1990 the family relocated to Florida where Herman dedicated his life to a Lapiz Lazuli Mine in Chile; Las Flores de Los Andes. He remained a principal of such until his death. His daughter Kimberly, sister Hilda, nieces and nephews say good-bye to a valiant man. His ashes will be spread across the sea in both Florida and Chile. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Andre Agassi Charitable Foundation for underprivileged children.

SCHEIDT--Stephen. Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, its Board of Directors, Officers, and Staff notes with deep sadness the death of Dr. Stephen Scheidt, a truly esteemed former Board Member, colleague, and friend. He will be dearly missed and fondly remembered for his many years of devoted service to the health needs of the people of New York as an exemplary physician, educator, and tireless fiduciary leader in his work as an Empire Board Member. Empire extends its deepest sympathy to the entire Scheidt family. Mark Wagar President and CEO, Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield

ROSENBERG--Frances P. , of Lawrence, MA and New York City. Born 1916, died August 18, 2007. Beloved sister of the late Harold N. Rosenberg and Lillian G. Ross. Aunt, greataunt, and great-great-aunt. Aunt Faye is survived by Paul D. Rosenberg of Morristown, NJ and Nancy R. Reinish of New York City, and Ellen and Ruth Rosenberg of Philadelphia, PA.
FINKELSTEIN--Sally, Fe bruary 1, 1907 to August 19, 2002. Gold, diamonds, rubies, emeralds. As always, your family

RILO KILEY ''Under the Blacklight'' (Warner Brothers) The new Rilo Kiley album lasts only 37 minutes, but that may be long enough to flummox old fans. Over the course of three full-length albums, Rilo Kiley became the quintessential Los Angeles indie-rock band, and Jenny Lewis, the lead singer, has become a low-key rock star. She also sang on a hit CD by the Postal Service, and last year she released a well-received (though uneven) solo album, ''Rabbit Fur Coat.'' Some people probably wondered whether the old band would ever return.

TOUMEY--Dorothy Agnes Henry , of New Canaan, CT passed away August 16, 2007 with her family at her side. Beloved wife of the late Hugh J. Toumey, father of Donald J. and Kenneth D. Toumey, sister of Ethel H. White, and grandmother of Meghan E., Paul D. and Kerry A. Toumey. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Monday, August 20, 2007, at 10am at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Connecticut. Interment will follow at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan. The family will receive friends at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, Connecticut on Sunday, August 19, 2007, from 4-8pm.

THE MEKONS ''Natural'' (Quarterstick/Touch and Go) Perhaps it was inevitable that the Mekons would get around to an album of bucolic themes. Thirty years on this post-punk band from Leeds, England -- some of the members live in America now -- is still poetically shambly-bumbly. The Mekons are almost classicists now, reflexively favoring what's old and textured. And they're skilled at it, finding easy sweet spots of ragged harmony when they put their voices together.

HARVEY--Larry D. , 69, died peacefully at home in East Hampton, NY, on Wednesday August 15th, after a valiant struggle with cancer. He was the beloved husband of Donna, loving father of Pamela and Susan, father-in-law of Jay and Darin, and adoring grandfather of Jason, Hunter, Courtney, Zach, Sam and Lily. Born in Mexico, Missouri, he was a graduate of Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri, and received an advanced degree in Hotel Management from the University of Denver. Larry was for many years a highly respected member of the hotel community in New York City; serving as the Executive Director of Catering at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for eleven years and then as the Executive Director of Catering at The Plaza for 15 years. He was a member of the University Club in New York City and served on the Board of Directors of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation. He was a member of the Waldorf-Astoria Distinguished Alumni Association and a recipient of the Westminster College Alumni Award, as well as a Churchill Fellow of Westminster College. Larry was a recipient of the Cardinal's Award for Humanitarian Efforts, Hospitality & Tourism Division, awarded by the Archdiocese of New York and, also, a recipient of the Jerusalem Founders Man of the Year Award, presented by Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem. One of his proudest accomplishments was in being the author of ''A Plaza Wedding'', published by Villard Books, a division of Random House, in 1996. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 25th, at 3:00pm at the Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 94 Pantigo Road, East Hampton, New York, to be followed by a reception to celebrate Larry's life at the Maidstone Arms on Main Street, East Hampton, New York. Larry's family and friends will cherish all the good memories he leaves behind. Memorial contributions in Larry's name may be made to the Jeffrey Modell Foundation, 747 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017. HARVEY--Lawrence D. The Members of The Waldorf Astoria Distinguished Alumni Association mourn the passing of our fellow confrere, Larry Harvey. Our thoughts and prayers are with his lovely wife, Donna, his daughters, Pam and Susan, their spouses and his six grandchildren. You brightened the lights of New York on your arrival in 1978, they will be a little dimmer with your passing. Your contributions to the hospitality industry and fellow human being will be part of your legacy. Your friend and colleague, John G. Flynn, Chairman

SOLOMON--Dr. Robert , on August 17, 2007, at age 75. Husband of Bonnie (Rubin), father of David, Yoram and Tara Solomon, grandfather of Jordan Solomon and brother of Geraldine Phillips and Pearl Shampain. Graveside service Tuesday 1pm, Cedar Park Cemetery. Services by Zion Memorial Chapel, 914-381-1809.
LEVIN--Jane Hochstadter , 95. Predeceased by husband Maurice. Survived by daughter Linda Saeks (Allen). Private Interment.

HURRICANE CHRIS ''Louisi-Animal'' Hurricane Chris, a previously obscure 18-year-old rapper from Shreveport, La., scored one of the summer's biggest and most addictive hip-hop hits with ''A Bay Bay,'' currently No. 9 on Billboard's Hot 100 chart. And yet J Records doesn't plan to release his debut album until Oct. 16. What's an impatient hip-hop fan to do? (And is there any other kind?)

WARNER--John D., ''Jack'' on August 17, 2007, Jack Warner died after a long-term battle with cancer. Born on July 19, 1930 to Leonard Joseph Warner and Mary Howard Warner of Westfield, MA. Warner graduated from Westfield High School and Yale (Class of 1953). He also played semi - professional baseball. Warner served as an infantry officer in the Marine Corps during the Korean War and later worked in public service in Boston. Warner lived on Nantucket for many years. He wrote four successful books, including his recent memoir ''Reflections in the Rearview Mirror.'' He leaves beloved wife Polly, four children, three stepchildren, and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brother, Leonard Joseph Warner, Jr., of Westfield. Nickerson Funeral Home in Chatham will hold a wake on Monday, August 20 from 2-5pm and 7-9 pm. A funeral mass will be held at Holy Redeemer Church in Chatham at 10am on Tuesday August 21. Burial services will be held on Nantucket Wednesday, August 22. In lieu of flowers: Marines Helping Marines, Marine Corps League, P.O. Box 141, Westminster, MD 21158. Checks payable to: Department of Maryland MCL Or: Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation, P.O. Box 3008, Princeton, NJ 08543. Memo: in memory of John D. Warner.

GROSSMAN--Charles. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York, its Board of Trustees, clergy and administration mourn the untimely passing of Charles Grossman, former trustee and VicePresident of the Congregation. His was the intellect of wisdom, the voice of reason, and the heart of goodness. He lead us in straight and good paths. We shall miss him. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary GROSSMAN--Charles. A good man and good friend is lost far too soon. We will really miss you, Charlie. Our heartfelt condolences to Carol, Ellie and Laura. Susan and David Rahm GROSSMAN--Charles on August 18th. Beloved husband of Carol and father of Ellie Grossman (Ray Fisman) and Laura Grossman. Born September 13, 1943 in Houston, TX. Graduate of Harvard College and Columbia University, MBA and JD. Respected real estate investor and advisor. Recognized for his integrity, decency and kindness. Trustee of Temple Emanu-El of NYC, Orchestra of St. Luke's and Manhattan School of Music. Founding member of the Real Estate Academic Initiative at Harvard University. Former Chairman of the Pension Real Estate Association and former Chairman of the International Council of Shopping Centers. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday 6:00pm8:30pm. Services Tuesday August 21st, 2pm at Temple Emanu-El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Orchestra of St. Luke's NYC, The Skirball Center of Temple Emanu-El, Manhattan School of Music or St. John's School, Houston TX.

YASGUR--Irving. You embraced us with your strength, gentleness, love of life and family. We never called you Irving, you were dad and grandpa. We will love you always and think of you often. Harvey, Arlene, David, Drew and Noah

Some United States military veterans who were injured while serving in Iraq participated in the Parapan American Games in Rio de Janeiro. The event ended last night. Most are hoping to make it to the 2008 Paralympics in Beijing. Competing is a way for the veterans to adjust to life after the war and honor the memories of fellow soldiers who were killed.

SEEVAK--Sheldon , born in Boston, MA on May 28, 1929, died suddenly on Saturday, August 18. Sheldon was a former partner of Goldman Sachs, where he founded the real estate department. Since retiring from Goldman Sachs, he was involved with a number of philanthropic organizations. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, great-uncle, friend and mentor. He is survived by his wife, Elinor A. Seevak; his daughters Alison Seevak and Marina Seevak; his son Evan Seevak; his daughter-in-law Sarah Pearson; his grandchildren Gabriel, Emma, Abigail, Nathaniel, and Anna; his sisters Roddy Langsam and Jacqui Seevak Sanders; his sisters and brothers-in-law Amy and Henry Singer and Gerri and Larry Alpert; and numerous nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 21st at 11am at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1868 Beacon St., Brookline, MA.

Michael K. Deaver, who arranged some of Ronald Reagan's most memorable photographic backdrops for public consumption and privately gave the president blunt, sometimes contrarian advice, died Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 69. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his family said.

LUGER--Norton M., M.D. Loving husband of Rosalind Massow for 48 years, treasured uncle, delightful friend, and a truly caring physician suddenly on August 18. Dr. Luger was the first Chief of Medicine at Booth Memorial Hospital, Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Medical School, former President of Queens County Medical Society, former Vice Chair of Board of Directors of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Greater NY, Fellow of NY Academy of Medicine, Member of Sigma Xi, Captain in the U.S. Army, Honorary Police Surgeon and medical activist. Funeral Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel (180 W. 76th St.) at 12:45pm on August 21. Donations sent to Cornell Medical School.

HERSKOWITZ--Bertha on August 18, 2007. Beloved wife of Sandor Herskowitz. Loving mother of Esther (David) Malach, Allen (Bonnie) Herskowitz and Renee (Tom) Mauriello. Adored by her grandchildren Stephen (Jen), Jamie, Kara, Sydney, Christopher, Mathew and Harrison, and great-granddaughter Sarah. A beautiful, kind woman with a heart of gold, our Mutti, our Ama, who asked for very little but gave so much. She survived Auchwitz but couldn't overcome Alzheimer's disease. Shiva will be held at the home of Esther Malach, Riverdale NY.

FLORATONE (Blue Note) Floratone is an instrumental collective made up of the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell, the drummer Matt Chamberlain and two producers, Lee Townsend and Tucker Martine. As the odd lineup suggests, its self-titled debut comes with some process-heavy back story: about how Mr. Frisell and Mr. Chamberlain improvised in the studio, and how their producers spliced and shaped the results into song sketches, which the musicians then fleshed out.

McCULLOUGH--Robert Willis , on Tuesday, August 14, 2007 at Greenwich Hospital after a brief illness. Robert W. McCullough, 86, was born on September 19, 1920 in Montclair, NJ to Mr. and Mrs. W. G. McCullough. He grew up at Cummings Point in Stamford. He attended the Brunswick School, graduated from The Taft School and Brown University. He served in World War II as a Commander Officer of a Destroyer Escort. He spent his working years as a Senior Officer of the Collins and Aikman Company an later as Chairman of the Board of the Chesapeake Petroleum Co. He was on the Board of Trustees of Brown University and Chairman of South Street Seaport Museum. Mr. McCullough served as Commodore at Riverside Yacht Club and The New York Yacht Club. A distinguished sailor, he was active for many years in the America's Cup, he skippered Constellation in the 1967 Cup trials, was business manager of the Courageous Syndicate when she victoriously defended the Cup, and Chairman of the America's Cup Committee. He also successfully raced his yachts, INVERNESS. He was a member of the Cruising Club of America, The Storm Trysail Club, The Pawling Mountain Club and for 30 years a member of the Fales Committee at the United States Naval Academy. The beloved husband for 65 years of Margaret Hammons McCullough and adored father of Constance LindsayStewart of Redding, CT, Sandra Margaret McCullough of Riverside, CT, D. Scott McCullough of Boothbay Harbor Maine and Linda Anne McCullough of Cos Cob, CT, father-in-law of Michael LindsayStewart, sisters Dorothy McCullough of Riverside and Marilyn Thyrre of Coral Gables, Florida and many devoted nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sisters, Margaret Simpson and Patricia deGraff and his brother Donald F. McCullough. A memorial service will be held at 11am, September 21 at Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Brown University Sports Foundation, Christ Church, Greenwich, CT or the South Street Seaport Museum, NYC.

RANGELL--Meyer , 91, died on Saturday, August 18th in Worcester, Massachusetts. His passage was sudden; he had been in good health. Mr. Rangell was blessed with 33 years of marriage to his cherished first wife, Lea. After her untimely death, he married Evelyn, recently deceased, whom he adored. They too, spent 33 years together in love, dividing their time between the Catskill Mountains and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. He was the father of his cherished daughter Anne Richstone and her husband Michael, of Massachusetts, and son Harmon Rangell and his wife Linda of New York. He was the beloved brother of Sydelle Levitan of New York, Dr. Leo Rangell of California, and the late Dr. Nelson Rangell of Colorado. He was adored by his grandchildren Dr. Lee Richstone of New York, Danielle Ayotte and her husband David, of Massachusetts and was the beloved great-grandfather of Ryan, Rachel and Benjamin Ayotte. He is also survived by grandchildren Melissa, Bradley, Nathaniel, Alison, Eric, Gina and Rosa, and great-grandchildren Jeremy and Alex. His tremendous intellect, generosity, and love touched all who knew him. Mr. Rangell was born in New York City in 1915 and educated at the City College of New York and the University of Chicago. Thereafter, he became a social worker in New York City and later founded the Midtown Typewriter Company. Mr. Rangell had a lifelong commitment to helping the underprivileged and oppressed and was a dedicated pacifist. His social activism included pioneer work in the field of antidrug abuse, serving as a Member of the Board of Trustees at Daytop Village. He spoke out forcefully against poverty, racism and injustice through innumerable essays, and his letters were published frequently in the New York Times. In 2004, his writings were published in a 697 page compilation entitled, Speaking Out: Toward an Ethic of Personal Integrity and Citizen Responsibility in a Democratic Society. A private funeral service for his close family and friends will take place on Tuesday, August 21st, at the Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island, New York.

THE NEED FOR CASH As problems that began in subprime mortgage lending have expanded into the broader markets, hedge funds have come face to face with the ghost of past financial crises: the one-two liquidity punch from banks and investors. [C1.] THE BERNANKE WATCHBen S. Bernanke, grappling with his first crisis since taking over as Federal Reserve chairman in February 2006, is being intently watched to see how he handles the economy. [C1.]

PONVERT--Antonio , 76, at his home in Newport, RI. Raised in Oyster Bay, Tony was a graduate of St. Paul's and Yale, and a member of the elite U.S. Air Force Security Service, stationed in Germany and Libya. He was the first director of the Newport Preservation Society, and member of the Ida Lewis Yacht Club and the Newport Reading Room. Tony was an accomplished and knowledgeable fly fisherman, photographer and artist. He had a vast knowledge of art and architectural history, literature, and the best restaurants and bars in every major city across the globe. He was a very funny and dear man; a gentleman in the truest sense of the word -generous, kind, gracious, and unfailingly loyal. He is missed and loved by his six children, seven grandchildren, brother and sister, nieces and nephews, two former wives, and by countless friends and acquaintances whose lives he touched and enriched in ways that he never knew. A memorial service will be held Saturday August 25 at Saint Columba's Chapel, Middletown, RI.

KISSIN--Eva A. , 84, devoted wife of Benjamin, beloved mother of Ruth, charming, articulate and delightful, she devoted her early adulthood to her family and to the Brooklyn Museum, and the balance of her life to the study of literature and film. She served on the National Board of Film Review and as Adjunct Professor at New York University. She is survived by her daughter Ruth Helman. The funeral will be held at 11am, Monday, August 20, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Family only at graveside. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders.

When you think about it, it's not the diabetes that kills you, it's the diabetes causing cardiovascular disease that kills you. DR. DAVID NATHAN, director of the Diabetes Center at Massachusetts General Hospital. [A14]

I knew Michael Roberts' work as a writer, photographer, stylist and illustrator long before we were introduced in the late 1990s. Were we introduced? Or did we meet one day at a fashion show and just start talking? We quickly discovered that we had a link to the same unpublished Vivienne Westwood profile, for Vanity Fair, in the mid 90s. I had been asked to write a profile of Westwood, which I did, but publication of the piece was delayed and delayed until, eventually, the editorial window closed for her. Michael had photographed her-appropriately, under glass. He had found an enormous bell jar and Westwood had gamely consented to be photographed as if her head were a museum specimen. Or an offering at a pagan feast, brightly colored. She is a genius.

Christian Miles has a job most soccer fans would envy. A television soccer commentator for nearly ten years, Miles does live game commentary for some of the world's top leagues on Fox Soccer Channel. He serves as a sideline reporter for FSC's Major League Soccer coverage and he co-hosts two studio shows on FSC -- Fox Soccer Matchday and Soccer Sunday +. Miles is also the official play-by-play announcer for Chivas USA of M.L.S.

C.J. Nitkowski, the longtime major league veteran now playing with the Softbank Hawks in Japan, has answered our questions from time to time all year. Here are his latest responses from the e-mailbag .

The Boston Red Sox are still riding high atop the American League standings. But their principal owner is happy enough to keep barely afloat.

Former Senator Fred D. Thompson is not only testing the waters for a run for president - he's stirring the pot. He took a not-very-veiled swipe at the Republican frontrunner, Rudolph W. Giuliani, for supporting gun control.

Thousands of spectators turned out for the festivities surrounding the 57th Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance on the Monterey Peninsula of California, where some of the rarest vehicles in the world were on display and in competition. Judging at the event included 24 classes, from antiques (pre-1916) through post-World War II sports cars, with special categories for Aston Martins and models from the Auburn-Cord-Duesenberg group.

Senator Chris Dodd, the Democratic presidential candidate and chairman of the Banking Committee, said today that the recent volatility in the country's mortgage market is "far too serious" an issue to get turned into a political football that gets pushed off until after the next presidential election.

The last night of the International Pinot Noir Celebration features an outdoor salmon bake in which wild salmon, prepared in traditional Native American style on alder stakes over a fire pit, is the centerpiece of an extravagant buffet. As it had been some years since I had last attended the I.P.N.C., I had assumed that I would simply stroll in and find a seat in the grassy quadrangle at Linfield College when the time came. Wrong. More than 1,000 people attend the salmon bake, and they all line up well in advance so they can present their tickets to the diligent staff.
The market convulsions of August have calmed enough today for the locker-room talk to gear up. And it seems that a favorite target will be people woefully stuck up in their ivory towers.
Gen. Michael V. Hayden, the C.I.A. director, just released a public summary of the agency's internal post-mortem on its performance before the Sept. 11 attacks.

I hadn't visited the Basilica of San Clemente in about ten years, so I had a bit of a surprise when I went with a friend this week. A decade ago, when you wanted to visit the area underneath the basilica - one of Rome's most interesting underground ruins - you bought your tickets from wizened old nuns who kept the change in awooden box.

BioForm Medical filed with securities regulators on Monday for an initial public offering to raise as much as $115 million. J.P. Morgan Chase, Piper Jaffray, CIBC World Markets and Jefferies will underwrite the offering.

Gordon Brothers Group announced Tuesday it will sell a majority of Spencer Gifts Holdings in a management-led buyout backed by Acon Investments, a private equity firm in Washington. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

The controversial social scholar Charles Murray, writing at The American magazine's site, feels it's time to abandon the SAT test. His complaints aren't totally new: "The image of the SAT has done a 180-degree turn. No longer seen as a compensating resource for the unprivileged, it has become a corrosive symbol of privilege. 'Back when kids just got a good night's sleep and took the SAT, it was a leveler that helped you find the diamond in the rough,' Lawrence University's dean of admissions told The New York Times recently. 'Now that most of the great scores are affluent kids with lots of preparation, it just increases the gap between the haves and the have-nots.'"
The writing was not exactly on the wall, but Benny Feilhaber had a feeling that it might be a good time to move on.

Robert Stone was born on August 21, 1937 - he turns 70 today. As it happens, next month is also the 40th anniversary of the publication of his first novel, "A Hall of Mirrors."

KANSAS CITY, Mo. - When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed the Veterans of Foreign Wars national convention here yesterday, she told the story of how she met a "bright, young captain" in the 82nd Airborne Division named Patrick Murphy in 2003 during her first trip to Baghdad.

With a lengthy interview and a series of stories out today, a speech planned for this afternoon and an Op-ed in a major newspaper, Illinois Senator Barack Obama's voice is rising above the din of the crowded presidential field this morning.

Nasdaq is in discussions with major OMX shareholders to persuade them to accept only shares in its takeover bid for the Nordic market operator, enabling it to offer more cash to key hedge fund investors, The Financial Times reported Tuesday.

Two years ago, eBay paid $2.6 billion for Skype, saying the Internet-based phone service provider would provide a new way for the auction site's customers to talk to merchants. But so far, that synergy has yet to materialize.

Blackstone Group will spend around $165 million to buy as much 70.1 percent of Indian garment maker Gokaldas Exports, the first of a number of deals in the region the New York private equity firm has promised.

General Electric is seriously considering selling GE Consumer Finance, a Japanese unit that offers financial services, and may invite bids as early as September, according to the Nikkei business daily.

Landesbank Sachsen Girozentrale, the German state-owned bank getting emergency funding, has about 3 billion euros ($4 billion) in investments linked to U.S. subprime mortgages, according to Bloomberg News.

Powerful proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services on Monday urged shareholders in Topps to reject the trading card vendor's $385 million buyout agreement with Michael Eisner's Tornante and private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.

Google revealed on Monday that it had acquired a stake in Chinese community Web site Tianya.cn, indicating a foray by the search giant into social networking in the world's second-largest Internet market.

The new chairman of Britain's Virgin Radio said the station's initial public offering was on track despite financial market turbulence and persistent speculation that the business will go to a single bidder.
Try as he might, not even veteran interviewer Charlie Rose could get Microsoft's chairman and chief executive, Steve Ballmer to disclose whether the company continues to mull an acquisition of Yahoo.

Lone Star Funds said Monday it was seeking a court order to terminate its roughly $400 million purchase of Accredited Home Lenders Holding, saying the subprime mortgage lender had not met the conditions to close.
Juma Technology, a telecommunications services firm, announced Monday that it has raised $5 million in its first investment round.

SunTrust Banks, long considered a potential takeover target, said Monday that it expected to eliminate about 2,400 jobs by the end of next year as part of a plan to save $530 million annually by 2009. The job cuts equal about 7 percent of SunTrust's year-end work force of 33,599 people. The bank, based in Atlanta, expects the cuts to reduce pretax earnings by $45 million this quarter.

Ford Motor may have chosen the new owner for Jaguar and Land Rover by the time it reports its third-quarter results in October.

VMware, with the proceeds from its $1.1 billion initial public offering burning a hole in its pocket, is putting some of that cash toward challenging Google for Silicon Valley's most-coveted prize: computer-programming talent.

Atticus Capital has raised its stake in Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold to 7.5 percent, as the hedge fund prepares to take on the mining company's management.
Pain relief drug developer NeurAxon of Waltham, Mass., has secured $32 million in a second round of venture funding, twice the size of its first round.

In yet another casualty of the fallout in the mortgage industry, Capital One Financial said Monday that it would stop making residential mortgages and close GreenPoint Mortgage, its wholesale mortgage banking unit.

The Chinese government announced Monday that it would allow mainland Chinese citizens to invest in the Hong Kong stock market, the most significant move to date by Beijing officials to dismantle the barriers that prevent most Chinese from making international investments.

The acquisition of Wild Oats Markets by Whole Foods Market was delayed Monday by a federal appeals court in Washington. The appellate court said that it needed more time to consider the Federal Trade Commission's argument that the deal should be blocked pending the outcome of an appeal of a lower court ruling.
The struggling mortgage investment firm Luminent Mortgage Capital took steps to bolster its liquidity Monday, but the company signaled its troubles were not completely over.

Structured Credit, an Irish underwriter of credit products for investment banks that was placed in provisional liquidation last week, has been given time by the High Court of Ireland to complete a reorganization plan.

The Seattle SuperSonics’ Kevin Durant, the second overall pick in the N.B.A. draft, and his teammate Nick Collison were cut from the national team as the United States set its 12-player roster for the Olympic qualifying tournament. The event begins tomorrow in Las Vegas. On the team are Kobe Bryant, LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony, Amare Stoudemire, Dwight Howard, Jason Kidd, Chauncey Billups, Michael Redd, Mike Miller, Tyson Chandler, Tayshaun Prince and Deron Williams.

Officials suspended efforts to save six coal miners as a group of experts concluded that the area was structurally unstable and would probably collapse again.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer is seeking federal disaster assistance for Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island because of the rainstorms and tornado that hit the area this month. Governor Spitzer said yesterday that he had asked the Federal Emergency Management Agency to make a major federal disaster declaration for homeowners, renters and business owners in those boroughs who suffered damages from the severe storms that swept through on Aug. 8. He said the weather’s impact, including flooding, was devastating. The state was seeking implementation of a FEMA program that includes relief for temporary housing expenses, household repairs and low-interest loans. A FEMA spokeswoman on call last night did not return a message left for her.
The remains of the last person missing since the Interstate 35W bridge collapsed into the Mississippi River have been found.

The United States allowed two goals in the final eight minutes yesterday and lost to Tajikistan, 4-3, at the under-17 World Cup in Changwon, South Korea. Tajikistan was making its debut at the under-17 tournament.
Pedro Martínez held the Brevard County Manatees, a Brewers affiliate, to two runs, both unearned, and two hits in five innings in a 4-3 victory for Class A Port St. Lucie.
Basketball.

A lawyer for Chris Benoit’s personal doctor suggested in court papers that Benoit, the former professional wrestler who killed his wife, his son and himself in June, had a hormone disorder that justified the amount of steroids he was prescribed.The doctor, Phil Astin, has pleaded not guilty to federal charges of improperly prescribing drugs to two patients other than Benoit. In a motion to suppress evidence filed yesterday, Astin’s lawyer, Manny Arora, said that “the amount of medication in question was not excessive and would be medically appropriate based on the medical condition of Mr. Benoit.”.

Tommy Robredo and Elena Dementieva won their opening matches at the Pilot Pen, an ATP hardcourt tournament in New Haven. Robredo, the No. 2 seed in the men’s draw, reached the third round with a 6-4, 6-4 victory against Marc Gicquel of France. Dementieva, seeded sixth among the women, beat Mara Santangelo of Italy, 6-2, 3-6, 6-0.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about hedge funds that invest according to computer models, misstated the title of Roger Lowenstein’s book about the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, which used that technique. It is “When Genius Failed,” not “When Geniuses Fail.”.
A film review in Weekend on Friday about “Marigold” referred incorrectly to the rating. It is PG-13; it is not unrated.

A picture caption with an article on Thursday about the fatal shootings of six Italians in Germany linked to a mob feud misspelled the name of the town in northern Germany where they were found. As noted correctly in the article, the town is Duisburg, not Duisberg.

Because of an editing error, the TV Watch column yesterday about Karl Rove’s appearances on Sunday-morning talk shows misstated the sponsor of a Washington dinner at which he once performed a rap routine. It was the Radio and Television Correspondents’ Association, not the White House Correspondents’ Association.

An article on Saturday about Republican members of the House who have said they will not seek re-election next year misstated the decision of a House Democrat, Luis V. Gutierrez of Illinois. While he announced 18 months ago that he would not seek re-election, he said Thursday that he had changed his mind and would seek a ninth term.
Iowa’s top receiver, Dominique Douglas, and the reserve Anthony Bowman were suspended after being arrested in connection with credit card fraud.

A picture caption with an article on Thursday about the fatal shootings of six Italians in Germany linked to a mob feud misspelled the name of the town in northern Germany where they were found. As noted correctly in the article, the town is Duisburg, not Duisberg.

An article last Tuesday about the low water levels in the upper Great Lakes misstated the amount of water diverted from Lake Michigan to Chicago and northern Illinois for water supplies there. It is more than 2 billion gallons a day, not more than 2 billion gallons a year.
A theater review yesterday about the Broadway revival of “Grease” misspelled the given name of the actress who plays Frenchy. She is Kirsten Wyatt, not Kristen.

The three-time defending champion Roger Federer was seeded No. 1 at the United States Open for the fourth consecutive year yesterday, and Justine Henin topped the women’s seedings.Thirteen players who have won Grand Slam titles are among the 32 men and 32 women seeded for the last major tournament of the year, including the men’s No. 2, Rafael Nadal, the three-time French Open champion; and No. 5 Andy Roddick, who won the 2003 United States Open. The defending champion Maria Sharapova is seeded No. 2 in the women’s field, followed by No. 3 Jelena Jankovic.
A blogger has filed a federal complaint against former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, accusing him of violating election laws.
Two Marine Corps pilots, a crew chief and a Navy corpsman were identified as those killed in the crash of a search-and-rescue helicopter during training on Friday.

Boxes containing personal information from the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research that were supposed to have been shredded turned up last week in a trash bin off base, the police said. A spokeswoman for the Army Medical Command said the files were research study records. An investigation is seeking to determine what information they held and why they were off base.
Planned Parenthood filed a lawsuit seeking to strike down a new Missouri law that it claims could eliminate abortion services in large parts of the state.

Water continues to leak steadily into a Boston Big Dig tunnel, an independent analysis shows, despite claims by officials of the agency overseeing the project that the problem is under control. The analysis by an engineering firm contradicts a report last month by the agency, the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority, that said water discharge from the tunnel was cut in half from 2003 to 2006. Four men were convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court of breaking into a man’s home and attacking him last August in an attempt to learn the location of a young Pakistani couple planning to marry against the wishes of the bride-to-be’s father, prosecutors said yesterday. The men — Javed Khalid, 53; Azad Malik, 67; Hussain Sada, 29; and Shafiq Mohammed, 41 — were convicted of first-degree burglary, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said that the four men forced their way into the West Sixth Street home of Rana Hussain, 48, handcuffed him and punched and kicked him. They demanded the location of Mr. Hussain’s nephew, then 19, and Mr. Khalid’s 15-year-old daughter, who had met at James Madison High School and planned to marry, Mr. Hynes said. He said the girl had been promised to a man in Pakistan. Mr. Hynes said they beat Mr. Hussain with a pipe and threatened to shoot him, but he did not say where the couple was. Each of the men faces up to 25 years in prison, prosecutors said.

A Bridgeport police sergeant has notified Trumbull that he is suing town police officers for injuries he sustained because of a police pursuit. The sergeant, Carl Leonzi, 65, says that he was on his way to work on the morning of Feb. 13 when three robbery suspects being chased by the Trumbull police on the Merritt Parkway crashed their car into his. The suspects got away. “I never knew what hit me,” Sergeant Leonzi told The Connecticut Post. Trumbull officers were pursuing a vehicle that matched the description of one used in an A.T.M. theft, said Deputy Chief Michael Harry of the Trumbull Police Department.

Six months after the head of the New Haven Police Department’s narcotics unit was arrested on federal theft charges, a national group that evaluates police operations issued a report yesterday calling for tighter supervision and stricter policies for the narcotics unit. The organization, the Police Executive Research Forum, has conducted similar assessments for more than 100 other departments. Lt. William White, the head of the narcotics unit, was charged in March with stealing nearly $30,000 of what he thought was drug money.

A federal judge has sided with Connecticut officials in their battle to halt construction of a natural gas pipeline beneath Long Island Sound. Judge Stefan R. Underhill of Federal District Court ruled against the federal Commerce Department, which three years ago rejected Connecticut’s objection to the plan. The judge said the department’s contention that national interest outweighed adverse coastal effects was not supported by the evidence. Connecticut’s attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, released the decision yesterday, and said it doomed the project. John Sheridan, a spokesman for the project, said the two companies supporting it, Spectra Energy and the Keyspan Corporation, had not decided on a next step.

A man who became entangled in a lovers’ triangle over the Internet pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday in State Supreme Court for fatally shooting his rival, a co-worker at a factory in a Buffalo suburb. The man, Thomas Montgomery, 48, of Cheektowaga, averted a murder trial by pleading guilty to shooting Brian Barrett, 22, of Lockport, three times at close range in the parking lot of the Dynabrade Corporation in Clarence last September. Mr. Barrett’s body was found in his truck in the parking lot two days later. Both men were involved in an Internet relationship with a West Virginia woman using her daughter’s Web page to pose as an 18-year-old. Mr. Montgomery could be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer approved low-cost hydropower contracts yesterday with western New York municipalities, the Tuscarora Nation and Niagara University. The contracts are part of the agreements to relicense the Niagara Power Project in Niagara Falls, New York State’s largest power generator. Federal officials approved an application in March to renew the license until September 2057, with low-cost power for local communities part of the agreement that led to the relicensing, state officials said. The project, operated by the New York Power Authority, opened in 1961. Its 13 turbines generate 2,441 megawatts.

FIRST COMMERCIAL A380 FLIGHT Singapore Airlines will begin auctioning seats on eBay next Monday for the first commercial flight of the A380 superjumbo jet, scheduled for Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney. Proceeds will go to charity. Singapore will be the first airline to take delivery of the long-delayed Airbus double-decker aircraft, which is certified to hold 853 passengers in a single-class configuration. Singapore said it would configure its A380s with 471 seats in three classes: economy, business and what the airline calls “a class beyond first.” No United States carriers have ordered the planes, but international airlines that are buying A380s have all said they intend to fly them with no more than about 550 passengers in economy and premium cabins. Singapore, which has ordered 19 A380s, has not yet unveiled its new first-class cabins for the jets, but is expected to do so soon. A380s have previously flown passengers on noncommercial demonstration flights.

KATZ--Morris. 77, N. Woodmere, NY, nationally known gold jewelry designer Maurice Katz, has lost his battle with a brain tumor. His beautiful jewelry creations will live on. Survived by wife, Roberta Katz, daughters Jessica Katz, of Queens and Lisa Kianoff of Alabama, son-in-law Alan Kianoff and granddaughters Natalie and Hayley. Funeral is August 22, 11am, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Memorials to the Brain Tumor Foundation in NY or any Jewish organization.

RICHTER--Max. Co-founder of the folding carton company, Fold Pak, died Saturday August 18th, 2007 at The Rosenthal Hospice Res idence in Stamford, Connecticut. He was 74. Mr. Richter died of complications from dementia. Born, raised, and educated in Hamburg, Germany, he immigrated to the United States in 1956. In America, he worked for the Riegel Paper Corporation until 1977 when he and three colleagues bought its folding carton division, based in Newark, New York. Under their leadership Fold Pak expanded from a one-plant-based, narrowly defined folding carton company into multifaceted business with four plants around the nation. Max was vice president of sales and concentrated on the white Chinese take-out cartons. By late 1980s Fold Pak had cornered 60% of the US market. Still today Fold Pak is the name brand for those particular food pails. The firm was sold to Gulf States Paper in 1998 and is now owned by Rock Penn of Norcross, Georgia. Max stayed as a consultant until May 2005. His passions were gardening, flying his airplane, and riding his horse. Kind and beloved husband of Judy (Hofmann) Richter, he is also survived by his mother Carla, two sons, Hans and Philip, daughter-inlaw Jennifer, two granddaughters, Maxine and Margot, brother Ernst, and two cousins Gisela Richter and Irma Pedersen. A celebration of Max's life will be held on Saturday August 25, 2007 at 11 am at Coker farm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to John Hopkins-Neurology Attn: Dr. A. Hillis Johns Hopkins Outpatient Center, 5th floor. 601 North Caroline Street, Baltimore, MD 21205. Services entrusted to Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Stamford, CT.

YASGUR--Irving. Your joy for life will be missed by all you have touched. Sharon and Alan Briskman YASGUR--Irving (July 13, 1918 -August 19, 2007). Irving was an active member of his synagogue, a community leader and a US Army veteran. He is survived by Beatrice, his loving wife of 65 years, his three children Phyllis (Jim), Carol (Mike) and Joseph (Sylvia), seven grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. He was loved, respected and admired by family and friends. Mr. Yasgur, 89, died of heart failure in his home. His funeral is today at 11am at Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, NY. In lieu of gifts, please make donations to Westchester Jewish Center. YASGUR--Irving. Our heartfelt condolences go out to the Yasgur, Laub, Widder, Kopp, Stanley and Friedman families on the loss of one of Tom Brokaw's ''Greatest Generation''. Bill Kopp and Nancy Weiss YASGUR--Irving. Dearest dad, we were all blessed to have you in our lives. You inspired everyone that was lucky enough to know you. We will miss you forever. Carol, Michael, Gillian, Allison, Scott, Cooper, Nolan and Slater

HERSKOWITZ--Bertha on August 18, 2007. Beloved wife of Sandor Herskowitz. Loving mother of Esther (David) Malach, Allen (Bonnie) Herskowitz and Renee (Tom) Mauriello. Adored by her grandchildren Stephen (Jen), Jamie, Kara, Sydney, Christopher, Mathew and Harrison, and great-granddaughter Sarah. A beautiful, kind woman with a heart of gold, our Mutti, our Ama, who asked for very little but gave so much. She survived Auchwitz but couldn't overcome Alzheimer's disease. Shiva will be held at the home of Esther Malach, Riverdale NY.

SACKETT--Ross D. age 77, of Fontana, WI died Thursday, August 16, 2007 at Walworth, WI. He was born March 26, 1930 in Chicago, IL to parents DeForest and Margaret (Ross) Sackett. He was united in marriage to Marvyda Wild in September of 1951 at Mattoon, IL. Some of Mr. Sackett's more recent accomplishments include Holt, Rinehart, & Winston, Inc., in New York: Engineering and Science Editor; Vice President, General Manager College Department, Executive Vice President Director, and President; CBS in New York: president, CBS Education and Publishing Group, Director CBS, and Director CBS Foundation. For Encyclopedia Britannica Education Corporation of Chicago, IL, he was President and CEO, Director and member of the executive committee of Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., member of the Editorial Board, Chairman Voting Trust, Encyclopedia Britannica Educational Corporation. Mr. Sackett was also an author, owner of several businesses, restorer of Victorian homes, and was an avid historian. He is survived by his wife Skip of 56 years, sons Scott and Stuart, daughters Cynthia and Amy, as well as 12 grandchildren and numerous friends. He was preceded in death by his son Dave. He loved books, architecture, sports and hiking.

STERN--Madeleine B. July 1 1912 to August 18 2007. Beloved companion of the late Leona Rostenberg, darling daughter of Lillie Mack Stern and Moses R Stern, treasured cousin of Zelda Mack, a joy to her many friends and admired by a vast number of people. Madeleine was a 1932 Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Barnard College. She gained international fame as an author and editor, and as a leader in the Antiquarian Book Trade where she was a partner in Rostenberg and Stern Rare Books. She was also a Guggenheim Fellow and wrote over 30 books on feminists and American history, including Louisa May Alcott, whose thillers written under a pseudonym, she and Dr. Rostenberg jointly discovered. She developed a deep reciprocal affection for Leona's family. Madeleine was comforted in her last days, by Leona's family and friends Loven Lavia, Jan Turnquist, Paulette Rose, Katherine Houghton, and Liliane Wilcox. Services at Campbell's Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. Tuesday August 21 at 11 am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Orchard House, a musemum dedicated to Louisa May Alcott. P.O Box 343, Concord MA, 01742

GLICKMAN--Joyce. May our memories of so many happy times, endless ''girly'' chatter, and sisterly love help us to always celebrate her life. We will forever have her in our hearts.

CURRAN--Catherine Gamble. Born Beijing, China 1926. Died August 18, 2007 at her home in Manhattan. A philanthropist and patron of the arts and education, she graduated from Riverdale Country School and Mount Holyoke College and lived in India, London, England, Manhattan and Harbor Point, Michigan. As President of the Sidney Gamble Foundation for China Studies she oversaw a collection of early photographs of China taken by her father, co-curating the exhibition which toured the US and China and is now archived at Duke University. She was a Trustee of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Princeton - in - Asia, Young Concert Artists, and the Little Traverse Conservancy of Northern Michigan, and also served on the Boards of Mount Holyoke College, the New York City Ballet, the National Dance Institute, the American Federation of Arts, the American Friends of Covent Garden and the Royal Ballet. She was a Fellow of the Frick Collection, the Morgan Library, and the Royal Society of Arts, London, and a member of the visiting Committee to the Department of Drawings and Prints of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and of the Drawings Committee of the Morgan Library. She was on the Advisory Councils of the National Dance Institute and the School of American Ballet. Mrs. Curran was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Little Harbor Club. She will be deeply missed by her children, Constance (Roemer) McPhee of New York and Peter (Bonni) Curran of Ketchum, Idaho, and her grandchildren Michael McPhee and Jessica and Cody Curran. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to one of the organizations mentioned above. CURRAN--Catherine G. We mourn the grievous loss of our beloved Cathie Curran, treasured friend and longtime member of our Board of Directors. Her thoughtful, generous, gracious presence is already terribly missed. Our warmest sympathy to her children and grandchildren. Young Concert Artists, Inc. Susan Wadsworth, Director Peter Marino, Chairman of the Board CURRAN--Catherine G. The Trustees and staff of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the loss of Catherine G. Curran. An esteemed member of our Board since 1986, a great patron of the arts and education, Cathie brought a highly cultured and sophisticated view to our organization. Her thoughtful intelligence and great equanimity made her a wonderful colleague, and her longstanding generosity will always be remembered and appreciated. We will miss this gracious friend. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her children Peter, Robert, and Constance. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Norma Hurlburt, Executive Director
