Fern Schair, Board Chair Carol Sherman, Executive Director

ROACH--Max. The Board and Friends of the NYC Housing Symphony Orchestra mourn the loss of their friend, patron and former board member whose musical gifts were matched by his humanity and generosity. Our deepest sympathy to his children. Judith L. Chiara, President Janet Wolfe, Executive Director ROACH--Max. Manhattan School of Music mourns the passing of Max Roach. One of the jazz world's most influential musicians, he studied composition at Manhattan School of Music from 1950 to 1952, and was honored by MSM with an Honorary Doctorate in 1990. An icon and mentor to generations of musicians, his incomparable and innovative legacy will be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

WAGNER--Morton J., ''Mort,'' born October 5, 1925 passed away on August 19, 2007 in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. A retired Executive Vice President of Smith Barney, he was with the firm in many capacities from 1966 until 1999. Founding Chair of both the Securities Industry Association (SIA) Investor Education and Continuing Education Committees, he served on both the SIA Public Trust and Confidence and Diversity Committees. Mort was Founder and past President of the nationwide Alliance for Investor Education. He was a past Trustee of the Museum of American Financial History and was a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Consumer Affairs Advisory Committee. He graduated from the Securities Industry Institute (SII) at Wharton in 1981 and is past Chair of the Securities Industry Institute's (Wharton School) Board of Trustees and an ''Emeritus Advisory Trustee.'' A two-term past Chair of the SIA Economic Education Committee and a Trustee of the Securities Industry for Economic Education (SIFEE), Mort also served two terms as Co-Chair of the SIA National Sales and Marketing Committee. He was also a Broadcast Pioneer, Mort changed careers, after over 20 years as an owner/operator of broadcasting properties. Mort graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1949. Mort is survived by his wife Phyllis and his five children. Claudia (Charles), Wendy and Bruce (from his first wife Bunny) and grandchildren Ian and Jennifer (Geoffrey). Along with Andrea and Joshua from Phyllis. He was a man larger than life and loved by so many. He influenced so many lives and will never be forgotten. Carpe Diem -Don't Postpone Joy! Funeral services will be held Thursday 11:15 at ''The Riverside.''

KUPER--David. To Lauren Klein and family. We grieve with you upon the tragic passing of your father. Adena Berkowitz and Rabbi Zev Brenner KUPER--David. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the untimely loss of David Kuper, beloved father of Martine Fleishman, former chair of the Westchester Women's campaign, past chair of our recent 90th anniversary mission to Israel, and cherished friend, whose generosity and energy have made a profound impact in the world of philanthropy. The Fleishmans set a shining example of leadership both in New York and in South Africa, strengthening the Jewish people and all in need. We extend our heartfelt condolences to David's wife, Sonia, his children, Martine and Stanley Fleishman and Lauren and Ari Klein; his grandchildren, Adam, Nicole, Marc, Daniel, Joseph, and Benjamin; and the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

With former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee looking more and more like a presidential candidate, his productivity in Congress is likely to face more scrutiny. The legislative Web site of the Library of Congress, from 1995 through 2002, when Mr. Thompson was in the Senate, shows a total of five bills of which Mr. Thompson was the head sponsor that became law, and a sixth that passed the Senate and was replaced by an identical House bill that was signed by the president.

the former Nebraska senator, governor, one-time presidential candidate, almost New York City mayoral candidate and current president of the New School -- be thinking about getting back into politics? Mr. Kerrey has made it known that he might be interested in running for the Senate seat in Nebraska should Chuck Hagel, a Republican, not seek re-election -- and Democratic leaders have made it clear that they would like Mr. Kerrey to run. Mr. Kerrey, in an interview yesterday, said it was unlikely but not impossible.

REID--Dorothy Gaffney, 89 Was born in Brooklyn, New York March 27, 1918, and passed away on July 19, 2007. Beloved mother of son, Clement, granddaughters Tracey and Robin. Of Lakewood, WA, formerly of San Rafael, CA, Weston, CT, and New York City. Devoted wife of Eugene G. Reid (writer and publisher of ''Yardage''). A graduate of the Pratt Institute in New York. A painter, illustrator, and sculptor of many fine, beautiful works, including abstract paintings, cut glass works, photography, as well as beautiful hand made presents for family and friends. Everyone cherished gifts that she had given. She worked as an artist, designer, and art director at AbbottKimbal advertising agency (New York) in the 1930's -50's, where her work appeared in Vogue, The New Yorker, and other publications. The family house that she co-designed with Mr. Reid and Olindo Grossi (dean of architecture at Pratt Institute) appeared with two illustrations in the New York Times on Feb. 1, 1959. She lived a life centered around beauty and truth, and always seemed to naturally draw out the best of those around her. She is greatly loved and is survived by son, Clement, granddaughters, Tracey and Robin, cousins Patricia Gleason and Alice Degan, and other relatives and friends. Interment private. Universally beloved by those who knew her and her art works, and by her many devoted friends and family.

LUGER--Norton, M.D.It is not possible to say goodbye after 75 years of friendship, to a most wonderful friend to me and my family. Nortie was there for us in times of sadness and in times of joy. The sound of his laughter will remain with us for the rest of our lives. So long, Tuly, and thank you. With love, Helen Reiser and family

SOMMER--Gloria, 82, formerly of Frankiln Lakes, NJ, died August 16 in Gainesville, GA. Her loving family and friends will miss her gracious and generous spirit. Devoted wife to Nolan and mother of Suzanne, Nancy, Robert and the late Bradford, sister Dorothy and a niece, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Little Davenport Funeral Home, Gainesville, GA.

BRICKNER--Francis J. Born October 5, 1924, in St. Paul, MN. Called Home to Our Lord on August 18, 2007, where he joins his beloved wife, Charlotte, in paradise. He proudly defended his country during WWII in the United States Coast Guard, serving in the South Pacific. He was a man of honor, integrity, quiet strength and dignity, who generously cared for and loved his children, Thomas, John, Marybeth, Eileen, Diane, Frank Jr., Joseph, and their families. He will be missed by the ''Buckley Girls'' Marion and Florence, and their families. Kiss Mommy for us. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:45am, Holy Trinity RC Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Monday and Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-10pm.

MERCK'S VIOXX STRATEGY None of the 45,000 people who have sued Merck, claiming that they or their loved ones suffered heart attacks or strokes after taking the painkiller Vioxx, have received money from the company, which is appealing guilty verdicts and avoiding payments in the meantime. As a result, Merck's stock is recovering nicely and its ultimate liability from Vioxx is decreasing. [C1.]

Devoted Grandfather of Adam, Daniel, Rebecca, Nathan and Ruby. Much loved brother, brotherin-law, uncle and friend. Leader of the fight against McCarthyism. The Democratic National Committee is taking steps to rein in the free-for-all primary calendar in which states are moving up their contests to gain influence. The first target: Florida. On Saturday, Florida Democrats will make their case to the party's Rules and Bylaws Committee. The state's primary -- set for Jan. 29 -- is earlier than party rules allow.

SEEVAK--Sheldon. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of The New York University Child Study Center mourn the loss of Sheldon Seevak, a visionary supporter of the Center. Shelly truly understood the value of research in unlocking the root causes of psychiatric disorders; he and Ellie generously underwrote research whose findings will benefit families across the country. We will miss Shelly and his inexhaustible search for answers. Our thoughts are with his family and all those who love him. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., Director, NYU Child Study Center SEEVAK--Sheldon, Shelly -The Neidich family has lost a wonderful friend. We celebrate an extraordinary life well lived, and the family you built with Ellie. We are fortunate to be among the countless people you touched. Amazingly, your achievements at Goldman Sachs merely served as a foundation for the countless contributions you made to a host of non-profits. While your financial support was significant, it was the commitment of your time and the application of your boundless intellectual curiosity which made a lasting impact. Those of us who owe you so much will never forget and will forever be in your debt. SEEVAK--Sheldon, born in Boston, MA on May 28, 1929, died suddenly on Saturday, August 18. Sheldon was a former partner of Goldman Sachs, where he founded the real estate department. Since retiring from Goldman Sachs, he was involved with a number of philanthropic organizations. He was a devoted and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, great-uncle, friend and mentor. He is survived by his wife, Elinor A. Seevak; his daughters Alison Seevak and Marina Seevak; his son Evan Seevak; his daughter-in-law Sarah Pearson; his grandchildren Gabriel, Emma, Abigail, Nathaniel, and Anna; his sisters Roddy Langsam and Jacqui Seevak Sanders; his sisters and brothers-in-law Amy and Henry Singer and Gerri and Larry Alpert; and numerous nieces and nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 21st at 11am at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1868 Beacon St., Brookline, MA.

Goodbye, Des Moines, hello, Nantucket! After sweating their way through the crowds at the Iowa State Fair, a ferryload of presidential candidates are following the moneyed set to Nantucket for big-ticket fund-raisers. The island is a perennial Democratic port of call, but this year the traditionally liberal beach resort is also attracting Republican candidates, perhaps reflecting the unusual character of the party's contenders this year.

FRANKLIN--Joan Sayward. Her friends, neighbors, and colleagues deeply mourn her death on August 11, after a brief illness. Born in Cape Elizabeth, Maine in 1928, Joan attended the Waynflete School in Portland. In 1950 she graduated from Wellesley College. In 1956 she married Robert Franklin, and in 1962 they established Cinema Sound, Ltd., an audio recording studio on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The news and educational features they produced were syndicated to radio stations nationwide and included Night Talk, broadcast Sunday nights on WOR in New York and programs for the American Museum of Natural History, the Carnegie Corporation and Rodale Press. When Bob Franklin died in 1980, Joan continued to run the company, producing educational and instructional audio. A longtime West Side resident, Joan was president of the West 75th Street Block Association. Through her efforts, she enriched the Upper West Side community. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

KENNEDY--Louisa Livingston, 73, the wife of Moorhead Kennedy, died August 19, 2007 on Mt. Desert Island, Maine. Louisa was the former spokesperson for the Iran hostage families from 1979-1981. Funeral services will be held 11:00AM, Saturday, August 25th, 2007 at St. Mary's by the Sea, Northeast Harbor. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Louisa's memory may be made to the Mt. Desert Island Historical Society, 373 Sound Drive, Mt. Desert, ME 04660. Services by Jordan-Fernald, 1139 Main St., Mt. Desert. Condolences may be expressed at www.jordanfernald.com

DEAVER--Michael. Legal Action Center mourns the loss of Mike Deaver, dear friend and member of our Board of Directors. Mayers, Chairman of the Board Paul N. Samuels, President/Director

GROSSMAN--Charles. Manhattan School of Music is deeply saddened by the passing of its dear friend, Charles Grossman. A valued member of its Board of Trustees, his warmth, intelligence, and judgment will be sorely missed by all. We are grateful for all he did to support the enrichment of our young musicians. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his wife, Carol, and his family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President GROSSMAN--Charles, on August 18th. Beloved husband of Carol and father of Ellie Grossman (Ray Fisman) and Laura Grossman. Born September 13, 1943 in Houston, TX. Graduate of Harvard College and Columbia University, MBA and JD. Respected real estate investor and advisor. Recognized for his integrity, decency and kindness. Trustee of Temple Emanu-El of NYC, Orchestra of St. Luke's and Manhattan School of Music. Founding member of the Real Estate Academic Initiative at Harvard University. Former Chairman of the Pension Real Estate Association and former Chairman of the International Council of Shopping Centers. Services Tuesday August 21st, 2pm at Temple Emanu - El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Orchestra of St. Luke's NYC, The Skirball Center of Temple Emanu-El, Manhattan School of Music or St. John's School, Houston TX. GROSSMAN--Charles. Charles Grossman, a former Managing Director of ING Clarion Partners, one of the world's largest real estate investment management firms, and Chairman of the International Council of Shopping Centers, ICSC (2005-2006) died Saturday, August 18, 2007 after a brief illness. He was 63 years old. A respected expert on retail real estate finance, Mr. Grossman worked at ING Clarion Partners from 1988 until his retirement in 2006. While with ING Clarion, Mr. Grossman managed approximately $19 billion in real estate assets. He was also a member of the firm's Executive Committee and a member of the Investment Policy Committee of ING Clarion Real Estate Securities. Prior thereto, he was associated with James D. Wolfensohn, Inc. and was the founding partner and Chief Executive Officer of Schroder Real Estate Associates, an institutional investment management firm jointly owned with Schroder plc. He began his career at Irwin Management Company of Columbus, Indiana, which managed the capital of a prominent Midwestern family. Born in Houston, Texas, in 1943, Mr. Grossman learned about retailing while working in his family's apparel store. Mr. Grossman was a graduate of Harvard College (B.A., Magna Cum Laude, 1965), Columbia University School of Law (J.D., 1968), and Columbia University School of Business (M.B.A., 1969). As a Harvard undergraduate, he was a co-founder of the Eliot House Forum on Developing Nations. He served as Chairman of the International Council of Shopping Centers Educational Foundation and as member of ICSC's Board of Trustees starting in 1996. Mr. Grossman is credited by many shopping center professionals with educating the industry, notably by sharing his expertise on the subject of shopping center finance through ICSC and other industry forums over the years. Mr. Grossman was also a Founding Sponsor and member of the International Advisory Board of the Harvard Real Estate Academic Initiative. He was also past Chairman and member of the Board of Directors of the Pension Real Estate Association and from 1994 to 1999 was Chairman of the PREA Institute Committee. Mr. Grossman was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Orchestra of Saint Luke's, the Manhattan School of Music, and Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York. He chaired Emanu-El's House Committee, which undertook the award-winning recent restoration of Temple Emanu-El. He was a director of the Skirball Center for Adult Jewish Learning at Congregation Emanu-El. Mr. Grossman is survived by his wife of over 40 years, Carol, and their two daughters, Ellie and Laura. A memorial service for Mr. Grossman will be held Tuesday, August 21, 2007 at 2:00 p.m. at Temple Emanu-El in New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Mr. Grossman's name to the Orchestra of St. Luke's, the Skirball Center at Congregation Emanu-El, the Manhattan School of Music, or St. John's School (Houston, TX). GROSSMAN--Charles. Forest City mourns the passing of Charlie Grossman. Charlie, Managing Director of ING Clarion Partners, was a leader in the industry, a true professional and an extraordinary gentleman. He will be missed by his friends at Forest City Ratner Companies and Forest City Enterprises. GROSSMAN--Charles. The Board of Directors of the Orchestra of St. Luke's mourns the untimely passing of its beloved trustee, Charles Grossman, and extends its heartfelt condolences to his wife, Carol, and daughters, Ellie and Laura. Charlie possessed great knowledge and wisdom. He was exceptionally generous and showed great devotion to the musicians of St. Luke's. He made an immeasurable difference to our organization. We will miss him.

President Bush said that the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam was destructive and that leaving Iraq would be similarly dangerous.

There may be something to write somehow about the process of travelling to the races. Leaving by airplane in the evening after a race you encounter a virtual paddock - with everyone from teams dressed in their civilian clothes and you can't recognize them.

A new ad by Nike celebrates the female athlete.
The Florida Democratic Party has no plans, at least for now, of blinking in the showdown over the date of its presidential primary next year.
Today President Bush used an appearance in front of a group of veterans to argue against the early removal of American forces from Iraq, drawing historical parallels to the end of the Vietnam war.

Ivy Stark's résumé defines eclecticism. Toward the beginning of her career, she cooked at the Sign of the Dove; much more recently, she cooked at Rosa Mexicano. And as she toggled from one culinary tradition to another, she decided to gain the sort of formal education about wine that not many chefs have, earning a certificate from the American Sommelier Association.

Of course, there were no jokes about the high drama of the United States Open draw even though the United States Tennis Association held it in a small conference room of the 71st floor of the Empire State Building. A view of the Statue of Liberty was framed by oversized photographs of Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe.
Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman's Aug. 22 column, "Go Green and Save Money".

It appears the bloodbath is beginning. Lehman Brothers, a leader in packaging subprime mortgages into securities, is shutting down one of its home lending units and laying off 1,200 employees, or about 4.2 percent of its total workforce. The bank said it would take a $52 million hit to third-quarter earnings.

You may have heard the teaser about the Eli Manning-Tiki Barber clash that led off "SportsCenter" on Tuesday night. You may have heard (not literally, but almost) the blaring headlines from New York's tabloids. The cover of the Daily News showed shouted "ELI TAKES DOWN TIKI," followed by "Vicious feud boils over." The back page read "ELI TORCHES TIKI."

It's as close to an admission of fallibility as you're likely to hear from a prominent political correspondent: "I predicted here that the August congressional recess would be a difficult time for Republicans, because they would be returning to their districts to face voters who were furious over the Iraq war," writes Karen Tumulty at Time's Swampland. "But if this morning's Washington Post is right, the exact opposite has happened: It's the Democrats who are being put on the defensive over the war."
It was like being interrogated.
Gentlemen, start your engines!

More banks have stepped forward and said they have availed themselves of the Federal Reserve's discount-lending rate cut amid the credit market's turmoil last week. The four biggest banks in the United States -- Citigroup, J.P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Wachovia -- said that they each borrowed $500 million through the so-called discount window by taking out loans directly from the Fed.

Top-seeded Justine Henin could again face Serena Williams in the quarterfinals of the United States Open, which begins on Monday, while Roger Federer might play Andy Roddick, whom he defeated in last year's final, in that same round. Those were among the potential matchups randomly decided today at the Open draw ceremony in the Empire State Building.

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.
The Delorean is coming back, and excitement is rife in the blogosphere.
All aboard!
Many lawyers may still moan about the burden of billable hours. But for a select few, the system has just become even more lucrative.

If you want to know something as simple as who heads the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, don't bother to ask the safety agency's communications office. Without special permission, officials there are no longer allowed to provide information to reporters except on a background basis, which means it cannot be attributed to a spokesman.

Despite the difficulties companies have had recently in raising debt for buyouts, at least one acquiror has found little trouble in doing so. Britain's Rio Tinto has raised $40 billion to fund its takeover of Alcan, the Canadian aluminum producer, The Financial Times reported Wednesday.
Accredited Home Lenders may be suing to keep its buyout from collapsing, but it seems like it has more pressing matters on its hands. Namely, survival.

Apparently, the United States Open will be blessed with good weather on Monday for its opening day. But it may be cursed with ho-hum matchups. Or so the conventional wisdom goes. We'll know for sure later today when the Open draw is conducted at the Empire State Building.
In a realm where simulation is all, authenticity may lie in the details.

August has traditionally been considered a slow news month (as a newspaper employee who long lacked the seniority for late-summer vacation, I'd beg to differ -- remember Boris Yeltsin on that tank?), so the press tends to draw up a lot of coverage of anniversaries -- get ready for Katrina redux. Laura Rozen at Mother Jones's MoJoBlog brings up the fourth anniversary of something a great proportion of Americans have likely forgotten, or at least tried to erase from their memories: "It was only four years ago that Rep. Bob Ney (R-Ohio) and Walter Jones (R-NC) announced the official name change in Congressional cafeterias from French fries and French toast to Freedom Fries and Freedom Toast."
After mostly sidestepping the comparison, President Bush plans to embrace it today in one respect.

Is Iraq like Vietnam? After mostly sidestepping the comparison, President Bush plans to embraced it in one respect in a speech today. As in Vietnam and Cambodia, he thinks the costs of pulling out are being underestimated by critics of the war in Congress and across the nation. Here is part of the prepared text for the speech, as released by the White House:

The U.S. Open will begin Aug. 27 and run until Sept. 9 at the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing. The last of the season's major tennis tournaments, the Open is a New York institution and one of the most exciting two weeks of the summer for tennis fans.

Like a lot of the Book Review's editors, I'm a long-distance commuter. I bomb in and out of the city every weekday from Garrison, N.Y., about an hour up the Hudson River from Grand Central Terminal. The Metro North trains I ride look exactly like the one pictured above.

So much for a lazy August. The waning days of summer have seen a series of bruising fights on and off the presidential campaign trail that have pitted state against state and candidate against candidate. The skirmishes are likely to spill over into the post-Labor Day campaign season.

Online brokers TD Ameritrade and E-Trade Financial have been holding merger talks, The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. However, it is not clear that the basis for the story is: the companies have said publicly they would explore a deal, and people close to both companies told DealBook that no deal is imminent.

Dubai World agreed to pay $5 billion for a 9.5 percent stake in MGM Mirage and half of the Las Vegas casino owner's biggest development, bringing billionaire shareholder Kirk Kerkorian his biggest investment in the company.

Apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said on Tuesday its shareholders approved a roughly $15.3 billion takeover offer from an entity controlled by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers. The real estate investment trust said it expects the deal to close October 5.
Does Warren E. Buffet have his eye on Countrywide?

Nymex Holdings, parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange, confirmed on Wednesday that it is holding talks with several suitors as it seeks to expand in Europe. It also said it may fire as many as 150 employees.
In a busy summer of online video investment, some start-ups are beginning to break away from the pack of YouTube wannabes, says the Red Herring.

What has become of Bear Stearns? Fortune notes that, by all rights, this should be a Bear Stearns moment. Investors are skittish, and Wall Street players are unsure what to do next -- precisely the conditions under which the scrappy independent has traditionally thrived.

Accredited Home Lenders Holding, the subprime mortgage lender that is suing Lone Star Funds to force the buyout shop to go through with a deal to acquire it, said Tuesday it would sell about $1 billion of loans to avoid margin calls.
Beset by cost-cutting, layoffs, and high-profile drug failures, what's a big pharma to do? How about spend $90 billion to take out a competitor?
A fugitive U.S. hedge fund manager who admitted defrauding investors out of millions of dollars was arrested in Greece on Monday, Greek police said on Tuesday.

Troubled cable TV company Virgin Media, which two weeks ago postponed its auction due to turmoil in the credit markets, suffered a fresh blow Tuesday with the news that its chief executive, Steve Burch, was leaving immediately for "family and personal reasons".

Three years ago, at a news conference at Tavern on the Green restaurant that featured a free-flowing bar, former President Bill Clinton helped introduce a new Internet search engine, Accoona, which was said to be powered by innovative artificial intelligence technology.

Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, was flying high in February when he decided to buy a portfolio of prime Midtown Manhattan office towers for nearly $7 billion, using only $50 million of his own money. His 2003 purchase of the General Motors Building on 59th Street and Fifth Avenue for $1.4 billion, though derided at the time as reckless, had been vindicated as the value of the building soared, enhancing Mr. Macklowe's reputation as a visionary tycoon.

Bank of Montreal, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Canada's four other biggest banks agreed to work together to ensure that the C$120 billion ($113 billion) market for asset-backed commercial paper continues to "perform satisfactorily."
Canadian media and printing company Transcontinental looks to expand its presence in Ontario after making a $130-million bid to take over PLM Group, Canada's fourth-largest printer.
Trusts representing creditors of the defunct futures and commodities broker Refco sued its legal, accounting and financial advisers yesterday for more than $2 billion over the company's collapse.
A day after an influential proxy adviser threw its weight behind Upper Deck's $10.75-per-share bid for Topps, the firm said it had decided to withdraw its offer for the rival maker of trading cards.

Investors are often counseled, but often forget, that they should protect their downsides as they seek profits. According to Breakingviews, Pershing Square Capital's William Ackman has done just that as he pursues a shakeup of Target, which reported healthy earnings growth for tis second quarter.

As Ford Motor awaits offers for its Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look atwhat has changed in the year since Alan R. Mulally left Boeing to be chief executive at the car maker.
With Northwest Airlines' former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?
The trick to eccentricity: Don't go crazy with it.
Abbie Cornish, the Aussie Ingénue Of “Candy” and “Elizabeth: The Golden Age,” Talks With Lynn Hirschberg about satisfying her wanderlust.

Mark Stucklin of Spanish Property Insight wades into the debate over the state of Spanish real estate with a detailed analysis of the latest numbers. Stucklin, who also writes about Spain for The Sunday Times, reviewed data from several different sources to provide a straightforward, economist's perspective on the market.
A look at the auditions for the show "Fuerzabruta," which has cast members perform in a pool.
Ralph Lauren turned Polo into a $13.5 billion fashion Disney.
A look at some of the plays running in London this summer.

Whenever I return to a familiar city, I eat to confirm I have arrived. In New York, I eat a sesame bagel with cream cheese. In Paris, a croissant. In Rome, many would race for a cappuccino at the nearest bar.
“Hannah Takes the Stairs” is notable for what the movie represents: an evolutionary entry in the Do It Yourself (or D.I.Y.) independent film movement.
Lawyers for Bernard Spitzer say Roger Stone, a Republican consultant, left an anonymous, invective-laced phone message for Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father.
Countrywide Financial said Wednesday that Bank of America had made an equity investment of $2 billion in the company.
An internal report recommended better communication about troubled students, classroom locks and other steps.
The rap singer was jailed by a Manhattan judge  for violating her probation after she was arrested on charges she hit a neighbor with a Blackberry.
Clouds persisted Wednesday over European credit markets, with some commercial banks still reluctant to lend to each other.
A 70-year-old German woman came to South Korea this week with a tragic personal love story that is resonating with many people on this divided peninsula.
Hurricane Dean began battering Mexico’s Gulf coast as residents fled or hunkered down at home.
The crash in Iraq came as the alliance between Iraq’s Shiite prime minister and the U.S. government continued to fray.
Garret Anderson hit a grand slam, a three-run homer and two doubles and also set a franchise record with 10 runs batted in as the Angels continued their dominance over the Yankees.
The producers of a CBS reality show featuring 40 children living on their own were warned while the show was being taped that they might be violating child-labor laws.
The Mets have won seven of their last eight games and opened a six-game homestand in grand fashion, with Luis Castillo stepping into a starring role in the bottom of the ninth.
The Upper Deck Company withdrew its offer to buy a rival baseball card maker, the Topps Company, yesterday, clearing one obstacle to a proposed private equity takeover of Topps.
All but 2 of the 27 schools on the new list are in New York City, including a dozen schools designed for students with severe disabilities.

The Weekend Explorer column on Friday about the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood referred incorrectly to the status of St. Clement’s Episcopal Church, on West 46th Street. Though it houses a theater, the building continues to serve as a church; it is not a former church.

An article on Saturday about “Kid Nation” and other forthcoming reality television shows facing legal issues misspelled the surname of a chef who stars in one of the shows. He is Gordon Ramsay, not Ramsey. The name was also misspelled in the title of the show, “Ramsay’s Kitchen Nightmares.”.

An article on Saturday about a rush of applications for high-skilled employment visas paraphrased imprecisely the comments of Bill Wright, a spokesman for Citizenship and Immigration Services. He said that because of the high volume of applications, the agency could not acknowledge them immediately but was working to send out receipts and was updating weekly a public list of applications received. He did not say that the agency had not been able to notify applicants that their petitions had been received.

An obituary on Aug. 15 about the record producer Tony Wilson rendered incorrectly the name of a 1983 12-inch single by New Order that became a best seller but lost money for his company. It was “Blue Monday,” not “Blue Mondays.”.

An obituary yesterday about Leona Helmsley, the widow of the real estate magnate Harry Helmsley, misstated the title of a book about them by Richard Hammer. It is “The Helmsleys: The Rise and Fall of Harry and Leona,” not “Unreal Estate: the Rise and Fall of Harry & Leona Helmsley,” which was one of the prepublication titles.

An article on Sunday about the death of two New York City firefighters in a fire at the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero gave an outdated name in some copies for the hospital where they were taken. It is New York Downtown Hospital, not NYU Downtown Hospital.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the F.B.I.’s investigation of Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said that the senator’s spokesman did not respond to requests for an interview. The spokesman did reply and referred a reporter to a statement, part of which was quoted in the article, that had been provided to news organizations.

A correction in this space on Friday, to an article on Aug. 14 about the number of votes in Parliament the governing party in Turkey would need to win confirmation for its presidential nominee, Abdullah Gul, if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, misstated the total number of seats in the Parliament. If there were a third round, Mr. Gul would indeed need 276 votes, not 267 as originally reported, but the number of seats in Parliament is 550, not 500.

A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on July 31 about a Swedish study of metal emissions from automotive tires and brake linings misstated the status of asbestos as an ingredient in brake linings. Although asbestos is banned as a brake-lining ingredient in some countries, including Sweden, it is still used in the United States.

The About New York column on Aug. 11, about Kurt Thometz, who runs a bookshop specializing in rare and obscure books from his Harlem brownstone, misspelled the surname of his wife and misstated the location of the Harlem Book Fair. His wife is Camilla Huey, not Hoey, and the fair is on 135th Street, not 145th.

The caption for a picture with the On Baseball column on Sunday, showing Phil Rizzuto and Pee Wee Reese together, referred incorrectly to the date the photograph was taken. It was Sept. 29, 1952, not before Game 1 of the World Series, which was played that Oct. 1.
Corrections: For the Record

An article in Business Day yesterday about the average income of Americans from 2000 to 2005 misstated, in some copies, the nation’s total adjusted gross income in 2005. It was $7.43 trillion, not billion.

Jair Jurrjens allowed one hit in his second major league start and the Detroit Tigers got consecutive home runs from Magglio Ordóñez and Carlos Guillén to edge the visiting Cleveland Indians, 2-1, in the opener of an important three-game series last night.
A versatile veteran who may play a hybrid role at linebacker, defensive end David Bowens wants to be ready for everything this season, including the worst possible weather.
Marion C. Blakey, the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, will become the new head of the Aerospace Industries Association, a trade group.
The Bush administration violated federal law by missing deadlines to produce a study on the impact of global warming, now as much as two years overdue, a federal judge ruled.
A New Jersey man was ordered to stand trial on charges of stalking the Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel and dragging him out of a hotel elevator.
Prosecutors dropped charges against a self-described pedophile blogger who was arrested last week.
A federal appeals court upheld the racketeering and fraud conviction of former Gov. George Ryan, but he will be allowed to remain free on bail while his lawyers make a new appeal.

A commission heavy with advocates of congestion pricing was named yesterday to study Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s contentious traffic-cutting proposal and present a recommendation to state and city lawmakers.
If approved, early elections would have to be held within 45 days.
Officials said a four-day exercise that removed more than one million private vehicles from Beijing’s roads was a success that could mean a clearer sky during next summer’s Olympics.
The army said it had agreed to let the families of Islamic militants holed up in the Palestinian refugee camp Nahr al Bared, north of Tripoli, leave the battered camp.

Fifteen-year-old Jean strode into the Queens Center mall yesterday ready to make an impression. He had insisted on wearing a navy blue blazer, though it was so oversize it created a three-inch tent on each shoulder. When a camera pointed in his direction, he flashed a profusion of teeth.
Students at Dhaka University, fed up with having the army on campus, burned a military van and damaged at least 50 vehicles, witnesses said.
A woman held in a psychiatric hospital after publishing an exposé in an opposition newspaper detailing the harsh care of patients in the same hospital has been released.

A judge set bail at $5 million each for the two men accused of tying up and robbing Knicks forward Eddy Curry at his suburban Chicago home.Demorris Hill, 25, and Antoine Larkins, 28, each of Chicago, are also charged in the armed robbery of Miami Heat forward Antoine Walker during a home invasion at the player’s Chicago town house.

The American rookie John Isner waited out nine hours of rain, then beat Benjamin Becker, 6-3, 6-4, in 57 minutes last night in the first round of the Pilot Pen in New Haven. James Blake also won in straight sets, 6-4, 6-2, over Arnaud Clément. There were nine service breaks in the match, six by Blake, who broke Clément in the final game of each set. Clément was visibly upset by shouts from the pro-Blake crowd, many coming as he was about to serve. Blake grew up in Connecticut.

The Miami Hurricanes football team played its first game at the Orange Bowl in 1937, but after this season the team will have a new home. The Hurricanes will play at Dolphin Stadium starting in 2008, leaving the historic but decaying Orange Bowl. University trustees voted to make the move yesterday, despite an offer of $206 million by city officials to renovate the Orange Bowl. Miami agreed to a 25-year lease and could collect more than $2 million in additional revenue each year compared with the Orange Bowl.
Rain washed out the first day of play yesterday in the Forest Hills Women’s Classic, a United States Open warm-up.

The former N.B.A. forward Eddie Griffin died last week when his sport utility vehicle collided with a freight train in a fiery crash, the medical examiner’s office in Harris County, Tex., said yesterday.Investigators used dental records to identify Griffin, 25, who began his tumultuous pro career with Houston in 2001. He was waived by the Minnesota Timberwolves in March. Griffin, a five-year veteran, who was the No. 7 pick in the N.B.A. draft in 2001, had battled alcohol problems since coming out of Seton Hall. He was suspended by the league for five games in January for violating the antidrug program.The Houston police said in a report that the driver of the S.U.V. went through a barrier and struck the moving train about 1:30 a.m. Friday. The driver’s body was badly burned and there was no identification.

Music acts that impersonate real performers can be fined $5,000 to $15,000 under a new state law. A bill signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday prohibits performances that try to cash in through false and misleading representations of names, billings and promotions similar to the original act. The measure is meant to address financial losses suffered by recording artists like the Platters, the Coasters and the Drifters when their acts and routines are copied without permission, the governor’s office said. The law requires performing groups claiming a connection to a particular act to have at least one member of the original group and the legal right to use the name. Otherwise, they must label the production a tribute. The legislation was labeled the Bowzer Bill for Jon Bauman, above, Bowzer of the band Sha Na Na, who has lobbied for the legislation in Albany.
California lawmakers ended a partisan two-month budget stalemate, signing off on a $145 billion plan to do away with the state deficit.

A man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to two and a half years in federal prison for making false bomb threats concerning the Hoboken PATH station, prosecutors said. The man, Miguel Reyes, 33, formerly of Newark, pleaded guilty in April to making the false bomb threats, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Reyes admitted that he made three calls to 911 in October and November last year saying there would be an explosion in the station. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Beginning on Monday, East Drive in Prospect Park will no longer be open to motor vehicles on weekday evenings, city officials said yesterday. Currently, drivers can use East Drive on weekdays from 7 to 9 a.m. and from 5 to 7 p.m.. The road is closed on weekends. City officials said the road was being closed as part of an effort to expand recreation in the park. Molly Gordy, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department, said city traffic studies have indicated that the closing should not unduly affect neighborhoods in the area.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday that he had signed into law a bill expanding the circumstances under which social workers must report suspected child abuse to the state’s hot line. The law requires the workers to report suspected abuse they hear about from third parties in addition to cases they observe firsthand or learn about through contact with a child’s parent or guardian. The new law came about after a 4-year-old girl was found with severe injuries in Schenectady last year. A patron at the motel where the girl was staying with her mother and siblings reported hearing screams, and the motel manager called the county social services office, but there was no follow-up investigation until the girl was taken to a hospital two weeks later.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, broke ground yesterday on the second phase of the Harlem River Park Greenway and Esplanade. The $8.7 million project, financed through a combination of city, state and federal funds, will extend the waterfront park and bike path north from 139th Street to 142nd Street. Phase 1, completed in 2003, opened the esplanade from 135th to 139th Street. Phase 2 is expected to be completed by August 2008, the mayor said.

Three months after their arrest on federal charges of forced labor and harboring illegal immigrants, a Muttontown couple were released yesterday on $4.5 million bail after agreeing to strict house arrest. The couple, Varsha Mahender Sabhnani, 35, and her husband, Mahender Murlidhar Sabhnani, 51, have been in custody since they were arrested in May. Federal prosecutors have said the couple, who operate a perfume business, kept two Indonesian housekeepers as virtual slaves, subjecting them to physical abuse. The Sabhnanis have denied the charges. Judge Thomas Platt of Federal District Court, who initially denied bail for the couple but was overruled by an appeals court last month, imposed security restraints that included 24-hour armed guards on the Sabhnanis’ property. Both were required to wear electronic monitoring bracelets.

Former Mayor Sharpe James said he does not have enough cash to hire one of the high-profile lawyers who represented him at his arraignment last month, according to court papers filed yesterday. The lawyer, Raymond M. Brown, said in a filing that Mr. James told him “that his personal funds will not be able to meet the projected budget for the hiring of this law firm,” The Star-Ledger reported yesterday. Mr. James, 71, was indicted on July 12 on federal corruption charges. He faces multiple fraud counts accusing him of using city-issued credit cards to pay for $58,000 in personal expenses.

City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn announced yesterday $4.9 million in new financing for restoration work of the historic Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village. The red-brick building, offset with limestone trim and a distinctive bell and clock tower, is considered the city’s premier example of High Victorian Gothic style. A report released this year found deterioration in the building’s facade and rusting of its iron structure, among other problems. The money will be used to renovate its exterior and to shore up its structural integrity.
George Tenet, the agency’s former director, failed to fully prepare for the threat of Al Qaeda, a report said.
Despite foreign aid arriving, Peruvians throughout the earthquake-ravaged zone are struggling to get the basic food and water they need to survive.
The White House is trying to distance itself from the Iraqi prime minister before President Bush’s troop buildup is re-evaluated.
Haleh Esfandiari looked tired and much thinner from her ordeal but pronounced herself well.
After another day of anxiety in the credit markets, Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.
Ali Hassan al-Majid, the man known as Chemical Ali for his role in gassing villages in northern Iraq under Saddam Hussein, stood for the first day of his trial on Tuesday.
Jack Corcoran, a sophomore from Atlantic City, has claimed the starting fullback position at Rutgers, which means he gets to block for Heisman Trophy contender Ray Rice.
Officials said the mine where six workers were trapped could resume operating with a new name.
President Bush met with the leaders of Canada and Mexico at a gathering that focused primarily on strengthening ties and some thorny trade and border issues.
Hurricane Dean, the most powerful Atlantic storm to hit land since 1988, caused damage in Chetumal, Mexico, before being downgraded to a Category 1.
During his seven-plus seasons with the Florida Marlins, Jeff Conine played with Carlos Delgado, Paul Lo Duca, Moises Alou and Luis Castillo.
A study found that nearly 30 percent of children who are eligible for state-sponsored health care have yet to enroll.
A special camp works to reunite children with their incarcerated mothers.
There is much speculation in the commercial real estate market that Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, is in trouble.
After a dozen miners died in the Sago Mine in West Virginia last year, Congress passed a bill that required mining companies to track workers underground.
Giants quarterback Eli Manning did not seem uncomfortable throwing a shot back at Tiki Barber, who commented Sunday night that Manning was “uncomfortable” with leadership.
Lawrence B. Pedowitz will conduct the review, which comes in response to the recent scandal surrounding a referee who conspired with professional gamblers.
The Spitzer administration will aggressively lobby against new federal rules that threaten the governor’s plans to make health care coverage universal for children in New York.
Questions have surfaced about the Fire Department’s decision on Saturday to send more than 100 firefighters, two of whom died, into the former Deutsche Bank building.
Levi Rudolph pitched four-plus innings and drove home a run with a bunt single as Lake Oswego, Ore., defeated Hamilton, Ohio, 6-1, Tuesday to advance to the Little League World Series semifinals.
Delta Air Lines named Richard H. Anderson, the former head of Northwest Airlines, as its new chief executive, passing over two Delta executives once considered the top candidates.
An underwriter has pulled out of the initial public offering for Accoona, a new Internet search engine that former President Bill Clinton helped introduce.
In the wake of Tiger Woods’s decision to skip the opening FedEx Cup event, several players spent a rainy day discussing the merits of their ballyhooed monthlong playoff.
The known casualty toll from a series of truck bombs near the Syrian border has soared to more than 500 dead.
Consumers looking for a deal on an iPhone may be able to knock $100 off the price of the smartphone by buying from an unexpected discount source: Apple Inc.
It has become clear that the shuttle’s design, which puts a large fuel tank insulated with foam above a fragile spacecraft, is fundamentally flawed.
After turning millions of Internet users into virtual explorers of the world, the Internet search giant is now hoping to turn many of them into virtual stargazers.
Many Medtronic shareholders may be happy to see Arthur D. Collins Jr. step down as chief executive.
Rejection of military service as an option of young blacks has resulted in a sharp drop in black recruitment figures since the war began.
For survivors of some of the worst floods to hit the north of India in decades, the real endurance test is just beginning.
Behind the Orwellian rhetorical tactics, President Hugo Chávez’s efforts to amass and retain power are undermining Venezuela’s democracy.
Google believes it finally has found the formula to cash in on YouTube’s potential as a magnet for online video advertising and keep its audience loyal at the same time.
States have been trying to get some of the election attention lavished on Iowa and New Hampshire.
The idea of a single trustee for the New York State pension fund draws the disdain of many academics, experts and a few pension officials in other states.
Longtime coach John McLaren has provided a steadying influence since Mike Hargrove resigned as suddenly as the Mariners’ manager on July 2.
In the wake of the Virginia Tech shooting mayhem, there is evidence that some of the most far-reaching shady gun marts continue to operate in Virginia.
As the lead negotiator for two sports unions — referees in the National Basketball Association, and umpires in Major League Baseball — Lamell McMorris sees evolution, not irony.

First Magnus Financial Corporation, one of the largest independent American mortgage lenders, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, becoming the latest provider of home loans to collapse as the housing market slumps.
The emergency shelter for overheated Arizonans appears to be San Diego.
The Electoral College should be done away with, but in the meantime, any reforms should improve the system, not make it worse.
The results brought the value of the nation’s largest university endowment, now overseen by Mohamed A. El-Erian, to $34.9 billion.
Sylvia Siegel spent 16 years fighting against rates and rules that she maintained were unfair to consumers.
Trusts representing creditors of the defunct futures and commodities broker Refco sued its legal, accounting and financial advisers yesterday for more than $2 billion over the company’s collapse.
Jeremiah Trotter, a leader of the Philadelphia Eagles’ defense for much of the last decade, was released yesterday in a surprise move that could lead to his retirement.
The warning came amid official anger over lengthy delays and large cost overruns at the field, discovered in 2000.
A Supreme Court decision from June could impact a racially balanced schools plan that has been maintained for 18 years by White Plains.
Tanja Liedtke was a dancer and choreographer who was named artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company in early May.
A workers’ rights group in the United States released a report Tuesday detailing what it called brutal conditions and illegal practices in Chinese toy factories.
A Queens College biology student has been traveling to an island in New York Harbor to study the feeding habits of cormorants, which are prodigious vomiters.
Benny Feilhaber, who was born in Brazil but moved to the United States as a youngster, had a breakout summer playing for the United States in the Concacaf Gold Cup and Copa América.
The Pentagon said that it would shut down a database that had been criticized for including information on antiwar protesters.
Former Senator Fred D. Thompson, who has not officially declared his presidential ambitions, took a not-very-veiled swipe at Rudolph W. Giuliani for supporting gun control.
The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a safe landing at the Kennedy Space Center, apparently not much worse for wear.
The Angels released reliever Edwar Ramírez, not once, but twice. This season, Ramírez has emerged as an intriguing part of the Yankees’ revitalized bullpen.
Jon Lucien had been a mainstay of smooth jazz since the early 1970s.
Comments from policy makers and government officials tugged at a market looking for any evidence the Fed would cut rates to help contain the credit crisis.
A Jesuit priest convicted of sexually abusing two teenage boys more than 30 years ago now faces accusations of abuse that is said to have occurred from 1999 to 2003.
Staples, the office supplies retailer, posted an 11 percent rise in quarterly profit yesterday, but sales slipped in North American stores open more than a year.
A Jewish physician from Hawaii personally delivered 15 new surfboards to Palestinian surfing enthusiasts in Gaza.
Herb Pomeroy was a trumpeter who influenced generations of musicians as a teacher at Berklee College of Music and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Target’s profits were as good as analysts had expected, and Saks lost less money than expected. These days, that is good news.
Senator Barack Obama said that even if the military escalation in Iraq was showing signs of progress, American troops should not be entangled in the strife there.
France believes that it may hold the key to peace in Iraq, proposing itself as an “honest broker” between the Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish factions there.
What has changed in the year since Alan R. Mulally left Boeing to be chief executive at Ford Motor? In a sense, everything and nothing.
A Pakistani man suspected of aiding Al Qaeda and imprisoned for three years was released because the Supreme Court took up his case of detention without trial.
Kurt Busch won for the second time in three races, prevailing in a rare Tuesday event after two days of rain postponements at Michigan International Speedway.
Here are excerpts from some of the comments that Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke have made about the housing market over the last six years.
FedEx is trying to drum up frenzy over the FedEx golf playoffs that start at the Westchester Country Club on Thursday.
Real estate billionaire Samuel Zell’s $8.2 billion deal to take the Tribune Company private is now one step closer to being completed.

A recent Op-Ed article about the death toll in Darfur incorrectly characterized a ruling by the British Advertising Standards Authority on Save Darfur Coalition advertisements. The authority did not find that the ads, which put the number of dead at 400,000, “breached standards of truthfulness.” Rather, it told Save Darfur to present the figure as opinion, not fact.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,700 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:.
The penalty for “Chinglish” is usually humiliation. Still, Chinese citizens are asked to snitch, Mao-era style, on those who shame China with their shaky English.
Michael Achenbaum is hoping a new hotel,  Gansevoort Park, will do for Garden City on Long Island what  the Hotel Gansevoort did for Manhattan’s meatpacking district.
MTV Networks said it would fold its floundering digital music service into a venture with RealNetworks, owner of the Rhapsody music subscription service.
The People’s Bank of China said it was raising the one-year yuan lending rate 18 basis points to 7.02 percent from 6.84 percent, effective Wednesday, to curb inflation.
Nearly 30 percent of children who are eligible for state sponsored health care have yet to enroll, a study says.
The inclusion of French brings the total number of languages in the dual-language program to five, including Spanish, Chinese, Haitian-Creole and Russian.
Nina Berman’s photographs of  wounded Iraq war veterans have been traveling the country, and 10 are now at the Jen Bekman Gallery.
The battles over who owns what are some of the hairiest in the theater business. Take the cases of “Three Mo’ Tenors” and “Naked Boys Singing!”
Gwen Stefani modestly rocked Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, yesterday.
Fox led the Monday night ratings, rebroadcasting a two-hour special, but CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” rerun earned the night’s highest ratings.
Christopher Plummer is to play Julius Caesar next summer in Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra” at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Canada.
Broadway bound, reluctantly, “If I Did It” won’t be in one chain’s stores, “Survivor” to China and more culture news.
The nation’s three largest booksellers have made decisions about carrying “If I Did It,” O. J. Simpson’s book about the 1994 murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman.
Music acts that impersonate real performers may be fined $5,000 to $15,000 under a new New York State law.
A grave digger, a pro wrestler and a chicken farmer are among the 16 people who will compete on “Survivor: China.”
“August: Osage County,” the raved-about play by Tracy Letts, will come to Broadway from Chicago.

Monteverdi couldn’t have been more open about his belief that sacred music should be as pointedly dramatic as opera, the new form he helped create.

8 P.M. (Fox) ANCHORWOMAN It’s that old, familiar story. A television station owner tries to boost ratings by putting a babe in the hot seat. The results are anyone’s guess. In this reality-cum-comedy series, Phil Hurley, the owner of KYTX, a middle-market station in Tyler, Tex., hires Lauren Jones, above, a Versace-clad swimsuit model, onetime Miss New York and former World Wrestling Entertainment diva with no journalism experience, to anchor the news. But his crew — Annalisa Petraglia, the reigning anchor; Dan Delgado, the news director; and Michelle Reese, a hard-nosed reporter with her eye on CNN — is having none of it.
“Snapshots" has a gutsy, self-confident, liberal determination that smacks of bygone idealism. The result is not always great theater.
The joy and pain of the Williamstown Theater Festival’s absorbing revival come from watching a top-drawer cast embody a growing, reluctant awareness of receding hopes.
In the past few years protecting the environment has emerged as a religious issue. Now, something similar is taking place in the way people of faith view their daily bread.
The opening of the  International Slavery Museum in Liverpool is part of a series of events across Britain on the bicentenary of the 1807 British law that banned the slave trade.

In “Seizing Destiny,” Richard Kluger writes a detailed history of how the United States put together the pieces of real estate that would eventually make it the wealthiest, most powerful nation on earth.
An optometrist opened a boutique spa and is hoping his three daughters will run it some day. They haven’t signed on quite yet, though.
The new figure from the Iraqi Red Crescent Society makes last week’s bombings the worst attacks since the invasion.
Barfry, Fiorini, Sanctuary T and Toloache open this week and new positions for Susana Trilling, Scott Campbell and Christos Christou.
Here are several cooking schools in Paris. All can answer phone requests in English, and all offer classes for children.
The Belgians make a lot of beers that defy categorization. We gathered 23 that may not have a whole lot in common except that they are excellent summer quenchers.
Sharon Fogarty's one-act musical “comedy” is a despairing portrait indeed.
An alternative to the Belgian beer accompaniment of  mussels and fries.
Barolo Tasting.

An article last Wednesday about the fruit market in Benton Harbor, Mich., misstated the origin of some produce sold at a farmers’ market in Madison, Wis. Only produce grown in Wisconsin can be sold there; farmers from out of state are not allowed.

A court ruled that the immigration minister had acted improperly when he revoked the visa of an Indian doctor because of his association with the men involved in the botched bombings in London and Glasgow in late June.
A workers’ rights group in the United States released a report today detailing what it called brutal conditions and illegal practices in Chinese toy factories.
Rubs can enhance a great steak, but they can’t save a bad one.
The president said today that a hasty withdrawal would unleash a bloodbath in Iraq reminiscent of the Vietnam War era.
Despite the drizzle, about 2,000 people showed up at the Bryant Park lawn for the final night of free outdoor movies this summer.
In the future, the Federal Reserve Bank should push harder against a bubble while it is still inflating.
To score points before sentencing, Tim Donaghy and Michael Vick could soon reveal the monsters beneath the beds of David Stern and Roger Goodell.
Bill Cowher said his current state of relaxation reaffirmed his decision to leave Pittsburgh’s sidelines and that he did not miss coaching or training camp.
Remarks by President George W. Bush at the Veterans of Foreign Wars national convention at the Kansas City Convention and Entertainment Center in Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 22, 2007.
The White House is trying to distance itself from the Iraqi prime minister before President Bush’s troop buildup is re-evaluated.
Lawyers for Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s father say a Republican consultant left him an invective-laced phone message.
Mourners paid their respects to Joseph Graffagnino, one of two firefighters killed in the burning Deutsche Bank skyscraper.
There are many instances in which warrantless surveillance has been held to be permissible under the Fourth Amendment.
Murat and Nina Koprulu turned a crumbling property in Istanbul into a summer home.
Quickie cooking classes are readily available in Paris:  it is easy to pop into a class, connect with the city in a different way and, as a bonus, improve your French.
As Ray Bradbury turns 87, the celebrated science fiction and fantasy writer is taking something of a victory lap, partly the result of mining his extensive files for rare and unfinished work.
This week, the performance artist Rhetta Aleong  is taking part in the choreographer Reggie Wilson’s latest project.
A recipe for Fresh Corn Tamales with Chanterelles.

SEEVAK--Sheldon. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of The New York University Child Study Center mourn the loss of Sheldon Seevak, a visionary supporter of the Center. Shelly truly understood the value of research in unlocking the root causes of psychiatric disorders; he and Ellie generously underwrote research whose findings will benefit families across the country. We will miss Shelly and his inexhaustible search for answers. Our thoughts are with his family and all those who love him. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D., Director, NYU Child Study Center SEEVAK--Sheldon, Shelly -The Neidich family has lost a wonderful friend. We celebrate an extraordinary life well lived, and the family you built with Ellie. We are fortunate to be among the countless people you touched. Amazingly, your achievements at Goldman Sachs merely served as a foundation for the countless contributions you made to a host of non-profits. While your financial support was significant, it was the commitment of your time and the application of your boundless intellectual curiosity which made a lasting impact. Those of us who owe you so much will never forget and will forever be in your debt. SEEVAK--Sheldon. Shelly exemplified the concern of the individual and the desire to make this world better; the hallmarks of the Facing History and Ourselves community. He demonstrated along with his wife, Ellie the age old adage it is better to give than receive and he did so with warmth and a kindred smile. We extend our condolences to Ellie and the family. Cecilia Chan Dorothy & Andrew Tananbaum SEEVAK--Sheldon, born in Boston, MA on May 28, 1929, died suddenly on Saturday, August 18. Bobby Flay has introduced a new line of sauces, seasonings and condiments, most of them bearing the Mesa Grill label and a few under his own name. Sampling them all, I found the steak sauces the most distinctive, notably the Mesa Grill Steak Sauce (9.7 ounces, $10); it's simply the best-tasting ketchup on the market. In fact, its base ingredient is ketchup, but the deft addition of bold seasonings gives it real personality to glorify a juicy burger or a pile of crisp fries.

High-end restaurants around town serve coffee from La Colombe Torrefaction, a Philadelphia importer and roaster that started training baristas years ago to make artful designs in cappuccino froth. Now the owner, Jean-Philippe Iberti, and three partners, including Douglas Wolfe, above, have opened a relaxed but very focused brick-walled cafe in TriBeCa, where well-made espresso, cappuccino, latte, American coffee and some teas are served, properly, in china cups ($2 to $3.50). There are no flavored coffees or sugary concoctions. The closest the cafe comes is its modestly sweetened, slushy coffee granita ($3.50). Pastries from Petrossian round out the inventory.

A correction in this space on Friday, to an article on Aug. 14 about the number of votes in Parliament the governing party in Turkey would need to win confirmation for its presidential nominee, Abdullah Gul, if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, misstated the total number of seats in the Parliament. If there were a third round, Mr. Gul would indeed need 276 votes, not 267 as originally reported, but the number of seats in Parliament is 550, not 500.

BERNSTEIN--Theodore. February 12, 1930-August 20, 2007. Soul-mate of Nina, Father Extraordinaire of Peter (Sarah), Amy (Kevin), and Laura (Ed). Devoted Grandfather of Adam, Daniel, Rebecca, Nathan and Ruby. Much loved brother, brotherin-law, uncle and friend. Leader of the fight against McCarthyism. Activist, ILGWU union leader, lawyer, true hero, mentor, compassionate, funny, brilliant, inspiration to many. True mensch. BERNSTEIN--Theodore (Ted), a dedicated and admired trade unionist, died August 20, 2007 in Great Neck, NY. The members and directors of the 21st Century ILGWU Heritage Fund are extremely saddened by Ted's passing. Ted Bernstein was an important part of ILGWU's history. He worked for the ILGWU (and its successor union, UNITE) for over 40 years. He served as the director and chief administrator of many employee benefit funds serving the union's members and staff. He was one of the most respected professionals in the field of employee benefits. Admired for his intellect and integrity, he was a role model and an inspiration for many young union professionals. He ardently believed in the union's commitment to advancing the social and political rights of all working people. Until his death he was the Vice Chair of the 21st Century ILGWU Heritage Fund. He will be sorely missed. Jay Mazur, President Irwin Solomon, Secretary of the 21st Century ILGWU Heritage Fund.

WAGNER--Morton J., ''Mort,'' born October 5, 1925 passed away on August 19, 2007 in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. A retired Executive Vice President of Smith Barney, he was with the firm in many capacities from 1966 until 1999. Founding Chair of both the Securities Industry Association (SIA) Investor Education and Continuing Education Committees, he served on both the SIA Public Trust and Confidence and Diversity Committees. Mort was Founder and past President of the nationwide Alliance for Investor Education. He was a past Trustee of the Museum of American Financial History and was a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Consumer Affairs Advisory Committee. He graduated from the Securities Industry Institute (SII) at Wharton in 1981 and is past Chair of the Securities Industry Institute's (Wharton School) Board of Trustees and an ''Emeritus Advisory Trustee.'' A two-term past Chair of the SIA Economic Education Committee and a Trustee of the Securities Industry for Economic Education (SIFEE), Mort also served two terms as Co-Chair of the SIA National Sales and Marketing Committee. He was also a Broadcast Pioneer, Mort changed careers, after over 20 years as an owner/operator of broadcasting properties. Mort graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1949. Mort is survived by his wife Phyllis and his five children. Claudia (Charles), Wendy and Bruce (from his first wife Bunny) and grandchildren Ian and Jennifer (Geoffrey). Along with Andrea and Joshua from Phyllis. He was a man larger than life and loved by so many. He influenced so many lives and will never be forgotten. Carpe Diem -Don't Postpone Joy! Funeral services will be held Thursday 11:15 at ''The Riverside'' at 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Pete Doherty, the lead singer of the group Babyshambles, who was arrested Monday in East London on suspicion of possessing drugs, was released yesterday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Doherty has been undergoing court-ordered rehabilitation treatment, but the charge of breaching his bail conditions was dismissed because he was not brought to court within 24 hours, said a prosecutor at West London Magistrates' Court. This month a judge warned Mr. Doherty that he must prove his desire to quit drugs within a month or face jail.

WILLIAMS--Blake Austin, 31, passed away peacefully on August 18th, 2007. As funny as he was soulful, Blake was truly a beautiful person. During his short time in this world, he traveled extensively, lived in both Los Angeles and NYC, achieved his MBA, and made countless friends who will never be able to replace him. Of all that he loved in life, he loved his family most. He is deeply missed.

FINE--Morris, 93, passed away peacefully on August 20, 2007. He is survived by his wife of 27 years, Anne, his children Richard, Lawrence, and Margery, daughter-inlaw Rae, and his granddaughter Emma. He will be missed as well by his nieces and nephew Judy, Mel and Adele, and by his stepchildren and grandchildren Paul, Carmela, Jonathan, Jamie and Carly. He is predeceased by his first wife, Beatrice, and his sister Bertha. Morris looked back with pride on his many wonderful years of interesting and important work for the American Jewish Committee. He will be remembered by his many friends, young and old, as forever kind and loving. Services on Thursday, 12:45 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. FINE--Morris. The American Jewish Committee mourns the passing of Morris Fine, who had been deeply connected with the agency for seven decades. Morris joined the AJC staff in 1937. Three years later, he became head of its Jewish Research and Information Service, and led efforts to combat Nazi propaganda in the U.S. In 1946, he was appointed editor of the American Jewish Year Book, a position he continued to hold over the years while also assuming other leadership roles. In 1974, he was appointed Director of Foreign Affairs, leading the AJCs international programs in Latin America, Europe and the Middle East. He directed major studies on Jewish life behind the Iron Curtain and on the future of the American Jewish community. With sharp intellect, quiet demeanor and unbound passion for Jewish well-being and security. Morris made invaluable contributions to AJC, the Jewish people and the civic good. And his long years of service made him a venerated repository of AJC institutional memory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his grieving family. May his memory forever be a blessing. David A. Harris, Executive Director Richard Sideman, President

The Wild Edibles fish stores have taken a step for conservation: in cooperation with the Blue Ocean Institute, an environmental organization in East Norwich, N.Y., they are using signs and symbols to indicate the sustainability of their seafood. A variety is coded green if the fish is abundant and sustainably harvested, yellow if there are some problems with the fishery, or red if catching it or farming it results in a severe environmental impact.

THE FED'S DILEMMA The Fed finds itself between a rock and hard place when it comes to dealing with the current credit crunch. In 2004, former Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan encouraged borrowers to take out more adjustable-rate mortgages. Last year, Fed Chairman Ben S. Bernanke predicted that housing would ''most likely experience a gradual cooling rather than a sharp slowdown.'' It has become clear that the chairmen were wrong. Economic Scene: David Leonhardt. It's a rare liqueur that can find its way into cocktails and yet hold back sweetness enough to be sipped on its own, chilled or on the rocks. Canton Ginger Liqueur, a pale gold blend of French Cognac and ginger essence made from Vietnamese baby ginger, delivers spicy heat up front to make its presence known in a martini-style drink or when splashed over sliced peaches or pineapple. But it finishes with mellow smoothness. At 56 proof, it is stronger than many liqueurs. Canton was developed by John Cooper, whose father, N. J. Cooper, known as Sky, introduced a ginger liqueur from Asia called Canton in the 1980's. The son changed the formula and packaging and revived the name.

DONALD--Norman H., Jr., 93, died on August 19 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Atlanta of natural causes. A geologist, he obtained a BA degree in geology at Princeton University in 1936 and later a further degree in geology and geological engineering from the Colorado School of Mines. A graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, his earlier education was received at St. Bernard's School in New York City. In 1944 he became Chief Geologist for the St. Joseph Lead Company at Balmat, New York and he was transferred to the company's New York City office where he became Chief Geologist and Vice President in charge of world-wide exploration and production until his retirement in 1967. Formerly, he was associated with the New Jersey Zinc Company, a provider of lead and zinc to the World War II war effort, a company of which his father Norman Donald, Sr. was a director. He is survived by his wife, the former Grace Klaus of Atlanta, two sons Norman H. Donald III, of Dawsonville, GA and Williamson P. Donald of Chadd's Ford, PA. He is survived by a brother Douglas D. Donald of New York, NY, stepchildren Peter Feininger and John Feininger of Atlanta and Gail Van Winkle of Little Silver, NJ, four grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Angelene Pell Donald, a daughter Annette, a sister Mary May Miller and grandson Norman H. Donald IV. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Rye, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Scholarship Fund of St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301 or to a charity of choice. The Cremation Society of the SOUTH is in charge of services. 770-420-5557

CURRAN--Catherine Gamble. Born Beijing, China 1926. Died August 18, 2007 at her home in Manhattan. A philanthropist and patron of the arts and education, she graduated from Riverdale Country School and Mount Holyoke College and lived in India, London, England, Manhattan and Harbor Point, Michigan. As President of the Sidney Gamble Foundation for China Studies she oversaw a collection of early photographs of China taken by her father, co-curating the exhibition which toured the US and China and is now archived at Duke University. She was a Trustee of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Princeton - in - Asia, Young Concert Artists, and the Little Traverse Conservancy of Northern Michigan, and also served on the Boards of Mount Holyoke College, the New York City Ballet, the National Dance Institute, the American Federation of Arts, the American Friends of Covent Garden and the Royal Ballet. She was a Fellow of the Frick Collection, the Morgan Library, and the Royal Society of Arts, London, and a member of the visiting Committee to the Department of Drawings and Prints of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and of the Drawings Committee of the Morgan Library. She was on the Advisory Councils of the National Dance Institute and the School of American Ballet. Mrs. Curran was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Little Harbor Club. She will be deeply missed by her children, Constance (Roemer) McPhee of New York and Peter (Bonni) Curran of Ketchum, Idaho, and her grandchildren Michael McPhee and Jessica and Cody Curran. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to one of the organizations mentioned above.

Wolff, M.D. President, Medical Board

The Trustees, Overseers, Physicians, Faculty and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Leona Helmsley. She and her late husband, Harry Helmsley, a Life Governor of the former New York Hospital, were long and dedicated supporters of the Medical Center. Their generosity established the Helmsley Medical Tower, which provides valuable clinical and living space, and funded two major centers, the Helmsley Cardiovascular Center and the Helmsley Rehabilitation Center. In 2006, Mrs. Helmsley helped to establish advanced facilities for colon and rectal surgery--the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Center for Colon and Rectal Surgery and the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Surgical Suite. Mrs. Helmsley was a committed advocate for medical research, education and the needs of patients and their families. Her legacy will be important to New Yorkers for generations to come. We join with all those who knew her in mourning her loss. Our deepest condolences are extended to Mrs. Helmsley's family and friends. John J. Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I.
