Senator John Warner, veteran of wars past and longtime Republican of Virginia, today called on President Bush to issue a strong signal to the Iraqi government by withdrawing a small contingent of American troops home around Christmastime.

Not everyone in Los Angeles is embracing David Beckham. The L.A. Galaxy midfielder has catapulted the Major League Soccer team to the top of the soccer world's consciousness. But the team, which has two M.L.S. titles in 11 years, is not the only team in the city. Chivas USA, founded in 2004, attempts to draw on a much deeper history and, the team hoped, a more loyal and far-reaching fan base.
Images from Times Square Ripley’s Believe It or Not! Odditorium.
The Food and Drug Administration today addressed a concern long thought to be on its agenda: sunscreen labeling.
The efforts by ad agencies to whip up online-video trends are almost heartbreakingly dumb. But it's wrong to weep for all of them.

Earlier this week Hurricane Dean was gaining strength and heading straight toward the Mexican coastline known as Riviera Maya, the booming resort and residential strip south of Cancún. It was scary news for the local property industry, which spent months recovering from the devastation left by Hurricane Wilma two years ago.
Stephen Holden reviews "Resurrecting the Champ," starring Samuel L. Jackson and Josh Hartnett.
Stephen Holden reviews "The Nanny Diaries," a film about being a nanny on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

One of the easiest, yet most mortifying, mistakes to make in finance is to misplace a decimal point. It seems Morgan Stanley's Mary Meeker did just that in writing about YouTube's new advertising model.
On Sept. 18, the United States will be waking up to life without the Pentagon's Talon program, a database set up to track terrorism threats but later expanded to include nonviolent protests.

Even for Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has experienced more than one last stand during his time atop Iraq's shaky coalition government, the past few days must have been grueling. Several prominent senators and presidential candidates are calling for his ouster, President Bush and his lieutenants are voicing frustrations and a National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq's progress, released today, expressed deep doubts that he can overcome sectarian differences.
It's too early to know what to make of the new Southern magazine Garden & Gun.

Brazil will bring a potent, star-studded lineup that includes Ronaldinho and Kaká to the United States in September for its games against the United States in Chicago on Sunday, Sept. 9, and against Mexico in Foxborough, Mass., on Wednesday, Sept. 12. Both games fall on FIFA international "fixture" days.

Democratic candidate John Edwards jump-started his "One America'' campaign with a bus-tour in New Hampshire today, a four-day rollout that began with a speech replete with the populist, anti-establishment themes he's been pounding home elsewhere on the stump and at recent debates.
Dear Readers:
Felipe Massa was in quite a good mood at the beginning of the press conference, it seemed, as this race in Turkey is the place where he scored his first Formula One victory, last year.
Images from "Excellence and Elegance: Decorative Arts of the Eighteenth-Century Qing Court" at the Metropolitan Museum.

I am going to be in Brazil for Christmas and New Year's with a friend. Can you suggest a nice area to spend four to seven days at Christmas before returning to Rio for New Year's, or would you recommend staying in Rio?
The start of the United States Open guarantees two developments: the promise of live televised tennis and the end of the "Greatest Road Trip in Sports," also known as the U.S. Open Series.

My head today is full of stray and no-account thoughts, replies to Big Mama and other points of interest. I'm sorry if I seem a little untidy, but Mr. Roberts had the pole position, so I let his interview go on through before I turned back to Sept. Vogue. The topic still seems incendiary and very soon it won't be as we slide toward another NY Fashion Week, more shows, more strange encounters with the so-called American Ideal.

As he promised, President Bush's speech before the Veterans of Foreign Wars yesterday contained a number of comparisons between Iraq and the Vietnam war: "Then as now, people argued the real problem was America's presence and that if we would just withdraw, the killing would end The world would learn just how costly these misimpressions would be."

We New Yorkers like to think we're on the front edge of things, but there are trends --- or at least curiosities --- that pass us by. That happen elsewhere but not here, allowing others to enjoy what we are so cruelly denied. That force us to accept that we may not really be at the center of the universe. That leave us bereft.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Tim Henman, the great English hope with a classic game, is holding a news conference right now in Flushing Meadows to talk about his retirement, and British papers like the Times of London and The Guardian have already written appreciations (he spilled the beans to them earlier).

[UPDATED] The young Americans are out. Or, at least close to it. They could be playing for pride only in the final game of the first round of the U-17 World Cup in South Korea. They lost to Tunisia, 3-1, Thursday. The United States is bottom of the group with 0 points. Only a game on Aug. 26 against Belgium is keeping the Yanks around. Belgium beat Tajikistan 1-0.

The other day, I was looking at some absolutely amazing pictures of my kids, on a beach, at sunset, that my wife took with our trusty Canon SD800 digital camera. It was just amazing to see the quality that could come from a little tiny shirt-pocket cam like that. I smiled. "Yep," I thought, "the pocket digital camera has finally arrived."

I'll be on book leave for the next few months, slaving away on a book with my wife and so writing neither my column nor contributing to this blog. In my absence, I've recruited a first-rate team of diverse commentators to blog in this space - and hence make this space far more interesting than it ever was when it was just my sandbox.
The last thing I'd want to buy, I'd guess, is a used sex manual.

The only thing worse than losing is losing really, really badly. And the only thing worse than that is losing so badly that history is made. And that's what happened last night in Baltimore, where the Rangers routed the Orioles 30-3, an offensive outburst unseen in 110 years.

The PGA Tour's attempt to heighten interest in the latter part of its season begins today with the start of The Barclays, the first event in a new playoff tournament called the Fed Ex Cup. But Tiger Woods is absent, raising questions about how much meaning the playoff will have. Can golf, and other sports like Nascar and horse racing, really generate late-season interest with playoff formats, or do they appear more like gimmicks?

An Associated Press-Ipsos poll released this week indicated that liberals read more than conservatives, and Pat Schroeder - the president of the American Association of Publishers, and the former Democratic House member from Colorado - made headlines when she tried to interpret the results.

The popular social networking site MySpace is teaming up with MTV to hold a series of "candid, unfiltered discussions" this fall between young voters and the major Republican and Democratic presidential candidates.

Goldman Sachs is in advanced talks to take a quarter of a privately owned cement maker in east China for nearly $80 million, marking the latest foreign foray into the country's fragmented cement sector, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source.

In this month's Wired magazine, columnist Clive Thompson makes an outrageous and thought-provoking claim: that geeks like Bill Gates are better suited to comprehending the world's problems than non-geeks.
Yeah, sure, we live in a wondrous age of innovation and technology—but there’s still a lot that won’t arrive for a few more years.

When Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry was reinstated as the chief justice of Pakistan's Supreme Court in early July, the question immediately arose of how intensely he would challenge Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the man who tried to remove him.

It's a classic campaign theme that's bound to come up in presidential races. And, during the 2008 election cycle in particular, when it comes to the idea of "change," each of the leading Democratic presidential contenders is trying it on for size.

Ford Motor Chief Executive Alan Mulally said on Wednesday that volatility in global credit markets was a concern in its disposal of British luxury brands Jaguar and Land Rover, but the conditions were not slowing down the sale.

The number of Iraqis fleeing their homes has soared since the American troop buildup began in
February, according to data from humanitarian groups.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts on Wednesday denied a report by the Times of London saying that the private equity firm has put its $1.25 billion initial public offering on hold.

Efforts in Congress to more than double taxes on managers of private equity firms would generate little or no extra revenue to help pay for middle-class tax cuts that many lawmakers are seeking, a study finds. Buyout and venture capital firms would restructure their affairs to sidestep new tax laws, according to the study, by Michael Knoll, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
The scandal-filled legal battle between Wal-Mart Stores and its former senior marketing executive, Julie Ann Roehm, has been tossed from a Michigan state court, Portfolio.com reported.

Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said on Thursday that it will have boosted its fundraising to more than $100 million this year after a second round of investments, this time from Goldman Sachs, Bessemer Venture Partners and the Stripes Group.

Home Depot's plans to sell its wholesale supply division to a group of private equity buyers is in doubt because the investment banks involved are reluctant to fund the deal, even at a lower price, The Financial Times reported.
Goldman Sachs's Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund rose 12 percent last week after the securities firm shored up the money-losing pool with $3 billion of cash, investors told Bloomberg News.

The top 100 legal firms in Britain collected more than 12 billion pounds ($24 billion) in fees over the last year and the best-paid partners netted more than 2 million pounds each from their share of profits, according to a report in Legal Business magazine.
HSBC has suffered an early setback in its attempt to secure a 2.5 billion pound ($5 billion) takeover of Korea's sixth-largest banking group, Korea Exchange Bank.

Borse Dubai's planned $4 billion cash bid for OMX seemed in jeopardy on Thursday after Sweden's Financial Supervisory Authority ruled it broke the law when it bought a large stake in the Nordic market operator on August 9. But the regulator will allow the sale to continue.

The initial public offering VMware, the year's best so far, was a bright spot amid gloomy market conditions. But MarketWatch notes that some analysts think that the virtualization software maker's stock, which has already soared more than 150 percent, may be burning too hot, too fast.

Further indications of the financial damage done by the collapse of Sentinel Management Group started to emerge on Wednesday when Capital Fund Management, a Paris hedge fund, said it stood to lose 27 percent of its assets as a result of the cash management firm's troubles.
Amstar Financial became the latest subprime casualty, announcing Wednesday that it is closing its mortgage banking subsidiary and transferring the operations to The Money Store.

Three hedge fund investors in steel giant Arcelor asked a Dutch court Wednesday to block the company's 30 billion euro ($40 billion) takeover by Mittal Steel, saying that a revised share swap deal has cost them 152 million euros ($205 million).
The U.S. mortgage unit of HSBC said Wednesday it will close an office in Indiana, a move that will affect about 600 workers, amid a severe downturn in U.S. credit and housing markets.

Stocks rallied Wednesday, building on the recent recovery, as takeover talk and bets that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next month cooled worries about the impact of the tightening credit market on equities and the economy.

Publicly listed British private equity house 3i Group plans to build on its already strong relationships in India with the establishment of its first dedicated India infrastructure fund, which has an initial target of $1 billion.

TXU and the private equity firms trying to buy the company spent about $17 million on lobbyists and advertising during the most recent session of the Texas state Legislature, according to a report by a group that tracks political spending.
Neuromed Pharmaceuticals, a developer of pain medicines, announced Wednesday that it had raised $53.3 million in private financing to develop an opioid painkiller.

PayPal founder Max Levchin's latest start-up Slide, which makes helps MySpace and Facebook users make sparkly slide shows, may seem frivolous. But Mr. Levchin expects the lighter side of the Web to generate serious money, even more than PayPal did, which he sold to eBay for $1.5 billion in 2002.

MGIC Investment, which agreed in February to buy rival mortgage insurer Radian Group but has since had second thoughts, has filed a federal lawsuit in Milwaukee to force the Philadelphia company to give it more information.
RCM Technologies, which provides specialty professional staffing, made public Wednesday its $105 million offer for Computer Task Group after it was rebuffed twice by the board.

Wall Street bonuses may be cut for the first time in five years as a result of the credit market freeze that is paralyzing leveraged buyouts, mergers and myriad computer-driven trading strategies, according to specialists.

Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted of insider trading, may remain free on $2 million bail while he appeals, a federal court ruled Wednesday.

Wall Street registered its approval Wednesday of a potential takeover of the commodities exchange operator Nymex, sending the parent company's stock higher. The share price jumped after the chairman of Nymex Holdings, Richard Schaeffer, said late Tuesday that the company had had preliminary discussions with a possible buyer. He said any deal must offer a meaningful premium to the current stock price.

The country's four biggest banks announced Wednesday that they had each borrowed $500 million from the Federal Reserve, taking an unusual step to ease the credit squeeze that has been rattling the financial system for weeks.

Bank of America said Wednesday that it has agreed to invest $2 billion in troubled lender Countrywide Financial, buying preferred shares that carry an interest rate of 7.25 percent and can be converted into common stock at $18 each.
Make them stop and stare (for the right reasons).
The iDJ2, available next month for $799, has a bright color screen and inputs for microphones and other analog audio devices.
David Pogue explores the time-saving qualities of macro software.
Helio’s latest phone, the Fin, is as thin and menacing as a shark’s dorsal appendage slicing through the water.
If your home movies are just too dull to be endured, you have a new option: turn your family members into claymation characters.
Is there a way to connect two monitors to a Windows XP computer so I can keep my e-mail window up in one and do the rest of my work on the other?
With Web conferencing, you can make a call home seem like a news update.
Don’t rely on a confusing (or broken) hotel alarm clock when traveling.
After decades as the undisputed leader of the market for professional 35-millimeter cameras, Nikon finds itself in an unfamiliar position in the digital age.
How long can I store pictures on a memory card?
Senator Joseph Bruno, New York State’s lead Republican politician, made a good move by severing his party’s relationship with Roger Stone.
A federal appeals court today cleared the way for Whole Foods Market to buy rival organic grocer Wild Oats Markets.
A funeral was held today for Joseph Graffagnino, the 33-year-old firefighter who was killed in the blaze that tore through the Deutsche Bank building on Saturday.
The director of national intelligence last week confirmed the role of U.S. telecommunications companies.
Two firefighters were reported to be injured today in the accident at the problem-plagued building in Manhattan.
Scientists used virtual reality goggles, a camera and a stick to induce the sensation, a journal reports.
Grace Paley, who explored the struggles of ordinary women in precise, pungent stories, was 84.
The court heard testimony from the family of victims on the third day of the trial aides to Saddam Hussein for charges of crimes against humanity.
The ruling by Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister, is a direct challenge to the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
If the Yankees wind up with the wild card, and the Angels keep their momentum, the teams will most likely meet in the 2007 American League Division Series

PHOENIX, Aug. 22 (AP) — Brandon Webb allowed a run in the first inning, stopping his scoreless streak at 42 innings, but he won his sixth consecutive start to lead the Arizona Diamondbacks past the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-2, on Wednesday night.

George Zahringer III of New York City made a 4-foot putt on the 18th hole to edge England’s Gary Wolstenholme, 1-up, yesterday in the first round of match play in the United States Amateur Golf Championship in Daly City, Calif. Thirty-two winners advanced to two rounds of play today.

Less than half the number of blast-resistant trucks will be delivered to Iraq by year’s end than planned because of the time it takes to equip them with radios and armaments and then deliver them by sea.

A 20-year-old Bronx man was fatally stabbed in a building in Fordham about 8:15 p.m. yesterday, the police said. The victim, identified as Rafael Perdomo, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The attacker fled from the scene near the intersection of East 187th Street and Elm Place. There had been no arrests last night, the police said.

A former receptionist at the Sid Jacobson Jewish Community Center was charged yesterday with stealing credit card information from 18 of the organization’s members and using it to bill as much as $20,000 in retail charges. The receptionist, Elizabeth Young, 22, pleaded not guilty at her arraignment on charges of identity theft and grand larceny. Kathleen Rice, the Nassau County district attorney, said Ms. Young stole credit card information when she processed payments last fall. Her lawyer, Glen Hardy, said Ms. Young had nothing to do with the theft.

A 78-year-old woman died after a fire broke out shortly before 6 p.m. yesterday in her apartment complex, the Yonkers police said. The woman, Madeline Paciarello, who lived by herself in a first-floor one-bedroom apartment at Kristensen Houses at 45 Seymour Street, was brought out of the burning building to St. Joseph’s Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead. The fire was under control by 6:15 p.m.; all the other residents of the complex escaped. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.
Despite the loss, José Reyes stole three bases including his 67th, which broke the team record Roger Cedeño set in 1999.
Asian stocks pushed higher early Thursday, as a strong showing on United States markets inspired investors to unwind some of the recent damage.
The Food and Drug Administration said it had not yet detected any chemical or biological contamination in the Chinese-made dog treats.

A western Pennsylvania doctor was charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a 5-year-old autistic boy who died after the doctor administered a chemical treatment, state police said. The boy, Abubakar Tariq Nadama, went into cardiac arrest at the office of the doctor, Roy E. Kerry, after undergoing chelation therapy on Aug. 23, 2005. Chelation (pronounced kee-LAY-shun) removes heavy metals from the body and is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treating heavy metal poisoning. Some people who believe autism is caused by a mercury-containing preservative once used in vaccines say chelation may also help autistic children. The boy’s parents have filed a wrongful death suit against Dr. Kerry, 69, and the state is trying to revoke his license.

An Army major, his wife and his sister were indicted on charges that they accepted up to $9.6 million in bribes for Defense Department contracts in Iraq and Kuwait. The indictment, by a federal grand jury, charges the major, John Cockerham, his wife, Melissa, and his sister Carolyn Blake with conspiracy to defraud the government, commit bribery and obstruct justice, as well as money laundering conspiracy, while Major Cockerham was a contracting officer in Kuwait in 2004 and 2005. He has also been charged with bribery. If convicted of conspiracy charges, all three could face up to 20 years in prison and fines totaling $750,000 each. Major Cockerham could also receive a sentence of up to 15 years in prison if found guilty of bribery.

The California Public Employees’ Retirement System said it accidentally printed the Social Security numbers of almost a half-million retirees on brochures sent out last week. A mail-processing computer inadvertently added the partial or full Social Security number of each retiree on the mailing label attached to a brochure sent to 445,000 people announcing a board election, said a system spokesman, Brad Pacheco. The fund sent letters to its members apologizing and promising new procedures to prevent future mix-ups. The system manages retirement and health care benefits for 1.5 million current and retired public workers and their families.

The oldest of three boys charged in the beating and stoning of a homeless Army veteran in Daytona Beach pleaded no contest to aggravated battery. Prosecutors will recommend that the boy, Jeremy Woods, 17, be sentenced to 15 months in prison and nearly four years of probation for the March attack, said Linda Pruitt, a spokeswoman for the state attorney’s office. Mr. Woods and two 10-year-olds were charged with beating the man, John D’Amico, 58, so badly that he needed reconstructive surgery. Mr. Woods was the only one charged as an adult and could have faced up to 15 years in prison if convicted.

A month after passing a temporary ban on public nudity, the Brattleboro Selectboard voted 3 to 2 on Tuesday to reject a proposed ordinance that would have made the ban permanent. When the temporary ordinance expires next month, public nudity will no longer be illegal. It is all about tolerance, one board member said. “We in this country are going down a slippery slope these days,” said Dora Bouboulis, noting a national newspaper recently published an article about the ordinance under the headline “Tolerant town gets intolerant.”.

An “Arts, Briefly” report on Aug. 11 about the hiring of Shawn Killinger as a host on the QVC shopping network referred incorrectly to the hours she is scheduled to appear beginning in December. She will be seen overnight, not during the day, and her appearances will last three to four hours, not a guaranteed four hours.

An “Arts, Briefly” report yesterday about the casting of Christopher Plummer in a 2008 production of Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra” referred incorrectly to the Canadian theater festival where it will be presented. It is the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, which was until recently known as the Stratford Festival, not the other way around.

A review on Tuesday of the New Juilliard Ensemble’s concert at the Museum of Modern Art, which included a performance of “Umberhulk,” misspelled the surname of the composer of that work, as did the museum program. He is Andy Vores, not Vorhes.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday, about the discovery of remains of a field of manioc grown by the Maya in Central America in the first millennium A.D., referred incorrectly to the nature of the discovery. The researchers said it was the earliest evidence for cultivation, not domestication, of the tuber in the Americas. Manioc was domesticated — that is, modified to become a more usable food resource — a few thousand years earlier, probably in Brazil.

An article on July 31 about efforts to stabilize the shrinking year-round population of Fishers Island, N.Y., an enclave for the wealthy in summer, referred incorrectly to public services on the island. Although most homes have septic tanks, there is in fact a sewer system that serves an estimated two dozen homes, according to an engineer who does inspections on the island.

An article in Business Day on Monday about a promotion in 7-Eleven stores for “The Simpsons Movie” misidentified Gregg Brilliant, who commented on the campaign’s success. He is a spokesman for 20th Century Fox, not Fox Broadcasting.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the efforts of a start-up search-engine company, Accoona, to go public misidentified the publication edited by Danny Sullivan, who commented on the performance of the search engine. He is editor in chief of the blog Search Engine Land, not editor of the online publication Search Engine Watch. (Mr. Sullivan founded Search Engine Watch, now owned by Incisive Media, but is no longer its editor.).

Because of an editing error, an article and headline in Business Day yesterday on the investment returns posted by the endowment of Harvard University misstated the return for fiscal 2007, which ended June 30. The return was 23 percent, not 22.4 percent. (The figure published in The Times did not take into account net distributions to the university.) The article also misstated the value of the University of Virginia endowment. It is $4.3 billion, not $880 million.

An article on Aug. 13, 1997, about an investigation into the police beating and torture of Abner Louima while he was in custody at a Brooklyn station house misstated his age at the time. (The same error appeared in at least nine other articles in 1997 and 2002, the year his case came to trial.) He was 30 then, not 33, and is now 40. A reader of The Times’s Web site noticed the error on a Times Topics page that was updated around the 10th anniversary of the attack.

An art review on Aug. 10 of “A Vicious Undertow,” a film by Jesper Just at the Perry Rubenstein Gallery, referred incorrectly to another filmmaker whose camera work was similar. He is Max Ophuls, not his son, Marcel Ophuls, a documentary maker.
The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, condemned Israel for what he termed an escalation of violence against Palestinians.
The Academy of Sciences of South Africa said its studies had found no scientific basis for the use of nutritional supplements as a first-line defense against H.I.V.
Nepal will cut climbing fees for Mount Everest in the off-season to lure more mountaineers and increase tourism.
Japan’s largest power company, Tokyo Electric Power, took emergency measures for the first time in 17 years to address an imminent power shortage as electric demand hit a record high.
Esteban Batista scored 26 points, including the basket that forced overtime with less than two seconds left in regulation.
The government has slightly eased its two-month rollback of prices, allowing retailers to mark up the prices of some basic commodities and farm goods by 20 percent.
A 60-year-old postman has been arrested on suspicion of stealing mail addressed to Queen Elizabeth II, The Sun reported.
A plan to transform downtown Jamaica, Queens, into a vibrant “airport village” cleared an important City Council committee Wednesday.

A small fire in a restaurant at 511 Lexington Avenue yesterday afternoon led to an evacuation of the Radisson Lexington Hotel, above, fire and hotel officials said. The Fire Department said a fire was reported on the first floor of the building about 3:30 p.m. Fire officials said 78 firefighters responded, and the fire was contained in the ductwork. The fire was under control about 4:30 p.m., fire officials said. Two civilians and one firefighter were treated for minor injuries, the department said. Brian Dunne, a spokesman for the hotel, said the restaurant, Raffles Cafe, was a separate business from the hotel, which was not damaged.

After 54 years, the replacement of Circle Line as the operator of ferries to the Statue of Liberty is going to take a few months more. The National Park Service said yesterday that Hornblower Yachts, the California company it chose to succeed Circle Line, would begin carrying tourists to the statue and Ellis Island on Jan. 1, instead of Oct. 2. But fares will increase by 50 cents on Oct. 2 to $12 for adults and $5 for children. Hornblower is still negotiating to purchase Circle Line’s fleet of seven boats, said Terry MacRae, chief executive of Hornblower. Circle Line, which has operated the service since 1953, has agreed not to contest the park service’s decision to award the ferry contract to Hornblower.

A man who stopped to help a driver in a disabled car on the Prospect Expressway early yesterday was killed when a drunken driver in a third car smashed into his car and the broken-down vehicle, the police said. The police said the victim, Rafael Rafailov, 50, stopped to assist a vehicle that was stopped in the middle southbound lane about 1:20 a.m. Mr. Rafailov and the driver of the disabled car were outside their vehicles when a car driven by Alexey Bushuyev, 22, of Brooklyn, struck their cars, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev and the driver of the disabled car, who was not identified, suffered minor injuries. Mr. Rafailov was declared dead at the scene, the police said. Mr. Bushuyev was charged with driving while intoxicated.

Thirteen people have pleaded guilty as part of an ongoing investigation of the state’s home health care industry, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The 13 — a Medicaid recipient, 10 health aides and 2 nurses — have pleaded guilty to a variety of charges in Brooklyn, Mr. Cuomo said. He said some of the aides had false certifications and lacked proper training and some billed for hours they had not worked. The nurses pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges for false billing, Mr. Cuomo said, while the recipient admitted splitting her payments with a home health aide who provided no services. Each month, more than 80,000 New Yorkers receive some sort of Medicaid-financed home health services.

Four Queens men who prosecutors said were suspected members of the Crips street gang were charged yesterday with robbing at least 16 bodegas in South Queens in the last five months, the authorities said. Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said that in one case, the men are charged with robbing one store and walking down the street to rob another just minutes later. The men, Gregory Burrowes, 27, Jeremy Edwards, 20, Keon Gill, 21, and Ryan Carter, 20, are charged with robbery and assault, Mr. Brown said. He said that not all of them participated in every robbery and that some suspects had not yet been arrested. In two of the robberies, he said, shots were fired and a worker was hit in both legs. The police have not yet arrested the suspected gunman, Mr. Brown said.

A subway track worker was injured yesterday when he fell off a mechanical lift parked beneath the elevated tracks at the Broadway Junction station. A spokesman for Transport Workers Union Local 100 identified the worker as Martin Meyer and said he had worked for New York City Transit for more than 20 years. Mr. Meyer fell from the lift platform about 12:20 p.m. and landed on the cab or hood of the truck on which the lift was mounted, according to the union and the transit agency. The lift was being used to gain access to the underside of the elevated tracks. Mr. Meyer was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where a spokeswoman said he was in stable condition. Paul Fleuranges, a spokesman for the transit agency, said the cause of the accident was unclear. “All the safety equipment was in place,” he said.

Ending a dispute over the location of the ends of the Erie Canal, Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that Albany and Buffalo are the official eastern and western ends of the historic waterway. Supporters believe the designation will help develop the areas, particularly Buffalo’s inner harbor. When the canal was built in 1825 it stretched 363 miles from Albany to Buffalo; an expansion in 1905, which allowed the passage of larger vessels, moved the navigable ends to the Hudson River in Waterford and the Niagara River in Tonawanda.

A 2-year-old boy was killed and two other children critically injured late Tuesday night in a fire at a three-story house, fire officials said yesterday. Firefighters who arrived at the home on Franklin Street around 10:30 p.m. found four children, ages 5 to 2, inside. A woman was standing in the doorway with two other children, said Steve Trella, a Meriden fire marshal. Denise D’Aniello, grandmother of the injured boys, said in a telephone interview, “I kept screaming to the firemen to go upstairs because there was three more babies.” Her grandsons Trent and Tristen D’Aniello were taken to the burn unit of Shriners Hospital for Children in Boston, where a spokeswoman said they were in critical condition. Fire officials said the cause of the blaze was being investigated. The office of the chief medical examiner identified the dead boy as Hunter Jandreau. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Washington hired Ed Tapscott, the former Charlotte Bobcats president, as the director of player development. Tapscott, who was briefly the Knicks’ interim general manager, was Charlotte’s president from 2003 to 2006.

Lindsay Davenport returned yesterday after taking almost a year off to have a child, losing a doubles match at the Pilot Pen in New Haven. Davenport and Lisa Raymond were beaten by Cara Black and Liezel Huber, 6-7 (1), 6-3 and 10-4 in the match tie breaker. Black and Huber have won six doubles titles this year, including the Australian Open and Wimbledon. “Obviously, this is the first step in a long process,” Davenport said.

Rick Hartmann of Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton, N.Y., shot a four-under-par 67 to hold a one-stroke lead after the first round of the 92nd Met Open Championship at The Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, N.Y. A stroke behind Hartmann were Mark Schaare of Knob Hill (N.J.), Charlie Meola of Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., and Anthony Casalino of Willow Ridge in Westchester County. Andrew Giuliani of Van Cortlandt, the 2006 M.G.A. Player of the Year, was at par 71.

Cedric Jones, a New England Patriots wide receiver for nine years and an administrator for the N.F.L. for the past 14, yesterday was named the athletic director of the New York Athletic Club. Jones succeeds 84-year-old Ray Lumpp, who is retiring after 47 years. Lumpp began in 1960, the year Jones was born.Jones played for the Patriots from 1982 to 1990. His last position for the N.F.L. was senior director of youth football. Lumpp was an Olympic gold-medal basketball player in 1948 and played five seasons (1948-53) with the Knicks and the Baltimore Bullets.

The N.C.A.A. placed the Purdue women’s team on two years’ probation yesterday after it determined that Katrina Merriweather, a former assistant, wrote a paper for the former point guard Cherelle George and made more than 100 illegal recruiting calls. 9 P.M. (CNN) GOD’S CHRISTIAN WARRIORS In the late 1970s conservative Christians began to play a larger role in American politics, a response in part to Roe v. Wade, the United States Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. By the 1980 national election the Moral Majority, founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, helped defeat 12 incumbent senators. “Whoever speaks up most gets to shape the culture,” Ron Luce, the evangelical activist, said more recently to a crowd of thousands in San Francisco at this year’s BattleCry rally, above, whose mission is to train young Christians to “battle” secular “virtue terrorists.” In this special, the final installment in a three-part series about religious fervor, Christiane Amanpour looks at the ways evangelicals influence American politics, and speaks with Mr. Falwell in what was to be his last interview, just one week before his death in May, about his battle against abortion and his thoughts on the 2008 presidential campaign.

It’s not often that a writer turns out an article then finds his topic has become his neighbor. But that’s what happened to Michael Hall after he reported a story for the current issue of PLAY on the TV show “Friday Night Lights.” Hall, a senior editor at Texas Monthly, discovered that “Lights,” which is filmed in Austin, was making the rounds of the neighborhoods. “They shot a bar scene half block from my house last week,” Hall says. “They park cameras and trucks and catering services a block from our house in a church parking lot. People are used to seeing them. They’re all over Austin -- bars, record stores, book stores, and generally the hipster places.”.

For their new Hawthorne collection, two ceramists, James Klein and David Reid, who run a Long Island City company called KleinReid, created olive and yellow glazes specially engineered to leave drip marks around the bases of objects fired in the kiln. ''We spent the summer developing the glaze so that it would run and drip and make a natural decorative element'' around the curvaceous forms of the vases, Mr. Klein said. The five handmade vases range from 7 1/2 to 16 inches in height, and are priced between $100 and $190. (Above, Laburnum, at center, is 9 inches tall and costs $130; below, the 12 1/2-inch-tall Belvedere, shown on left and at center, is $140, and the 16-inch-tall Willow, at right, is $190.) Information: (718) 937-3828. TIM McKEOUGH

An article in Business Day on Monday about the pending deal to take Tribune Company private referred incorrectly to Tribune's retirement benefit plans. The company has not halted contributions to retirement plans, nor would the proposed transaction to take the company private eliminate contributions to a retirement plan in exchange for stock ownership. The article also misstated the decline in Tribune's print and online advertising revenue for the first half of 2007 compared with the same period in 2006. The decline was 8.7 percent, not 11.2 percent.

Table Tools, a new set of flatware from Umbra, was designed by Will Alsop, a British architect known for his exuberant modernist buildings. Always on the lookout for interesting forms, Mr. Alsop, shown above in his London studio, modeled the cutlery on his own grip, squeezing strips of clay as though they were utensils. Then he digitized the shapes to create molds for production. The stainless-steel utensils, above right, ''should be comfortable in the hand,'' said Mr. Alsop, who also wanted them to look good on the table. But with a price tag of $40 for a four-piece place setting, he said, ''they're inexpensive, and that's what I'm most delighted about.'' Table Tools will be available in early October at the National Academy Museum Shop, 1083 Fifth Avenue (89th Street), (212) 369-4880, or they can be ordered from umbra.com. TIM McKEOUGH

Burial will take place at a later date at Arlington National Cemetery. Visit the family's personalized online Guestbook at www.AndersonMcQueen.com Anderson-McQueen Funeral Homes, 2201 Dr. MLK Jr. Street North, St. Petersburg, Florida 33704 (727) 822-2059 handling funeral services.

Carbon-footprint calculators are growing like landfills on the Internet. Sites like carbonfootprint.com, safeclimate.net and climatecrisis.net help you calculate your energy use, expressed in a number -- your ''carbon footprint'' -- although that is still an ambiguous figure. How you figure out if you're a big user is tricky (national averages are a moving target, as a tour of three or four such sites shows). But at Dockside Green, a new mixed-use development opening next year in Victoria, British Columbia, residents will be able to track their energy use minute by minute, gauging their habits directly against those of anonymous neighbors. The apartments will be equipped with a device called the MACH-Stat, which shows electricity, water and heat usage, and calculates each household's carbon footprint. ''You'll be able to see your consumption for today and yesterday, for this week and last week,'' said Joe LeRoy, whose company, Houle Controls in Victoria, helped customize the device, which is made by Reliable Controls for Dockside Green. Home installations begin at $2,500. Information: reliablecontrols.com. PENELOPE GREEN

FELSKI--Cynthia A. Entered into God's loving care on August 19, 2007 at the age of 57. Beloved wife of the late Kerry. Loving mother of Paul and Ann. Cherished only child of the late Walter and Marie Sperks. Daughter-in-law of Fern and the late Ervin. Sister-in-law of Connie (Mark) Lichtenberger, Tom and Tim. Caring aunt of Hailey and Whitney. Special niece of the late Ann and the late Jack Chester. Close cousin of Ralph (Karen) and Charles (Rose) Chester and survived by close uncles and cousins. Cyndy was a great cook and hostess, and truly had a knack for making everyone feel special in her home. She grew up in Chicago and graduated from Marquette University and received her Masters degree from CUNY Baruch College. She retired last year from Lenox Hill Hospital as Administrative Director of Pathology, Cyndy was a devout Catholic and was to be inducted next month as a Lady in the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. She was also a proud member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum (New York Chapter). Cyndy will be deeply missed by her family and all whose lives she touched. We are deeply indebted to the Fisher family and our close friends for all they've done for us. If desired, memorials to Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, NY would be appreciated. Visitation will be Thursday 7-9pm, Friday 2-5 pm and 7-9pm at the ''Heights & Hill Funeral Directors'', 115 Atlantic Ave., Brooklyn Heights, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday, 11:15am at Assumption Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn Heights, NY. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery Brooklyn, NY

The British singer Amy Winehouse has pulled out of concerts in the United States and Canada next month to ''address her health,'' BBC News reported yesterday. Ms. Winehouse, 23, recently canceled performances amid reports that she had been in and out of rehab. Her spokeswoman, Tracy Miller, said Ms. Winehouse had been advised to postpone her North American shows until next year. ''Until then, Amy has been ordered to rest and is working with medical professionals to address her health,'' she said. Ms. Winehouse was hospitalized earlier this month for ''severe exhaustion,'' and recently canceled concerts, including two with the Rolling Stones in Germany. It is unclear whether she will appear as at the MTV Music Video Awards in Las Vegas on Sept. 9.

MINING METHOD IS QUESTIONED The Bush administration is on the verge of enshrining the practice by coal-mining companies of removing mountaintops, a 20-year-old technique that involves blasting off the tops of mountains and dumping the rubble into valleys. Not surprisingly, environmentalists oppose the plan. [A1.]

An article on Aug. 13, 1997, about an investigation into the police beating and torture of Abner Louima while he was in custody at a Brooklyn station house misstated his age at the time. (The same error appeared in at least nine other articles in 1997 and 2002, the year his case came to trial.) He was 30 then, not 33, and is now 40. A reader of The Times's Web site noticed the error on a Times Topics page that was updated around the 10th anniversary of the attack.

Music sales may be slow these days, but last week the soundtrack to Disney's ''High School Musical 2'' -- whose premiere on Friday on the Disney Channel set a cable ratings record -- sold 615,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, the second-best sales week for any album this year. (Linkin Park's ''Minutes to Midnight'' sold 623,000 in May.) Miley Cyrus's ''Hannah Montana 2: Meet Miley Cyrus,'' also a Disney release, rose two spots on the Billboard chart to No. 2, with 83,000 copies sold. The first ''High School Musical'' album sold 30,000 to reach No. 16; its total sales now stand at 4.1 million. Dave Matthews and Tim Reynolds's ''Live at Radio City'' (RCA), recorded in April, opened at No. 3 with 70,000, and last week's No. 1, UGK's ''Underground Kingz'' (Jive), fell to No. 6 with 60,000, a 62 percent drop.

If you have ever longed to peer into the gardens behind the electric gates and tall hedges in the Hamptons but were afraid of snarling dogs and irate owners, this is your chance. On Saturday, the Guild Hall of East Hampton will hold a lecture and garden tour called ''The Garden as Art,'' offering access to six private gardens: the oceanfront estates of Alexandra Munroe and Robert Rosenkranz (bottom), Chris Browne and Andrew Gordon, and Barbara and Lloyd Macklowe; and the village gardens of David and Jeanie Orenstein (below), Carol and Norman Mercer, and Craig Socia. Tickets are $125 for the garden tour and $50 for breakfast and a lecture by the plant explorer Dan Hinkley, introduced by Martha Stewart. Information: (631) 324-0806. CHRISTOPHER MASON

CURRAN--Catherine G. The St. Hilda's & St. Hugh's community expresses our profound sorrow for the loss of Catherine G. Curran, grandmother of Michael McPhee, class of 2007. Mrs. Curran was a great supporter of St. Hilda's & St. Hugh's since 1995, when Michael enrolled in our school as a toddler. The school sends its sincere condolences to the Curran and McPhee families.

GROSSMAN--Charles. The Senior Management and staff of ING Clarion are deeply saddened by the death of Charlie Grossman. Charlie's leadership and vision contributed to the growth of our firm, and we all were the beneficiaries of his wisdom, wit and grace. Charlie was a great partner and a good friend to many of us. He will be greatly missed. Our prayers are with his family. ING Clarion

MANY new and amusing products for the home were introduced last week at Accent on Design, a trade show for the home furnishings industry held in New York at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Among the lighthearted items on display were fabric printed to look like wood veneer; a coffee table book that opened into a lamp; and a half-electric, half-candle-powered table light.

BERNSTEIN--Theodore. Working Theater mourns Ted's loss, a warm, committed individual and dear friend of our Company. We'll miss him and always be grateful for his support.

CHEEVER--Henry Jackson Sargent (Harry), of Riverside, Connecticut, born January 20, 1951, died tragically as the result of a boating accident on August 18 in Wareham, Massachusetts, a place he loved. A graduate of the Groton School, Harvard College and Harvard Business School, his career in banking spanned more than 30 years. He remained with Chemical Bank through a number of mergers, eventually retiring from JPMorgan in 2006. He is survived by his loving family: his wife, Margaret Sproul Cheever; two children, David Archibald Cheever and Hannah Margaret Cheever; a sister, Julia Cheever Altshuler of San Francisco, CA; two brothers, Francis Sargent Cheever, Jr. of Washington, D.C., and George Martin Cheever of Pittsburgh, PA; and numerous nieces and nephews. Harry was dearly loved and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, Connecticut at 11:00 am on Saturday, August 25. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 200 Riverside Avenue, Riverside, CT 06878 or to the Fairfield County Chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 200 Connecticut Ave., Suite 5H, Norwalk, CT 06854.

WOLF--Melvin. We mourn the passing of Mel Wolf, a lifetime friend and former business partner, co-founder of Wolf & Macklowe Company. His warmth, compassion and kindness will be missed. We enjoyed 45 years of wonderful adventures and memories together. We will miss you. Harry, Linda and Billy Macklowe.
DIMIAN--Bella Verea, of New York City, died peacefully at her home on Tuesday, August 21st. Survived by her brother Leonard Verea and her nephew David Lapid. Loving wife of the late George Dimian.

Cherished greatgrandfather of Shira, Arielle, Leora, Ilana Lupkin, Jacob William Walker, Rebecca and Sammy Gross. Founding partner of Daving Quality Paper Corp. Services today, 9:45am ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

Trevor Day School occupies the Andrew Goodman Building on West 88th St., dedicated in 1993 to the memory of Dr. Goodman's son, Andrew. We daily honor the achievements and sacrifices of the Goodmans and extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Goodman's family. David M. Thomas President, Board of Trustees Pamela J. Clarke Head of School Trevor Day School

Cherished grandfather of Rae (Mike) Beth, John (Shannon) Colin (Melissa), David (Meghan), Matthew, Leigh, Zachary, Rachel, Michael. Five great-grandchildren. Beloved uncle of John and Joan Rapoport, grandniece Sara Rapoport and grandnephew James Rapoport. Service August 24, 2007 at 9:30am, I.J Morris Funeral Home in Dix Hills, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to Elizabeth Hospice 150 W. Crest St. Escondido, CA 92025.

PACKER--Augusta Landes. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Augusta Landes Packer. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Howard F. Sharfstein, President

A New York City judge has ordered the hip-hop artist Foxy Brown, right, jailed for violating her probation, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Officials had sought to have her probation revoked after she was arrested on charges that she hit a Brooklyn neighbor with her cellphone, said Jack Ryan, a spokesman for the city's Department of Probation. They also complained that Ms. Brown had skipped her anger management classes and failed to get permission before traveling outside the city. Judge Melissa Jackson of Manhattan Criminal Court ruled on Wednesday that Ms. Brown would remain behind bars until a Sept. 5 hearing. Ms. Brown, whose real name is Inga Marchand, was on probation for attacking two manicurists at a nail salon in 2004. She was arrested for allegedly assaulting Arlene Raymond on July 30, after the two got into a fight over the volume at which Ms. Brown was playing her car stereo.

FELSKI--Kerry P. Entered into God's loving care on August 19, 2007 at the age of 58 years. Loving husband of the late Cynthia. Dear father of Paul and Ann. Devoted son of Fern and the late Ervin. Brother of Connie (Mark) Lichtenberger, Tom and Tim. Caring uncle of Hailey and Whitney. Also survived by aunts, uncles, cousins, other relatives, co-workers and many friends. Kerry was a Senior VP at Morgan Stanley. He grew up in the Midwest and graduated from Marquette University, and has a Masters degree from Washington University. He was to be knighted next month into the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem, an honor he was looking forward to. He was also a proud Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum (New York Chapter). So many people will miss Kerry's commanding presence and generosity. Special thanks to the Fisher family and our close friends for being there when we needed you the most. If desired, memorials to Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, NY would be appreciated. Visitation will be held Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the ''Heights & Hill Funeral Directors'', 115 Atlantic Ave., Brooklyn Heights, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday at 11:15am at Assumption Roman Catholid Church, Brooklyn Heights, NY. Interment to follow at the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY

IF whitewater kayaks are the BMWs of the paddling world, recreational kayaks are the minivans. Meant for use on protected bodies of water, recreational kayaks are the widest, most stable and cheapest available. They also used to be synonymous with low quality, but in the last five years manufacturers have vastly improved the boats to woo beginners. ''Manufacturers are developing better designs with large, nonintimidating cockpits, plush seats and comfort features such as cup holders and dashboards,'' said Murray Hamilton, the manager of new product technology for Necky Kayaks. Since even novices have little to fear in them, they have also become the most popular.

For those who liked the look of leather but wanted something lower-maintenance, the choices used to be vinyls like Naugahyde and faux leather. But now Joseph Noble, a Dallas fabric company, has introduced Technology Leather, a new vinyl that is more supple than many others and more durable than leather. It comes in various textures including Brilliant, above, a dead ringer for patent leather. Unlike real patent leather, though, it will not crack or wrinkle. Brilliant is available in 12 colors and costs $39.50 a yard (to the trade). Information: (214) 741-8100 or josephnoble.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

LASHIN--Marilyn. Loving daughter of Nathan and Sylvia. Beloved sister, dear aunt and great-aunt. Marilyn was a pioneer female attorney who enjoyed all aspects of life itself. She fought COPD beyond all expectations, her family and friends will miss her. Donations to American Lung Association. Graveside service August 24, 11am, Mt. Hebron, Queens , NY.

FINE--Morris, 93, passed away peacefully on August 20, 2007. He is survived by his wife of 27 years, Anne, his children Richard, Lawrence, and Margery, daughter-inlaw Rae, and his granddaughter Emma. He will be missed as well by his nieces and nephew Judy, Mel and Adele, and by his stepchildren and grandchildren Paul, Carmela, Jonathan, Jamie and Carly. He is predeceased by his first wife, Beatrice, and his sister Bertha. Morris looked back with pride on his many wonderful years of interesting and important work for the American Jewish Committee. He will be remembered by his many friends, young and old, as forever kind and loving. Services on Thursday, 12:45 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

WEINSHENKER--Murray (Mickey). Today the world is a sadder place. Mickey has died -He and Carol, his wife of 52 years, shared a good and loving life bringing into this world three fantastic kids, Lori Streeter, Michael Weinshenker and Mindy Weinshenker - Boerrigter who together with Alan, Naomi and Hans gave us the most fabulous grandchildren, Joe, Josh, Jess, Matt, Daniel, Tarissa and Dustin; the circle of life continues. Add to that our extended family and our warm and wonderful friends; life was good. Mickey is gone but his legacy remains. We will miss his sense of humor and his kindness. We will miss his passionate anger at the injustice in this world. But most of all we will miss our Mickey, our dad, our poppy, and our grandpa. Rest easy honey. Memorial Service, Friday 11:00am at Greenwood Cemetery's Historical Chapel in Brooklyn, NY.

Vladislav Tkachiev and Maxime Vachier-Lagrave have tied for first in the French Championship. Andrei Sokolov finished third. The results can be found on the French Chess Federation's Web site.

In this week's Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reports on the situation of car buyers who get stuck with lemons. All 50 states have laws regarding such vehicles, but he finds that in many cases the cars have been shipped to a state where they can be resold as if they had clean records. He writes:

The Democratic National Committee meets tomorrow in Washington to discuss whether to impose sanctions on Florida for moving its primary up from Feb. 5 to Jan. 29. (The party had stipulated that only a handful of states, including Iowa and New Hampshire, were allowed to hold nominating contests before February). The Florida Democratic Party demurred, and now the D.N.C. appears to be considering stripping the state of its delegates and telling the presidential candidates not to campaign there.

Biogen Idec shares moved higher Friday on news that the Federal Trade Commission has approved activist investor Carl C. Icahn to purchase more of the company's shares, MarketWatch reported. Stock in the biotech company rose 5 percent to $62.89, a 52-week high.
For the first time in more than 50 years, the median home price is expected to decline in 2007.
So many stage actors persevere with no or little pay, waiting for a break that pays.  Damian Baldet finally got his.

Update 3:45 p.m. EasternJohn Schwartz called The Lede from the courthouse with an update: After the lunch break, the proceedings were taken up mainly by the defense's efforts to persuade the judge that the police acted without Captain Nowak's consent in searching her car and in taking her statement without her lawyer present -- familiar battlegrounds in many criminal cases (not to mention television shows).

Negotiations over the fate of Home Depot's professional supply unit are likely to drag on through the weekend as financing of the $10.3 billion deal remains up in the air, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Bankers and lawyers are expected to keep battling over whether the banks in the deal can withdraw their financing commitments, in what one person told The New York Times was "the most expensive game of chicken you've ever played."
Traveling with the Edwards family in Iowa, it became clear that running for president and raising children do not always fit together neatly.
Paper Cuts is on hiatus.

Sounding positively Rudy-esque, Senator Hillary Clinton raised the specter yesterday of a terrorist attack before next year's election. She said that such a thing could help the Republicans keep the White House -- unless she were the Democratic nominee.

Honda recently released the vitals on its 2008 Accord, which hits showrooms Sept. 12. We'll have some early driving impressions in the blog next week, followed by a full review in the Automobiles section of The Times. Until then, here are some early returns.

In the Democratic presidential race, it's been a week of ambiguously controversial remarks. Michelle Obama got things going with "if you can't run your own house ", and now The New York Post reports that Hillary Clinton, in a New Hampshire appearance, had this to say about a potential devastating terrorist attack on the United States: "It's a horrible prospect to ask yourself, 'What if? What if?' But if certain things happen between now and the election, particularly with respect to terrorism, that will automatically give the Republicans an advantage again, no matter how badly they have mishandled it, no matter how much more dangerous they have made the world."

I'm about to go on vacation, so this will be my last post until after Labor Day. As I'm about to leave I'm thinking about some wines that I've enjoyed in the last week or so and how inadequate our usual descriptive language is to characterize their appeal.
Thanks for your comments and suggestions about ceiling height. I spoke to John Agnelli twice this morning and, as usual, he has his own point of view on the ceiling issue.

This Sunday's issue of the Book Review - the cover is at right - features, among other things, Darcey Steinke's review of Mary Gordon's new memoir, David Brooks on Drew Westen's book "The Political Brain" and Gerald Howard's essay on Norman Mailer's 1970 movie "Maidstone."

The Lab judging panel will be busy this weekend picking a winner in the speak-to-the-Prime-Designer contest. (You can still enter today.) As they toil tirelessly, let us ponder this designer's ethics, and whether it's better to live in simulated joy or be really miserable.

Coming soon from The New York Times: a new blog on the fierce competition and engrossing culture of college football. From the Bowl Championship Series and Heisman Trophy watch, to news and features about one's alma mater or local collegiate team, The New York Times will take readers inside America's great fall weekend ritual with interviews, insights and analysis from the tailgates to the sidelines.
Mr. Barre was a prominent economist who served as French prime minister during the presidency of Valery Giscard d’Estaing in the 1970s.

The Imperial College in London awarded a doctorate in astrophysics -- a real one, earned the old-fashioned way with an abstruse, math-heavy 48,000-word thesis -- on Thursday to, of all people, Brian May, who sings and plays guitar in the rock band Queen and wrote or cowrote "We Will Rock You" and many of the band's other hits.
As homeowners fall behind on mortgages, regulators are paying closer attention to advertising. Quicken Loans no longer offers the Secure Advantage Loan.

Gary Rivlin of The Times reported on Thursday about a curious trade dispute between the United States and Antigua and Barbuda over Internet gambling sites. The tiny Caribbean nation instigated a trade complaint "against the United States, claiming its ban against Americans gambling over the Internet violated Antigua and Barbuda's rights as a member of the W.T.O." Antigua won the case in three different forums, and now is asking "the trade organization to grant a rare form of compensation if the American government refuses to accept the ruling: permission for Antiguans to violate intellectual property laws by allowing them to distribute copies of American music, movie and software products, among others."
Silicon Valley denizens have been claiming that the credit crunch afflicting much of the deal landscape won't affect them. In one case, their having been proven right has burned naysayers.

A food tour is a way to participate in, and not just observe, life in New York City. And with the right guide, it can be almost exhilarating. Have you been on a worthwhile culinary tour of New York? Share it here.

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, who has said that his positions on some issues have "evolved" or changed in recent years, is set to discuss the details of a his health care plan in Florida today, which also seems to be something of an evolution from proposals he has supported in the past.
Daniel Clowes's books include "Ghost World" and "David Boring."
To our readers:

For all the lumps the Blackstone Group has taken in the past two months, Stephen A. Schwarzman deserves credit for being the first of the buyout titans to take his firm public. So says Breakingviews, but there's a caveat: while Mr. Schwarzman has done well for himself, he will have to start making money for his new public investors as well.
Precision Therapeutics, a life-sciences company, filed on Friday to raise up to $80.5 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

After being on the block for more than a year, eccentric fashion designer Betsey Johnson has finally found a buyer, The New York Post reported. Private-equity firm Castanea Partners has agreed to take a controlling stake in the company, known for its club girl chic and quirky fashions, sources told the paper.

HRJ Capital, the investment firm whose partners include retired football players Joe Montana and Ronnie Lott, said one of its funds lost 12.3 percent in the first two weeks of August, erasing most of its 2007 gain, Bloomberg News reported.

Riverstone, an energy-focused private equity firm, said on Friday that it has hired John Browne, the former chief executive of BP, as a managing director and the managing partner of its European operations. The firm will open an office in London, where Mr. Browne lives.
The Blackstone Group has gotten out its calculator and tallied up the cost of a Congressional proposal to more than double the tax rates buyout firms.
Past-their-prime rock bands have a new groupie: venture capital.

The fate of hedge funds and investors with funds tied up in collapsed U.S. investment management firm Sentinel was placed Thursday night in the hands of an independent bankruptcy trustee, amid continuing unease over the way certain creditors of the firm were treated.

By discrediting virtually every step taken thus far to help the housing market and the mortgage industry, Countrywide Financial Chief Executive Angelo Mozilo killed Wall Street's buzz about the credit crunch being over.
Armchair quarterbacks will be able to put their play-calling skills to the test this football season thanks to a new online fantasy game from startup YOUbeQB.

The Canadian government released a report today that was supposed to outline how Canada would meet its Kyoto goals _ to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 6 percent from 1990 levels by 2012. Instead that report mostly explains why the goal can't be met.

A worsening credit crunch and its broad impact on financial markets has some dealmakers predicting that leveraged buyouts are on hold for the rest of the year and perhaps well into 2008, Reuters reported.

Accredited Home Lenders said on Thursday that Chief Financial Officer John Buchanan is resigning effective Aug. 31. The company disclosed the resignation in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Shareholders of WCE Holdings, which owns the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, on Thursday approved a takeover offer worth C$50 million ($47.6 million) by IntercontinentalExchange.

Merrill Lynch has put its own money to work alongside a couple of hedge funds in yet another highly structured equity deal, which will provide financing for an Indonesian coal mine at a time when global demand for this commodity continues to increase, FinanceAsia reported.
Mark Cuban, who made his $2.3 billion fortune as an internet entrepreneur, has some news for you: The Internet is "dead and boring", Mr. Cuban told Portfolio.com in a Q&A.
All In...
Toronto-Dominion Bank posted a 39 percent increase in fiscal third-quarter net income on higher profit throughout the company and sought to explain why it may hold onto its online brokerage unit.

Shareholders in steel services company Ryerson elected 11 directors nominated by the company at its annual stockholders meeting Thursday morning, according to an early tally, thwarting efforts by activist investor Harbinger Capital to install its own slate.
Bank of America Center, an architectural icon on downtown Houston's skyline, has been sold to Dallas-based Novati Group and an affiliate of the General Electric Pension Trust.

Bruce Wasserstein is no stranger to the gyrations of Wall Street. In a Q&A with BusinessWeek, the Lazard chieftain, who has helped broker more than $250 billion in deals in his career, gives his take on the latest market meltdown.
Silicon Valley investors will be soon waking up to JAVA - and Sun Microsystems hopes the new ticker symbol will help perk up its stock.
Could the subprime skunk that is fouling the public market actually be a bit of a blessing for Silicon Valley's high-technology investors?
New York's Public Service Commission voted unanimously Thursday to authorize National Grid's $7.3 billion stock acquisition of KeySpan.
For presidential candidates campaigning in Iowa, the place to be is the state fair. Diners are popular in New Hampshire. But for those visiting Silicon Valley, it's the Googleplex.

The size of the commercial paper market, a crucial source of short-term financing for businesses, decreased 4.2 percent last week, the biggest drop in at least seven years, as investors fled asset-backed debt and opted for the safety of Treasuries.
As federal regulators have pursued insider trading cases this year, one of the oddities they have spotted is an increase in cases involving husbands and wives.
A federal appeals court has rejected the attempt by regulators to block Whole Foods Market's $565 million takeover of the rival Wild Oats Markets.
BNP Paribas, the French bank, said on Thursday that it would reopen three funds next week that it had frozen in a step that accelerated a slide in financial stocks.
The Bank of China, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, said Thursday that it held almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by American subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.
United Airlines said Thursday that it might sell all or part of its maintenance operations to outside investors to raise cash to modernize and expand the unit.
To attract new clientele and more business, McDonald's is going modern in Europe.
Abu Dhabi National Energy, a state-controlled United Arab Emirates investor in oil and power assets, agreed to buy the Canadian unit of Pioneer Natural Resources for $540 million.

Home Depot was scrambling Thursday night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, according to The New York Times.
After leaving a one-bedroom rental in Gramercy Park, a family found a home in a Crown Heights row house.
Each August, two married directors invite actors, musicians and designers to their house on the shore of Lake Lucille to spend a week working on a play.
An exhibition of sketches by automobile designers offers a rare glimpse inside Detroit’s design studios in the muscle-car era.
An excerpt from the new American Girl book.
Lifetime’s two-hour movie is an uneasy combination of crime thriller, romantic melodrama and snuff film that doesn’t ask us to suspend our disbelief so much as overcome our gag reflex.
Images from the artist Bob Cassilly's project to transform a St. Louis cement factory.
