A charter school in Florida has come under fire for tying its Hebrew-language based curriculum to religion. Opponents of the Ben Gamla Charter School say that it is impossible to teach Hebrew - and aspects of Jewish culture - outside of a religious context.
More vérité than cinema, the documentary “Skid Row” is so raw that it’s virtually unwatchable.
A surreal nightmare of gleaming surfaces and razor-sharp edges, “The Bothersome Man” unfolds in a sterile city where nothing is quite as it seems.
“Resurrecting the Champ” is a cautionary fable that every journalistic go-getter dreaming of front-page bylines would do well to heed.
As “The Nanny Diaries” wobbles along uncertainly, it rests on the tense, squared shoulders of Laura Linney.
“Kamp Katrina” chronicles a married couple who  opened their backyard to displaced people on the condition that they find jobs.
Luridly earnest and laughably immoral, “Illegal Tender” is an old genre movie with a new look. Call it Hispanixploitation.
“The Hottest State” doggedly peels away the gloss to dive into the emotional swamp where two young people get lost in each other.
Despite their quirks, the three real estate agents and their clients — three couples in search of a dream home — featured in “Closing Escrow” are improbably endearing.
“Right at Your Door” is  a doomsday-style film by Chris Gorak with a twist worth waiting for.
The documentary “Deep Water” begins like a Boy’s Own adventure tale but ends up more akin to tragedy.
That weird exhalation you hear at the multiplex these days is the sound of female characters settling for less than they deserve. It happens again in “Dedication.”
The maudlin, grotesque western “September Dawn” apes “Schindler’s List” in hopes of creating a Christian Holocaust picture.
With “Mr. Bean’s Holiday,” the British comedian Rowan Atkinson continues a tradition that in the right hands never gets stale: comic pantomime.
Military prosecutors argued in a special appeals court that defects in their cases identified by two military judges can be repaired and that prosecutions at Guantánamo can proceed.
Senator John McCain, who turns 71 next week, hopes to be the oldest person elected to a first term as president.
A federal judge in Miami cleared the way for the former Panamanian leader to face money laundering charges.
A funeral was held today at St. Patrick’s Cathedral for Robert Beddia, a 23-year-veteran of the fire department who died on Saturday doing the work he loved.
Michael Vick admitted in court papers today that he financed gambling associated with a dog fighting ring.
The number of detainees held by the American-led military coalition in Iraq has grown by 50 percent under the troop increase ordered by President Bush, military officers say.
Shares in the bank fell 5.4 percent in Hong Kong a day after it reported holding almost $9.7 billion in securities backed by subprime mortgages.
Today’s anti-Hamas demonstration was the largest since the Islamic militant group seized control of Gaza after a week of factional fighting in June.
Three British soldiers died in an incident involving a bomb dropped by a U.S. plane, British officials said.
The figures provided a break from dismal housing news, but economists cautioned the rise was unlikely to last.
At least eight Iraqis were killed in the fighting in northwest Baghdad early this morning, the military said.
Two police officers were killed today in the Chechen capital of Grozny as they pursued a rebel, who was also killed, the Chechen Interior Ministry said.
A 71-year-old man was killed after he was struck by a train while leaning over on a station platform, the police said.

Nykesha Sales scored 25 points to lead the Connecticut Sun to a 93-88 victory in triple overtime against the visiting Indiana Fever in the W.N.B.A. Eastern Conference semifinals. It was the first overtime playoff game in league history. Connecticut (19-16) took a 1-0 lead in the best-of-three series. Anna DeForge had a season-high 31 points for the Fever (21-14).In Western Conference semifinals opener last night, Nicole Powell scored 22 points and the Sacramento Monarchs played sterling defense in an 86-65 victory over the visiting San Antonio Silver Stars.
The Padres took a wild game from the Mets at Shea Stadium on Thursday night.

David Beckham, fresh off a flight from London after playing for England on Wednesday, got feisty after being tackled from behind by Jesse Marsch of Chivas USA last night in a 3-0 win over the Los Angeles Galaxy in Carson, Calif.Marsch ran up behind Beckham, the Galaxy’s captain, and applied a high kick to his upper right hip during injury time at the end of the first half. Beckham ran up to Marsch, shouting in his face. A shoving match ensued between the teams.Beckham was in the starting lineup about six hours after arriving from London.

Home Depot was scrambling last night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, people involved in the talks said.

An article Aug. 4, about a Congressional report that criticized the Securities and Exchange Commission’s handling of an insider trading investigation of the Pequot hedge fund, misstated one aspect of the report’s findings. The article stated that the report said there was no evidence that John J. Mack, a Wall Street executive, had provided inside information to Pequot. In fact, the report drew no conclusion about whether insider trading had occurred or whether Mr. Mack had provided inside information, although it did say there was “more than a sufficient basis” to question Mr. Mack as part of the investigation and that the S.E.C. had erred in resisting an investigator’s request to do so.

A front-page article on Monday about the impact of the “High School Musical” movies on the fortunes of the Disney Channel referred imprecisely to the channel’s current viewership among children 6 to 11 and 9 to 14. It is the highest-rated basic-cable channel for those age groups in prime time, not overall.

A listing of American military deaths on July 13 misidentified the country in which Master Sgt. Randy J. Gillespie was killed. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq. An updated Names of the Dead appears today on Page A12.

An article on Aug. 15 about the names on the seating list for the funeral of Brooke Astor, the Park Avenue socialite and philanthropist, referred incorrectly to the hymns that Mrs. Astor wanted sung at the service. They came from the hymnal, not from the 1928 version of the Book of Common Prayer, of the Episcopal Church, to which Mrs. Astor belonged. The article also misstated at one point part of the name of a New York City arts group Mrs. Astor supported. It is the Municipal Art Society, not Arts.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday, about the release of the Iranian-American academic Haleh Esfandiari from an Iranian prison on bail, misstated how Lee H. Hamilton, the head of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, got the answer to his plea to Iran’s supreme leader for her freedom. It was from the Iranian mission to the United Nations in New York, not the Iranian Embassy. (Iran and the United States have not had diplomatic relations since April 1980).

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday, about the release of the Iranian-American academic Haleh Esfandiari from an Iranian prison on bail, misstated how Lee H. Hamilton, the head of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, got the answer to his plea to Iran’s supreme leader for her freedom. It was from the Iranian mission to the United Nations in New York, not the Iranian Embassy. (Iran and the United States have not had diplomatic relations since April 1980).
United Airlines said yesterday that it might sell all or part of its maintenance operations to outside investors to raise cash to modernize and expand the unit.

The trading company Sumitomo said it and three partners planned to invest about $3.3 billion to develop a nickel project in Madagascar amid increasing worldwide demand for nonferrous metals. Sumitomo and the Korea Resources Corporation of South Korea will join with two Canadian companies, the Sherritt International Corporation and SNC Lavalin, to develop a nickel mine, build smelters and create shipping infrastructure, the company said. Production is expected to begin in the second half of 2010, said Sumitomo, based in Tokyo.

Japan’s central bank, the Bank of Japan, left its interest rates unchanged because of worries about the fallout from the credit squeeze in the United States. Before the subprime mortgage crisis emerged in the United States, the markets had expected the Bank of Japan to raise the pivotal overnight call rate, now at 0.50 percent.

Toronto-Dominion Bank posted a 39 percent increase in fiscal third-quarter net income on higher profit throughout the company. For the period that ended July 31, the company posted net income of 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($1 billion), or 1.53 Canadian dollars a share, compared with 796 million Canadian dollars, or 1.09 Canadian dollars a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent, to 3.65 billion Canadian dollars, or about $3.43 billion.

Abu Dhabi National Energy, a state-controlled United Arab Emirates investor in oil and power assets, agreed to buy the Canadian unit of Pioneer Natural Resources for $540 million. Production at the Canadian unit of Pioneer, based in Irving, Tex., is more than 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day and will help Abu Dhabi National come closer to its goal of producing 100,000 barrels a day.

The cement maker Holcim increased profit more than analysts estimated on expansion in China and India and may acquire a controlling stake in Ambuja Cements of India. Second-quarter net income more than tripled, to 2.07 billion Swiss francs ($1.72 billion), bolstered by a gain of 1.1 billion francs from the sale of a stake in its South African unit, Holcim, based in Jona, Switzerland, said. Sales rose 16 percent, to 7.27 billion francs. Holcim will offer up to $1.34 billion to gain a majority of Ambuja, based in Mumbai.

Chile’s economy expanded at the fastest pace in two years in the second quarter, bolstering expectations that the central bank will continue to raise interest rates to prevent accelerating growth and consumer demand from stoking inflation. The economy expanded 6.1 percent from a year earlier, the central bank reported on its Web site, the biggest expansion since 6.3 percent growth in the first quarter of 2005.
Soaring costs have apparently doomed an ambitious project to build what might have been the nation’s first offshore windmills.
New Jersey officials are grappling with an order that law enforcement agencies inquire about the immigration status of people they arrest.
The Police Department has fired a counterterrorism detective who failed a drug test, finding that his claim that his wife had served him marijuana-spiked meatballs was not credible.
A retired New York City police sergeant has been cleared of charges that he participated in the beating of a tourist.
A State Supreme Court judge dismissed a lawsuit in which a group of tenants claimed that the owners of a housing complex violated rent stabilization laws.
Rape suspects can be forced to undergo H.I.V. testing under a law signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.
A North Wildwood man has been arrested in the fatal stabbing of a Welsh tourist.
A veteran city official admitted in State Supreme Court that he had accepted paid trips from contractors doing business with Buffalo.
A Long Island man who posed as a lawyer was convicted in State Supreme Court of stealing $6 million and practicing law without a license, prosecutors said.
A West Windsor woman pleaded guilty to criminal restraint for forcing an immigrant to care for her sick husband and do housekeeping, prosecutors said.
Los Angeles appears to be in a centuries-long seismic lull between periods of powerful earthquake activity, while communities inland could be at higher risk of big quakes.
A Marine drill instructor has been charged with 224 counts of abusing recruits, a Marine spokesman said.
The truck driver convicted in the nation’s deadliest human smuggling incident was sentenced to new prison terms he will serve along with a life sentence already given.
Immigration agents raided the world’s largest hog processing plant and also homes in four surrounding counties, arresting 28 people suspected of identity theft.
A full federal appeals court will hear the case of Ali al-Marri, the only person on the American mainland known to be held by the military as an enemy combatant.
Senate leaders tapped colleagues to recommend whether State Senator Louis DeLuca should be punished for asking someone to threaten his granddaughter’s husband.
Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, has told colleagues he will not seek re-election next year, Republican officials said.
Sectarian violence and new fighting brought by U.S.-led operations are accelerating the partition of the country into sectarian enclaves.
Since leaving Congress, Robert G. Torricelli has made donations from his Senate campaign chest to politicians with influence over his business interests.
Many of those mourning Joseph Graffagnino, a firefighter who died in the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, expressed indignation at the loss of life.
For Division I athletes in sports like fencing, winning championships does not guarantee financial stability.
If President Bush took the time to study the real lessons of Vietnam, he would not be so eager to lead America deeper into the quagmire he has created in Iraq.
One glance at the ruptured steam pipe that ran under Lexington Avenue leaves no doubt how it produced a geyser of steam and muddy water.
On the third day of the trial of Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali, testimony revealed that two brothers were thrown to their deaths from a helicopter.
The ruling on Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister, is a direct challenge to the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
A stark U.S. intelligence assessment gives a dim prognosis on the likelihood that Iraqi politicians can heal deep sectarian rifts before next spring.
The governor of North Carolina signed legislation that would protect subprime borrowers from highly risky adjustable-rate mortgages.
The team, which has sent 19 players to the disabled list this season, is unraveling.
West Littleton was called to the mound on Wednesday night for what might be considered the easiest save in baseball history.
In a retail market keen on the word “natural,” exports of Brazil’s beauty products have been rising quickly.
For foreclosed borrowers hit with unexpected tax bills, figuring out if they have been wrongly charged can be an insurmountable burden.
Barnes & Noble said Thursday  that second-quarter profit rose 8.9 percent as demand for the latest Harry Potter book produced the fastest revenue growth in almost three years.

An editorial yesterday about the Central Intelligence Agency incorrectly cited the changing of the name of the C.I.A. headquarters building as a sign of shifting priorities by its former director, George Tenet, after President Bush assumed office in 2001. The building was renamed in 1999 by an act of Congress to honor George H.W. Bush, the current president’s father.
The PGA Tour’s postseason experiment seems to be designed for a golfer like Rory Sabbatini.
The Bush administration’s refusal to comply with open-government laws is ultimately more important than any single scandal.
Policy makers and Wall Street analysts are being forced to scale back their expectations for growth in the overall economy.
A military investigator has recommended dismissing all charges against a Marine Corps infantryman accused of killing Iraqi civilians in Haditha in late 2005.
A public school has stirred debate over whether it can teach Hebrew without violating the church-state divide.

A man being questioned in a homicide escaped from police custody yesterday afternoon by jumping from a third-floor window at a Queens police station onto the roof of a lower building, the police said.

Pinch-hitter Kenny Lofton’s infield single against Joel Zumaya broke a scoreless tie with two outs in the 10th inning yesterday, and the Cleveland Indians went on to beat the host Detroit Tigers, 3-1.
The Bush administration has said for the first time that American telecommunications companies played a crucial role in domestic eavesdropping.
The team has decided to leave the pitcher in Class A in Florida for now, because it allows him to take advantage of the rehabilitation services at its minor league complex.
Finding a contractor capable of dismantling the Deutsche Bank building safely is proving to be a daunting task.
The chief of the federal prosecution service’s investigations committee said that the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the journalist who was fatally shot in Moscow last year, might soon be solved.
If John Lauro is not known as “The Attorney for the Damned,” as Clarence Darrow was described, it is not for want of trying.
Hurricane Dean, weakened to a tropical depression, is no more, but its remnants continued to hit Mexico.
British farmers will be able to export meat and live animals beginning tomorrow.
A Moscow woman set fire to her ex-husband’s penis as he sat naked watching television and drinking vodka.
Bishop Jia Zhiguo, the underground Roman Catholic bishop of the Zheng Ding Diocese in Hebei Province, was arrested.
The chief prosecutor at the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Carla Del Ponte, has been appointed ambassador to Argentina by her native Switzerland.
Leaders of Shas, the ultra-Orthodox party, proposed legislation to outlaw cremation, a day after the country’s only crematory was heavily damaged in a suspected arson fire.
A private Afghan television station broadcast a video of a kidnapped German aid worker in which he warns that his health is deteriorating.
The air force grounded its fleet of hundreds of Su-24 attack planes after one of the jets crashed during a training flight in Russia’s Far East.
There is “no hope” of finding survivors from a flood in a Shandong Province coal mine that trapped 181 miners underground a week ago, a provincial official said.

Pablo Prigioni had 20 points and Luis Scola added 16 yesterday to help Argentina, the defending Olympic champion, defeat Uruguay, 90-69, in its opener in the FIBA Americas tournament in Las Vegas. Uruguay center Esteban Batista was held to 7 points, shooting 3 for 10. Emilio Taboada led Uruguay (1-1) with 14 points.Carlos Arroyo had 16 points and 8 assists for Puerto Rico in a 108-67 victory over Panama. Ricardo Sanchez scored 19 points and Carmelo Lee had 17 for Puerto Rico (1-1). Gary Forbes scored 19 points for Panama (0-2).Samuel Dalembert scored 6 of his 18 points in the final minutes and Jermaine Anderson scored the last 6 points to finish with 17 in Canada’s 80-73 victory against Venezuela (0-2).

Nikolay Davydenko and Tommy Robredo, the top two seeds in the men’s draw at the Pilot Pen in New Haven, were eliminated in straight sets yesterday in the third round.And in the women’s draw, a qualifier advanced to the semifinals when Agnes Szavay defeated eighth-seeded Alona Bondarenko, 6-1, 6-4.Davydenko, the defending champion, lost to Gilles Simon, 6-4, 6-4. Robredo fell to Stanislas Wawrinka, 6-3, 6-3. Igor Andreev beat fourth-seeded David Ferrer, 3-6, 7-6 (3), 6-4.James Blake, seeded third, won, 3-6, 7-6 (2), 6-1, after being down three match points to Agustin Calleri.

Tim Henman announced yesterday that he would retire after playing one last time at Wimbledon — next month, when Britain plays Croatia in a Davis Cup playoff at the All England Club.The 32-year-old Henman, who reached four Wimbledon semifinals but has not won a Grand Slam title in his 14-year career, said a sore back and a bad knee led to his decision.

Brazil’s star players Ronaldinho, Kaka and Robinho were picked yesterday for the 22-man roster for games next month in the United States. Brazil, the South American champion, will play the United States on Sept. 9 in Chicago and Mexico three days later in Foxborough, Mass.

Jean-Baptiste Gonnet and Taichi Teshima each shot a course-record six-under-par 64 yesterday to share the lead after the first round of the Dutch Open in Zaandvoort, Netherlands. Seven golfers were one stroke behind, including the former United States Open champion Michael Campbell.
Pro Bowl wide receiver Donald Driver was taken to the locker room just before halftime with an injury to his right foot.
The Knicks guard said the did not condone dogfighting, a day after he made a stir with a statement of support for quarterback Michael Vick.
The former principal of a Montessori school in Manhattan has appealed her conviction for having sex with an under-age student.
Two firefighters were injured when a worker lost control of a small forklift on the 23rd floor of the troubled Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan.
The New Mexico attorney general has reopened an investigation into whether the CBS reality show “Kid Nation” violated the state’s child-labor laws and other state regulations.
Some alumni were disturbed when the Black Knights hired Stan Brock, whose only head coaching experience was in the Arena Football League.
The Bank of China said Thursday that it held almost $9.7 billion of securities backed by American subprime loans, the most of any Asian company.
In an address in Hanover, N.H., John Edwards issued a thinly veiled criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
In competing press conferences, rival advocacy groups said that (1) there could be a citywide taxi strike in September, and (2) there would not be a strike.
Two American pilots facing criminal charges after their executive jet collided with a commercial airliner last year are willing to testify but will not return to Brazil to do so.
For presidential candidates campaigning in Silicon Valley, the place to be is  Google’s headquarters.
Mitt Romney, an architect of Massachusetts’ universal health coverage plan, is unveiling his proposal for overhauling the nation’s health care system.
A Bush administration proposal to screen foreign aid workers and recipients for possible ties to terrorists has drawn criticism from private and religious aid groups.
The United States Tennis Association has hired the firm of a former city police commissioner to try to keep tabs on all betting activity surrounding the United States Open.
Residents and tourists in the New York region are speaking wistfully of haze, heat and humidity.
A man who was sent to death row in a 1970s serial murder case in Georgia has been linked by DNA evidence to the 1975 rape and strangulation of a Syracuse woman.
Curtis Granderson of the Detroit Tigers has written the words  “Don’t think. Have Fun” on his cap as a reminder to play baseball loosely and not scrutinize every situation.
A man was cleared of murder charges after offering cellphone records as alibi evidence.
The Yankees climbed into the pennant race by beating mediocre teams after the All-Star Game break. Now they have built enough confidence to hang with the elite.
Central bank officials cut the discount rate by half a percentage point and have encouraged banks to tap the discount window to help ease the credit squeeze.
The head of the Justice Department’s civil rights division announced that he was resigning, the latest in a long string of departures from the department.
Using virtual-reality goggles, a camera and a stick, scientists have induced out-of-body experiences in healthy people.

Smithfield Foods, the world’s biggest hog and turkey producer, reported yesterday that quarterly net income doubled on rising beef and pork sales. Hormel Foods said its profit fell on higher costs to make Spam meat products and bacon bits.
Rioting inmates rounded up rivals in a Brazilian jail cell and set it on fire on Thursday, killing 25 prisoners in the latest episode of gang violence in Brazil’s lockups.
Of all the questions the Giants hoped to answer during training camp, one persists: At some point, will they find defensive end Michael Strahan waiting for them at home?
Stocks slipped yesterday as investors worried about the economic outlook after the head of the Countrywide Financial Corporation said the housing downturn could create a recession.
BNP Paribas, the French bank, said on Thursday that it would reopen three funds next week that it had frozen in a step that accelerated a slide in financial stocks.
A federal appeals court today cleared the way for Whole Foods Market to buy rival organic grocer Wild Oats Markets.
There is a new presidential candidate named Ray Hopewood — but believe in him at your peril.
The personal assistant of the top general in the California National Guard is on leave after revelations that the aide’s personal Web site contained derogatory statements.
The government has issued a rare written apology in a case involving an Iraqi refugee who was improperly imprisoned.
Butch van Breda Kolff, a happy-go-lucky nonconformist, coached more than 1,300 college, professional and high school basketball games.
Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced guilty pleas from the former operators of two schools for home health aides who sold state certifications.
The measure, which was discussed at a meeting of team scouting and farm directors this week, could be implemented as early as next season.
The Food and Drug Administration proposed sweeping new rules for sunscreens, intended to give consumers more detailed information.
Grace Paley explored the struggles of ordinary women in precise, pungent stories.
In contrast to the months before and after the 2000 census, officials say they will not suspend raids on illegal immigrants during the population count in 2010.
Reports of four more deaths have brought to 12 the number of people who have died since the rains began.
Two major airlines were fined $300 million each Thursday after admitting that they had conspired to fix prices on international flights.
Down to his last strike with his team on the brink of elimination, Deion Rosalia stayed calm and settled himself at the plate.
Betty Johnson, the mother of the Jets’ owner, has spent most of her life cultivating the seeds that became her family’s full-bloom passion for the sport.
The size of the commercial paper market, a crucial source of short-term financing for businesses, decreased as investors fled asset-backed debt and opted for Treasuries.
Arthur Bremer, the gunman who tried to kill Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, will be released from prison.
For reliable prognoses to become a routine part of medical care, they must become a priority of medical research and education.
Did the Iranian government encourage a fleeting era of reform in order to identify its opponents so as to come after them?
Bringing transparency and accountability to the earmark process is a significant reform, a pledge Democrats made and a pledge we kept.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan expressed admiration on Thursday for two Indians who voiced support for Japan in the World War II era.
As federal regulators have pursued insider trading cases this year, one of the oddities they have spotted is an increase in cases involving husbands and wives.
Profit rose for the first time in eight quarters after Gap Inc. eliminated jobs and reduced inventory.
Plainclothes officers and some civilian supporters of Myanmar’s military government broke up a peaceful march for a second straight day on Thursday.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,701 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The attacks underscored the degree to which the insurgency, weakened since 2004, has managed to survive and conduct operations.
In contrast to the months before and after the 2000 census was conducted, raids on illegal immigrants will not be suspended during the population count in 2010, federal officials say.

Prosecutors in Los Angeles filed seven misdemeanor counts stemming from two drunken-driving arrests against Lindsay Lohan, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The district attorney charged Ms. Lohan, 21, with two counts each of driving under the influence, driving with a blood-alcohol level above .08 percent and being under the influence of cocaine, and one count of reckless driving. The police found cocaine on Ms. Lohan during the arrests on May 26 in Beverly Hills and on July 24 in Santa Monica. In each incident, the amounts tested were below the .05 grams required for felony charges, according to the district attorney’s office.
A winner at Edinburgh Fringe festival, Beverly Sills remembered, Edward Albee celebrates his 80th birthday and more culture news.
A surreal performance piece won the annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award at the Edinburgh Fringe festival.
Could the subprime problems that have fouled the public market be a mixed blessing for Silicon Valley’s high-technology investors?
Edward Albee’s 80th birthday in March will be marked by a number of productions in the New York area, collectively titled “The Albee Season.”

The British singer Amy Winehouse, top, received four nominations for the 12th annual Music of Black Origin (Mobo) Awards, BBC News reported yesterday. Ms. Winehouse, 23, who just canceled a string of concerts because of illness, is up for best British female, best R&B act, best video and best song. The rapper Dizzee Rascal, above, has also been nominated for four awards: best United Kingdom male, best hip-hop act, best song and best video (for “Sirens”). Mobo winners are chosen by voting on the awards show’s Web site (mobo.com).The presentation will be at the O2 arena in London on Sept. 19; it will also be broadcast live on the digital channel BBC Three.

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Metropolitan Opera and New York City Opera will present a tribute to Beverly Sills on Sept. 16 at 5 p.m. at the Metropolitan Opera. The public event, dedicated to Ms. Sills, left, who died on July 2 at 78, will include scheduled performances by Natalie Dessay, Anna Netrebko and Nathan Gunn, winner of the first annual Beverly Sills Award. The Met’s music director, James Levine, will play the piano. Among those expected to speak are Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Barbara Walters, Plácido Domingo, Henry Kissinger, Julius Rudel and Stanley Sills, Ms. Sills’s brother. Tickets will be free (limited to two tper person) and available at the Metropolitan Opera box office, first come first served, starting Sept. 16. The program will be broadcast live on Metropolitan Opera Radio on Sirius, the 24-hour satellite radio channel, and streamed live via RealNetworks at metopera.org.

Giuseppe Tornatore, the director of “Cinema Paradiso” and other films, was mugged while taking a walk Tuesday evening in central Rome, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Tornatore was taken to a hospital after two young men attacked him, the newspaper Corriere della Sera quoted the director as saying, and suffered head trauma as well as several minor injuries. He was strolling after leaving his office when the two men asked him for directions, the newspaper said; while one thanked the filmmaker for the help, the other hit him on the head from behind. The two men made off with Mr. Tornatore’s wallet, mobile phone and watch, the paper reported.

Music at the Anthology (MATA), the new-music organization founded by the composers Philip Glass, Eleanor Sandresky and Lisa Bielawa, will hold a 10th-anniversary benefit concert on Sept. 25 at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 521 West 21st Street. For information: matafestival.org or (212) 563-5124. ...Vanessa Redgrave; her sister, Lynn Redgrave; and their brother, Corin Redgrave, will each receive a Lifetime Achievement Award at the 10th Annual Savannah Film Festival, which runs from Oct. 27 to Nov. 3 in Savannah, Ga. Information: scad.edu/filmfest/about.cfm.

“Anchorwoman,” Fox’s new reality series following a ratings-strapped small-town television affiliate after it hires a former swimsuit model with no journalism experience to read the news, drew just 2.7 million viewers Wednesday in its one-hour debut at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Fox finished fourth for the night, just behind ABC. CBS led over all in total viewers, as its 8 p.m. game show, “Power of 10,” delivered the night’s largest audience (8.7 million). NBC, which ranked second in total viewers, earned top ratings among adults 18 to 49, getting a boost at 9 from “Last Comic Standing,” which earned its best numbers in that demographic for the summer and a total audience of 7.3 million. CBS’s “Criminal Minds” rerun finished first at 9 (8.2 million), as did a repeat of its “CSI: NY” at 10 (8 million). On Sunday, “Ice Road Truckers” had the best ratings on cable television for the night. Its season finale set a record for the History Channel, as an audience of 4.8 million viewers tuned in at 10.
The Parrish Art Museum’s show feels at times like a master class led by artist Eric Fischl, although a somewhat anachronistic one. Painting is hardly dead.
The Portland Museum of Art provides an engrossingly detailed picture of how Mr. Wright achieved his vision, with many examples of his furniture, plans, drawings and publications.

A traveling teeny-bopper tour produced one of the year’s definitive hip-hop moments:  T. I., Jay-Z, Mr. West, Diddy and 50 Cent, all sharing the stage on Wednesday.
The Boston photographer Margot Balboni presents 26 striking color photographs of the American landscape, made over the last two decades, in the form of an alphabet.
The Jets took a hard line and refused to budge, trading their disgruntled offensive lineman Pete Kendall to the Washington Redskins today for a 2008 or 2009 draft pick.
The consummate ambition that Chinese artists brought to diminutive scale is a striking feature of the Metropolitan Museum’s small late-summer show.
In addressing social problems among Aboriginal people, critics say the conservative government of John Howard has adopted a paternalistic tone not seen for decades.

8 P.M. (TCM) BEDTIME FOR BONZO (1951) It’s all Ronald Reagan all day long on Turner Classic Movies, including this dandy about a professor (Reagan, above) with a deadbeat dad who tries to disprove his future father-in-law’s theory about inherited genetic traits by teaching a chimpanzee the difference between right and wrong. Lucille Barkley plays Valerie, the professor’s fiancée and the university dean’s daughter. Diana Lynn plays Jane, the other woman seen a little too frequently in the professor’s house. The marathon begins at 6 a.m. with “Love Is on the Air” (1937) and ends at 4:30 a.m. tomorrow with “Prisoner of War” (1954).
The bassist Gary Peacock, the pianist Paul Bley and the drummer Paul Motian took a normal jazz-club performance and turned it upside down at Birdland on Wednesday.
A jaunty assortment of parlor magician’s tricks ornament this fast and funny production.  But the real magic happens when the bad actors take over.
Mr. van Breda Kolff, who coached more than 1,300 high school, college and professional basketball games, was 84.
While Americans fear an epidemic of foreclosures, brought on by the subprime mortgage meltdown, Britain is already suffering one.
In many ways, Charlie Parker, the subject of a festival this weekend, was the quintessential New York hero: a maverick and bon vivant, a subject of notoriety and myth.
Marcel Broodthaers at Michael Werner Gallery, “Through the Lies of Your Dark, Dark Eyes” at Envoy, “microwave, five” at Josée Bienvenu and more.
Despite some flaws,  the Times Square Ripley’s Believe It or Not! Odditorium is so entertaining and provocative that it’s worth special attention.

Michael Erard’s book is about verbal pauses, fillers and errors and what they might mean.

We will know that Eli Manning has met the big-boy challenge when teammates do not have to defend him so vigorously in the locker room.
In the company’s new ad campaign, 18 women step up to deliver a unified message: We’re athletes, so ditch the female modifier.
For many New Yorkers, leaflet advertising is a giant pain. City Councilman Simcha Felder was behind a bill that makes the unsolicited distribution of fliers illegal.
The Crandall Canyon Mine disaster did not mark the first time that Robert E. Murray has taken a position far afield of the experts.
The performance of Richard E. Stickler has thrown into question his future with the Mine Safety and Health Administration and drawn criticism onto the agency.
A Senate subcommittee that oversees labor questions said that it would hold a hearing on the Crandall Canyon Mine collapse.
A book about Nicolas Sarkozy’s pursuit of the presidency, told through the eyes of France’s most celebrated playwright, is caught up in a media frenzy.

Reggie Wilson and Andréya Ouamba’s “Accounting for Customs” is one of the most memorable — though brief (15 minutes) — site-specific pieces I have seen.
A time-tested self-discovery course takes combat veterans into the Colorado mountains to help heal emotional scars.
The electronic and informational needs of our houseguests have expanded.
A sea-kayaking journey on the Maine coast without forgoing hot showers and a warm bed by paddling from one bed-and-breakfast to another.
The allure of oceanfront property with a salty New England feel and nearness to fall leaf peeping makes New Hampshire’s coastline appealing for second-home buyers.
Word has gotten out about the majestic scenery and still affordable second homes in the Thousand Islands, bringing buyers from around the United States.
A trip to the old Dutch town of Kinderhook, N.Y., in Columbia County uncovers presidential timber.

PALEY--Grace . A wide eyed chronicler of ordinary lives, she knew the personal was political long before the rest of us, putting the personal into her protests and the political into her art and blending the two seamlessly and joyfully. The War Resisters League and the A.J. Muste Memorial Institute mourn her passing and share her family's grief.

FOR CHILDREN BUG HUNT (Tomorrow and Sunday) The wilds of Staten Island will be the scene of a safari this weekend. But no one will need weapons: just a magnifying glass, a small jar and guide books. Think of it as a small game hunt -- very, very small game. The quarry will be in the meadow around the Staten Island Children's Museum, where young entomologists will search for insects and learn about their life cycles, as well as make a bug journal. At noon and 1, 2 and 3 p.m., 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, (718) 273-2060, statenislandkids.org. Free with admission: $5.

NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL FRINGE FESTIVAL This is your last weekend to take a gander at the dizzying array of shows being performed throughout the city as part of the 11th annual New York International Fringe Festival. This year's Fringe, taking place at 20 downtown theaters, features 190 emerging dance and theater companies from 9 countries and 17 states -- not to mention spoken word, puppetry and performance art. Dance highlights over the final three days include ''Her Kind: The Life & Poetry of Anne Sexton,'' by Wild Child Presents of New York, with choreography by Laurel Dugan; ''Requiem pour une âme seule,'' by the Parisian choreographer Isabelle Barbat, right; the dance-theater piece ''The Hoarde,'' by Vissi Dance Theater in New York, written, directed and choreographed by Courtney Ffrench; ''unrest'' by the Los Angeles-based Ledges and Bones Dance Project, with choreography by Holly Johnston; and ''what remains is the (stillness) of objects,'' directed by Jill A. Samuels and Hillary Spector, by Room in Association with Nomad Theatrical of New York. Who knows what you're going to find at these shows -- they could be stinkers or they could be delights -- but taking a chance on nascent creators is really what the Fringe Festival is all about. (Through Sunday at several downtown theaters; 212-279-4488, 888-374-6436, fringenyc.org; $15.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

An article and headline on July 23 about a new Israeli third-grade textbook referred imprecisely to the way it described the 1948-49 war with Arab countries that followed Israel's declaration of independence. The textbook said that Arabs view the war as a catastrophe; it did not say that the war was a catastrophe for the Arab population or that the establishment of Israel was a catastrophe for the Palestinians. The Times, which did not have a copy of the textbook when the article was published, attributed the descriptions of what the book said to the Israeli Education Ministry. The text, translated from the Hebrew, says in a passage about the war: ''Arabs call this war the Nakba'' (which means catastrophe) ''whereas the Jewish people call it the War of Independence.'' This correction was delayed to get a copy of the book.

REVENGE OF THE BOOKEATERS Whether they always finished their own homework is debatable, but on Sunday evening a Who's Who of downtown comedy stars, writers and indie rockers will perform in a benefit show for 826NYC, the free tutoring center for children in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Among those scheduled to appear are Feist, the indie chanteuse known for her magpie vocal style, who will do a reading; Britt Daniel, the singer of the Austin, Tex., band Spoon; A. C. Newman, the newlywed leader of the New Pornographers, the Canada-by-way-of-Brooklyn musical collective; the lo-fi local quartet Grizzly Bear; and the comedians Leo Allen, Eugene Mirman and the host, Demetri Martin. (The indie-rocker Sufjan Stevens, above, performed at last year's program.) Most of them do not volunteer at the center, which was founded in 2004 by the writer Dave Eggers and others. (It's located behind the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Company, a storefront lure for local children, and as many as 200 come in weekly for writing help.) Aside from a fondness for one another, what unites this crew? ''Is it bragging to say that everybody's pretty smart?'' said Sarah Vowell, the writer and also president and chief cheerleader for 826NYC. ''Demetri Martin -- it's not hyperbole to say that he's probably the best comic ever to make jokes about palindromes. Even with the musicians there's a kind of reverence for words and language that has a natural affinity for the cause,'' said Ms. Vowell, who helped corral the guests and will also perform. ''They're not eggheads. There's an unpretentious, joshing charm about a lot of them.''

BILL DOUGLAS RETROSPECTIVE As a child growing up in a small mining village in Scotland, the filmmaker Bill Douglas suffered hunger, abandonment and extreme poverty. Through years of neglect and loneliness he would escape to the local cinema, paying his admission by redeeming empty jam jars. The deprivations of those years, and his eventual deliverance, were the inspiration for three of Mr. Douglas's four films, a trilogy of remarkable simplicity and emotional resonance. Ferociously unsentimental, it is the work of a man forced to grow up on only imagination and hope. Set in 1945, ''My Childhood'' (1972), the first installment, follows young Jamie (Stephen Archibald) as he learns that his mother has been confined to an asylum and his father is a man who lives a few houses away. With a near-silent maternal grandmother and a distant half-brother as his only companions, Jamie forms a touching attachment to a German P.O.W. In ''My Ain Folk'' (1973), Jamie has moved in with his paternal grandmother (Jean Taylor Smith, above right, with Mr. Archibald), a cruel woman who blames Jamie's mother for ruining her son's life. Filled with death and departure, this segment of the trilogy is the most devastating, as a bereft Jamie is finally consigned to a children's home in Edinburgh. Ending on a hopeful note, ''My Way Home'' (1978) brings Jamie, via National Service in the Royal Air Force, to Egypt and to a friendship that will alter the course of his life.

'ERNST LUDWIG KIRCHNER: BERLIN STREET SCENE' There are many reasons to visit this small if delightful collection exhibition at the Neue Galerie on the Upper East Side, not least of which is a chance to acquaint yourself with a new acquisition: Ernst Ludwig Kirchner's ''Berlin Street Scene'' (1913-14), above, bought at auction last November for $38 million. It also happens to be a terrific painting and a high point of early German Expressionism. And the subject matter? It depicts a pair of ladies soliciting customers along a busy Berlin avenue. Their illicit occupation is beyond doubt: their calcium-white faces, rouge lips, feathered hats and fitted gowns are telltale signs, though it is interesting to note that the models for the women in the painting were Erna and Gerda Schilling, sisters and dancers at a Berlin nightclub. But what gives the painting its charged and anxious atmosphere is the effect that the two women are having on the men around them. One of them, at far right, turns his head away in disdain, while another, at left, glances longingly out of one eye. Then there is the central figure with his back to us, who is determined to appear unmoved by their presence. Meanwhile, in the background, a No. 15 bus pauses to make a stop at the edge of the crowd. The number is significant, for according to the exhibition catalog the No. 15 streetcar serviced the red-light district in Berlin. (Through Sept. 17, Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, 212-628-6200, neuegalerie.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

LINCOLN CENTER OUT OF DOORS Anyone intrigued by the cultural significance of tea should head to this free festival tonight to discover the Taiwanese Way of Tea. The Trance Music Ensemble, above, which includes pipa, cheng, zither and flute players as well as actors and calligraphers, will perform Taiwanese ceremonies incorporating traditional and contemporary culture in a program called ''Tea and Music in Dialogue.'' Since the 1980s, a distinct ceremony based on oolong tea and inspired by Ming and Ching traditions has developed in Taiwan. Tonight's holistic performance incorporates poetry, music, calligraphy and, of course, tea -- which will be served to the audience as part of the ritual. The musical selections were chosen by Ku-fang Lin, the Trance Music Ensemble's founder and artistic director. These include ''Farewell Feast,'' a song whose lyrics are from a poem by the famous Chinese poet Li Bai about friends parting ways. The program also includes ''Hsiang Yu Lays Down His Arms,'' for pipa, and ''The Soaring Partridge,'' for flute. (Tonight at 7, South Plaza, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5766, lincolncenter.org.) VIVIEN SCHWEITZER

KELMAN--Michael , of Annandale, NJ died August 22nd. He was 67. Services will be held at Kearns Funeral Home. Whitehouse, NJ on Saturday August 25 from 2-4 pm. He will be interred at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY. Michael's childhood home. Michael was born on July 9, 1940 in Brooklyn and moved with his family to Sag Harbor in 1946. After graduating from Randolph Macon College he met and married Susan Lindsay on October 6, 1962. Mike spent much of his career in publishing and advertising in Manhattan, most recently with North American Precis Syndicate. He and Susan lived in Huntington, NY for 40 years before moving to Annandale, NJ to be closer to their granddaughter. An avid hunter and outdoorsman, Michael's love of animals was well known. His wit, intellect and cooking skills will be missed by all. Mike was preceded in death by his father, Irving Kelman. He is survived by his mother, May Kelman, wife, Susan Kelman; sons, David Kelman (Gail), Andrew Kelman and Christopher Kelman (Angela); granddaughter, May Ann, brothers Robert Kelman (Maryann) of Chicago and Peter Kelman (Nancy) of Boston and sister Edith Kelman of Atlanta. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the American Diabetes Association, P.O. Box 11454, Alexandria, VA 22312, or the charity of your choice, in Michael's memory.

A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush’s speech comparing the mission in Iraq to other wars described imprecisely the timing of the American withdrawal from Vietnam. Two men who admitted robbing and killing an aspiring British politician on a Georgetown street were sentenced to more than three decades in prison. The men, Jeffrey Rice and Christopher Piper, pleaded guilty in May to second-degree murder and robbery for the July 2006 death of Alan Senitt, 27. Mr. Senitt’s throat was slashed as he tried to protect a female companion from robbery and sexual assault. It was a “savage and senseless killing,” said Judge Neal Kravitz of Superior Court, as he sentenced Mr. Rice to 52 years in prison and Mr. Piper to 37. Both men apologized at the hearing.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed California’s overdue spending plan after using his veto power to trim $700 million and temporarily eliminate the state’s operating deficit. The action by Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, means the state can immediately begin releasing billions of dollars in payments to schools, hospitals, state contractors and social service agencies that have had payments cut off since the fiscal year began July 1. The budget spends $145.5 billion, with $103 billion in the general fund used for day-to-day government operations.

A former campaign aide to a Florida congressman and two other men were found dead in an Orlando home in an apparent double-murder and suicide, the authorities and relatives said. Officials have not determined a motive for the deaths of the three men, Ralph Gonzalez, 39; his roommate, David Abrami, 36; and a friend, Robert Drake, 30. Investigators found signs of a struggle in the house, and the men are believed to have died several days before their bodies were discovered Thursday. Mr. Gonzalez was executive director of the Georgia Republican Party from 2001 to 2002. He managed Representative Tom Feeney’s 2002 campaign and was president of Strategum Group, a political consulting firm based in Orlando that represents Republican candidates.

Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco has approved clemency requests from 183 convicts and former convicts, including dozens of pardons for decades-old drug crimes. The cases include shoplifting, obscenity, arson and second-degree murder. In all the cases, Ms. Blanco, a Democrat, acted on the recommendation of the State Board of Pardons. Ninety-nine of the pardons, commutations and grants of parole eligibility went to people convicted of drug crimes, most of them for distribution or possession of heroin and cocaine. One went to a man given a life sentence for dealing heroin in New Orleans in 1975.

(Cinemax) THE DEPARTED (2006) Matt Damon plays Colin Sullivan, the boyish but sinister protége of an Irish- American mobster (Jack Nicholson, far left with Mr. Damon) who goes undercover as a state police officer; Leonard DiCaprio is Billy Costigan, a state cop who infiltrates the underworld and slowly loses his grip. Now each organization has discovered that it has a mole in its midst. Martin Scorsese won his long-awaited Academy Award for best director with this crime thriller, based on the Hong Kong film “Infernal Affairs,” which also snared Oscars for best picture, best editing (the wondrous Thelma Schoonmaker) and best adapted screenplay (William Monahan). Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis gave a nod to Alec Baldwin and Mark Wahlberg in their roles as detectives: “As do the rest of the actors, they prove that what really counts here, in the end, isn’t the film, but all its swaggering men.”.

Symphony Space, which opened in January 1978, announced its 2007-8 schedule, as well as a tribute to its coming 30th anniversary. Among the highlights: there will be fall, winter and spring film series with John Sayles, Jonathan Demme and Jim Jarmuschas curators; Stephen King will read from ''The Best American Short Stories 2007'' on Oct. 10; a 30th-anniversary celebration will be held on Jan. 10; and Ursula Oppens will celebrate Elliott Carter's 100th birthday on Jan. 17. Last but not least, the Wall to Wall Bach program, on May 17, will pay homage to the first Wall to Wall presentation, which was also the first program ever mounted at Symphony Space, a formerly boarded-up theater on the Upper West Side that became its home. Information: symphonyspace.org.

A front-page article on Thursday about the John Galt Corporation, the demolition subcontractor working on the Deutsche Bank building at ground zero, gave an erroneous attribution for statements about the safeguards under which Galt was hired and about Galt's failed bid for another city job in the Bronx. The statements -- both in paraphrase and in direct quotation -- were by John Gallagher, a spokesman for Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, not by Mr. Doctoroff himself. (Mr. Gallagher was speaking in his own right, not for Mr. Doctoroff.)

SCHILLER--Irving, on Wednesday, August 22, 2007. Beloved husband of Dr. Patricia Schiller. Father of Louise Schiller and Jonathan Schiller. Grandfather of Zachary, Joshua, Aaron, Will and Isaac. Judge Schiller worked his entire professional career in public service. Working more than 40 years with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, DC where he was an enforcement attorney and an administrative law judge. He was a man of faith and was a founding member of Temple Sinai in Washington, DC. He served as Temple president from 1962 to 1963. He had a constant and delightful sense of humor. He loved spending summer holidays with his family on Martha's Vineyard where he built a summer home in 1952. He served his country in the United States Army during World War II. Funeral service will be held at Temple Sinai, 3100 Military Rd. NW, Washington, DC on Sunday, August 26th at 10:30 am. Interment King David Memorial Gardens, Falls Church, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Legal Aid Society.

SMITHLINE--Clarice Stein, died in Palm Beach, August 20. Beloved aunt of Susan and Michael Stein. Also leaves behind niece and nephew-in-law Gilda and Henry Block and stepdaughter Whitney Schneider, whose husband Ira and son Reid share the loss. Wife of the late Sol I. Smithline; sister to the late Arthur Stein. After graduating from Barnard at 18, Clarice began a career with Abraham & Straus and became Fashion Director during its heyday. This brilliant woman maintained a lifelong interest in art, politics and culture, and will be sorely missed for her verve, elegance and loving spirit. Receiving: Monday, August 27, 10am; service: 11am at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel.

The Cure, which a few weeks ago postponed its album from the fall to the spring, yesterday postponed its Sept. 23 concert at Madison Square Garden to a date still to be set. ''With all apologies for any inconvenience or disappointment it may cause,'' the band, whose lead singer is Robert Smith, right, said in a statement, ''we have made a decision to move the September/October 2007 North American Cure shows to April/May 2008.''... Lindsay Lohan, who was charged on Thursday with misdemeanors in two cases of driving while intoxicated, pleaded guilty to two counts of being under the influence of cocaine and pleaded no contest to counts of reckless driving and driving with a blood alcohol level higher than .08, The Associated Press reported. Under a plea agreement, she will serve 24 hours in jail. ... The Venice Film Festival will establish a prize in honor of the Japanese director Takeshi Kitano, to be awarded for career achievement and innovation, Variety reported. Mr. Kitano won the festival's Golden Lion award in 1997 for ''Hana-bi.''

David Hasselhoff, left, the former star of ''Baywatch'' and ''Knight Rider,'' accepted libel damages from the publisher of magazines that accused him of being drunk and abusive in a Hollywood nightclub, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Northern & Shell PLC, publisher of the British edition of OK! magazine, and Northern & Shell North America Ltd., publisher of the American edition, ''accept that their allegations were false,'' Mr. Hasselhoff's lawyer said in London. ''Each defendant has agreed to publish an apology in their magazine and together have agreed to pay the claimant substantial damages.'' The amount of damages in the out-of-court settlement was not disclosed.

ISRAELS--Miriam. All of us at Citymeals - on - Wheels are deeply saddened by the loss of Miriam Israels, our first volunteer and powerful force behind our special events from our beginning -role model, Board member and loving friend. Miriam was a woman with dramatic personal style, joie de vivre, energy and talent for bringing people together in smartly orchestrated settings. Her compassion for the elderly, her dedication to Citymeals grew even into her late eighties. When she could no longer travel to the office, she wove her seductive persuasion from home by fax and phone. Feeling this loss ourselves, we wish to send comfort and affection to her devoted sister Ida and to all her adoring family. Gael Greene, Citymeals Founder and Chair Marcia Stein, Executive Director

SOLOMON--Dr. Robert, 75, Of Mamaroneck, NY passed away on August 17, 2007, peacefully at home. Born and raised in Jersey City, NJ, he graduated from the Medical School of Lausanne, Switzerland and was in practice as an Otolaryngologist in Port Chester, NY for 30 years. He was a past president of the medical staff at United Hospital, Port Chester, NY and was a member of the hospital board of trustees. He chaired the medical committee at the Westchester Golf Classic for 20 years. He was on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine and St. Agnes Hospital. After retiring from private practice, he was on the faculty of The NY eye and ear infirmary. He was a lifelong, diehard New York Giants football fan and Jazz enthusiast. He is survived by his wife Bonnie (Rubin), sons Yoram and David Solomon and daughter Tara Solomon. Grandson Jordan Solomon, who was so special to him. He is also survived by two sisters Geraldine Phillips and Pearl Shampain. Bob saved many lives and enhanced many others, he will be remembered for his devotion to his wife and children, and grandson, as well as the patients he served in his many years of work for the benefit of United Hospital. He had a keen intellect, great sense of humor and a heart of gold. His sense of integrity was unsurpassed and he had a true zest for life. He will be missed by many. Donations may be made to The American Lung Association or The Phelps Memorial Hospice.

BORDEAUX-GROULT-Pierre, died in his 92nd year on Wednesday, August 22nd at the American Hospital in Paris. He was born on March 21, 1916 and was educated in France and in England, receiving degrees from l'Ecole des Hautes Etudes Commerciales and Oxford University. In World War II, he served with the Free French Forces in Africa and, subsequently, with the French Forces in Germany. He was awarded the Croix de Guerre and the Bronze Star. Later, he held a number of positions with the Mouvement Europeen, becoming Treasurer in 1958. He was also the Founding President of the Comite d'Action pour l'Union Europeenne, a founder of l'Association pour la Concorde Civile et la Fraternite dans les Balkans and a founder of the French food company, Tipiak, S.A. He was an Officier de la Legion d'Honneur, Chevalier des Palmes Academiques and Officer of Merit of the Republic of Germany. He is survived by his wife Calixte, four children, Robert, Daphne, Elisabeth-Charlotte, Marie-Brunhilde and two stepchildren, Henry Mortimer and Victoria de Navacelle and seven grand and step-grandchildren. His first wife, Elise, his son Richard and his grandson Thomas predeceased him. He will be laid to rest at the Chateau de Moncley, his wife's ancestral home.

SULLIVAN--John Thielen. Lawyer, Chairman of the Executive Committee, First Investors, died Friday, August 17, peacefully at home in Mill River, MA. He was 75. Mr. Sullivan died after a brief bout of prostate cancer. Born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Cora Mae (Solma) and Charles Morris Sullivan, he was raised in Toledo, Ohio. He graduated from The University of Notre Dame and Yale University Law School. His legal career began at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, and continued at the SEC Enforcement Division where he soon served as Chief of the Wall Street Branch. After three years at Cole & Dietz, he became a partner at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, where his practice revolved around securities law and international banking. He served as Chairman of the firm's Management Committee from 1981 until his retirement from the partnership in 1986. His association with First Investors began in 1968 when he represented Glenn Head and David Grayson in their purchase of the company. He served as outside counsel, on the Board of First Investors Consolidated Corporation, and ultimately on the Boards of most of the F.I. companies. He stepped in as President for a year following the death of David Grayson in 1994. History, philosophy and religion were his passions, as well as riding his horse. His first wife was Pamela Wylie, who died untimely in 1969. Loving and beloved husband of 22 years to Anne (McClelland) and tender, attentive father of Charles. He is also survived by nephews Patrick Robie, Jason St. John Robie and Michael Robie and nieces Martha Thorsrud and Margaret Shiple, their spouses and children. He was predeceased by his sister, Mary Sullivan Robie. A funeral was held Saturday, August 18 in Mill River, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The American Cancer Society, toll-free: 1-800-227-2345, or mailed to Memorial Processing Center, P.O. Box 7, East Syracuse, NY, 13057-0007. Please include Mr. Sullivan's and family address P.O. Box 313, Mill River, MA 01244

After just one night of the new reality series ''Anchorwoman,'' the Fox network had seen enough, canceling it as soon as the dismal ratings came in. The show, which followed the efforts of a former swimsuit model, Lauren Jones, right, to become a news anchor at a television station in Texas, pulled in only 2.7 million viewers. Preston Beckman, the executive in charge of scheduling for Fox, said in a telephone interview yesterday, ''We're getting close to the start of the fall season and this is not a time for us to allow our circulation to be going down.'' Fox has won every week of the summer in the ratings for viewers between the ages of 18 and 49, the competition that Fox, ABC and NBC all use to determine the ratings winner. But that streak will come to an end when this week's numbers are calculated, Mr. Beckman said. Last week Fox broadcast the finales of its two biggest summer hits, ''Hell's Kitchen'' and ''So You Think You Can Dance.'' If it had somehow managed to match the success of those other reality shows with ''Anchorwoman,'' the network might have been able to keep that streak going. But Fox executives never expected it to, and the show underperformed their modest expectations, Mr. Beckman said. He added that Fox had produced only five half-hour episodes of ''Anchorwoman'' and used two of them Wednesday night.

The guitarist and songwriter Brian May, below, completed his doctorate in astrophysics three decades after he put academia aside to form the rock group Queen, The Associated Press reported. He was awarded his qualification Thursday by London's Imperial College after submitting his 48,000-word thesis, ''Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud,'' which seeks to prove that planets and dust clouds in the solar system orbit in the same direction. Mr. May was an astrophysics student at Imperial College when he joined Freddie Mercury and Roger Taylor to form Queen in 1970, but dropped out as the glam-rock band became one of Britain's biggest music groups in the 1970s, with hits including ''Bohemian Rhapsody'' and ''We Will Rock You.'' Following Mr. Mercury's death in 1991, Mr. May released two solo albums. He will be formally presented with his doctorate in May at a ceremony at the Royal Albert Hall in London.

AIRLINE MANAGERS IN JEOPARDY Ten current or former British Airways managers may face prosecution in the United States after the airline colluded with other carriers in fixing fuel surcharges. British Airways was fined $300 million after pleading guilty to two criminal counts of conspiracy in setting extra charges on passenger and cargo flights to offset rising fuel expenses. The names of those exempt were contained in a plea agreement published yesterday.

LIPTON--Sidney, M.D. Passed away peacefully at 93 on August 23, 2007. He was a gifted and dedicated surgeon, loved and respected by his students, patients and colleagues for his many contributions to medicine. Survived by his devoted wife, Greta; father to Dr. Lynne Levitsky, Barbara Chargaff, A. Paul Bogaty, Esq., the late Dr. Diana Lipton and the late Dr. Nina Bogaty; father-in-law to Dr. Sidney Levitsky, Thomas Chargaff and Joan Bogaty, Esq.; beloved by his five grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Services to be held at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, on Sunday, August 26, 2007 at 1:00pm. Visitation at home, Monday through Wednesday, August 27-29, 5:00-10:00pm.

François Pinault, the French billionaire, has picked Monique Veaute, an art-events manager, to run his Venice exhibition location, the 18th-century Palazzo Grassi, and to develop a new contemporary arts center in a disused customs building, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. She succeeds Jean-Jacques Aillagon, a former French culture minister, who was named president of the Château de Versailles in June. Ms. Veaute, 56, lives in Rome, where in 1986 she helped create Fondation RomaEuropa, which organizes a dance and theater festival.

REVASCH--David. A kind, brilliant and generous friend to all who knew him. He was a giant of a man with a beautiful smile and always giving great advice to all of us in need of a trustworthy friend. David, rest in Zion. Shalom. Murray A. Wilson

BIRGE--June (Rossbach) Bingham, 88. Wife of the late Jonathan Bingham, former Bronx Congressman, died August 21 at home in Riverdale, NY. She leaves husband Robert Birge, children Sherrell Downes, Timothy Bingham and Claudia Meyers, 10 grandchildren, 14 great grandchildren. Daughter June Mitchell (Micki) Esselstyn predeceased her. Service at Wave Hill, Riverdale, NY, September 7 at 4pm. No flowers please. Kindly donate to Riverdale Mental Health Association, 5676 Riverdale Avenue, Suite 202, Bronx, NY 10471.

The Bravo Network of Canada will broadcast ''The Fiddle and the Drum,'' choreographed by the Alberta Ballet's artistic director, Jean Grand-Maître, on Oct. 22. The work, which had its premiere in Calgary, Alberta, in February, features 10 songs by Joni Mitchell and is danced before projections of her paintings. In June, the National Ballet of Canada, in partnership with the Luminato multimedia festival, will present its Toronto premiere.

PALEY--Grace. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the loss of our colleague, Grace Paley. Grace taught at Sarah Lawrence from 1966-1989 and remained an active member of our community. She was a great lady, loved and admired by her many students and her fellow teachers. We will always remember and honor her work as a writer, teacher and political activist. We send our condolences to her husband, Robert Nichols, and to her family. Karen Lawrence, President Pauline Watts, Dean of the College

CAPPELLI--Jennifer (nee Selwyn), of Scarsdale, NY, died August 24th. She was 46. Beloved wife, partner and best friend of Craig. Devoted and cherished mother of Alex and Sophia. Dear sister of Jane Braverman of Weston, CT. Adored daughter-in-law of Louis J. and Virginia M. Cappelli. Also survived by loving brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews and cherished friends. Friends are invited to call at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home on Saturday, August 25, from 6:00pm to 9:00pm. Funeral Service will be held on Sunday, August 26 at 2:00pm at The Unitarian Church, White Plains, NY. CAPPELLI--Jennifer. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Sterling Bancorp and Sterling National Bank mourn the untimely passing of Jennifer Cappelli, adored daughter-in-law of our Chairman, Louis J. Cappelli. We extend our sincere sympathy to Mr. and Mrs. Cappelli, their son Craig and the entire Cappelli family.

An own goal off the foot of Red Bulls defender Carlos Mendes in the 80th minute helped the host New England Revolution to a 2-1 victory last night in Major League Soccer. Mendes sent the ball back 40 yards toward Red Bulls goalkeeper Jon Conway, intending for a goal kick.The Red Bulls (10-9-3) took a 1-0 lead in the 30th minute on a goal by Jozy Altidore. Taylor Twellman tied the score in the first minute of the second half for the Revolution (12-5-6), the Eastern Conference leader.

Ray Stewart shot a four-under 68 yesterday to take a four-shot lead after two rounds of the Champions Tour Boeing Classic in Snoqualmie, Wash. Stewart, who survived a 10-man playoff in a qualifier for this tournament, was at 10-under 134.

Lorena Ochoa had eight birdies but finished with two bogeys in shooting a 66 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Sophie Gustafson entering the final round of the L.P.G.A. Safeway Classic in Portland, Ore. Ochoa is at 11-under 133 after two rounds at Columbia Edgewater County Club. Gustafson, who shared the lead after the first round with Ji-Young Oh, was one shot back after a 68. Oh was third, four shots back.

Top-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova won her first title this season when the qualifier Agnes Szavay retired with a back injury yesterday while leading, 6-4, 0-3.

Dario Franchitti, the IndyCar Series points leader, won his second pole of the season yesterday at Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, Calif. He will start at the front of the 18-car field in today’s Motorola Indy 300, followed by Danica Patrick, Tony Kanaan and Hélio Castroneves.

The United States held Canada to two field goals in a dominant second quarter, pulling away in a 113-63 victory yesterday in Las Vegas to remain unbeaten in the FIBA Americas tournament. Carmelo Anthony scored 25 points and Michael Redd added 19, including five 3-pointers.Kobe Bryant had 15 points, Amare Stoudemire had 12 and LeBron James added 10 points, 8 rebounds and 4 assists. The United States (3-0) closes pool play tonight against Brazil.The former Arkansas player Olumuyiwa Famutimi scored 17 points to lead Canada (2-2).

Becky Hammon scored 15 of her 20 points in the first half and the San Antonio Silver Stars beat the visiting Sacramento Monarchs, 86-61, to tie their Western Conference semifinal series at 1-1. Rebekkah Brunson led the Monarchs with 18 points and 8 rebounds. The deciding game of the series will be tomorrow night in San Antonio.In Game 2 of the Eastern Conference semifinals, Anna DeForge scored 26 points to help the host Indiana Fever defeat the Connecticut Sun, 78-59, to tie their best-of-three series. Game 3 is tomorrow night. Katie Douglas led the Sun with 11 points.

Tim Wakefield allowed three hits in seven shutout innings yesterday as the Boston Red Sox pounded the White Sox’ pitching for a third consecutive game in Chicago in a 14-2 win. Wakefield joined his teammate Josh Beckett at a major league-leading 16 victories.
A pickup truck plowed through a crowd leaving a pre-wedding celebration in western Canada, killing six people and injuring 19, the police said Saturday.

David Umphreville, Jr. had a two-run single and Zane Conlon snared a line drive to end a rally as Warner Robins, Ga., won the United States crown and advanced to the Little League World Series final with a 5-2 victory over Lubbock, Tex., yesterday in South Williamsport, Pa.

Mia Hamm and her longtime teammate Julie Foudy will be inducted into the National Soccer Hall of Fame today in Oneonta, N.Y. Hamm and Foudy, along with Kristine Lilly, Brandi Chastain and Joy Fawcett, were the Fab Five nucleus of the United States team that won the Women’s World Cup in 1991 and 1999. They also won gold medals at the 1996 and 2004 Olympics.

A Houston-area high school football standout who had orally committed to play at the University of Oklahoma next year was shot to death at an apartment complex on Friday.The police arrested a 19-year-old Louisiana man, Emile Lewis, and charged him with murder.Herman Mitchell, 17, died at Ben Taub General Hospital of multiple wounds, said Lt. John Martin of the Harris County Sheriff’s Office. The 6-foot, 200-pound senior linebacker for Westfield High School had accepted a scholarship offer to play for Oklahoma.Witnesses reported that Mitchell and another teenager were fighting in the parking lot before the shooting, Martin said.

Bernhard Langer hopes to celebrate his 50th birthday a day early today by claiming an unlikely victory at the KLM Open at Zandvoort, the Netherlands.Langer, a two-time Masters champion, was four strokes off the lead heading into the final round after carding a third-round 67 yesterday that left him at five under par. A victory would make Langer, a German, the oldest European Tour winner, and would give him a 43rd tour title.

Arkansas defensive end Marcus Harrison was suspended indefinitely after being arrested Friday night in Fayetteville on a felony drug charge and several misdemeanors. He was also charged with failure to appear for a court date in another case.Coach Houston Nutt said in a statement yesterday that Harrison, a 23-year-old senior, had violated team rules and would not play in the No. 21 Razorbacks’ season opener against Troy on Sept. 1.

Arsenal handed Manchester City its first loss of the season yesterday in the English Premier League, 1-0, and Chelsea beat Portsmouth, 1-0, to move into first place.Cesc Fabregas scored in the 80th minute to give Arsenal the victory and Frank Lampard scored in the first half for Chelsea, which has 10 points from four games. Manchester City is second with 9 points, 2 more than Wigan, Liverpool and Arsenal.In other matches, Liverpool beat Sunderland, 2-0; Birminghan won at Derby County, 2-1; Aston Villa defeated Fulham, 2-1; Bolton beat Reading, 3-0; and Wigan drew, 1-1, at West Ham.

In its uniquely intimate look at a long-term couples-therapy group, Laurie Abraham’s article (Aug. 12) demonstrates that truly committing to a process of finding out (with an excellent therapist) what will make a marriage better, and sticking with it, no matter how long it takes, could at the very least improve relationships and, in many cases, save marriages. How unfortunate that this form of therapy is largely available only to upper-income couples. Most marriage counseling is not covered by insurance, despite the fact that troubled marriages may lead to depression, anxiety and substance abuse, which can result in lost productivity and high additional health-care costs, to say nothing of divorce and its impact on children. The current in-vogue therapy, largely dictated by what insurance companies will and will not cover, is short-term cognitive behavioral therapy. This would not have repaired the 22-year marriage of Clem and Marie, nor is it likely to have much impact on long-ingrained dysfunctional patterns of behavior and communication in marriages that usually stem from each spouse’s unresolved family-of-origin issues.

Hugh Johnson, a serious if eccentric wine writer, did a delightful pop-up book years ago about hosting a fantasy dinner. Since it was his fantasy, he had dibs on the guests and the wines, and so entertained Napoleon, Sir Winston Churchill and other high-ranking poobahs. The Samurai Sipper has often fantasized similarly, only I'd pass on Thomas Jefferson an d have Edie Falco over for a post-Carmela henfest instead. I'd toy with serving a pinot grigio from Lorraine Bracco's vineyards in Italy, but would decide that's overkill. A 2003 Rosso del Soprano from Astor Wines and Spirits, 399 Lafayette Street, is hardly subtle. Still, Edie might be struck by the wine's wild grapes, grown since antiquity in Messina, and by my $150,000 Steinway & Sons Model D music system, which didn't fall off a truck.
Raise some serious brows.

Striking a chord with rock chicks from St. Bart's to St. Marks, Hogan has designed its limited-edition Guitar bags as a nod to the icons who put the muse in musician. The ponyskin Chrissie (left) is a tribute to -- no surprise here -- Chrissie Hynde, the outspoken frontwoman of the Pretenders, while the marbleized leather-and-suede Angie presumably riffs on the dissolute glamour of the ultimate groupie and former Mrs. Bowie. The bags will be available starting in September at Hogan, 134 Spring Street.
Girls Gone Wild. In A Good Way.

I am trying not to think what Freud would say about this roomful of mostly women brandishing big sticks. At Equinox on Broadway and 19th Street, we stand in rows facing a mirror, eyes trained on our wooden swords as well as on our leader, Ilaria Montagnani. Moving to the beat of music that sounds like rhythmic jackhammering, we squat, lunge, slice and slash. The class is called Forza. The footwork is simple, and there are only 13 sword moves. The difficulty comes in making each cut precise, putting the whole body behind the swing and controlling the stick.
The artist and poet Matthew Brannon Invests Fall's silhouettes with an inner life.

SCORE A STYLE POINT for the manly man. Rogues Gallery, a cool men's wear company in Portland, Me., is returning to its roots this fall with a line of vintage washed T-shirts, screen-printed by hand with images of Maine places and icons ($75 to $95 at Barneys New York). Look for pine trees, geese and roaring bears as well as Sabbathday Lake and, oddly, an homage to Jack London and his story ''To Build a Fire.'' (Never mind that Mr. London was a Californian and the story set in the Yukon -- the guy was totally rugged). Henleys, hoodies, bags, belts and jewelry round out the collection; come spring, the company will even make suits for the inner outdoorsman.
Channeling Siouxsie Sioux in punk neon and leather.
