The French men's-wear store Celio, founded by two brothers as a Gallic riff on the likes of Abercrombie & Fitch, now has a homegrown answer to A. & F.'s in-store hotties. Meet the Shoppenboys.

We interrupt our regular coverage of the fall collections with this man- (and woman-) on-the-street report. Coming to you live from the Siren Music Festival at Coney Island, the TV on the Radio concert at the McCarren Park Pool in Williamsburg and P.S. 1's annual summer Warm Up in Long Island City, where the personal style quotient was so off the charts that it practically raises the question: Who needs fashion?

When Harvey Weinstein announced this spring that he was going into the dress business, a couple of magazines made a fuss, but for the most part the fashion people treated him exactly as they would any newcomer. They regarded him with surprise and suspicion. It makes no difference that Weinstein is a successful producer of movies (he and his brother, Bob, started Miramax Films) and that those movies defied all kinds of conventions to win a total of 45 Oscars. Nor is there anything about his person that would send a fashion editor up the wall. He is polite, gregarious, at times charming. None of the bad faults for which he is legendary in Hollywood -- the screaming, the harassing -- are on display in fashion circles. And maybe it is for that reason that something about the sight of this bearish hetero sitting among the thin, knowing fashionistas compels sympathy as much as bemusement. Instead of getting in someone's face, Weinstein, in this environment, has the companionable air of a man holding out his mitts so his wife can unwind her knitting yarn.

As women get older, their color palette can often shrink to a rotation of blacks, blues, browns and variations therein. That muted hues are easier to apply and more flattering is accepted style wisdom. The innovators at M.A.C. hope you will forget this wisdom when their new C Shock collection hits shelves, with nary a taupe eye shadow. Taking a cue from the runways -- the models' eyes at Alexander McQueen were rimmed in acid green -- C Shock includes a range of eye makeup in aqua with green pearl, soft lemon yellow, and royal blue with pink pearl. All that's required is courage. And moderation.

WHEN FACING THE CAMERA on ''American Morning'' as a general correspondent every day from 6 to 9 a.m. on CNN, Alina Cho has bigger concerns than under-eye circles. ''Back in the day, newspeople sat behind desks. Now they do full-body shots,'' said Ms. Cho, who relishes the challenge because it taps into her zeal for clothes. In addition to reporting on hurricanes and politics, twice a year she covers New York Fashion Week.
Chapter 21

At the fall shows, the catwalks reverberatedwith the sound of stomping boots as Dr. Martens -- those Humvees of footwear and artifacts of a million misspent youths -- enjoyed a fashion moment. Yohji Yamamoto spearheaded the return, collaborating with the brand to create a limited-edition line; chunky lace-up boots also lent a subversive edge to feminine frocks at Chloé. When the German doctor Klaus Maertens made his first cushion-soled boot in 1945 -- to support an ankle he'd injured skiing -- he could never have imagined that his orthopedic innovation would evolve into an enduring symbol of youthful rebellion. The iconic brand's rise began in 1960, after R. Griggs and Co. Ltd. secured the rights to manufacture the Air Cushion Sole in England. With a newly Anglicized name, the eight-hole, cherry-red boot was launched as a work shoe. This proletarian association, and the fact that the steel safety toe could double as a deadly weapon, made it a part of the skinhead uniform. For the next three decades, ''Docs'' were worn by successive style tribes, their meaning subtly evolving with each new appropriation. While rude girls had been wearing Docs since the 1970s, it was not until the early '90s that women truly claimed them as their own. Riot-grrrl bands like Bikini Kill and their fans rejected high heels as ''phallicizing'' tools of the patriarchy. Instead they juxtaposed Dr. Martens' implicit symbolism of machismo and violence with torn baby-doll dresses, becoming at once the date-raped prom queen and her defiler. Over time the original outrage of this uniform was repackaged as a fun look sold at the mall, and it was left to the lesbian community to keep alive the radical spirit of ''chicks with Docs.'' Whether the recent catwalk sightings of Dr. Martens marks a reawakening of a feminist fashion consciousness is doubtful. But given the choice between the riot-grrrls' growl and the inane purring and pole scratching of the Pussycat Dolls, maybe it's time for women to strap on their boots.
Got that happy vibe? Time to grin and wear it.
Girls Gone Wild. In A Good Way.

Candy-colored boots were the uniform during last week's rain as buses and taxi cabs created mini tidal waves along Fifth Avenue, often drenching unsuspecting tourists in flip-flops. But New Yorkers were prepared, some wearing Wellington-style rain boots in darker colors, which were no match for the rainbow-colored umbrellas. Even a tiny dog wore rain gear.
restaurant.mc 57 Main Street

Mixing business with pleasure is rarely a good idea, but for the sculptor and modernist master Isamu Noguchi, friendship was one of his greatest catalysts. The fall show at the Noguchi Museum in New York, ''Design: Isamu Noguchi and Isamu Kenmochi'' (Sept. 19 to March 16), will focus on the close bond between the two Isamus and on their experimental, meticulously made and often collaborative work.

Ethan Watters (Aug. 12) sounds the usual alarm against American cultural imperialism in ''imposing'' our symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder on people suffering trauma around the world, like the recent tsunami in Asia. Yet he makes the differences seem greater than they are: the loss of one's role in the group among Sri Lankans is not so different from ''diminished interest in activities'' and ''feelings of detachment'' in PTSD. Afghans experienced ''nervous anger'' and ''the mental sensation of internal stress or pressure,'' which are similar to the ''irritability'' and ''hypervigilance'' described in our diagnosis of PTSD. ''Nighttime visits by vengeful spirits'' among Cambodians sound a lot like nightmares to me.

Selfridges in London has gone from high street to high end with the Wonder Room (right), its new luxury jewelry and gift emporium set to open Sept. 1. Shoppers who enter the 19,000-square-foot space from bustling Oxford Street will be able to stroll through an arcade of miniboutiques hawking such big-ticket items as Tiffany diamonds and Chanel fine jewelry, pause for a glass of wine in the Wonder Bar, then duck into a Dover Street Market-like concept store featuring an ever-changing bazaar of obscure perfumes, first-edition books, rare teas and other curiosities. ''We didn't want the space to have a precious, museumlike quality,'' explains Anne Pitcher, the buying and merchandising director for Selfridges. ''It's entirely accessible. It's Hermès to Chrome Hearts, with a wall of sunglasses in between, and that's the fun of it.''
Have shag bag, will travel.

Laurie Abraham's tale of marriage therapy lasting one year, two years, with no certainty of results -- a costly procedure, both in dollars and in the opening up of the most private matters before an audience -- gave me no lasting proof that this method works over the long haul. Frankly, it may deny the couple the years of freedom and independence of a divorce, followed by an opportunity to make a better selection the second time around.

PHOTOGRAPHING MOUNT SHASTA, MAY. 11, 2007 James Whitmore, 29, a waiter from Bend, Ore.: ''I was probably thinking more about technical stuff than the beauty of it, like 'Is it going to be too hazy?' I don't have a lot of good equipment; I don't have the right filters. My picture didn't come out nearly as well as this one did. I moved to Oregon from Nebraska two years ago. Nebraska's always home; it'll always be a special place to me. It has its own charm, but it's a different mentality. It's extremely conservative. The West is -- I feel like it's more like where my spirit, my soul and my heart is. It was a move that needed to be done.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

These are good times for design -- and for designers. They can go the functional route, turning out plastic stacking chairs and sectional sofas that sell by the truckload, or they can go the design-art route, creating limited-edition pieces that are sometimes sublime and sometimes ridiculous. Or they can do both, and no one will accuse them of selling out. And between the limitless possibilities of design art and technological innovations, functional doesn't preclude fanciful. There has probably never been so much good stuff out there to buy.
The Golden Age of Pret-à-Porter . . . Ovoid Rage . . . Injectable Collectibles . . . Chris Benz . . . Chicks With Docs.

A new TV dramedy, ''Lipstick Jungle,'' will begin later this season on NBC, but those of us who use cosmetics every day already know that jungle well: it's anywhere makeup and skin-care products are sold. High-end department stores or drugstores with more quotidian picks carry vast arrays of beauty products designed to baffle and confuse you, or so it seems. Some products offer vague instructions on how to use them; others are shrouded in self-serving dermababble that's best deconstructed by molecular biologists and chemists. Some products are self-explanatory, but provide no clues as to where they fit into your daily routine. When exactly do you use a primer? Should your sunblock be applied before the moisturizer, or does it double as a moisturizer? Does makeup remover clean your face, and why do some cleansers exfoliate?
With An Outlandish Hat And An Eye For Talent, The English Aristocrat And Editor Isabella Blow (1958-2007) Turned The Fashion World On Its Head.

EN GARDE, GOYARD: Louis Vuitton's latest favorite bag is the extra-light, super-sturdy Neverfull, which has sped past the Speedy bag to become the company's top seller. Made in signature monogram canvas, the tote has side drawstrings that allow it to expand as cargo is added. Purportedly, the bags can hold 400 pounds; the hardiness of your shoulder sockets is a separate issue. To heap newness on novelty, the price points are also tempered: the bags come in three sizes (the smallest holds a stack of magazines; the largest, left, easily doubles as a weekender) and cost $575, $620 and $665, at Louis Vuitton boutiques and eLuxury.com.

One evening in June, the Portuguese novelist José Saramago was addressing a small gathering at a book party in Lisbon. The occasion was the reissue of a volume of his poems originally published in 1975. Saramago, who is 84, is an austere man, extremely tall and so lean that he is practically concave. The night was hot, but he was wearing, as usual, a dark suit and tie. An outspoken atheist, Saramago maintains that religion is to blame for most of the world's violence. Yet in his old age he resembles nothing so much as a steely churchman from a Renaissance altarpiece, a St. Jerome in the desert.
Have shag bag, will travel.

King, creative director for Hallmark, on its Shoebox line, which is introducing more-topical cards as it faces competition from e-mail greetings.
High-gloss leather rocks on.
To have and to hold on to.
Fall fashion is for the birds. Designers have plucked inspiration from every plumed creature known to man, turning runways into chic aviaries.

The Swiss take their beauty as seriously as their watchmaking. But even among their high-tech temples to vanity, the L.Raphael salon stands out like a tourbillion at a Swatch fair. This seven-story building on Geneva's tony Rue du RhÃ$(4$)ne is home to the Orwellian-sounding Meso Omega Booster (a skin treatment that distributes vitamins via a small gun loaded with thin needles) and an oxygen-based body treatment called Oxy-Slim. The rich and lazy can also partake in semi-permanent makeup for lips and eyes that lasts up to six years.
Navy, old? not anymore.

Some years back, a now ex-girlfriend and I were persuaded to join a couples group to see if it could help our relationship. Our first session featured a woman who could not forgive her husband for accidentally pushing her down the stairs years before, despite his continual and sincere apologies; a blue-collar husband no longer sleeping with his upwardly mobile wife because she wouldn't join his lifestyle of six-packs and TV sports; and a psychologist -- not the group leader -- who belittled her quiet husband with a catalog of his faults and problems (including his irritable-bowel syndrome).

''GRID AND BARE IT,'' 600 4-inch-square works on paper by the Cathouse Associates, will be at the Peekskill Coffee House, in the Flat Iron Building, 101 South Division Street, Sept. 4 to Oct. 31; reception Oct. 25, 6 to 9 p.m. (That evening a GeneFree video, ''Gender Benders,'' will be projected on an exterior wall of the building.) ''ENVIRONMENTAL VISIONS: BEAUTY AND FRAGILITY,'' a group show including work by Shiela Hale, will be at Haskins Laboratories, 300 George Street, New Haven, Conn., Aug. 29 to Nov. 23; reception, Sept. 6, 5-7 p.m.

Alexandra Jefford's jewelry is more sculpture than accessory, which is probably why London art heavies like Jay Jopling and Gary Hume are snapping it up. Jopling was so smitten, he not only bought a ring for his wife, the photographer Sam Taylor-Wood, but also gave Jefford a one-day show at his gallery in St. James's. The jeweler is drawn to vibrant colors and geological oddities like the trapiche sapphire in this brooch (about $5,580). Her work is available at Maxfield, Los Angeles, and Kabiri, London, or go to www.alexandrajefford.biz.
Channeling Siouxsie Sioux in punk neon and leather.
This fall, the exceptions are the rule. If it looks good on an Ewok, it'll look good on you.

This year marks a century since the term ''brassiere'' was legitimized stateside in Vogue. To celebrate, we chart the evolution of what has proved to be one of the most significant fashion inventions of our time.

THE NEWS Pressed by Congress, the C.I.A. made public a 2005 report by its inspector general detailing the agency's failures in addressing the threat of terrorism before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. BEHIND THE NEWS The report said that George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence from July 1997 to June 2004, should be held to account for the failings, but the Bush administration has refused to discipline Mr. Tenet, who was awarded a Presidential Medal of Freedom in December 2004, or others named in the report.

Saving isn't as much fun as spending, true. But once you get into the habit, what you might blow on your closet could end up netting a much prettier penny down the line. We asked the investment adviser Andrew Fleming, the founder and president of Fleming Financial Advisors in Chicago, to pick a portfolio of fashionable alternatives so you don't wind up the best-dressed person in the shelter.

As the current editor of Ladies' Home Journal, which in 1952 launched and still runs the column Can This Marriage Be Saved, I was gratified to read Laurie Abraham's article. Her piece plumbs the maddening depths of marriage discontent and détente in much the way that our column has for 55 years. That it remains one of our readers' favorite columns is testament to the unabated yearning in modern times for marriages that are stress-free and soul satisfying.
Cerebral Minimalism Comes To Heel.

TIME TO FEED THE FRENZY: Before Lancôme's third Pout-à-Porter limited-edition lip color, P.S. Kiss ($24), arrives in stores on Oct. 1, the company is assiduously manufacturing buzz. In the footsteps of Chanel and M.A.C., Lancôme has produced a promotional video for YouTube that will also play on lancome-usa.com. It stars the designer Peter Som, who created the dark-red lipstick with the company's artistic director Gucci Westman. An advance waiting list is scheduled to open Saturday at 10 a.m. at Bergdorf Goodman in New York. Unbeknown to Lancôme's publicity department, though, customers unimpressed by the formal opening date began signing up earlier this summer; like-minded gate-crashers may call (212) 872-2740. Or, sidestep the circus and get the same look for less with N.Y.C. New York Color's Ultra Moist LipWear in Port (99 cents at ulta.com) or Smashbox Photo Finish Lipstick in Enchanting ($22 at sephora.com).

Debbie Harry As the lead singer of the seminal New Wave band Blondie and a successful solo artist in her own right, Debbie Harry, with her mix of pop and punk, is a music and fashion icon -- though she's reluctant to take full credit for her past sartorial choices. ''I don't know what was going on in my head,'' Harry says with a laugh. Her memories of her Perfecto motorcycle jacket appear on Page 316. Currently on tour to support her new album, ''Necessary Evil,'' Harry recently gave permission for several Blondie songs, as well as a new solo track, to be used for a stage adaptation of ''Desperately Seeking Susan.'' Despite all the nostalgia, Harry's true passion remains listening to new music. ''There's a ton of great stuff out there,'' she says. ''One of my favorite underground bands in New York is Heloise and the Savoir Fair'' (center).

The notion that fashion is just about clothes is as outmoded as the low-rise jean. These days, designers are also rethinking our living spaces. Their furniture, not surprisingly, bears an uncanny resemblance to what lands on their catwalks.
This fall, the exceptions are the rule. If it looks good on an Ewok, it'll look good on you.

We interrupt our regular coverage of the fall collections with this man- (and woman-) on-the-street report. Coming to you live from the Siren Music Festival at Coney Island, the TV on the Radio concert at the McCarren Park Pool in Williamsburg and P.S. 1's annual summer Warm Up in Long Island City, where the personal style quotient was so off the charts that it practically raises the question: Who needs fashion?

I swooned at the sight of Cécilia Sarkozy at her husband's inauguration in May. In her champagne silk Prada dress, the bodice stroking her torso, tiny pleats opening up at her waist and the skirt falling gracefully over the knees, she looked fresh, modern and sensual. And I wasn't the only fashion editor to salute this injection of glamour into a world usually dominated by pantsuits and momsy coat-and-dress combos. The French fashion press was even comparing her to Jacqueline Kennedy during the White House years.

As a onetime egg donor who has sometimes questioned the ethics of selling my genes, I appreciate the message of Peggy Orenstein's article that a family is a family, with all that entails, ''regardless of whose genes are involved.'' Though focused on the recipient, the article was reassuring to a donor (who is related to a 3-year-old somewhere out there) in its reiteration of the benefits of egg donation and its explanation of why some women choose not to adopt.

Indian women have always gone the distance for beauty. They've had to. Even now, when globalization has plunked down card shops and appliance outlets in every town with more than five sacred cows, makeup-buying options are limited outside the big cities. In most places, you're talking waxy lipstick in three cadaverous shades, sold at the general store. But there's a reason, beyond a fortunate gene pool, that India regularly cleans up at the international Miss Strut pageants. Women there have a history of being resourceful, as Sharada Dwivedi and Shalini Devi Holkar explain in ''Almond Eyes, Lotus Feet'' (Collins), a fascinating compendium of traditional beauty and healing remedies spun as the fictional memoir of a princess.

In reading Alex Kotlowitz's thoughtful article (Aug. 5), I came out with a greater appreciation of the problems Mexican immigrants face in small-town America but with no clearer idea of a solution. They come here at great cost, they work hard and well, they are nice people, by and large, and ask nothing more than to live among us and pay their own way. But with their apparent disinclination to learn English, they seem to care little about blending in to America's nebulous but fairly welcoming culture. Do we have a right to expect this of them, or they of themselves, given the long, ill-paid hours they labor? In my opinion we do, as do they. Fluency in language, perhaps more than anything else, could give them and us the understanding and acceptance they deserve, and that we can hardly afford to lose. It could help them become committed Americans, as it has for every other immigrant group. This is why we and they must make a greater effort, formally and informally, to encourage this process.

Can supplements and jelly beans give you the skin of a 20-year-old? We gave a few a trial run, then asked Dr. Amy Newburger, a dermatologist in Scarsdale, N.Y., and the author of ''Looking Good at Any Age,'' and Dr. Wahida Karmally, the director of nutrition at the Irving Institute for Clinical and Translational Research at Columbia University, for a more professional opinion. Their verdict? Take a multivitamin (Dr. Newburger gets hers at Costco) and eat more fruits and vegetables instead.
The artist and poet Matthew Brannon Invests Fall's silhouettes with an inner life.

I am going to be in Brazil for Christmas and New Year's with a friend. Can you suggest a nice area to spend four to seven days at Christmas before returning to Rio for New Year's, or would you recommend staying in Rio? -- Stephanie Seckington, Bath, England

Your window to brag that you knew the Virgins when is about to close. Until last year, they had no label, no shows and no record, so knowledge about this cool New York band was strictly by hipster word of mouth. Donald Cumming and Wade Oates met while modeling on a Ryan McGinley shoot in Mexico and decided to start a band to play the songs that Cumming had been recording in his East Village bedroom. They had barely recruited Nick Zarin-Ackerman and Erik Ratensperger and sent out demos before they were opening for Patti Smith and Sonic Youth and touring with Jet. It didn't hurt that the model Jessica Stam was seen wearing their T-shirt backstage at the Lanvin show. As for the actual music (expect a major-label album in the new year), think the Strokes you can dance to.

Recently dubbed the sixth borough, the City of Brotherly Love is fast shedding its second-tier status. The Second and Third Street corridors that stretch from Old City to Northern Liberties have been cleaned up. This once-scruffy blue-collar neighborhood known more for its heroin dealers than its hipsters is filling up with Pilates studios, shiny new condo towers and underground fashion and design boutiques.

Peggy Orenstein's article (July 15) about the experiences of women who conceive and bear children using other women's eggs focuses on their frustrations about infertility, their desires for a pregnancy and a child and the difficulty of their decisions. I hope that you will soon give the same sort of sympathetic attention to the women who are providing these eggs. What is it like to undergo the grueling egg-retrieval process in exchange for a check? How thoroughly are these women being informed of the risks they are taking -- including, as Orenstein briefly mentions, the possibility of adverse reactions requiring hospitalization and a small chance of death? Are they being told just how inadequate are the existing data about short-term and long-term risks? Who is recruiting them and profiting from the exchange? Orenstein's article concludes with the happiness of an egg-recipient mother-to-be, looking forward to building her family ''regardless of whose genes are involved.'' Until we consider the women who are providing the eggs that carry those genes, that rosy wrap-up seems premature.

All right -- I've had it up to here with getting older. And so I have decided I'm going to put an end to it. I have tried this before. In fact, if I had a minute less for every self-help book I've bought, fish-oil capsule I've swallowed and lotion I've slathered on my face in the hopes of looking younger, I'd be back playing with blocks. But this time it's going to be different. This time I have the guarantee of Dr. Jeannette Graf, a dermatologist and the author (with Alisa Bowman) of ''Stop Aging, Start Living.'' Dr. Jeannette writes, ''Not only does this program help you look more youthful on the outside, it also slows the aging of every cell in your body on the inside.'' And let's face it, nobody wants to have 17-year-old skin and a 51-year-old spleen.

COMMUTING to Manhattan by car has long meant enduring mind-numbing traffic and paying more and more for tolls, parking and gas. So in April, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed charging cars $8 to enter Manhattan below 86th Street on weekdays, suburban drivers had reason to groan yet again. But the plan, which is likely to be revised during negotiations with lawmakers in Albany next year, may turn out to be a net benefit for commuters who drive into Manhattan or take mass transit. That's because the city's plan appears focused on reducing the number of cars that come into the city and on raising billions of dollars to improve mass transit in the region.

Your first novel, ''The Septembers of Shiraz,'' has become a surprise hit, in part because it so vividly captures the veiled world of post-revolutionary Iran and the unjust fate of one Isaac Amin, a Jewish rare-gem dealer who winds up in jail. Is the novel at all autobiographical?

Debbie Harry As the lead singer of the seminal New Wave band Blondie and a successful solo artist in her own right, Debbie Harry, with her mix of pop and punk, is a music and fashion icon -- though she's reluctant to take full credit for her past sartorial choices. ''I don't know what was going on in my head,'' Harry says with a laugh. Her memories of her Perfecto motorcycle jacket appear on Page 316. Currently on tour to support her new album, ''Necessary Evil,'' Harry recently gave permission for several Blondie songs, as well as a new solo track, to be used for a stage adaptation of ''Desperately Seeking Susan.'' Despite all the nostalgia, Harry's true passion remains listening to new music. ''There's a ton of great stuff out there,'' she says. ''One of my favorite underground bands in New York is Heloise and the Savoir Fair'' (center).
Ladies, start your engines. High fashion goes high-octane.

Don't be surprised if the saleswoman at Saks asks for ID before she hands over Dior's new L'Or de Vie La Crème. Laced with Chateau d'Yquem, it's the latest in cosmetic hooch, at an intoxicating $320 a jar. Capitalizing on the fact that grape seeds are packed with antioxidants (the scourge of free radicals, those molecular demons behind wrinkles), the cosmetics industry has been hitting the bottle since 1995, when the French company Caudalie introduced a skin cream spiked with Bordeaux. Now even a scion of vintners is getting into the act. Davi, the new skin-care line by Carlo Mondavi, is a blend of grape leaf, fermented grape extract, green tea and other vitamin-loaded ingredients. But wine isn't the only booze young Hollywood is packing for rehab these days. Thierry Mugler's upcoming Angel La Part des Anges is a Cognac-inspired scent that is aged in cherry wood to produce a richer, plummier nose. Japan's SK-II contains a byproduct of sake, and Jo Malone's Blue Agava & Cacao has enough tequila notes that all you need is salt and a squeeze of lime. You can also fade your freckles with Caudalie's latest: Vinoperfect Day Perfecting Cream SPF 15, a pigment-lightening compound that, sadly, does nothing for a hangover.

Chris Benz may be originally from Seattle, but don't expect his customers to rock out in lumberjack flannels or defaced denim. ''I like the ease and recklessness of grunge, but I'm not into holes,'' says the 24-year-old Parsons graduate (top), who was awarded a Council of Fashion Designers of America scholarship before interning for Marc Jacobs and working for J. Crew. His debut collection (go to www.chris-benz.com) was inspired by old-school glamour: the jazz-era shirtdresses, mohair jackets, mink jockey caps and twill jodhpurs had a flapper-meets-slacker vibe that never seemed stagey. ''I'll do slouchy pants with low belt loops and a wallet chain for a tomboy look,'' he says. ''But I'm just as likely to put a chiffon flower on a blouse that Jordan Baker might have worn in 'The Great Gatsby.' '' He says his historical eclectism comes from a childhood spent rummaging through his grandmother's attic. Cedar chips and old clothes? Just don't call it grunge.

These are good times for design -- and for designers. They can go the functional route, turning out plastic stacking chairs and sectional sofas that sell by the truckload, or they can go the design-art route, creating limited-edition pieces that are sometimes sublime and sometimes ridiculous. Or they can do both, and no one will accuse them of selling out. And between the limitless possibilities of design art and technological innovations, functional doesn't preclude fanciful. There has probably never been so much good stuff out there to buy. And yet. It isn't easy to find objects that solve an actual problem and make you swoon at the same time. So a small exhibition of prototypes by the French designer Inga Sempé was one of the stealth highlights of Milan Furniture Fair week. I say stealth not because Sempé is unknown: her Chantilly sofa for Edra, a lush, almost louche creation covered in gathered jewel-toned satins and striped silks, was one of the high-profile hits of the fair.

The latest celebrity to feed the public's appetite for a taste -- should we say spritz? -- of stardom is Prince, the landmark artist and producer, who doesn't take a picture unless he's paid. His 3121 fragrance shares the same name as his No. 1 album. The fact that the scent is overtly sensual, with warm notes of patchouli and cedarwood mingling with brighter ones of bergamot and orange flower, comes as no big surprise from a man who has worn butt-less pants.

Your readers may have gained an incomplete picture of just how successful Thom Mayne's Lawrence House (now owned by Beth Harris) was in fulfilling his design aesthetic (Pilar Viladas, July 1). Mayne has published extensively on incorporating ''conflict'' into his structures. He truly achieved his goal. As a former co-owner of this structure, I found that its reflective surfaces and lack of demarcation of full rooms and the Escher-like tight stairways truly made this a house of torture -- and one that certainly helped contribute to my separation from my wife.

Another school year, another round of controversy about religion in public education. This fall, two new yet already divisive publicly financed schools are set to open: the Khalil Gibran International Academy in Brooklyn and the Ben Gamla Charter School in Hollywood, Fla. Both describe themselves as nonsectarian institutions that emphasize a particular language -- Arabic and Hebrew, respectively -- and both have been criticized on the assumption that they will be organized around the distinctive cultures (and thus religions) associated with those languages. Meanwhile, at the University of Michigan at Dearborn, a small firestorm has erupted over plans to install foot baths in school washrooms to help Muslim students perform the ablutions required for daily prayer.

It was a clear Sunday in August. I was lying on a dock in quiet Bellport on Long Island, soaking up the sun. The ropes on rocking sailboat masts were ringing out like bells. A cormorant was fishing in the sparkling waters of the Great South Bay. Ira, my partner, was beside me, blissfully taking the sun.

It was Aug. 24, 2005, and New Orleans was still charming. Tropical Depression 12 was spinning from the Bahamas toward Florida, but the chances of an American city's being destroyed by nature were remote, even for one below sea level. An entire industry of weather bookies -- scientists who calculate the likelihood of various natural disasters -- had in effect set the odds: a storm that destroys $70 billion of insured property should strike the United States only once every 100 years. New Orleanians had made an art form of ignoring threats far more likely than this; indeed, their carelessness was a big reason they were supposedly more charming than other Americans. And it was true: New Orleanians found pleasure even in oblivion. But in their blindness to certain threats, they could not have been more typically American. From Miami to San Francisco, the nation's priciest real estate now faced beaches and straddled fault lines; its most vibrant cities occupied its most hazardous land. If, after World War II, you had set out to redistribute wealth to maximize the sums that might be lost to nature, you couldn't have done much better than Americans had done. And virtually no one -- not even the weather bookies -- fully understood the true odds.

In 1964, a 3-year-old girl named Laudomia was unhappily confined to her sickbed. It was, as these things go, not a bad place to be confined; her bedroom was on the third floor of the Palazzo Pucci, a massive 14th-century villa in Florence, just behind the Duomo's pearl-gray immensity. But she was bored and restless, and so, to cheer her up, her father, an Italian aristocrat, brought her some perfume.

A limited edition of 50, the Delphine also comes in alligator, suede and leather. Krakoff's favorite is this $4,000 python version. Credited with turning Coach into a $2.5 billion accessories powerhouse in 10 years as its president and creative director, Reed Krakoff has a knack for translating his favorite things -- art, cars, travel, architecture -- into status bags that women gobble up like candy. His latest project is even more personal. The Delphine (named after his wife and No. 1 inspiration) epitomizes his modernist aesthetic. Its luxury lies in what's missing. ''There's nothing to hide behind,'' Krakoff says. ''It's organic yet disciplined, as the shape and balance had to be perfect in order for it to register.''

As someone who has been treated for and recovered from PTSD, I am acutely aware that the symptoms I experienced during the worst times of my trauma and recovery were acutely American. It disturbs me that we are actively selling a Western version of trauma and the route to recovery with a blind eye to the unique cultural expressions of suffering elsewhere in the world. Some observers of PTSD have also noted that the symptoms of the disorder even in the United States have changed and evolved with time. For example, the trauma symptoms displayed by veterans of World War I differed from the symptoms suffered by World War II veterans.

If names like Walter Albini, Ted Lapidus, Krizia and Guy Laroche don't send you sprinting to your favorite vintage dealer, it's time to bone up on your fashion history. By referencing the labels that epitomized European elegance 30 years ago, designers are reliving the golden age of pret-à-porter -- that heady era when dressing down meant settling for tights and Charles Jourdan sandals rather than fishnets and Maud Frizon pumps.

In its uniquely intimate look at a long-term couples-therapy group, Laurie Abraham's article (Aug. 12) demonstrates that truly committing to a process of finding out (with an excellent therapist) what will make a marriage better, and sticking with it, no matter how long it takes, could at the very least improve relationships and, in many cases, save marriages. How unfortunate that this form of therapy is largely available only to upper-income couples. Most marriage counseling is not covered by insurance, despite the fact that troubled marriages may lead to depression, anxiety and substance abuse, which can result in lost productivity and high additional health-care costs, to say nothing of divorce and its impact on children. The current in-vogue therapy, largely dictated by what insurance companies will and will not cover, is short-term cognitive behavioral therapy. This would not have repaired the 22-year marriage of Clem and Marie, nor is it likely to have much impact on long-ingrained dysfunctional patterns of behavior and communication in marriages that usually stem from each spouse's unresolved family-of-origin issues.

Tennis is one of the toughest sports for non-elite professional athletes. Not only do you have to play qualifying tournaments just to get into major events like the U.S. Open (unless your country is hosting the Grand Slam, in which case you may get a wild-card entry), but once there, you often face a seeded opponent in the first round and with that the prospect of an early exit. The United States national team leaves today for the Women’s World Cup in China and will open play Sept. 11 against North Korea. Samantha Hunt scored in overtime yesterday to give Canada a 4-3 victory over the United States and a three-game sweep in their under-22 women’s hockey series in Lake Placid, N.Y.Jinelle Zaugg scored twice and Sarah Parsons had the other goal for the United States. Molly Schaus made 38 saves, but could not stop Hunt’s wrist shot at 9 minutes 57 seconds of overtime.

Scott Dixon pulled ahead of Dario Franchitti on two counts yesterday: He took advantage of a late collision by Franchitti to win the Motorola Indy 300 in Sonoma, Calif., and he took over the lead in the IndyCar Series championship standings with two races remaining.Franchitti started the 80-lap race at Infineon Raceway from the pole and held an 8-point lead over Dixon in the standings. Dixon won for the fourth time this season. Hélio Castroneves was second; Franchitti, who collided with Marco Andretti on Lap 69, was third.

Gary Russell Jr. won his bout in the 119-pound division and Raynell Williams won at 125 pounds yesterday to earn the final berths on the United States Olympic boxing team in Houston.The winners in the other nine Olympic weight classes were decided Saturday night: Luis Yanez (106 pounds), Rau’shee Warren (112), Sadam Ali (132), Javier Molina (141), Demetrius Andrade (152), Shawn Estrada (165), Christopher Downs (178), Deontay Wilder (201) and Michael Hunter (201-plus).The world championships will be Oct. 23-Nov. 3 in Chicago. The top eight finishers in each division will qualify for Beijing.

Joe Carlucci, the owner of Famous Joe’s, a Danbury, Conn., pizzeria, is also a “pizza acrobat” and will demonstrate his singular way with a hunk of dough on Saturday on the corner of Mulberry and Broome Streets in Little Italy. In a 40-minute performance set to Italian folk music, Mr. Carlucci, who won a gold medal at the “Squadra Acrobatica” Pizza Olympics in Salsomaggiore, Italy, in both 2006 and 2007, will perform gymnastics while balancing and tossing several pies.

For the second year the New York International Fringe Festival, which ended yesterday after 16 days and 200 productions, will be followed by the FringeNYC Encore Series, offering quick revivals of selected shows. Starting on Thursday 12 of the festival’s productions will be presented in rotating repertory at SoHo Playhouse and the Bleecker Street Theater through Sept. 16. Among those chosen for remounting are “Hillary Agonistes,” by Nick Salamone and starring Priscilla Barnes, above, of the sitcom “Three’s Company,” as Hillary Clinton, and “Bombs in Your Mouth,” a comedy about dysfunctional half-siblings who reunite after their father’s death. The full lineup and schedule for the series will be posted at fringenyc-encoreseries.com.

The raunchy teenage sex romp “Superbad,” starring Michael Cera, Jonah Hill (far right) and Christopher Mintz-Plasse (near right) as high school friends on a quest for alcohol and girls, held the top spot at the box office for the second consecutive weekend, grossing $18 million and upping the film’s cumulative gross to $68.6 million in 10 days, according to estimates released yesterday by the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. The summer has been superhot for Hollywood, as the overall box office reached a record $4 billion, beating the 2004 record of $3.95 billion with one more weekend to go before summer is over. This weekend alone the top 12 movies took in $90.2 million, an increase of 7 percent over the same weekend in 2006. The thriller “The Bourne Ultimatum” (Universal) moved up from last weekend, rising to second place from third with an estimated haul of $12.4 million in its fourth week of release, and a cumulative take of $185 million in four weeks. Swapping places with “Bourne,” the comedy “Rush Hour 3” (New Line), starring Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, dropped to third place with $12.3 million for the weekend and $109 million overall in three weeks. Rounding out the top five were two new releases, “Mr. Bean’s Holiday” (Universal), the Rowan Atkinson comedy, which made $10.1 million, and the action film “War” (Lionsgate), with Jet Li and Jason Statham, which took in $10 million.

The Off Broadway “Frankenstein” coming this fall — not to be confused with the Mel Brooks monster musical “Young Frankenstein” — has some new cast members. Joining the previously announced Hunter Foster (“Urinetown”) as Dr. Victor Frankenstein, the mad scientist, are Steve Blanchard (“Beauty and the Beast”) as the monster and Christiane Noll (“Jekyll & Hyde”) as Frankenstein’s wife, Elizabeth. The new musical, inspired by Mary Shelley’s 1818 novel, will begin performances at 37 Arts on Oct. 10. ... The collective 12 Playwrights Inc., better known as 13P, will next present “Have You Seen Steve Steven?,” by Ann Marie Healy, beginning Sept. 15 at the East 14th Street Theater in the East Village. Ms. Healy’s comic drama, to be directed by Anne Kauffman (“The Thugs”), is about a Midwestern teenager whose life and sense of reality are knocked out of whack by what starts as a seemingly normal visit from a neighbor.

The Osnabrück Symphony Orchestra of Germany, led by the conductor Hermann Baeumer, will perform a program of Beethoven and Brahms in Tehran on Wednesday and Thursday, the Associated Press reported. The visit is part of an exchange program between the two nations, and follows a concert by the Tehran Symphony Orchestra last year in Osnabrück. “It’s a very small step in improving relations between the people in the two countries,” said Michael Dreyer, the head of Osnabrück’s Morgenland Festival, which played host to last year’s visitors from Iran. The female German musicians will observe Iranian law and wear headscarves.

Cormac McCarthy has been awarded the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for fiction for his novel “The Road,” the BBC reported. The prize was announced at the Edinburgh International Book Festival on Saturday, and Mr. McCarthy was not in attendance. Mr. McCarthy’s 10th novel, the story of a father and son in a postapocalyptic world, also won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. In Edinburgh, Byron Rogers won in the biography category for his book “The Man Who Went Into the West: The Life of R. S. Thomas,” about the Welsh poet. In announcing the awards Judge Professor Colin Nicholson of the University of Edinburgh said both books were “destined to become classics in their respective genres.” The University of Edinburgh began awarding the two prizes in 1919, and past winners include D. H. Lawrence and E. M. Forster.

A Turkish film about the fear of God overwhelming a true believer caught up in a powerful religious group was chosen as the best movie at the 13th Sarajevo Film Festival, Reuters reported. “Takva: A Man’s Fear of God,” directed by Ozer Kiziltan, won the Heart of Sarajevo award, which comes with a prize of 25,000 euros ($34,100). A jury led by the British actor Jeremy Irons made the decision, and the award was presented at the festival’s closing night ceremony Saturday. In the film a pious Istanbul man leads a solitary life until a religious group recruits him to work as a rent collector. His new job, which thrusts him into the modern world, tests his religious devotion. The seven-day festival included screenings of more than 170 feature films, shorts and documentaries.

Tom O’Horgan, who directed the original production of “Hair,” almost 40 years ago, will be honored at the opening night of the second annual Bad Plays Festival, which runs Sept. 10 to 30 at the Players Theater on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village. The three-week festival, presented by NY Artists Unlimited (nyartists.org), comprises plays intended to be so bad — meaning irreverent, satirical and bawdy — that they are, it’s hoped, quite good.

Luciano Pavarotti, below, was released from a hospital in his hometown, Modena, Italy, on Saturday after more than two weeks of treatment and testing since he was admitted with a high fever on Aug. 8, the BBC reported. Mr. Pavarotti, 71, underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last July, and has not been seen in public since. At the time, he was in the midst of a farewell tour and had hoped to continue the tour this year, but so far his health has not allowed him back onstage.

7 P.M. (USA) UNITED STATES OPEN Venus and Serena Williams will play back-to-back matches following the opening-night festivities, which will celebrate the 50th anniversary of Althea Gibson’s historic victory at what was then called the National Championships. During the ceremony, titled “Breaking Barriers,” African-American female pioneers in the fields of sports, entertainment, politics and the arts will converge on the court to celebrate Gibson’s life and career. Serena Williams, above, was the first black woman since Gibson to win the United States Open; Venus Williams was the first black woman since Gibson to win Wimbledon. Tonight Serena is scheduled to play Angelique Kerber of Germany and Venus will play a qualifier. For Venus this year’s tournament is about more than tennis; this budding designer will be decked out in an outfit and shoes from her new EleVen label, which is produced in partnership with the retailer Steve & Barry’s. The morning rounds begin at 11.

WEINTZ--Elisabeth Brewer ''Betsy'', 77, of Riverside, CT, died unexpectedly of an apparent heart attack August 22, 2007, while summering at her family home on Islesboro, Maine. Born March 26, 1930, in New York City, Betsy was the daughter of Warren Brewer and Elizabeth Miller Hunt. Betsy had a lifelong commitment to community service. She was a current member of the Leadership Council of the Harvard School of Public Health. Her most recent support led to the founding of the Harvard Humanitarian Initiative, a research and academic center devoted to advancing humanitarian practice, government and international policy in the protection of the world's most vulnerable people and the training of the next generation of humanitarian leaders. She devoted over 36 years to Greenwich Hospital as a volunteer in the emergency room. She also served as Chair of Emergency Room Volunteers, was on the Hospital Disaster Team and was a board member of the Executive Comittee of the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary. She served as president of the Old Greenwich Riverside Community Center for several years and was a trustee of the Greenwich Library. She served as board member of the Greenwich Adult & Continuing Education and the Community Cooperative Nursery School. She served on the Greenwich Arts Council, Junior League of Greenwich, and was on the PTA for Riverside Elementary School, Eastern Junior High School, Greenwich High School, and Brunswick School. Betsy loved to sing with the Blue Hill Troupe Ltd. and with the Greenwich Choral Society. What she loved even more was being with her family. Her love of the sea, sailing down the Intercoastal Waterway with her parents, crewing for her husband on Long Island Sound, and boating on Penobscot Bay with her grandchildren were some of her cherished times. She loved to travel, but mostly only with or where there was family. If Betsy could have, she would have saved every puppy in the window. There was never a moment in her life where there wasn't at least one dog by her side. She's survived by Rocky. Betsy was the first female ocean marine underwriter of the Insurance Company of North America, in Philadelphia. She later worked as the Administrative Assistant for the President and Chairman of the Board of American Sugar Refining Company in New York. She attended Rippowam Elementary School in Bedford, NY, Friends School of Wilmington, Delaware, Chapin School, NY, NY, and graduated in 1950 from Briarcliff College. In addition to her husband of 513/4 years, J. Retired Director of Public Affairs, NYC Department of Environmental Protection, co-founder and past president NYC Audubon, member NYC, NYS, and National Audubon Boards. BOWE--Frank . The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Frank Bowe, Ph.D., LL.D., a professor of counseling, research, special education and rehabilitation (CRSR) and the Dr. Mervin Livingston Schloss Distinguished Professor for the Study of Disabilities. He served on the University faculty since 1989. Dr. Bowe was a nationally recognized champion for the rights of people with disabilities an a highly regarded and prolific researcher in this area. On the Hofstra campus he was celebrated for his excellent teaching skills an for being a professor who brought warmth, humor and unwavering dedication to the classroom. Dr. Bowe was executive director of the American Coalition of Citizens with Disabilities from 1976 to 1981. He was the organization's first executive officer, and provided crucial direction during the nationwide sit-in regarding Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act in 1977, the world's first civil-rights provision for persons with disabilities, which eventually led to the American Disabilities Act, passed in 1990. In 1980 Dr. Bowe, who was deaf, became the first person with a disability to represent any nation in the planning of the United Nations International Year of Disabled Persons. In 1992 Dr. Bowe received the Distinguished Service Award from the President for his lifetime achievement. In 1994 he was inducted into the National Hall of Fame for People with Disabilities. He is also credited as one of the architects of provisions in the 1996 Telecommunications Act that have greatly enhanced the quality of life for Americans with disabilities. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis, and daughters Doran and Whitney. In tribute to the memory of Dr. Bowe, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half staff. John Miller Chairman, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

SCHEFF--Mollie , devoted to her family, friends and community, died at home in Sherman Oaks, CA, on August 23, 2007. CROTTY--Margaret McMahon , passed away on August 25, 2007. Born on July 4, 1913 she was a life long resident of Buffalo, NY. Mrs. Crotty was the daughter of Martin and Mary McMahon who emigrated from County Clare, Ireland to Buffalo at the turn of the 20th Century. She worked for the Internal Revenue Service until she married Peter J. Crotty, who was later President of Buffalo's Common Council, and longtime Chair of the Erie County Democratic Party. Mrs. Crotty is survived by her sister Eileen Gormley and her brothers Hon. Thomas P. McMahon and Rev. Gerald McMahon SJ. Mrs. Crotty is also survived by her seven children (Peter and James of Buffalo, Paul, Robert and Mary Shapiro of New York City, Kevin of Lexington, VA, and Gerald of New Vernon, NJ), 25 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on August 28, 2007 at St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Buffalo. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Canisius High School and Mt. Mercy Academy both in Buffalo.

WOLF--Melvin David 75 , of New York City and East Hampton, NY, died on Monday, August 20, at New York Beth Israel Hospital. Melvin was a long time New York City commercial real estate broker. He was President of the firm Wolf and Macklowe and other business associates include Julian Studley, and Henry Kessler. Born in New Jersey, the son of the late Victor and Irene Wolf, he is survived by his brother and sister-in-law Howard and Judith Wolf of Lawrenceville, NJ; a nephew and his wife Lewis and Connie Wolf of Las Vegas, NV; two nieces, Marcia Wolf of Lawrenceville, NJ, and Phyllis Wolf of Hamilton, NJ; and two great-nephews, Ian and Gordon Wolf, both of Lawrenceville, NJ. He was preceded in death by his life partner of many years, Charles Cohen. A graduate of Rutgers University, Mel was a veteran of the United States Army. He was an avid Yankee fan and art collector. He enjoyed swimming and world travel. Friends and family will remember Mel for his engaging personality and discussions about current events, movies, and theater. Mel was the chairperson of the Second Tuesday Lecture Series at the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Center in Manhattan for more than 20 years. Through his leadership, the series presented over 100 noted speakers representing every major cultural award in America, including Larry Kramer ( who founded Act-Up at a Second Tuesday lecture ), Christine Quinn ( NYC City Council President ), Alan Hollinghurst ( British Booker Award Winner ), David Dinkins ( NYC Mayor ), Michael Cunningham ( author of The Hours ), John Amaechi ( first out gay professional NBA basketball player ), and Arthur Laurents ( Broadway writer and director ). He was also a chairperson of the Pat Parker /Vito Russo Library book discussion group. A memorial service will be held at Crestwood Memorial Chapel 199 Bleecker Street New York, NY on Wednesday August 29, 2007 10:30am-12:30pm. Donations in honor of Mel Wolf may be made to the LGBT Center: The LBGT Center 208 West 13th Street New York, NY 10011 (212) 620-7310.

MUSHKIN--Sylvia , 98, died August 24. Loved by daughters Myrna Davis (and husband Paul) and Paula Marcisak; grandchildren Janet Marcisak Stickle (and husband Walter) and Matthew Davis; new great-grandson Jaden Stickle; many nieces, nephews and friends. McNALLY--Eleanor Holland , 88, passed away in Richmond, Virginia, on August 25, 2007. Mrs. McNally was born in the Hell's Kitchen section of New York City to Edward Aloysius Holland and her mother Margaret. She graduated from Holy Cross Academy and Katherine Gibbs in Manhattan and worked for the Travelers Insurance Company before World War II. In 1942 she married Ensign Frank J. McNally, Jr., a naval aviator, at Holy Cross Church in Manhattan. She is survived by her 10 children, 26 grandchildren, four great-granddaughters, four nieces and two nephews.

LEFKOWITZ--Rebecca , died on August 25, 2007 at the age of 99 years. She was a gracious Southern lady, born and raised in Atlanta, GA. She was married to her beloved husband, Louis L. Lefkowitz for 63 years, until his death in 1997. Loving mother of her late son, Hon. Joel L. Lefkowitz and his wife Helen and her daughter Marilyn Troy and her husband Stuart. Loving grandmother of Stephen, Charles, Michael, Edward, Julie and Richard and greatgrandmother of ten. Loving sister of Sarah Berlin of Atlanta, GA. She devoted her life to her husband, family and charity. She was an active supporter of Long Beach Medical Center and Temple Israel of Long Beach. Her memory will not fade for her loved ones and will be a blessing as she rests in peace with her husband.

WOODWARD--John. , died suddenly on August 22, 2007 at the age of 45. He was a Vice President in the Pharmaceutical Practice of Intrasphere Technologies, Inc. in New York City. Prior to joining Intrasphere, he was an Assistant Director at Pfizer, Inc., leaving as a Senior Manager in the Howmedica Division, after stints as a Senior Internal Auditor and Manager of Distribution Finance. He also was a Senior Auditor at Touche Ross, in Hartford, CT. John was a graduate Colgate University Hamilton, NY (1984) and The University of Hartford in Hartford, CT (1985). He is survived by his parents, Ronald and Adelaide Woodward of West Chester, PA, his sisters, Robin Woodward (of New York City) and Anne W. Lydon, his brotherin-law Joseph Lydon, and his niece Megan and nephew Joseph Lydon, all of Devon, PA. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Tuesday 5pm-9pm. HARRIS--Harold , a decorated veteran of WWII, died August 25, 2007, at his home in Washington, DC. Mr. Harris was born in the Bronx on May 8, 1920 and graduated from Richmond Hill High School in Long Island. A Master Sergeant in the Army, Mr. Harris led a mortar platoon from Normandy to Berlin. A survivor of the Battle of the Bulge, he was awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and was a proud member of the famed Spearhead Division. For 40 years Mr. Harris was an estate planner and insurance counselor in New York. He is survived by his wife Barbara; sons Richard of Voorhees, NJ, and Stephen of Mt. Laurel, NJ; daughters Carolyn of Washington, DC and Sharon of Sand Point, ID, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Tuesday August 28 at 10:30am at Joseph A. Gawler and Sons Funeral Home in Washington, DC.

Starting on Wednesday morning, Orville Schell, the author of nine books about China - including "Virtual Tibet," "Mandate of Heaven," "Discos and Democracy" and "To Get Rich Is Glorious" - will post answers to questions from readers on China's response to global warming. Earlier this month, Mr. Schell traveled to China and met with Chinese experts and officials to discuss global warming.

Today we have answers to reader questions from Yang Fuqiang in Beijing. Mr. Yang is the chief representative of the Beijing office of the Energy Foundation, a San Francisco-based non-governmental organization that promotes energy efficiency. Mr. Yang began his career working in Chinese energy research and has spent three decades working on energy and environmental issues. His present work is focused on finding ways to help China use energy more efficiently, which, in turn, can help reduce pollution.

Could the announcement be just a week away? Former Senator Fred D. Thompson has been hedging all summer on officially joining the Republican presidential field, but if the latest chatter in political circles is right, he may jump in as early as next Tuesday.

Home Depot said on Tuesday that it was lowering the price of its wholesale supply unit business by nearly $2 billion, confirming media reports. As previously reported, the retailer will sell HD Supply to a consortium of private equity firms for $8.5 billion, while holding onto a 12.5 percent stake in the unit and backing $1 billion in financing.

Private equity funds are likely to book significantly lower returns in the next few years, as tighter credit markets limit the resale value of their portfolio companies, buyout professionals and analysts told Bloomberg News.
Renaissance Technologies, the $30 billion hedge fund run by James H. Simons, is said to be considering a share sale, apparently shrugging off concerns about volatile global markets.

Shares of an $18 billion Dutch investment fund affiliated with the Carlyle Group dropped Tuesday, retreating after it received its second bailout from its private equity parent in a week, MarketWatch reported.

Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, who was convicted of fraud and obstruction of justice for stealing millions from the company, asked a federal judge to order his acquittal or give him a new trial. In papers filed today with Judge Amy St. Eve of United States District Court in Chicago, Mr. Black's attorneys argued that evidence prosecutors presented to the jury during his 15-week trial doesn't support last month's guilty verdict.

American Water Works, a subsidiary of the European utility RWE, filed with United States regulators to sell as much as $1.5 billion in stock in an initial public offering. All the shares to be sold are held by a unit of RWE, which bought American Water Works in 2003 for $4.6 billion.

Shares of the London Stock Exchange rose by as much as 5 percent Tuesday morning, on speculation that a new takeover bid could be triggered if the Nasdaq Stock Market sells its entire stake to another exchange.

NBC Universal is holding discussions to buy Sparrowhawk Media, which owns the international operations of the Hallmark Channel, for about $350 million, according to Reuters. Sparrowhawk, a private equity group backed by Providence Equity Partners and 3i purchased the international arm of the Hallmark Channel in 2005 for about $242 million.

Whole Foods Market said on Monday it had bought smaller rival Wild Oats Markets, following months of delays as U.S. antitrust authorities sought to block the $565 million deal. Courts in the Netherlands and France refused to grant injunctions seeking to block the Mittal Steel Company’s proposed $41 billion acquisition of a rival steel maker, Arcelor. Legal actions in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, by three hedge funds and in Paris by an activist shareholder were rejected by judges, removing obstacles to the creation of what would be the world’s largest steel maker, measured by sales. The steel companies already call themselves ArcelorMittal.

Many members of the Bank of Japan policy board agreed in early July that there was uncertainty in the outlook for adjustments in the American housing markets because of subprime mortgage problems, minutes of the central bank’s meeting of July 11-12 showed. Some members said it was not highly likely that the subprime loan problems would severely affect credit markets, the minutes showed, but if that were to happen, there was a “possibility that global financial and economic conditions could be badly affected.” The nine-member board agreed by an 8-1 vote to keep the overnight call rate target at 0.50 percent. The policy makers maintained the view that the United States economy would probably achieve a soft landing toward the end of the year.

The China Life Insurance Company, the country’s largest life insurer, said its first-half profit had more than doubled, topping forecasts. It was helped by investment gains in a strong stock market and rising premiums in the fast-growing Chinese economy. China Life said it earned 23.29 billion yuan ($3.08 billion) in the first half, compared with 8.97 billion yuan in the period a year earlier. China Life’s net investment income more than doubled, to 24 billion yuan, from a year earlier. Its gross written premiums and policy fees rose 17 percent, to 63.7 billion yuan, in the first half.

Airbus won a contract from EgyptAir for five 330-200s, a deal valued at $881 million at list prices. The order from the expanding Egyptian carrier includes options for an additional three planes, Airbus said. EgyptAir, the state-owned airline based in Cairo, said in a preliminary announcement Aug. 15 that two A330-200F planes to be used for training were part of the order, which will bring to 12 the number of A330-200s in EgyptAir’s fleet. Airbus is based in Toulouse, France.

ABB, the Swiss engineering company, will sell an oil and gas production plant, Lummus Global, to the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company for $950 million, ABB said. The buyout, subject to approval by regulators and Chicago Bridge shareholders, is expected to close in the fourth quarter, ABB said. ABB’s chief executive, Fred Kindle, said the sale was the final step in his company’s strategy to focus on power and automation technology. Lummus Global provides proprietary process technologies, project management, engineering and procurement services to the oil and gas industry. It has 2,400 employees and reported sales of $988 million last year. Chicago Bridge is based in the Netherlands.
Trusts representing creditors of the defunct commodities broker Refco said that they had sued its legal and accounting advisers on behalf of 75 foreign exchange customers.
A physician has been charged with sexually abusing women who had come to his office for ailments varying from lower back pain to sinusitis, the authorities said.
A deadly fire in 1987 led the fire department to standardize the system for inspecting buildings; the Deutsche Bank building fire is causing them to re-examine these methods.
Thornburg Mortgage Inc., the jumbo mortgage specialist sued by the Wachovia Corporation last week, said that it repaid the $5.1 million in collateral that was the basis of the bank’s litigation.
Paul Lo Duca, after a two-week stint on the disabled list, rejoined the Mets’ lineup for Monday’s game against the Phillies. Luis Castillo also returned.
The man whom Tony La Russa may pass as the manager with the most victories in St. Louis Cardinals history is a Hall of Famer and one of his most trusted lieutenants.
F.C. Dallas introduced the Brazilian star Denilson, and the club’s owner, Clark Hunt, called it one of the most important signings in the 12 years of M.L.S.
Alabama receiver Keith Brown and linebacker Prince Hall have been suspended for the season opener for unspecified violations of team rules, their coach.
The Stanley Cup champion Anaheim Ducks signed left wing Chris Kunitz to a four-year, $14.9 million contract extension, through the 2011-12 season.
David Beckham and Landon Donovan are among a glut of players whose injuries have decimated the Los Angeles Galaxy’s roster.
Elena Delle Donne, considered the top women’s basketball prospect in the 2008 recruiting class, has committed to Connecticut, her father said.
The Orlando Magic signed the 6-foot-11 forward Marcin Gortat.
A pitcher on the South Dakota State University baseball team, Kevin Morsching, died a week after sustaining head injuries in a skateboarding accident.
Alberto R. Gonzales held to the theme that in wartime the president has broad powers to protect the country.
As the credit markets tighten, some investors fret that the renegotiated deal for Home Depot’s wholesale supply unit may be an omen for other buyouts.
The Dutch government will spend $38 million over the next four years to prevent both the growth of Islamic fundamentalism and right-wing nationalism.
An investigation into the purchasing and delivery of billions of dollars of weapons has already led to several indictments of Americans, with more expected.
A town councilman in Stratford, Conn., has introduced an ordinance that would levy a fine against those gallivants around town with pants sagging beneath the buttocks.
Home foreclosures are expected to keep rising for months, and both parties in Washington are weighing a philosophical question with huge practical implications.
In the statement of facts that accompanied the agreement, Michael Vick admitted to financing the dogfighting operation and to being complicit in the killing of six to eight dogs that underperformed.
For President Bush, the back-to-back resignations of two longtime aides amount to a political housecleaning for his last months in office.
Chase Utley’s return to the Phillies could not have been more urgent as the injury-plagued team opened a four-game series with the Mets.

An article on Aug. 20 about the Church of San Clemente in Pisco, Peru, which was the deadliest spot in the recent powerful earthquake there, misidentified the denomination of the church. It is Roman Catholic, not Eastern Orthodox. The article also misidentified the patron saint of the parish. He was San Clemente Romano, or St. Clement, not St. Vincent de Paul. (The Vincentian Fathers administer the parish.).

A police officer in President Bush’s motorcade crashed his motorcycle at the Albuquerque airport and later died. The officer, Germaine Casey, 40, of Rio Rancho, crashed where a road enters an underground garage, said Trish Hoffman, a spokeswoman for the Albuquerque police. Mr. Bush had been heading to the airport after attending a fund-raiser for Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico. Less than a year ago in Hawaii, another motorcycle officer accompanying the president was killed in a crash.

Federal regulators ordered inspections of the wing slats on all newer Boeing 737 jets based on findings about a fire that destroyed a China Airlines 737 last week in Japan. The order applies to the owners and operators of 783 United States airplanes, but it will probably be imposed by other countries on the entire worldwide fleet of 2,287 newer 737s, said Les Dorr, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. Investigators in Japan found that a bolt from a wing slat had pierced the fuel tank of the jet, which caught fire after landing. All 165 people aboard left safely just before the plane exploded.

Officials closed a major Mississippi River bridge in West Memphis for nine hours after a pier under a small approach span in a construction zone settled nearly four inches overnight. The approach span for the bridge, which carries Interstate 40 was supported by other piers, said Randy Ort, a spokesman for the State Highway and Transportation Department. Mr. Ort said the entire one-and-a-half-mile-long bridge to downtown Memphis might soon reopen partly.
Prime Minister Surayud Chulanont said his army-backed interim government had agreed that parliamentary elections should be held on Dec. 23.

Fairfield University, Trinity College and Sacred Heart University, all in Connecticut, will pay tens of thousands of dollars each to various scholarship funds under agreements reached with the state’s attorney general, Richard Blumenthal. The accords end an investigation into relationships the institutions had with the College Board, the owner of the SAT and Advanced Placement examinations and a provider of student loans. The inquiry found that the College Board gave discounts on financial aid software to the colleges in return for being listed on their “preferred lender” lists given to students. The College Board announced last week that it was leaving the loan business.

A federal appeals court upheld the convictions of a former Philadelphia city treasurer, two bankers and others that resulted from a sweeping investigation of corruption at City Hall. The defendants had argued that their convictions, in May 2005, were tainted by the unusual removal of a juror during deliberations. But a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled that the lower court had acted properly. The former treasurer, Corey Kemp, was the highest-ranking person convicted in the investigation, which became public in October 2003 when an F.B.I. listening device was found in the office of Mayor John F. Street. Mr. Kemp is serving a 10-year prison term for accepting cash, trips and other gifts from people seeking city contracts.
A botched abortion has reignited a fierce debate over how the abortion law is applied.

A federal judge temporarily blocked a new state abortion law after Planned Parenthood said it would harm women by severely reducing the number of clinics available to provide the procedure. The law, scheduled to take effect today, puts more clinics under state supervision by categorizing them as outpatient surgery centers, requiring them to meet specific state building, staffing and health standards. Judge Ortrie D. Smith of Federal District Court granted a temporary injunction, saying he would hold a hearing on Sept. 10 on making it permanent.
A truck transferring soldiers and their families hit a concrete barrier on the roadside and crashed, killing 72 people and injuring 40 others, an army spokesman said.
Two brothers clawed their way out of a collapsed coal mine in the Fangshan District of Beijing after surviving underground for nearly six days.
CARE’s country director for Sudan said the government had abruptly expelled him from the country.
President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela will take part in negotiations between the government of President Álvaro Uribe and the guerrilla group know as FARC.
Even if the Federal Reserve succeeds in managing the credit crisis, its actions stir questions about the sustainability of the debt-fueled state of the American economy.
Jesse Levine is a scrappy player with a two-handed backhand and a baseliner’s sensibilities, so one of Roger Federer’s agents invited him to practice with Federer for two weeks in July in Dubai.
The Mercer County prosecutor has asked a judge to drop against two university officials in a case involving the drinking death of a fraternity pledge.

Because of an editing error, an editorial on Sunday misstated a new rule governing the expansion of the State Children’s Health Insurance Program. States must show that they have enrolled 95 percent of the children in families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty level before they can extend the limit above 250 percent, not to 250 percent.
Three senior fire officers were relieved of their posts for failing to inspect the building or planning for a fire there.
“South Park” is no longer merely the crudely animated, rudely scripted tales of Stan, Kyle, Cartman and Kenny.  It is now a creative powerhouse in its infancy.
The minister said that he would still support General Musharraf’s re-election if the president were to step down as head of the army.

After Justin Gatlin, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the 100-meter dash, blamed his massage therapist for a failed drug test, the spotlight landed on them.

Two major New York law firms announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge, creating what will be one of the nation’s largest law firms, with broad international reach.
Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct after making what a police officer described as sexual advances from an adjoining stall.

The Topps Company has postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $384.5 million buyout from a group led by Michael D. Eisner, the former Walt Disney Company chief executive, giving investors more time to consider the offer.

The debacle in mortgage lending that spurred wild daily swings in the markets has tripped up many hedge funds.
But it has been a boon to Convexity Capital Management.
Continuing construction, a sense of geographic isolation and waning buzz continue to hush the “pop” that speculators had predicted for a strip in Brooklyn.
Sales of previously owned homes fell to a five-year low in July and the glut of unsold properties climbed to the highest since 1991 as the housing slump dragged on.

A federal investigation of Senator Robert Menendez has shifted focus to the lobbying work of his former chief of staff, according to those familiar with the case.
United States Steel will buy the Canadian steel producer Stelco for $1.1 billion, a purchase making it the world’s fifth-largest steel maker.
Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson whined a bit recently that the winner’s prize for the four-tournament FedEx Cup playoff will be inaccessible until the victor is at least 45.
Presidential candidates are using the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina to attack the Bush administration and highlight their own initiatives to aid the people in New Orleans.

The Vatican introduced a low-cost airline that
will fly Catholic pilgrims from Italy to religious destinations around the world.
The announcement on Sunday has been hailed as evidence of movement toward national reconciliation by the widely-criticized Shiite-led administration.
President Nicolas Sarkozy of France also reiterated that a nuclear-armed Iran was “unacceptable” for France.
Nonprofit groups are stepping into an industry that has been widely criticized as predatory but that has reached as many as one in 20 Americans.

Two men who ran a Brooklyn firm that placed home health care aides admitted to a scheme that defrauded Medicaid out of more than $12 million.
The insurance company AIG is spraying a fire retardant goop on expensive homes threatened by wildfires in Idaho.
A new agency, called Engauge, intends to provide marketers with tangible results from campaigns and plans to grow by acquiring other agencies.
Tim McLoone’s dulcet tones can be heard in venues as cavernous as the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford and as cozy as a bar at the Jersey Shore.
Those arrested included a Chechen crime boss and career officers from Russia’s police and intelligence services.
A man who lived in a city shelter was accused of taking a television set, computer and other electronics from the senator’s Connecticut office, the police said.

David Tyree, a receiver and special-teams star, broke his left wrist in Saturday’s preseason game against the Jets, Coach Tom Coughlin said.

Now prosecutors are seeking to compel two reporters to testify about interviews with 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown’s parents, who are charged with murdering her.

Phil Hughes’s fastballs on Sunday averaged 88 to 91 miles an hour, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said, but should have been 91 to 93.

Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has finally done something important to advance the cause of justice. He has resigned.

His heart stopped. I saved his life. Cut to four years later, and an angry face-off.

Rolling Stones come to a halt, Poland and Germany argue over art, petition seeks to stop the Barnes’s move and more culture news.
Poland and Germany were embroiled yesterday in a dispute about art removed from each country during World War II.

In a petition filed yesterday, the Friends of the Barnes Foundation asked Judge Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans' Court to rescind his permission for the financially troubled foundation to move Albert Barnes's art collection to Philadelphia from its original home in Merion, Pa. The group asked the court to examine possible new sources of revenue that could offset the Barnes's $1.2 million deficit, including a $107 million allocation in the Pennsylvania State capital budget to finance the move; a new regulation permitting the museum in Merion to have 144,000 visitors a year, up from 62,000; and a proposed $50 million bond issue to provide an endowment. The petition also asked that the board of directors be removed and the foundation placed in receivership. ''What we're hoping is, by bringing new information and old information to the judge's attention, the court may be persuaded to reopen the case,'' said Walter Herman, a spokesman for the Friends of the Barnes, a group formed in 2004 to keep the collection from leaving the building where Mr. Barnes had installed it. The Barnes had no comment.

STONE--Malvina , born NYC, November 4, 1908, widow of Samuel Stone, cherished sister and sister-in-law, beloved aunt and great-aunt. Recognized accomplished Electrologist. Your invincible loving spirit will live on in our hearts.
