WOODWARD--John. , died suddenly on August 22, 2007 at the age of 45. He was a Vice President in the Pharmaceutical Practice of Intrasphere Technologies, Inc. in New York City. Prior to joining Intrasphere, he was an Assistant Director at Pfizer, Inc., leaving as a Senior Manager in the Howmedica Division, after stints as a Senior Internal Auditor and Manager of Distribution Finance. He also was a Senior Auditor at Touche Ross, in Hartford, CT. John was a graduate Colgate University Hamilton, NY (1984) and The University of Hartford in Hartford, CT (1985). He is survived by his parents, Ronald and Adelaide Woodward of West Chester, PA, his sisters, Robin Woodward (of New York City) and Anne W. Lydon, his brotherin-law Joseph Lydon, and his niece Megan and nephew Joseph Lydon, all of Devon, PA. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Tuesday 5pm-9pm. Funeral Service at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 50th Street, Wednesday 2pm.

HECTOR--Nancy Bean , born September 8, 1922, in Newington, Connecticut, died at home in New York on August 24, shortly before her birthday. She lived a full, exuberant life and returned to the city following the death of her beloved husband, Louis J. Hector, in November 2005, after 29 years in Miami. A journalist at Life Magazine and the NY Times Sunday Magazine, as well as the author of a children's biography of John F. Kennedy, she moved through her life generously and with unpretentious elegance. She faced her last years courageously, and she will be remembered as a person of integrity, the life of the party, a wise soul, a wonderful friend, a devoted member of the Cosmopolitan Club, Junior Fortnightly, and The Club--and also as a lifelong, outspoken, liberal Democrat. She also served as President of Planned Parenthood of Miami. Previously married to Theodore H. White and Charles Dewey Hilles, she is survived by her children-David F. White (Margaret) and Heyden White Rostow (Nicholas), both of New York, NY; her Hector step-children Denis (Joanna Lombard), of Coconut Grove, Fla., William, of Richmond, Va., Anne, of San Francisco, Ca., and Jay (Hilde Darre), also of New York; and seven grand-and step - grandchildren--Marga ret White, Theodore and Celia Rostow, and Dorothy Anne, William, Henry and Anna Hector. Memorial contributions may be made to The Brearley School. There will be a celebration of her life later this fall.

EPSTEIN--Edwin E. , 84, of Manhasset, NY, on August 23, 2007, following an extended illness. He passed away peacefully surrounded by his family. He was a prominent consultant to the grocery trade for 25 years, representing such food manufacturers as The Coca-Cola Company and Quaker Oats, and leading supermarket chains. He served as an advisor to senior management teams, and as a mentor to countless young professionals throughout the industry. He co-founded the Buying Skills program at the University of Southern California, where he taught for many years as a guest lecturer. Previously, with his brother David, he founded the Double E grocery chain, which was ultimately acquired by Pueblo International. Epstein then served as president of this NYSE-listed company. He grew up in Brooklyn. He served as a medic in the 99th Infantry Division in Germany during World War II, and later graduated from New York University. He was honored numerous times for his philanthropy, and served on the Auxiliary Board of North Shore University Hospital. A die-hard Jets fan and season ticket holder since 1961, his greatest joy was his family. He is survived by Elaine, his wife of nearly 55 years, sister Thelma and brother David, children Alan and Nancy of Los Angeles, CA, (and their children Melissa, Adam and Alison), Susan and Dr. Alan Sosnay of Scarsdale, NY (and their children Daniel and Jonathan), Barry and Bonnie of Roslyn, NY (and their children Jacob, Benjamin and Sarah) and Stuart and Randi of New York City (and their children Jack, Martha, Joseph and Eliza). The family would like to acknowledge the loving support of his wonderful caregivers, who were of great help during the final years of his life.

KATZ--Herbert , 96, on August 27, 2007. Devoted husband of Annette, his wife of 58 years, until her death in 1999. Beloved father of Jenne and her husband, Dan, and James and his wife, Susana. Loving brother of Muriel and the late Bea, cherished grandfather of Samantha and her husband, Jeffrey, Penny, Sandra and her husband, Keith, Kimberly and Kenneth. Proud great-grandfather of Beckett, Duncan and Aidan. A graduate of Rutgers University and Harvard Law School, Herbert was a past President of the Board of the Barnert Hospital Center of Paterson and an active member of New Jersey's business, legal and philanthropic communities all his life. Private services were held. Donations in his honor may be made to the Herbert and Annette Katz Endowment Fund, Harvard Law School, 125 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA 02138.

Despite preseason football on NBC, CBS finished first in the ratings on Sunday, getting a boost from ''60 Minutes'' and ''Big Brother.'' Nielsen estimated that the CBS news magazine attracted 8.8 million viewers at 7 p.m., while ''Big Brother,'' its 8 p.m. reality show, drew 7.6 million. Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC finished on top, as the game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles delivered 8.7 million viewers after a special broadcast at 7 of MSNBC's ''Countdown with Keith Olbermann'' (4 million). CBS ranked second in that demographic, ahead of ABC's all-repeat lineup. Fox was fourth over all, as its ''Teen Choice Awards'' earned 4 million viewers from 8 to 10.

LEFKOWITZ--Rebecca . The passing of our loving mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother will be deeply mourned. We are all blessed to have had her with us during her 99 years. She will always remain in our hearts. Love, Helen, Charlie, Lisa, Sam, Louis, Michael, Tatiana, Max, Eric, Molly and Julie, Todd and Mary-Ashley

First, there was all the familiar talk about ''energy efficiency'' on the campaign trail. Now, it seems endorsements from people connected to the 39th president of the United States, Jimmy Carter, are suddenly in vogue. First, Zbigniew Brzezinski, Mr. Carter's national security adviser, threw his support behind Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, praising his foreign policy vision in an interview last week on Bloomberg Television. Then Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, announced that he had been endorsed by Jack Carter, Mr. Carter's son, who ran unsuccessfully for Senate in Nevada last fall. Mr. Biden said the endorsement would help him in Iowa, ''where the Carter name is revered.''

STRAUS--Fran . Colleagues of The New York Times are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and colleague, Fran Straus, who died on Friday night from complications of leukemia. Fran was 48. MAUSS--Irving Howard, M.D. , June 9th 1914 to August 26th, 2007. Irv died peacefully in the hospital from complications following a fall two weeks earlier. He was a graduate of City College where he was a proud member of the Water Polo Team, and the University of Edinburgh College of Medicine (Scotland 1940). As well as being the oldest and very active member of the Paris Health Club where he was under the expert guidance of Fran Sperling. He was a Pediatrician in Rockaway, director of the PRIME program, (comprehensive child care), and on the faculty (previously acting Chief of Pediatrics) at North Shore Hospital. When he retired from North Shore at 79, a lectureship, which still continues, was named in his honor. Until his death he actively attended weekly grand rounds at North Shore. He served on the Board of Directors (both national and local) of Physicians For a National Health Program. (PNHP), and the Physicians for Social Responsibility (PSR, a Nobel Prizewinning Organization). As an avid member and supporter of literally dozens of organizations his concerns for Civil Rights and World Peace were life-long. He was a strong advocate for a better quality of life for the Citizens of New York and its Sister City, Tipitapa, Nicaragua. He and his late, dearly-missed wife of 64 years, Dr. Evelyn Abrams Mauss endowed a number of programs including a clean water project. He leaves behind his children, Steven Mauss, Susan Tunick and Peter Mauss, their spouses, Edith Thompson, Paul Tunick and Phyllis Odessey, his granddaughter Anna Tunick Tabachnik and her husband Serge, his brother-in-law, Dr. Herbert L. Abrams and his wife Marilyn, and his sisterin-law Margot Adams: as well as many, many friends and medical colleagues. Donations may be sent in his honor to The Dos Pueblos Project, 155 West 72nd St., #

Will the Stones ever roll again? The rugose rockers wrapped up their two-year Bigger Bang world tour on Sunday night at the O2 arena in Greenwich in southeast London, leaving their fans wondering if the show was the group's last. Mick Jagger, right, the 64-year-old frontman, gave no clues but thanked the audience for remaining faithful despite ''fire and ice and storms and trees, and God knows what,'' Reuters reported. The reference to trees apparently related to an injury suffered by the guitaristKeith Richards in 2006 in Fiji, where he reportedly fell from a palm tree, a report he later denied. The tour comprised 146 performances in 31 countries and Puerto Rico. The North American shows, accounting for slightly more than half the performances, attracted 2.2 million people and took in $300 million, according to Pollstar, a concert trade publication.

CROTTY--Margaret McMahon , passed away on August 25, 2007. Born on July 4, 1913 she was a life long resident of Buffalo, NY. Mrs. Crotty was the daughter of Martin and Mary McMahon who emigrated from County Clare, Ireland to Buffalo at the turn of the 20th Century. She worked for the Internal Revenue Service until she married Peter J. Crotty, who was later President of Buffalo's Common Council, and longtime Chair of the Erie County Democratic Party. Mrs. Crotty is survived by her sister Eileen Gormley and her brothers Hon. Thomas P. McMahon and Rev. Gerald McMahon SJ. Mrs. Crotty is also survived by her seven children (Peter and James of Buffalo, Paul, Robert and Mary Shapiro of New York City, Kevin of Lexington, VA, and Gerald of New Vernon, NJ), 25 grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on August 28, 2007 at St. Thomas Aquinas Church in Buffalo. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Canisius High School and Mt. Mercy Academy both in Buffalo.

MILLER--Pearl C . After the sudden passing of her revered uncle, Elias A. Cohen on July 2, 1952, Pearl dedicated over 50 years of her life to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp. Leading by example and putting others before herself, Pearl taught thousands of boys and girls how to live, play and work together. She brought out the best in anyone fortunate enough to meet her. Following Pearl's example, and in the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige,'' her adoring family, the dedicated staff, a grateful alumni and so many loyal friends are all helping to perpetuate Tranquillity Camp as an enduring monument to this great leader. Together, we will do our best to ensure that all generations of Tranquillity's children will mark this day as one to remember our beloved ''Pearl,'' the ultimate teacher. The Tranquillity family is proud to announce the successful completion of our 89th Camp season on August 23rd, 2007. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President Richard Lerner, Director

Feathered dancers and elaborate floats made their way through west London under sunny skies yesterday as the Notting Hill Carnival celebrated West Indian culture and the 200th anniversary of the abolition of the trans-Atlantic slave trade in the British Empire, Agence France-Press reported. Hundreds of thousands of spectators were drawn to the event, with ''Set All Free'' as its theme. The festival was begun in 1950 by immigrants from the British colonies in the Caribbean as an act of defiance after race riots the previous year. It was held in various parts of London before settling in Notting Hill in 1964.

NADICH--Rabbi Judah . It is with deep sadness that the Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of Rabbi Judah Nadich our esteemed founding Board member and Honorary Trustee. For many generations Rabbi Nadich was a prominent leader in our New York Jewish community as well as a national leader. He was internationally known for his role in liberating the concentration camps after WWII. His intellectual honesty, devotion to and care of his people was a life lesson to his children, grandchildren and thousands in the community. Our past President and current Trustee, his daughter Shira Nadich Levin, exemplifies those values and standards in her professional and personal life. Rabbi Nadich was instrumental in creating The Heschel School and has been a guiding force over the years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Hadassah, his daughter Shira, his son-in-law James Levin, their children Alexander, Gideon '96 (faculty member), Benjamin '01, and the entire family. Whether the spotlight has been on Bill Clinton's past, Elizabeth Edwards's battle with cancer, Jeri Kehn Thompson's relative youth or Judith Giuliani's previous marriages, potential first spouses have been the subject of much attention in the 2008 presidential campaign. A proposal before the Atlanta city council to criminalize the public wearing of low-riding, underwear-exposing pants is intriguing. (See tomorrow's Thursday Styles section.) Let's turn back the hands of time. Let's construe a disorderly fashion with disorderly conduct. This has been done many times in history, and for a reminder, I turn to one of my favorite studies, Aileen Ribeiro's "Dress and Morality" (Holmes & Meier Publishers: 1986). She cites Richard Steele, in The Spectator, from 1711: "The most improper things we commit in the conduct of our lives, we are led into by the force of fashion." People who complain that there is nothing new in fashion are quite correct. Fashion has always offended someone. But I wonder whether the Atlanta council members who support the ban are appalled at the "indecency" of baggy pants or the fact that the look has been so lasting and pervasive in our culture.

Central African Mining & Exploration of London started an offer for Katanga Mining of Canada on Wednesday, which it said valued the company at 1.52 billion Canadian dollars ($1.44 billion).

Strong results from domestic operations raised Bank of Nova Scotia's third quarter profit by 10 percent from the same period last year as the bank reported Tuesday that it had made 1.03 billion Canadian dollars ($970 million) in the most recent quarter.

The really important question about the sale of Home Depot's construction supply business apparently isn't the price, which Home Depot lowered 18 percent on Tuesday, to $8.5 billion, after round-the-clock negotiations.

Journeyman-with-a-sense-of-humor Justin Gimelstob might not have put up much of a fight (after a surprisingly competitive first set) against fifth-seeded Andy Roddick on Tuesday night, but before he left Arthur Ashe Stadium, and professional tennis, he gave the crowd what has got to be one of the funniest moments thus far in the tournament.

Manfred Wennemer, chief executive of the German auto parts maker Continental, says he is not concerned about being the world's biggest auto-parts supplier -- even though the purchase last month of Siemens VDO moved his company closer to the leader, Robert Bosch.

In the latest aftershock of the options backdating investigations, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday charged the former general counsel of KLA-Tencor and Juniper Networks with civil fraud charges.
Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor who has battled executives at Motorola, Time Warner, and other iconic corporations, now appears to have Biogen Idec in his crosshairs.

Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies after recent problems related to subprime mortgages. Their argument is simple: The United States is exporting financial products, but losses to investors in other countries suggest that American regulators are not properly monitoring the products or alerting investors to the risks.

A federal judge declined to acquit the former chief executive of Brocade Communications, Gregory Reyes, on Monday, saying there was sufficient evidence to convict him in the first criminal trial related to stock-option backdating.

NBC Universal announced on Tuesday the acquisition of a group of international cable television channels owned by Sparrowhawk Holdings of London, a deal that Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.
A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

William S. Lerach, a leading securities class-action lawyer who has been embroiled in a seven-year federal investigation into possible kickbacks to plaintiffs for their testimony, is retiring from his firm. Rumors that Mr. Lerach would leave had been swirling for months amid speculation that he would resign in exchange for the firm's not being indicted.

A Russian court issued an arrest warrant Tuesday for Mikhail S. Gutseriev, a former owner of Russneft, a young but larege oil company, on charges of tax evasion and fraud, a month after he published a letter critical of the government on a company Web site and in a Russian business newspaper.

Google said Tuesday that George Reyes, the company's longtime chief financial officer, plans to retire. He will be one of only a few of the Internet search giant's top executives to have left since its founding in 1998.

One mortgage lender announced Tuesday that it was hiring as it tried to take advantage of the turmoil in the market, while another said it was cutting jobs. IndyMac Bancorp said it had hired more than 600 former employees of the American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation and might hire 250 more.

The CME Group, created recently when Chicago's big futures exchanges merged, said Tuesday that it was closing trading pits for pork bellies and other products as traders increase their focus on electronic platforms.
The digital camera's features include high-speed infrared to beam photos to another Fuji camera and an eBay mode.
Based on the two most recent episodes, “We Got to Do Better,” on BET,  is more of a shrug than a wince.

The fascination of this documentary is the light it throws on Nureyev’s life and career before his escape from the Soviet Union, through candid observations by close friends as well as colleagues in Nureyev’s youthful Leningrad years.
Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal,  Justine Henin and the Williams sisters were among the players in action on the third day of competition.
Not too many properties can boast their own subspecies of jaguar, 650 varieties of birds and the occasional anaconda.

The Yankees have made their decision on Mike Mussina: It will be Ian Kennedy on Saturday at Yankee Stadium. Mussina, who was 0-3 with a 17.69 E.R.A. in his last three starts, will continue his throwing program to stay ready if Kennedy falters.
Tender and sad, Aaron Katz’s film “Quiet City” is a fully realized work of mumblecore poetry.
In “The Monastery: Mr. Vig & the Nun,” Jorgen Lauersen Vig comes across as a hybrid of quasi-Dickensian curmudgeon and modern grumpy old man.
“Balls of Fury” is raunchier and somewhat more imaginative than “Hot Rod,” and it will be must viewing for Christopher Walken completists.
The political career of Senator Larry Craig of Idaho appeared to be collapsing today amid the fallout over his guilty plea in connection with an incident in a restroom.
No reshuffling of administration staff, or an incremental wave of good news, is likely to change the president's polarizing dynamic.
A report on astronauts’ use of alcohol found no evidence of drunkenness prior to launches.
The president, touring the city devastated by wind and flood, said he saw “a more blessed day” ahead.
Mr. Kristal founded CBGB, the Bowery bar that was the cradle of punk- and art-rock in New York in the 1970s.
Moktada al-Sadr made the announcement after  fighting between his militia and rival Shiite forces that left 52 people dead.
Investors appeared for now to put aside concerns about tighter credit availability and other signs that the economy may be slipping.
The officer, Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, was found guilty of only one lesser offense, that of disobeying an order to refrain from discussing the case.
Taliban militants released 12 of their remaining 19 South Korean hostages today, officials announced.
Members of an Iranian delegation visiting Baghdad at the invitation of the Iraqi government were released Wednesday, a day after being arrested at their hotel by American troops
The volatility triggered by the mortgage meltdown in the United States further plagued stock markets today, prompting a drop of all major indices in Asia.
The Yankees need energy these days, and Johnny Damon, the center fielder who lost his job, is providing it.  After fighting through various leg injuries, Damon looks as spry as Melky Cabrera.

DOVER, Del., Aug. 28 — The deaths, more than three weeks ago and nearly three hours from here, echoed yesterday across the 400-acre campus, down the winding paths, past the historic buildings and converging at the student theater that is host to holiday concerts, dance recitals and the coronation of Mr. and Miss Delaware State University.

A knife-wielding robber needed only $4, so he refused to take a $10 bill from his 18-year-old victim and waited while the teenager made change at a pizza parlor, the police said yesterday. The victim came out of a store and was approached by the robber, who said, “Give me the rose,” Police Capt. Joseph DeCarlo said. “The kid told him, ‘Go in there and get one.’ But the suspect says, ‘I want that one, and your money, too,’ and pulls out a knife.” The teenager had only $10, Captain DeCarlo said, but the robber wanted only $4, so he told the teenager to get change. The teenager complied, and the man took the $4 and left, Captain DeCarlo said, though he was caught only blocks away. The suspect, James Mitchell, 48, of Mount Vernon was arraigned Tuesday on robbery and weapon charges.
The Phillies, fooled by Tom Glavine through seven innings, tied the score in the eighth inning before finishing off a rousing comeback victory in the 10th.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed a bill yesterday that would have required more regular inspections of New York City buildings that have been found to be hazardous. The move came days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg wrote a letter to the governor urging a veto.

Leandro Barbosa, the leading scorer in the FIBA Americas tournament, scored 21 points last night to lead Brazil to a 104-90 victory over Mexico in the second round in Las Vegas.Barbosa, the N.B.A.’s Sixth Man of the Year with the Phoenix Suns last season, was 8 for 13 from the field. He fell just short of his tournament average of 23.8 points.Also yesterday, Argentina defeated Canada, 85-70, and Venezuela beat Uruguay, 88-79.The United States, which earned a 127-100 victory against Mexico on Monday night, played Puerto Rico late last night.

Kirby Freeman was named Miami’s starting quarterback, beating out Kyle Wright in a scrutinized competition. Hurricanes Coach Randy Shannon would not say how Freeman separated himself in the race, only insisting that “Kirby gives us the best opportunity to win games.” Miami opens Saturday at home against Marshall.
Johnny Damon bathed himself in the ovation of a sold-out crowd after his two-run homer sneaked inside the right-field foul pole in the seventh inning.

The promoters of the season-ending Champ Car World Series event, which was to be held Dec. 2 in Phoenix, have canceled the inaugural event because of a lack of sponsor support. The race was to have been run on a newly constructed street circuit.The Sports Property, the group that promoted the race, also promoted the season-opening race in April in Las Vegas. That event will continue.The cancellation means the Champ Car series will have no more races in the United States this season. The other races will be held in the Netherlands, Australia and Mexico.
A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

A picture on Friday with an article about the impending release from prison of Arthur Bremer, who shot Gov. George C. Wallace, appeared in mirror image. The photograph, taken by The Associated Press in 1972, showed Mr. Bremer facing left, surrounded by police officers and security agents. The A.P. incorrectly re-released the picture last week with him looking right.

A picture on Friday with an article about an accident at the Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan in which two firefighters were injured by a falling forklift carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, showing the demolition scene, was by Suzanne DeChillo of The New York Times, not by Cary Conover for The New York Times.

An article on Sunday about Orthodox Jews who play in a softball league during summer vacations in the Borscht Belt misspelled the surname of a player for one team, the Lobos. He is Jack Eizikovitz, not Ezikovitz.

An article on Monday about a program in South Texas that helps families gradually rebuild shacks into homes misstated the surname of the Starr County ombudswoman who oversees the state’s Colonia Initiatives Program. She is Blanca Juarez, not Suarez. Also, the article carried an incorrect dateline, and a picture caption repeated the error. The article and photograph were from Rio Grande City; there is no town named Rio Grande.

An article in Business Day on Aug. 20 about the greeting card market referred imprecisely to the number of paper cards sold relative to online cards, and misattributed the statistic. The statement that the paper card market is five times as large as the e-card market applied to cards sold by one company, American Greetings, not the industry at large, and it should have been attributed to American Greetings — not the Greeting Card Association, a trade group.

An article in the Itineraries pages of Business Day on July 31 about the changing nature of hotel bars misspelled the surname of a businessman who said he found the bars to be a good place to interact with colleagues or clients. He is Larry Cerri, not Cerci.

An article on Aug. 16 about a joint project between I.B.M. and the Beacon Institute for Rivers and Estuaries, a scientific research organization, to create a center for river research that will monitor conditions in the Hudson referred incorrectly to John Cronin, the director of the institute. (The error was repeated in an editorial in the Westchester section on Aug. 19.) Mr. Cronin is the second Hudson riverkeeper, a private pollution watchdog — not the first, a distinction held by Thomas Whyatt, who served from 1973 to 1976.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about “Have You Seen Steve Steven?,” a forthcoming production at the East 14th Street Theater, misstated the name of the presenter. It is the collective 13 Playwrights Inc., not 12 Playwrights Inc.

The Basics column in Science Times on Aug. 21, about the properties of lead, misstated the result of adding lead to gasoline. Lead additives were used to raise, not lower, an engine’s combustion point.
Corrections: For the Record

A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Thursday, about the death of a 78-year-old Yonkers woman whose apartment was set on fire, included an erroneous given name from the police for the victim. She was Louise Paciarello, not Madeline.

An article yesterday about the fire inspection system for buildings in New York City misstated the surname of a spokesman for the Fire Department, who said he could not provide more information on the reasons for a decrease in inspections from fiscal year 2005 to fiscal year 2006. He is Firefighter James F. Long, not Young.

An article on Aug. 21 about the conductor Claudio Abbado referred incorrectly to the last time he performed in the United States. It was in Ann Arbor, Mich. — not New York — shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Swin Cash hit a layup with 8.5 seconds remaining in overtime to lift the Detroit Shock to a 71-70 victory over the Liberty in Game 3.
It has been widely speculated that O.J. Mayo will play one season at U.S.C. and then jump to the N.B.A.
Commissioner Bud Selig met for the first time with Miami city and county leaders, hoping that his influence would help the Florida Marlins’ quest for a new ballpark.

New Jersey is seeking to dismiss a lawsuit claiming that it is pressuring the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association into allowing civil unions at its boardwalk pavilion. The state argues in its motion, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Trenton, that a state discrimination investigation should be resolved first, said Leland Moore, a spokesman for the attorney general’s office. The association, a Methodist group, said in its lawsuit that the state was violating its First Amendment rights by pressuring it to allow the ceremonies. The New Jersey Division on Civil Rights is investigating two discrimination complaints from gay couples whose requests to use the pavilion, which the association owns, for civil union ceremonies were denied. The association filed a separate request with the court asking that the discrimination investigation be stopped. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Manuel Antonio Noriega can be extradited to France, where he faces charges of money laundering and up to a decade in prison, a federal judge in Miami ruled.

One of the six suspects accused of killing three people and wounding a fourth in a schoolyard shooting in Newark on Aug. 4 was extradited from Virginia to New Jersey yesterday, the authorities said. The suspect, a 16-year-old, will be held at a juvenile detention center and will likely appear for a hearing in family court next week, according to Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor. He was captured in Woodbridge, Va., on Aug. 18, barely an hour after the authorities arrested his half brother, Rodolfo Godinez, 24, in Maryland. Mr. Godinez is fighting his extradition to New Jersey. Investigators said the two half brothers are part of a group of six men and teenagers charged with murder, robbery, and other crimes in the attack of four youths who were at the playground that night.
The Pretoria High Court temporarily barred the city government from posting road signs that identify Pretoria as Tshwane.

The superintendent of the Paramus schools resigned Monday night, following criticism of her actions after the discovery of contaminated soil at the Green Brook Middle School last year that eventually forced the school to close in May. The superintendent, Janice Dime, who had worked in the district for 22 years, will resign and receive $212,000 in salary for the coming year, plus $20,000 in medical benefits, said Mario V. Sicari, the school board president.
A major congress expected to produce a new Communist Party leadership team will open on Oct. 15, the state news media reported.
An Indian businessman who had spent years evading authorities around the world appeared in a Calcutta court Tuesday to face a host of criminal conspiracy charges.

New York state paid nearly $10 million in Medicaid claims over five years for home care and transportation services for patients who were either in the hospital or had died, according to an audit by State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli. The comptroller criticized the Health Department for not identifying the overpayments. Department officials said they were already taking steps to detect fraudulent billing and questioned the audit, which they said overstated the bad bills by more than $2 million.
A candidate of the party of the presidential candidate Rigoberta Menchú, winner of the 1992 Nobel Peace Prize, was shot dead by gunmen.

Dozens of state construction projects will have to meet new environmental standards beginning next year, officials announced yesterday. The Dormitory Authority, a state agency that provides financing and construction services to universities and nonprofit health care facilities, will require new projects to meet environmental standards established by the U.S. Green Building Council. The agency has more than 72 projects that total more than $3.5 billion already under way, but those projects will not be forced to meet the new standards. The new standards are expected to reduce energy use by 32 percent per building.
A South African mining company claimed to have found a greenish-tinged diamond weighing in at 7,000 carats, but skeptics said the claim remained unproved.

A man was indicted on manslaughter charges in the death of a livery cab driver who was run down in the street, prosecutors said yesterday. The cab driver, Rafael Rafailov, 50, had stopped to assist another livery cab driver with a disabled vehicle on Ocean Parkway in Kensington last Wednesday when he was struck and killed by a third car. The driver of the third car, Alexey Bushuyev, 22, crashed to a halt nearby. His blood alcohol level tested at .11 percent, above the legal driving limit of .08 percent, prosecutors said. The manslaughter charges in the indictment carry a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison, prosecutors said. A lawyer for Mr. Bushuyev, Susan Kellman, said the charges were excessive. Noting that the disabled car was parked in the center lane, she said: “This seems like an accident. I don’t think you could have avoided it.”.

A 12-year-old boy was killed yesterday afternoon in Springfield Gardens when he was hit by a box truck while riding his bicycle, the police said. The boy, who was not named yesterday pending family notification, was riding alongside the truck just before 1 p.m. near 130th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard when he was hit by the vehicle, the police said. He was pronounced dead at the scene. No charges were issued against the driver yesterday, the police said.
The mayor of Argenteuil, a Paris suburb, said he would suspend the use of a foul-smelling spray against homeless people after rights groups and politicians across the spectrum attacked the measure.

Metro transit officials blamed aging infrastructure and a possible lightning strike for causing electrical problems that hobbled train service in the capital region for two straight nights. John Catoe, the Metro general manager, said a power surge that lightning might have caused probably blew a transformer near Reagan National Airport on Sunday, sparking small fires and sapping power to trains. The same problem re-emerged during yesterday’s evening commute, forcing officials to close some stations for hours.

An openly lesbian priest is one of five candidates nominated by a search committee to be the next Episcopal bishop of Chicago. The nomination of the priest, the Very Rev. Tracey Lind, dean of Trinity Cathedral in Cleveland, came as a surprise because the Episcopal Church passed a resolution at its last general convention calling on dioceses to “exercise restraint” by not consecrating any more openly gay bishops. The Episcopal Church has been under pressure from fellow churches in the Anglican Communion to declare a moratorium on gay bishops, a response to the election in 2003 of an openly gay bishop by the Diocese of New Hampshire. The election in the Diocese of Chicago is Nov. 10.

Former State Senator John Ford, once among Tennessee’s most powerful lawmakers, was sentenced to five and one-half years in prison for bribery. Mr. Ford, 65, was one of five former lawmakers convicted of bribery or extortion in a statewide corruption investigation. He was convicted in April of taking $55,000 in bribes from F.B.I. agents posing as dishonest businessmen representing E-Cycle Management. The company, which sought a change in state law for a business advantage, was a front created by the F.B.I.

A miner was missing and thought to be trapped after a cave-in at an underground gold mine near Winnemucca, the authorities said. Two rescue teams were sent to the scene at the Getchell Mine, said Dirk Fillpot, a Mine Health and Safety Administration spokesman. It was not immediately known how far below the surface the accident occurred. The Getchell Mine, owned jointly by the Barrick Gold Corporation and the Newmont Mining Corporation, is operated by SMD, an independent contractor, said Vincent Borg, a Barrick spokesman.

The Hawaii Superferry canceled its trip from Honolulu to Kauai at the request of Gov. Linda Lingle, who said she was worried about public safety after a protest in the water the day before stopped the ferry from docking. The ferry, which began operating Sunday, was turned away from Kauai on Monday night by about 65 protesters on surfboards, kayaks and canoes. Coast Guard vessels tried to clear the way, but after three hours, the ferry returned to Honolulu. A judge has temporarily blocked the ferry’s other service to Maui over environmental concerns.

About 160 illegal immigrants were arrested in a raid at a poultry processing plant in Fairfield, the authorities said. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents seized documents and other materials at the Koch Foods plant and at the company’s headquarters near Chicago, said Agent Brian Moskowitz. An official at the Fairfield plant, Monte Lobb, said he had fired many employees after finding out they were illegal immigrants and had repeatedly told the federal authorities he wanted to cooperate with them. An I.C.E. spokesman, Marc Raimondi, said deportation proceedings would begin immediately.

Todd Boeckman will start at quarterback when No. 11 Ohio State plays host to Youngstown State on Saturday in its season opener.Boeckman takes over for Troy Smith, who won the Heisman Trophy last season.The 6-foot-5, 235-pound Boeckman was listed No. 1 on the depth chart coming into spring practice, then solidified his position this summer over Rob Schoenhoft, Antonio Henton and Joe Bauserman.

Houston Rockets guard Rafer Alston was charged yesterday with slashing a man’s neck during a ruckus at a Manhattan nightclub — his second brush with the law this month. The police arrested Alston early Monday after responding to a brawl at a nightclub.Alston, 31, was arraigned on felony assault charges before being released without bail. A judge ordered him to return to court Jan. 3.Alston’s lawyer, Alberto Ebanks, said he was “absolutely innocent.”Alston, who grew up in Queens, was ordered to return to court Jan. 3. His lawyer did not respond to a telephone message.The arrest came three weeks after Alston was charged with misdemeanor assault and public intoxication in Houston.

Notre Dame defensive lineman Derrell Hand, arrested last month on a misdemeanor charge of propositioning a prostitute, will be allowed to play for the Fighting Irish after serving a three-game suspension imposed by Coach Charlie Weis.Hand appeared before the university’s disciplinary committee Monday, was reinstated to the team and began practicing that day, Weis said yesterday.

Ernie Els withdrew from the Deutsche Bank Championship yesterday for family reasons. Els, who is ranked fourth in the world, is returning to his home near London, where his children will be preparing to return to school, Els said in a statement.Els plans to return next week for the third event of the FedEx Cup, the BMW Championship in Lemont, Ill., and will play in the Tour Championship in Atlanta the following week.Els finished fourth Sunday in the first of the four FedEx Cup playoff events, the Barclays Classic in Harrison, N.Y.

Sacramento guard Kevin Martin agreed in principle to a contract extension with the Kings. Geoff Petrie, the Kings’ president of basketball operations, announced the deal, which is believed to be a five-year extension to begin in the 2008-9 season. Martin’s agent, Jason Levien, could not be reached for comment.Martin, who will begin his fourth N.B.A. season in the fall, was the Kings’ leading scorer last season with 20.2 points per game.

DePaul University in Chicago canceled the one remaining course taught by a professor who has accused some Jews of using the legacy of the Holocaust to stifle criticism of Israel. The professor, Norman Finkelstein, above, says he may respond by committing civil disobedience when classes resume Sept. 5. Mr. Finkelstein, 53, was denied tenure in June after six years on the DePaul faculty, but he was allowed to teach for the one year left on his contract. Mr. Finkelstein’s most recent book, “Beyond Chutzpah,” is largely an attack on “The Case for Israel,” by Alan Dershowitz, a Harvard law professor. Its publication led to a public feud, with Mr. Dershowitz threatening to sue Mr. Finkelstein’s publisher and urging DePaul to reject his tenure bid.

Mexico kept its game against the United States respectable into the second half before the United States pulled away for a 127-100 victory Monday night in the second round of the FIBA Americas tournament in Las Vegas.Carmelo Anthony scored 28 points, tying the American record in an Olympic qualifier. He had 16 in a sensational opening quarter, when the Americans shot 80 percent from the field.The United States played Puerto Rico late last night.Yesterday, Luis Scola Balvoa scored 23 points to lead Argentina to an 85-70 victory against Canada. Argentina led by 46-16 at halftime. Also, Hector Romero had 35 points and 11 rebounds for Venezuela in an 88-79 victory against Uruguay.The top two teams in the tournament earn berths in the Beijing Olympics and the third through fifth finishers advance to an Olympic qualifying tournament next July for a chance to earn a bid.
Prosecutors want an evaluation of the pit bulls taken from the kennel of Michael Vick, whose plea agreement said he must pay for the euthanasia of some or all of the dogs.
The sex scandal involving Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho is the latest challenge to the Republican Party.
Abdullah Gul’s victory breaks an 84-year grip on power by the secular establishment.
William S. Lerach, who has been embroiled in a seven-year federal investigation into possible kickbacks to plaintiffs for their testimony, is retiring from his firm.
A power struggle between rival Shiite groups erupted Tuesday during a religious festival in Karbala, as street battles were waged amid crowds of pilgrims.
Investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices and shrinking profits.
Businesses are having a hard time finding able-bodied workers, which could mean higher prices in the U.S.
President Bush said that an American withdrawal from Iraq would unsettle the entire Middle East, create a haven for Al Qaeda and embolden a belligerent Iran.
An agreement between Iran and the U.N. nuclear agency is inadequate and is likely to delay further international sanctions against the country, some say.
America must adopt measures that increase the supply of high-quality teachers while cutting down on the large number of teachers who bail out of the profession early.
For Yelena Isinbayeva, the greatest female pole-vaulter in history, the world record will have to wait.
The evidence of sloppiness and negligence offers guidance about how to continue deconstruction of the remaining floors of the former Deutsche Bank tower.
A large increase in the number of Americans who lack health insurance ought to send a strong message to Washington: action is needed to reverse this trend.
New data on incomes and poverty indicates that the spoils of the nation’s economic growth have flowed almost exclusively to the wealthy and the extremely wealthy.
Maria Sharapova’s destruction of her first-round opponent, Roberta Vinci, took a mere 50 minutes.
The resignation of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales does not mean an end to investigations into his actions during his tenure at the Justice Department.
Hotel employees confirmed that six Iranians were led away blindfolded and handcuffed by American soldiers who had arrested them at a hotel in central Baghdad.
Senator Larry E. Craig said that he regretted his guilty plea in connection with an airport restroom incident, and he accused an Idaho newspaper of hounding him.
Whole Foods Market said that it closed its acquisition of Wild Oats Markets, after months of delays as federal antitrust authorities sought to block the deal.
Though Joe Torre has not made it official, the Yankees are planning to drop Mike Mussina from the rotation, at least for his start on Saturday.
SADDLE RIVER, N.J., Aug. 28 — Soon after Michael Acciardi saw that the house next door to his was up for sale, he sidled over to its owner and asked, as diplomatically as he could, about any flaws.
Mike Lowell, who can become a free agent after the season, has been more reliable than any other player on the Red Sox.
A new era of tall, big-serving players may be on the horizon at the top level of men’s tennis.
A former Goldman Sachs associate accused of being the mastermind behind a complex insider-trading scheme pleaded guilty on Tuesday.
Secretary General Ban Ki-moon will press for an end to violence in Darfur and for speedy deployment there of a joint African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force.
Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco of Louisiana repeatedly parried with lawyers in a trial that has become a grim commemoration of Hurricane Katrina.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,723 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:.
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade plan to consolidate their trading floors and electronic-trading platforms and to shift more trading business to computer screens.
The Wall Street Journal will rechristen Pursuits, its Saturday leisure section, as Weekend Journal, the same name as the Friday section.

Federal marshals said that they were investigating reports that a man charged in five killings in Texas and suspected in one in Pennsylvania might have shot at other people during his flight to New York.
The subcontractor hired to demolish the Deutsche Bank skyscraper at ground zero was hired even though an agency was established to keep troubled contractors from getting work there.
Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies.
Senator Tim Johnson, speaking slowly and slurring some words after a life-threatening brain hemorrhage, announced to South Dakotans, “I am back.”
Michael Strahan told the Giants he would announce his retire-or-return decision on Wednesday or Thursday, the team said.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 — State investigators have been scrutinizing fees paid to the political consultant Hank Morris by investment firms seeking business with the New York State pension fund, including $12.3 million the Carlyle Group paid to a firm that employed Mr. Morris, according to companies that have been contacted as part of the inquiry.
Pro-democracy supporters expanded their protests against Myanmar’s military on Tuesday, marching through the streets in Yangon and the port city of Sittwe.
George Reyes will be one of only a few of the Internet search giant’s top executives to have left since its founding in 1998.
Martina Hingis and Lleyton Hewitt, who both breezed through the first round on Tuesday, are trying less to recapture their past than to keep pace with their future.
The officer, Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, was found guilty of only one lesser offense, that of disobeying an order to refrain from discussing the case.
Wendy’s International said that it had reached a deal to give the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz access to the company’s books as he considers making an acquisition offer.
For six months, from blogs to talk shows to cable networks to the right-wing press, the hysteria and hatred over a planned Arabic minischool never ceased. Regrettably, it worked.
Alejandro De Aza hit a sacrifice fly in the 11th inning to give the host Florida Marlins a 4-3 victory against the Atlanta Braves.
The police arrested six people at a police roadblock near a beach in Oaxaca, where the eggs are a delicacy believed to have aphrodisiac powers.
Some relatives of people who died on Sept. 11 said they feared the presence of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might inject politics into the event at ground zero.
Several European phone companies plan to announce significant expansions of Internet protocol television, or IPTV, this week.
A New Jersey doctor facing charges that he sexually abused 10 women in his care may have abused more patients.
Stocks plunged as investors grew more uneasy about the economy and about whether the Federal Reserve will take steps to prevent credit market problems from spreading.
From 2005 to 2006, the rich grew richer in the New York region and the poor, over all, remained poor, producing the widest income gap of any major metropolitan area.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican whose presidential campaign is in dire financial straits, is eligible to receive public financing for his struggling bid.
IndyMac Bancorp said it had hired more than 600 former employees of the American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation and might hire 250 more.
Average reading and math scores on the SAT test declined slightly this year, as the number of high school students taking the exam grew larger and more diverse than ever.
The Carlyle Group, the Washington private equity firm, agreed to lend its credit-investment affiliate in the British island of Guernsey $100 million.
Shares of the Internet service provider EarthLink climbed sharply Tuesday after it said it would cut 900 jobs — about half its work force — and close four offices.

Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the Navy officer and former astronaut who confronted a romantic rival at the Orlando, Fla., airport in February, will plead insanity at her trial on assault and kidnapping charges.
Troubles are mounting for the struggling Roosevelt school district in Nassau County.
Many states are planting native species, like switchgrass and asters, on roadsides, and reducing the mowing.

EPSTEIN--Edwin E., 84, of Manhasset, NY, on August 23, 2007, following an extended illness. He passed away peacefully surrounded by his family. He was a prominent consultant to the grocery trade for 25 years, representing such food manufacturers as The Coca-Cola Company and Quaker Oats, and leading supermarket chains. He served as an advisor to senior management teams, and as a mentor to countless young professionals throughout the industry. He co-founded the Buying Skills program at the University of Southern California, where he taught for many years as a guest lecturer. Previously, with his brother David, he founded the Double E grocery chain, which was ultimately acquired by Pueblo International. Epstein then served as president of this NYSE-listed company. He grew up in Brooklyn. He served as a medic in the 99th Infantry Division in Germany during World War II, and later graduated from New York University. He was honored numerous times for his philanthropy, and served on the Auxiliary Board of North Shore University Hospital. A die-hard Jets fan and season ticket holder since 1961, his greatest joy was his family. He is survived by Elaine, his wife of nearly 55 years, sister Thelma and brother David, children Alan and Nancy of Los Angeles, CA, (and their children Melissa, Adam and Alison), Susan and Dr. Alan Sosnay of Scarsdale, NY (and their children Daniel and Jonathan), Barry and Bonnie of Roslyn, NY (and their children Jacob, Benjamin and Sarah) and Stuart and Randi of New York City (and their children Jack, Martha, Joseph and Eliza). The family would like to acknowledge the loving support of his wonderful caregivers, who were of great help during the final years of his life.

GALLAHUE--John Jeremiah (Jack). Respected therapist and best-selling novelist John Jeremiah Gallahue, died August 27, 2007 at Beth Israel Hospital. Gallahue was a lifelong writer who grew up penning radio plays and scripts before he became a Jesuit in the New England diocese. During his time in the Jesuits he wrote for Catholic journals and afterwards for Look magazine. In 1960 he left the seminary and taught History of Civilization courses at Columbia University, the New School, and Fordham University, before beginning a private therapy practice. In 1973 his best-selling novel ''The Jesuit,'' was published, which was translated and distributed worldwide. He is survived by his wife, Susan Gallahue, and his three children, Sean, Fiona and Patrick. There will be a viewing on Wednesday, August 29th, from 2-5pm, and 7-9pm at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway. The funeral mass will be held at 10am on Thursday, August 30th, at Corpus Christi Catholic Church at 529 W. 121st Street.

SOLIMANO--Eileen Nolan. Eileen Solimano, 76, died Friday, August 24 at her sons home in Washington State following a long battle with cancer. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Eileen lived most of her life in New Jersey, first in West Orange and later in Chester. Following the death of her husband James in 1996, she moved to Naples, FL. She returned each year to Lake Wallkill in Vernon, NJ, where she spent summers with family and friends for 40 years. She is survived by her six sons James of Seattle, WA; Mark of Wayne, NJ; Matthew of Providence, RI; Daniel of High Bridge, NJ; Paul of Portland, OR and Michael of Burlington, VT, and nine grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral mass on Saturday, September 1st at 10am at St. Lawrence Church, 375 Main Street, Chester, NJ. Visitation will be held on Friday, August 31st at The Bailey Funeral Home, 8 Hilltop Road, Mendham, NJ from 24pm and 7-9pm (973-543-4720). In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made either to the ALS Hope Foundation, P.O. Box 40777, Philadelphia, PA 19107 or the Skagit Hospice Foundation, P.O. Box 1376, Mount Vernon, WA 98273.

SCHMIDT--Shirley. The family of Shirley Schmidt mourns the loss of their mother on August 27, after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Born in Brooklyn in 1929, she immigrated to Israel in 1954. 10 years later, she and her husband, Simon Schmidt, founded CBS Records/Israel. In 1977, Shirley Schmidt was named head of CBS/Israel, the first woman to lead a record company for CBS. An elegant woman, with remarkable grace and style, she was devoted to her family, her profession, and Judaism, a heritage of which she was fiercely proud. She is survived by her beloved children, Michal and Zeev Michael, a niece, nephews and countless friends. A memorial service will take place Wednesday morning, 9:30am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Burial will take place in Tel Aviv.

FERRIS--George, D.D.S., formerly of Queens, NY, died August 27, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne Ferris, father of Jessica D. Feinbloom, Roger A. Ferris and Charles J. Ferris. Grandfather of five. He practiced dentistry in Astoria, Queens for over 40 years. He frequently volunteered on dental missions throughout Latin America. Simply Divine, a kosher caterer in Manhattan, has introduced Divine to Go, a line of fresh hors d'oeuvres, soups, fish and vegetarian dishes, sides and desserts. Some are cold and ready to eat, but most should be reheated -- for a minute in a microwave oven, or longer on the stove or in a regular oven. There are more hits than misses, including tapas tidbits of mushroom tortilla omelet, Thai-style wild salmon salad, roasted tomato soup, pan-seared wild striped bass, breaded tilapia Milanese style, roasted potatoes, garlic spinach, apple-pear cobbler, apple tarte Tatin and biscotti. A somewhat rubbery Thai salmon cake and soggy vegetable samosas were disappointing, and a spinach lasagna was underseasoned.

TASSONE--Stephen and Grace, from injuries sustained in an auto accident. Beloved by daughter Margaret Wigert (and husband Christopher). Donations may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center or the Humane Society of North America. A devoted couple, united for 54 years in life and, finally, even in death.

A Grass-Fed Steer To the Editor:

Animal-shaped cookies from England come with a story. The owl and pussycat from the Edward Lear poem and two pairs of Aesop characters -- the tortoise and the hare, and the lion and the mouse -- have their tales printed on the colorful boxes of eight cookies. Two by Two Animal Biscuits are made by Artisan Biscuits in Derbyshire, England, with just flour, butter, sugar and simple flavoring agents like fruit juice or vanilla and do not taste like packaged cookies. They are $3.79 a box at Gourmet Garage stores and $4.95 at Blue Apron in Park Slope, Brooklyn. It's a simple concept to shove a tubelike gadget into an orange and squeeze the juice out through it. Now there is a particularly efficient plastic version, also made in England and designed for children. Called the Juiceator, it offers a lunchbox alternative to heavily sweetened juice box drinks. It's recommended for children 4 and up. (Some younger ones might need help from an adult inserting it into the fruit, but sucking out the juice through the straw at the end will be no challenge.) Hikers, too, might welcome it in their backpacks, with a few oranges that become biodegradable discards. Four Juiceators are $19.95, plus $6.95 shipping, from juiceatorusa.com.
