The calls for Senator Larry Craig, Republican of Idaho and subject of a scandal involving a "lewd-conduct" arrest in a public men's restroom, to resign are mounting. In fact, the chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, Senator John Ensign of Nevada, has now been quoted as suggesting that Mr. Craig's decision to plead guilty to a less serious charge of disorderly conduct from the situation at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport in June would be enough for Mr. Ensign to consider doing so.
Up until now, the country's major labor unions have been dragging their feet on picking a candidate to support in the 2008 presidential primaries, but that's beginning to change.
Aired Wednesday night
If Seung-Hui Cho's heart of darkness would ever be pried open, Diane Strickland would seem a likely candidate.

Now he tells us! Seven years after his first meeting with Alberto Gonzales, Robert Novak relays the news that "several Republican senators" believed in 2001 "that Gonzales was not qualified for a senior government position." Novak writes in his Washington Post column:

An article by Pete Thamel in The New York Times today examines the lack of blockbuster non-conference games in college football this season. Saturday's matchup between No. 15 Tennessee and No. 12 California in Berkeley is a notable exception.

Proposed legislation in Congress to raise taxes on private equity has prompted yet another company to hire a lobbyist to look out for its interests on Capitol Hill. But it's not a buyout firm -- and for now it appears to be simply hedging its bets.
The hot and cold United States team at the FIFA U-17 World Cup went ice cold yesterday in Cheonan, South Korea, losing to Germany, 2-1, in the second round.
Second-seeded Rafael Nadal practiced for slightly over an hour.

August has been a big month for dire market rumors, and here is the latest one: Blogs are abuzz about a spike in unusual options trades that appear, at least on the surface, to indicate that someone is betting on a huge market plunge next month.

This afternoon, on the final day of this week's forum, we have answers to your questions from Lu Zhi, a well-known scientist and environmentalist in China who heads the national office of Conservation International. Ms. Lu is a professor of conservation biology at Peking University in Beijing who is one of China's most prominent experts on biodiversity.
A. O. Scott reviews "Balls of Fury," starring Christopher Walken.

Ever since Michael Vick professed to have found religion this week, alert commentators are evincing a wise, knowing air in pointing out something most whelps learn the minute they start reading - that "dog" is "God" spelled backwards:

Would-be inventors, take note: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, is behind a fund that has raised $355 million in what seems to be an effort to back new technologies in their infancy. Mr. Myhrvold knows a thing or two about getting in early: He was part of Microsoft's original brain trust and once led its research arm.

Last year, a young quarterback named Tony Romo outplayed the Cowboys' incumbent starter, Drew Bledsoe, in the preseason. Although Bledsoe retained his position to start the season, memories of Romo's strong play lingered, and by Week 8 he was starting.
While other more glamorous blond players live on the show courts, sixth-seeded Anna Chakvetadze of Russia was toiling on Court 13 against Nicole Pratt, the 68th-ranked Australian.
By now, I'm sure you've seen about a dozen replays, from all angles, of that nutty game-ending play last night.
Capt. Lisa Nowak's complaints about an ankle monitor, a condition of her release from jail for confronting a fellow officer and romantic rival for another astronaut, were legion.

Commenting for the first time publicly about a disgraced donor, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sent her best wishes to Norman Hsu, the wealthy Democratic fundraiser who turned out to be a fugitive. Just yesterday, her presidential campaign was forced to give away to charity $23,000 of his tainted donations.

Univisión, the Spanish-language television network, is postponing its G.O.P. debate. Only Senator John McCain (coincidentally, the only Republican candidate who favored the comprehensive immigration legislation that failed this year) was able to commit to the original date, Sept. 16.
With major college football kicking off tonight, the stock watch for the 2008 N.F.L. Draft also begins.
Promotional spot for a new Fox sitcom, "Back to You."
Promotional spot for a new Fox sitcom, "Back to You."

Usually, the political bio-video falls into a few hoary subsets. There's the up-from-humble-beginnings one, a tried-and-true route. The showed-courage-with-a-tough-political-stance genre. The devoted-family-man-you-can-trust-with-your-vote one.

Do you have suggestions for someone who wants to do a little adventuring (by backpack) in Jordan this fall? I'll be joining my parents for a tour of Madaba and Petra and figured I'd do a few days on my own, perhaps a day or two in Amman and a visit to the Dead Sea.
By now, everybody, I hope, knows what LOL stands for. Most people probably recognize IMHO, BRB, and AFK. (If you don't know these, you can always Google* them.)

This year's chase for the eight playoff spots in baseball is the tightest in recent memory. The wild-card system, first used in 1995, has made September baseball exciting for more cities, but does the current system provide adequate compensation for the team that finishes with the best record in each league?

Even though Fred Thompson, the actor and former senator, has yet to declare himself a candidate, he has already hired and fired two communications directors and now is bringing on a third. This time his choice is a veteran campaign media manager who has previously worked for California Gov. Arnold Schwarznegger and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush.

Richard Gasquet, the 13th-seeded Frenchman, withdrew from his match against the American Donald Young today because of an illness. Young, the junior champion who is having his breakout summer on the Tour, advances to the third round against Feliciano Lopez, the 60th-ranked Spaniard, who needed a fifth-set tiebreaker to defeat Igor Andreev.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Last week we promised some first impressions of the 2008 Honda Accord. That task falls to me, since I just wrapped up four days with a jet-black V-6 sedan. Stop me before I gush.
David Pogue offers an updated list of online acronyms.
A federal judge formally approved a request by prosecutors to dismiss all remaining charges against Frank P. Quattrone, the former Credit Suisse banker.
A free ferry trip takes passengers from the canyons of Lower Manhattan to the splendid sanctuary of Governors Island.
In its third consecutive daily editorial about Senator Larry Craig, the Idaho Statesman editorial page asks Craig to resign.

It's game day! Warning: watching this video from our friends over at Sunday Morning Quarterback may make you want to get up and tackle the person in the cubicle next to you. We don't condone that, no matter how satisfying it might be.

After new details emerged about the criminal record of one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's top donors -- who has also given generously to many other Democrats over the years --- her campaign announced that it would give the $23,000 contribution from New York businessman Norman Hsu to charity. The question remains whether other donations that he bundled will be returned.

Add another assessment of the Iraq surge to the pile. A draft of a progress report requested by Congress from the Government Accountability Office is "strikingly negative" and questions a more optimistic report by the administration in July, according to The Washington Post, which obtained a copy.
David Pogue reviews the MovieBeam, a box that connects directly to your TV set and holds 100 movies on its hard drive.

H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said on Thursday it is renegotiating the sale of its money-losing Option One Mortgage subprime lending unit to Cerberus Capital Management, casting doubt on it ability to complete the transaction.
It may be the late-summer doldrums, but the debate over taxes and private equity is hardly on vacation. It has just gone to the Hamptons -- like much of the rest of Wall Street.

The bankrupt home loan provider American Home Mortgage Investment, said on Wednesday a federal bankruptcy judge has authorized the auction by two affiliates of 5,700 mortgage loans with an unpaid principal balance of about $1.62 billion.

In an attempt to capitalize on a credit crunch that has depressed prices for leveraged loans in the secondary markets, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers are actively raising funds to buy leveraged loans that trade at discounts in the secondary market, The Deal.com reports.

Global Hyatt, the hotel company controlled by the Pritzker family of Chicago, said Wednesday that it would sell a minority stake to a group of investors, including Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, for $1 billion.

A top Goldman Sachs dealmaker in London who has worked on some of the investment bank's most high-profile telecoms and media deals is leaving the the firm, The Telegraph reported. Alain Carrier, a Canadian, is leaving for a job in the Canadian government, according to the newspaper.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, four of the five largest securities firms, will earn less than expected through next year after a rout in subprime mortgages, according to a Lehman Brothers analyst.

Susan L. Decker, Yahoo's new president, is putting her stamp on the company in a reorganization of its management ranks that creates a new division responsible for generating the bulk of the company's revenue.
Is the Burberry Group an acquisition target? A Merill Lynch analyst thinks so and has identified luxury goods makers PPR and Coach as possible buyers.

French supermarket giant Carrefour on Thursday responded to its fiercest critics -- including some of its own shareholders -- by announcing a plan to spin off its European real estate into a separately listed company.
The collapse of the subprime mortgage market has claimed the scalp of a senior Royal Bank of Scotland executive in the United States and six of his colleagues.

A medical device maker, EndoGastric Solutions, has raised $30 million in venture capital, money that the company plans to use for sales and for marketing its StomaphyX device. The product was approved for sale in the United States in March.

After a month of disappointing returns and the high-profile collapse of several hedge funds, a new report has come out just in time to further raise the ire of those who feel that the rich fees collected by fund managers are undeserved.
Tenet Healthcare said Wednesday it has sufficient financial resources to stage a turnaround, rebutting an analyst's report that sent its shares to a record low on Tuesday.
Carlyle Capital, a unit of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Wednesday it hopes the worst of the credit crunch has passed, allowing it to resume paying a dividend.
Another day, another electric car company.
Citigroup's venture capital arm led a $400 million deal for a controlling stake in Waddington North America, a maker of disposable cups, dinnerware and cutlery, according to Reuters.

Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said on Wednesday it would acquire Macau's third largest lender, Seng Heng Bank. ICBC, China's largest bank, will pay 4.55 billion Hong Kong dollars ($590 million) for a 79.93 percent stake in the Macau bank, which is majority-owned by Stanley Ho.
Microsoft announced on Wednesday plans to acquire Parlano, a developer of group chat applications for large corporate customers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Was it just sore knees and the unforgiving hard court surface that caused Rafael Nadal to struggle in his four-set victory over Alun Jones? Or could he have been brooding about something inside the tender recesses of his mind, buried deep within his muscular armor?
Fred Grede, a former Chicago Board of Trade executive, was appointed trustee in the Sentinel Management Group bankruptcy Wednesday.
Alltel shareholders overwhelmingly approved a $24.7 billion buyout Wednesday that put the wireless company in the hands of two private equity firms.
President Nicolas Sarkozy will decide by the end of September whether to back the merger of the utility Suez with the state-run Gaz de France, a Cabinet spokesman said Wednesday.

Eric Nicoli stepped down as chief executive of the EMI Group Wednesdayahead of private investors' purchase of the music corporation, which had tried unsuccessfully throughout his eight-year tenure to merge with rivals.

The chief operating officer at Delta Air Lines, James M. Whitehurst, resigned Wednesday, a week after being passed over for promotion to the top post. Delta, which chose Richard Anderson, the former chief executive of Northwest Airlines as its chief on Aug. 21, said Mr. Whitehurst's departure was effective immediately.

My column today is about "pay-as-you-throw" trash collection, to me a brilliant and underutilized idea. The basic concept is that we should pay for trash removal the way we pay for electricity use: the more you use, the more you pay. Communities use various measures to determine how much your household is throwing away, then charge you accordingly.

The creative team for Mitt Romney is adding to the picture they are assembling for Iowa and New Hampshire voters with a new ad that features him quite literally running hard as a narrator declares "at every step, he's met extraordinary challenges."

Prosecutors in Düsseldorf are investigating seven current and former executives of WestLB, a bank owned by the German government, a spokesman told The Associated Press. The executives, six of them not identified, are suspected of violating a German law in connection with large losses in speculative transactions this year, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office, Arno Neukirchen, told the news service.
BNP Paribas, the French bank, said it reopened two investment funds it had frozen amid problems in the subprime mortgage sector in the United States.
The Indian state of Kerala, celebrated for its alternative model of development, is dependent on remittances.
The Following is a transcript of a June 11 police interview with Sen. Larry Craig of Idaho., as transcribed by Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport Police Department.
“Vanaja” is a coming-of-age tale that is engrossing, if slightly overlong, and absolutely timeless.
Monty Lapica’s film about the self-destructive behavior of a 17-year-old suffers from severe dramatic droop.
“10 Questions for the Dalai Lama” is a tedious title for an anything-but-tedious film that expertly merges the mystical and the mundane.
James Wan’s film is a middle-class white man’s payback fantasy, leavened with phony references to class difference.
This film is like “Ocean’s Eleven” if directed by Robin Hood and financed by Telemundo.
Images from "The Abstract Impulse: Fifty Years of Abstraction at the National Academy."
Images from "Infinite Island" at the Brooklyn Museum.
Martina Hingis, Andy Roddick, Tommy Haas and Maria Sharapova advanced on the fourth day of play at Flushing Meadows.

Let's take a little break from the Strahan watch to return to that other player who has been a topic of conversation. It's been awhile since we've given you a space here to talk about Michael Vick. And, well, a lot has happened since then.
In today's style section Gina Kolata writes about how some older women runners are faster than younger runners in road races.

The Yankees were so giddy after smacking around Josh Beckett for 13 hits in their 4-3 win on Wednesday, they didn't make much sense in their clubhouse interviews. Or, to put it more accurately, they exaggerated a lot in praising each other.
How do we plug our receiver into the PC so we can listen to these Internet stations on good speakers?
Viewers for whom action matters need to pay as much attention to how fast images are processed as to the size of the screen.
Samsung’s new i85 model has a personal media player for enjoying digital music and video between shots.
Is there a way to synchronize my BlackBerry Pearl phone with my computer so that I can enter the information onto the computer instead of typing it in on the BlackBerry?
A key remapping program can make life easier by letting you reassign certain key functions.
Motorola’s new Q Music 9M smartphone works with the V Cast music download service and has easy-to-use messaging features.
Fujifilm includes several youth-oriented features in its new Z10fd camera.
The fifth generation of the Roomba robotic broom still doesn’t have the personality of Rosie, the Jetsons’ mechanical maid, but it’s getting closer.
Forward-thinking graffiti artists may wish to try their designs on Hewlett-Packard’s $249 A826 Home Photo Center.
One’s first glimpse of Rapture from a descending bathysphere is dazzling, as whales and squid swim past underwater skyscrapers decorated with old-fashioned fluorescent signs.
The Flash Padlock U.S.B. drive from Corsair puts a hardware lock on the pocket data vault by requiring the user to punch in a code to see the stored files when the drive is connected to a computer.
Most people think that buying a fake luxury bag is harmless. But the counterfeiting rackets are run by crime syndicates that also deal in narcotics and weapons.
An earlier version of this article paraphrased incorrectly from a comment Senator Obama made to the convention about protests at military funerals.
San Francisco’s mayor, Gavin Newsom, remains committed to a plan to roll out a citywide Wi-Fi network despite EarthLink’s decision to bow out an agreement to build the system.
Iran is expanding its nuclear program in defiance of United Nations’ resolutions, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Thursday.
The Justice Department’s inspector general said today that he is investigating whether Alberto R. Gonzales misled Congress.
A day after a scathing state report criticized Virginia Tech’s actions before and after the shooting massacre, Charles W. Steger defended his administration’s actions.
Benazir Bhutto said Pakistan’s president agreed to resign as army chief as part of a deal that would allow him to serve another term as president if he is re-elected.
The freeing of the seven remaining hostages ended a six-week ordeal for the South Korean missionaries.
The small street protests over the last two weeks are the most sustained challenge to the junta in a decade.
A disgruntled former employee shot three men in succession in the Co-op City housing complex today.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about animal rights groups promoting vegetarianism as a way to curb greenhouse gases, misstated the annual budget of Vegan Outreach, a nonprofit group that has campaigned on the issue. It is $500,000, not $5 million.
David Beckham left in the 30th minute of last night’s SuperLiga final between the Los Angeles Galaxy and Pachuca after straining his right knee when he fell.
Manny Ramírez had a strained left oblique muscle, so he did not play for the Boston Red Sox on Wednesday, and he will probably miss several games.

Congressional auditors have determined that the Iraqi government has failed to meet the vast majority of political and military goals laid out by lawmakers to assess President Bush’s Iraq war strategy.
Colorado’s Aurora Organic Dairy agreed Wednesday to stop applying the organic label to some of its milk and to make major changes in its operations after its organic certification was threatened.
Roger Clemens was facing the Red Sox for the first time since they rocked him in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series in ’03.
Up next for the Mets, losers of four in a row, in this tour through the N.L. East contenders is Atlanta, which would like nothing more than to peck away, too.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about animal rights groups promoting vegetarianism as a way to curb greenhouse gases, misstated the annual budget of Vegan Outreach, a nonprofit group that has campaigned on the issue. It is $500,000, not $5 million.

An article in Business Day on Aug. 10 about international fallout from troubles in the United States’ subprime mortgage market misidentified the bank that bailed out IKB Deutsche Industriebank, which held subprime investments. It was the government-owned KfW development bank, which is IKB’s largest shareholder — not the Bundesbank, which is the central German bank.

An obituary on Aug. 16 about the composer and cabaret entertainer John Wallowitch misidentified the label on which one of his albums, “Wallowitch and Ross,” appeared. It was Miranda Music — not Original Cast Records, which was one of the distributors.

The Saturday Interview column in Business Day last week, about the market for “green” fashions, carried incorrect information in a quotation from George Feldenkreis, chairman of Perry Ellis International, about the amount of pesticide required to produce one T-shirt. About 0.038 ounces of pesticide are required, not three pounds.

A picture caption in some copies yesterday with a sports article about the Yankees’ 5-3 victory over the Red Sox referred incorrectly to Derek Jeter’s fifth-inning home run. It was a solo home run, not a two-run homer.

The East Hampton Journal on Aug. 17 about Hugh King, the Long Island community’s official town crier, misidentified the store in nearby Bridgehampton where Mr. King said local residents, unable to afford the high prices in East Hampton, did their shopping. It is a Kmart, not a Wal-Mart.

The Executive Pursuits column in Business Day on Saturday, about the life of a cut man, who attends to fighters’ injuries, misstated the name of a mixed martial arts team that recently participated in the semifinals of the International Fight League championship. The team is the Tokyo Sabres, not the Tokyo Sharks.
An article on Friday about the escape of a homicide suspect from a police station in Queens misstated the date that the police say the slaying occurred. It was July 28, not last Thursday.

An obituary on Aug. 12 about Moe Fishman, a veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, Americans who fought in the Spanish Civil War, referred incorrectly to his high school education. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan; he did not drop out. (He later dropped out of City College, primarily for financial reasons.).
An article on Tuesday about the toll taken on Greece by the recent fires gave an incorrect location for the town of Zaharo. As the accompanying map showed, it is on the Ionian Sea, not the Aegean.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about political contributions by Silicon Valley executives omitted the name of one presidential candidate who recently visited Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., and erroneously included another candidate. John Edwards spoke there; Barack Obama did not. The article also referred imprecisely to contributions from Google employees to Ron Paul, another candidate. Mr. Paul received $3,550 in employee contributions before he visited on July 13, not after.
BNP Paribas, the French bank, said it reopened two investment funds it had frozen amid problems in the subprime mortgage sector in the United States.
Cnooc, a Chinese offshore oil producer, said first-half profit declined 11 percent, less than analysts had expected, as the company reined in operating costs.
Bombardier, the commercial aircraft maker, posted a quarterly loss after writing off its investment in the Metronet Rail subway unit in Britain.
Prosecutors in Düsseldorf are investigating seven current and former executives of WestLB, a bank owned by the German government, a spokesman said.
Twelve ProTeams agreed to tougher doping measures in an effort to clean up cycling’s battered image.
Yi Jianlian, the sixth overall pick in the N.B.A. draft in June, signed a standard rookie scale contract with the Bucks in Hong Kong.

Cuba will not send a boxing team to the world championships in Chicago in October, heeding Fidel Castro’s fears about future defections after two fighters abandoned their teammates during the Pan American Games last month in Brazil.
Alejandro Valverde of Spain was barred from next month’s road world championships after cycling’s world governing body concluded he might have violated doping rules.
Three years after its stunning loss in the Olympics, the United States smothered Puerto Rico in a 117-78 victory in the FIBA Americas tournament.
Inspectors at Tarbes-Lourdes-Pyrénées Airport barred passengers on a new Vatican-backed chartered flight to the shrine at Lourdes from returning to Rome with carry-on holy water.
A 10-year-old Palestinian girl and two boys, 10 and 12, were killed by Israeli fire in northern Gaza.
Canada said it would expel a Sudanese diplomat in response to Sudan’s decision last week to expel Canada’s chargé d’affaires, Nuala Lawlor.
The Chinese defense minister arrived in Japan in the first such visit in nearly 10 years, hoping to ease tensions after strained ties halted top-level military exchanges.
More than 100 people have died in a remote part of southeastern Congo in what health officials fear is an outbreak of hemorrhagic fever.
The police used tear gas, water cannons and clubs against demonstrators staging nationwide protests over government social and economic policies.
The Italian Coast Guard said it had rescued 59 African immigrants who had been adrift off the Libyan coast.
A 16-story building collapsed while under construction in Baku, Azerbaijan, killing eight people.
President Bush’s signature education law, No Child Left Behind, may be changed to elevate other criteria and exclude results for some non-native speakers of English.

The Weaver Popcorn Company has switched butter flavorings, replacing a chemical linked to a lung ailment in popcorn plant workers. Weaver, based in Indianapolis, began shipping microwave popcorn a few weeks ago that contain no diacetyl, a chemical under scrutiny because of cases of bronchiolitis obliterans, a life-threatening disease often called popcorn lung. Mike Weaver, the company president, said his workers had experienced no such cases. Mr. Weaver said his company sold about 600 million bags of microwave popcorn a year.

Rescuers recovered the body of a miner killed in a cave-in at an underground gold mine, the authorities said. The worker, whose name was not released, had been missing since Tuesday, when the ground gave way at the Getchell Mine east of Winnemucca. He was operating a bolter, a large piece of equipment used to drill bolts into the hard rock, when the accident occurred. The Getchell Mine is owned jointly by the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto and the Newmont Mining Corporation of Denver.

The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Central Labor Council of Alameda County in California, the American Civil Liberties Union and other legal groups filed a lawsuit challenging new rules from the Department of Homeland Security that would force employers to fire illegal immigrant workers. The rules, announced Aug. 10, give employers 90 days to dismiss workers whose Social Security numbers do not match the records of the Social Security Administration. The suit charges that because there are inaccuracies in the agency’s records, the rules would threaten jobs of American citizens and legal immigrants. It seeks to stop the agency from sending out a round of letters to employers starting next Tuesday that would include a notice about the new rules.
The elections chief for Los Angeles County said she would retire at the end of the year.
Leona Helmsley stands in a long line of those who sought to govern from the grave.
The boy is accused of repeatedly beating a toddler in the head at a Woodbridge, N.J., day care center operated at a private home.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it would give away thousands of dollars that it received from a Democratic donor who is considered a fugitive in California.
A panel said officials could have saved lives last April by notifying students and faculty members earlier about killings on campus.
Prosecutors have had trouble obtaining convictions of the marines charged with killing civilians in Haditha, Iraq.

Four years after Frank Quattrone was accused of obstructing justice in an investigation in to possible I.P.O. kickbacks, a judge on Friday approved a request to drop all remaining charges against him.
Sandstorms in northwest China are reducing sections of the Great Wall to mounds of dirt and may cause them to disappear in about 20 years, state media said.
The United States and its allies need to be stepping up their efforts to resolve the serious dangers posed by Iran through comprehensive negotiations.
The need to be honest about Abu Ghraib and correct the abuses at military and C.I.A. prisons is not only about upholding the law and American values.
Except for Senator Tom Coburn, practically everyone in Congress wants to deal with the emerging crisis of depressed veterans tempted to take their own lives.
Serial numbers on pistols and other weapons in Turkey match those originally given to Iraqi security forces.
Current and former administration officials say the president’s hand is stronger now than it was in early July, when a string of Republican defections had many worried.
Ben S. Bernanke said the Federal Reserve was “prepared to act as needed” to prevent market woes from spreading, while the Dow closed up nearly 250 points as investors went bargain-hunting.
Jered Weaver won for the fourth time in five decisions and the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Mariners to complete open a five-game lead in the American League West.
Manny Ramírez was not in the starting lineup for the Boston Red Sox on Wednesday night because of a strained left oblique muscle.
Rafael Nadal, who has tendinitis and inflammation in his left knee, quietly gritted out a first-round victory, 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, that cast a shadow on his remaining Open path.
Serena Williams and Ahsha Rolle won second-round matches last night at the United States Open, separated by a few hundred yards that might as well have been a million miles.

The Department of Justice is investigating complaints of police brutality in Yonkers, Mayor Philip A. Amicone, left, said yesterday. He released a letter from the department’s civil rights division saying it had received claims of excessive force and discriminatory policing. Mr. Amicone said Yonkers would support the investigation, but he denied any systemic brutality.

A robber was sentenced to more than nine years in prison after admitting in a plea agreement that he robbed 28 banks throughout the Northeast in 2004. The defendant, Michael Gola, 33, of New Britain, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court after pleading guilty to 17 counts of bank robbery. Prosecutors said that he admitted robbing banks in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Rhode Island. They said he took nearly $55,000 in the robberies.

The state comptroller released an audit yesterday that questioned the Mamaroneck school district’s award of a computer service contract to an employee who did the work from Greece while he was on a leave of absence. Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli also criticized some of the oversight procedures used by the district for such contracts. In a statement, school officials said they had already corrected some issues raised by the report. The officials also said the employee had properly performed the computer contract.

Investigators for the Queens district attorney’s office, with the help of specially trained dogs, seized 5,200 of what they called counterfeit DVD’s hidden in stores. The dogs, Labrador retrievers named Lucky and Flo, are owned by the Motion Picture Association of America and were in Jamaica to help the investigators, Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, said yesterday. Mr. Brown said the dogs were trained to smell chemicals used in making the discs. Compiled by John Sullivan.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into a spate of bomb threats phoned in to businesses that resulted in employees’ wiring thousands of dollars overseas.

A Federal District Court judge refused, for procedural reasons, to consider an affidavit from a deputy police commissioner about the release of intelligence files related to the arrest of demonstrators at the 2004 Republican National Convention. In the affidavit, the deputy commissioner, David Cohen, objected to limits on information that could be blacked out from the files approved earlier by Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV. The judge, Kenneth M. Karas, said yesterday that he would not consider the affidavit under court rules. He said it could be submitted to Judge Francis, but added that “the city may have to explain why it did not offer such a declaration before appealing Judge Francis’s order.”.

A man accused of breaking into coffins at a cemetery has pleaded guilty to interference with a cemetery or burial ground, prosecutors said. The man, Joseph J. Vecchiarelli, 26, entered the plea on Tuesday, The Republican-American reported. John A. Connelly, a state’s attorney, said Mr. Vecchiarelli took a ring from one grave and gold teeth from others. A ring sold to a pawnshop was recovered and two sets of gold dentures were recovered from an apartment where Mr. Vecchiarelli was staying, The Republican-American reported.

A prisoner who was being treated at a hospital escaped by crashing through a plate-glass window early yesterday morning, the police said. The suspect, Gregory Pollock, 46, was arrested for possession of a controlled substance and resisting arrest. The police said that Mr. Pollock was being treated at Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill at 1:40 a.m. for reasons the police did not specify when he assaulted an officer and ran off, crashing through the window. He was captured about two hours later, five miles away, in Brownsville. The officer guarding Mr. Pollock will not face any disciplinary action, said Officer Martin Speechley, a Police Department spokesman. He was the third prisoner to escape in the last week. Maxie Dacosta Jr., 27, a murder suspect, leaped from a third-floor window of the 103rd Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens, last Thursday. Ezekiel Edwards, 17, facing attempted robbery charges, escaped early on Friday after he slipped out of his handcuffs and squeezed through a window at the 77th Precinct station house in Crown Heights. Both are still at large. Mr. Pollock faces two new charges: assault and escape.

A Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting another man near Prospect Park last week, the police said. The police said that the suspect, Tony Canales, 26, shot Antonio Bruce, 25, of Stanley Avenue about 11:20 p.m. on Aug. 22. Mr. Bruce was shot once in the abdomen on Parkside Avenue, the police said. Mr. Canales was charged with murder.
Venus Williams acquired Harold, the tiniest of her three dogs, this summer, shortly after she won her sixth Grand Slam title and her fourth on the grass of Wimbledon.
A believer of Norse mythology might have advised Yankees fans to not make too much out of their victory against the Red Sox on Tuesday night.
New Orleans hardly needs an anniversary to help it recall a disaster that upended the life of almost every resident.
Kraft Foods said Wednesday that Timothy R. McLevish, currently C.F.O. of Ingersoll-Rand, would take the same position at Kraft in October.
Dustin Pedroia, who has established himself as a strong contender for the American League’s rookie of the year award, lives about 20 yards from Fenway Park.

Every college athlete needs to make adjustments after arriving from high school. At least West Virginia’s Noel Devine gets to learn from one of the best. Devine, the small running back known for his spectacular plays that became must-view fare online, starts his college football career on Saturday playing behind Steve Slaton, who, after rushing for more than 1,700 yards last year is considered a top contender for the Heisman Trophy. “He’s like a big brother to me,” Devine says of Slaton, who the coaches asked to mentor Devine on and off of the field. Devine is also competing for the slot of second-string running back with Jock Sanders, another true freshman. It’s a challenge, he says, that “makes you know that you can’t slack on the job.”.

To see nature with a dose of adrenaline, consider a zip-line canopy tour, an increasingly popular adventure activity held at tree-top heights. From Africa to Alaska, thrill-seekers harness themselves to cables and slide from one tree stand to another, often for less than 20 seconds between stops, braking with a gloved hand. An entire canopy tour, sometimes coupled with hiking or other activities, can last up to four hours. Now with global appeal, canopy tours got their commercial foothold in Costa Rica, where it’s estimated that 25 percent of visitors see the rainforest hanging from zip lines. More than 1 million people have participated in the Original Canopy Tour, a Costa Rica-based outfitter that also has operations in Belize, Nicaragua, and Mexico, among other places. Injuries are rare, and prices are usually less than $100 even in the most exotic locales, so set aside your fear of heights and view forests in a whole new way.

The old Charles Street Jail in Boston will be reborn next week as the luxurious Liberty Hotel. And while the 100-foot ceiling and arched windows at the entrance of the building, above right, may be impressive, there's no chance of anyone forgetting its roots, or what Richard L. Friedman, right, the Boston developer responsible for reinventing the jail, likes to call its ''jailiness.'' There will be iron bars on the first two floors of the building, including the ballroom. The prison guards' catwalks, which once flanked the cell blocks, now overlook the lobby. ''It will be a great place for people-watching,'' Mr. Friedman said. (But frankly, wasn't it always?)

WHEN most people dream of showers, they imagine relaxing steam and a stretch of undisturbed time. Campers need not have such reveries. The best they can expect from a portable outdoor shower is a rush to lather and rinse before the water runs out. And a paradox is at play: the better the pressure, the more frantic the wash-up. The best-case scenario for most backcountry showers is having a shower from a bag warmed by the sun for an hour or two. For backpackers or rafters on the move or faced with clouds, plan B is campfire-heated water or bracing for from-the-river cold. In any event, showers are part of a trend: the toting of ''luxury'' items into the woods. ''Companies are producing a lot more products that incorporate more of the creature comforts of home,'' said Hud Knight, a merchandise manager at Backcountry.com.

After 14 years of selling fabric downtown at cut-rate prices, Mimi Sason, who ran Joe's Fabric Warehouse on Orchard Street with her uncle, has moved uptown. (Joe remains on the Lower East Side.) The new store is filled with textiles of all kinds, including cotton, silk, linen, wool, mohair and cut velvet. Ms. Sason, who sells decorator fabrics at designer discounts or better, says her prices are as low as the ones on Orchard Street; they start at $20 a yard and go as high as $95. The store also offers an upholstery service. Custom Design by Mimi, 116 East 57th Street (Park Avenue), (212) 355-0533. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Doris Rubin, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. Calinoff, Secretary RUBIN--Doris Konheim, at the age of 95 passed away peacefully at her home on August 27th surrounded by her family. She lived a full and rich life and felt blessed to have experienced this wonderful adventure, which was her life, and to have enjoyed her personal relationships with numerous friends and an extensive family. Doris, the Quintessential New Yorker, took full advantage of the best that our city has to offer. She was a patron of the Arts, supporting many of New Yorks Cultural Centers. In 1989, with her beloved husband of 57 years, Harry Rubin, they founded the Harry and Doris Rubin Lecture Series, an educational endeavor within the American Art Department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Series will continue to be supported by the Rubin Foundation. Doris was one of the original founders of The Manhattan Guild, an organization that was over many decades supported the activities of then young Tel Hashomer Hospital in Israel, now known as the Chiam Sheba Medical Center. She was a loving mother to, Richard, Robert and the late Stephen; a cherished motherin-law to Gail, Polly and Lynne; an adored grandmother to Jeffrey, Michael, David, Joseph and Katherine; and an energetic and affectionate great-grandmother to Sydney, Laura, Rachael, Sasha, Eric and Jalen. Merrill, Jody and Donna Lewen and their families were also an important part of Doris' extended family. She relished being a devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. Friends are invited to meet the family at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street on Thursday evening August 30th from 7 to 9pm. Services to be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street on Friday, August 31st at 10am. In lieu of flowers, if you wish, a donation may be sent to the charity of your choice. Doris had a zest for lifeand a style that was uniquely her own. RUBIN--Doris. Much love to our wonderful aunt Doris. We will cherish your devotion to all of us and remember you forever. Your nieces and nephews Alice and Michael Tannenbaum, Patricia Heffron, Nancy and Victor Greene, Anne and Robert Polansky, and your many great-nieces and nephews and your greatgreat-nieces and nephews.

The Web Site 1stdibs.com, favored by designers for its listings of antique and vintage furnishings for sale, has introduced a new feature modeled on an interiors magazine. Users can flip through pages to read articles on designers and tastemakers, interviews with prominent furniture dealers and profiles of well-known 20th-century designers. ''It's a hybrid of a design marketplace and stories about the people making it happen,'' said Michael Bruno, president of 1stdibs. Stories online today include a profile of Will Wick, a San Francisco interior designer (and 1stdibs shopper), written by Marian McEvoy, the former Elle Décor editor, above, and an article on the mid-century German-born designer Tommi Parzinger, by Louise Devenish, an appraiser and decorative arts consultant. Information is at 1stdibs.com. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

The Book Stool, created by the Paris-based industrial designer Arik Levy for a new French company called Eno, can be any size you like. What you buy is a set of cotton and nylon straps; what you fill them with -- a stack of old magazines, catalogs or books -- is entirely up to you. Mr. Levy's solution for turning unruly piles of reading material into extra seating is part recycling tool, part home organizer, part storage and part furniture. The Book Stool, which costs $39, is available at the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (866) 755-9079 or conranusa.com.

Thomas Schoos, the West Hollywood designer known for fashionable interiors like that of the new LAX nightclub opening tomorrow at the Luxor hotel in Las Vegas, looked beyond the world of night life for his Nature Line collection of rugs. Produced by Arzu, a Chicago-based nonprofit organization that makes and sells rugs woven by women in Afghanistan, Mr. Schoos's earth-toned rugs are made of vegetable-dyed wool and inspired mostly by his travels. Winter, above, one of four designs in his collection, was based on a forest scene in Kyoto. It's a far cry from Sin City. ''But you need to appreciate the yin and the yang to appreciate life,'' Mr. Schoos said. Available this fall in various sizes, for $2,500 to $11,000. Orders are accepted at (312) 321-8663, arzurugs.org. ARIC CHEN

KAGAN--Joan. A truly beautiful, fascinating and dynamic lady passed on August 28, 2007. Amongst other things, her career encompassed boxing manager and motion picture food stylist. She founded the Westchester Chapter of Juvenile Diabetes. A wonderful wife and mother, Joan is survived by her husband, Michael, and children, Deborah, Jack and Eric.

WILLIS--Arthur Livingston, Jr., died peacefully in his sleep on August 27, 2007 at age 89, in New York City. Arthur was a direct descendant of Robert Livingston, who helped draft the Declaration of Independence and Philip Livingston, who signed it. He was the son of Arthur Livingston Willis and Ruth Bullard Willis. He is survived by his two beloved sons, Philip Willis and Christopher Willis; and three grandchilden, Spencer, Kirsten and Britt. He is also survived by his brother, Charles Willis; his niece Laura and nephew David; and two great-nephews; as well as many beloved cousins and his dearest friend, Elinor Sheppard. Services will be private in Wappingers Falls, New York.

As more and more of the costs of care are shifted to consumers, people are going to need more credit. They are still going to need health care. RED GILLEN, of Celent, an insurance and banking research firm, on the rise in financing plans for doctors' bills. [A1]

ZELAN--Edna, at 100. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Stephen Zelan and Barbara Robey. Adored grandmother of Joshua Robey of Hollis, NH and Ethan Robey of New York City and their wives Denise April and Mary Lou Ortiz. Dear great-grandmother of Samuel, Cheri, and Jeffrey and great-great-grandmother of three. Devoted sister of the late George and Bertram Kaplan. Loving aunt of many. Services, Thursday, August 30, 1:30pm at the ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the National Council of Jewish Women, North Shore University Hospital, or YAI. ZELAN--Edna, Temple Beth El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Edna Zelan. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Nina Koppelman, President Richard J. Shapiro, Rabbi

I'm hooked on the A&E show "Intervention." If you haven't seen it (and if not, you should start TiVO'ing it post haste) this is the premise: they follow an addict - usually coke/crack, heroin, crustal meth or alcohol - and chronicle the typical day-to-day life of addiction. The lying, the stealing, the manipulating of friends and loved ones. It can be depressing at times, but it's as riveting as HBO's "Flight of the Conchords" is hysterical (unlike "The Two Coreys," which I had high hopes for, but is clearly scripted, totally unfunny, and Haim looks like he's been riding life's Tilt-a-Whirl for wayyyy too long.)

Senator John Warner, 80, just announced that he would retire from his seat in Virginia at the end of his term. The news throws into play what would have probably been a safe Senate seat for the Republicans had he decided to seek re-election.

It's hard to think of a good analogy for exactly what YouTube is becoming in modern society. It has attracted a critical mass of public attention in a way that predigital analogues like public-access cable television or the sign-encrusted kiosks of Paris or the proverbial Hyde Park Corner soap box never could -- to the point that it now matters pretty strongly to people and businesses and governments what is said and shown there, and they are doing things about it.

Barclays, blaming a "technical breakdown" in Britain's bank-clearing system, borrowed heavily from the Bank of England's lending facility for the second time in two weeks. Separately, Barclays also said it would take part in a rescue of a $1.6 billion debt fund it helped create.

WPP has invested in a Chinese venture capital firm that is leading the introduction of MySpace in China, according to The Telegraph. The advertising giant has ploughed an undisclosed sum into China Broadband Capital Partners, a Beijing-based investor in the technology and media sectors.

Lone Star Funds cut its takeover bid for Accredited Home Lenders, the subprime mortgage company, by 44 percent, to $214 million, after the company laid off 60 percent of its workers and stopped making new loans.

Convio, which provides fundraising and advocacy software and services for nonprofit organizations, plans an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Deutsche Bank has shut down its proprietary credit trading desk in London and up to seven employees have left the bank - including department head Gerry Jackson - as the credit crunch claimed yet more scalps Thursday. The remaining members of the team, believed to be about 15 strong, have been given other jobs in the bank, according to The Telegraph.

A federal court judge dealt a blow to Johnson & Johnson in its $5.5 billion lawsuit over the sale of Guidant to Boston Scientific, dismissing some claims and only allowing part of the case to proceed. The ruling, which was made public on Thursday, throws out the case against Abbott Laboratories but allows J&J to go ahead with its claim against Guidant for breach of contract.

Shareholders of WCI Communities, a struggling homebuilder, elected the billionaire Carl C. Icahn to the board on Thursday, more than four months after management rejected his $22-per-share takeover bid.

Major shareholders in the TSX Group, the parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, and its rival, the Montreal Exchange have mobilized to push for a merger between the companies, a deal the two exchanges have discussed but so far failed to reach.

If Ahsha Rolle wants to continue competing at this year's Open, she'll have to keep winning in singles. Reklaim Technologies, which hopes to create a profitable business around selling the byproducts of recycled tires, has secured $7 million in venture financing from Goldman Sachs.

Sentinel Management Group, a cash-management firm that recently filed for bankruptcy protection, won court permission to pay payroll, rent, utilities and insurance expenses in an amount up to $97,500.

Thornburg Mortgage, a jumbo-mortgage specialist that was forced to stop making new loans, has sold $500 million of convertible preferred stock to raise cash.

WestLB, the troubled German state-run bank, said Thursday that it had lost more than $820 million on speculative trades in global stock markets in the first half of 2007 - pushing it into a net loss for the period and renewing pressure for it to find a merger partner.
Bear Stearns hit a wall in its efforts to shield two hedge funds seeking bankruptcy protection from investor claims by arguing that they are based in the Cayman Islands.

A 32-year-old Bronx man fatally shot his 27-year-old longtime companion and then killed himself yesterday as the couple’s 9-month-old baby was nearby, the police said. The bodies of the couple, Arlington Marshall and Tricia Spooner, both shot in the head in what investigators called a murder-suicide, were discovered around 8:30 p.m. in Mr. Marshall’s basement apartment at 730 East 227th Street in Williamsbridge. A .38-caliber gun was recovered at the scene.

Exhausted and shriveled from nearly a day and a half in the water, Skip Storch completed a record swim by circling Manhattan three times in 32 hours 52 minutes 30 seconds.

Carmen Gonzalez, of East Harlem, died at 72 on Monday. She had regularly attended Mass at Our Lady Queen of Angels, a Roman Catholic parish on 113th Street in East Harlem, for years. When the church closed in February as part of a round of parish closings ordered by the Archdiocese of New York, Mrs. Gonzalez was devastated. She joined a small but fervent group of protesters who urged the archdiocese to reconsider.

Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, has renewed his demand that the Bush administration explain how millions of White House e-mail messages may have been lost, disclosing for the first time that there was a daily audit of the message system. Mr. Waxman, chairman of the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, said White House officials had failed to provide answers for three months, including naming the contractor that had audited the e-mail system. Mr. Waxman demanded in a letter that the White House respond by Sept. 10 and provide an internal report that analyzed the scope of the missing messages. Scott M. Stanzel, a White House spokesman, said officials would “respond expeditiously.”.

Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, left, a Navy officer and former astronaut, can remove an electronic monitoring bracelet from her ankle while she awaits trial on charges of attacking a romantic rival, a judge ruled. Captain Nowak had said in court that the bracelet was expensive, bulky and uncomfortable. The judge, Marc L. Lubet of Orange County Circuit Court, said that those claims did not matter, but that Captain Nowak had behaved well enough to remove the device. She is prohibited from contacting the former rival, Capt. Colleen Shipman of the Air Force, or Cmdr. William A. Oefelein of the Navy, the former shuttle pilot both women dated, Judge Lubet said. Captain Nowak, 44, was arrested in February after confronting Captain Shipman at the Orlando airport.

Kathleen Corbet, president of the credit rating company Standard & Poor’s, resigned after lawmakers and investors criticized the company for failing to judge the risks of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

The body of a woman was found under a bed in the Carter Hotel in Times Square yesterday, with her head and legs covered in plastic, the police said. The victim, who was described by the police as in her 20s but whose name was not released pending family notification, was discovered shortly before 2:30 p.m. in a sixth-floor room of the hotel on West 43rd Street. The medical examiner will determine the exact cause of death, the police said.
As if the Yankees and the Red Sox did not have enough reasons to hate each other, Joba Chamberlain’s two wayward fastballs have added another wrinkle.

The byline for a front-page article yesterday about the legal troubles of a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and contributor to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign misidentified one of the writers. The article was by Mike McIntire and Leslie Wayne — not by Leslie Eaton, another Times reporter.

The byline for a front-page article yesterday about the legal troubles of a prominent Democratic fund-raiser and contributor to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign misidentified one of the writers. A picture caption on Wednesday about a wildfire near Ketchum, Idaho, misstated the date the fire started. It was set by a lightning strike on Aug. 16, not last Friday.

An article on Wednesday about plans by the Republican Party to penalize states for moving up the dates of their primaries misstated the precedent for national political conventions that opened without a clear-cut nominee. It last occurred in 1976, not 50 years ago. (President Gerald R. Ford and Ronald Reagan arrived at the Republican convention that year without the number of votes needed for the nomination. Mr. Ford swayed enough delegates to win narrowly on the first ballot.).

Because of an editing error, a subheading yesterday with a report by The Associated Press in some copies of the baseball roundup reversed the score of the game between Detroit and Kansas City. The Royals — not the Tigers — won 5-0.

ENGLEWOOD, Colo., Aug. 30 (AP) — With No. 7 emblazoned across his chest, the high school senior preparing for the season opener Friday night drops back and throws a dart to a receiver in the back of the end zone.
Shaun Lane is a cornerback for Ohio State. His brother Ben Lane is a fullback for Youngstown State, which visits the Buckeyes on Saturday.

Michael B. Nifong, the former Durham County prosecutor, pleaded not guilty to criminal contempt charges stemming from his failure to turn over complete DNA testing results in the now-discredited rape case against three former Duke University lacrosse players. Mr. Nifong faces up to 30 days in jail and a fine of up to $500. As Durham County district attorney, Mr. Nifong led the investigation into a woman’s accusation that she was raped at a 2006 lacrosse team party where she had been hired as a stripper. He won indictments against three players, but eventually recused himself, and state prosecutors dropped all charges.

A judge rejected some elements of a challenge to a 2004 voter-approved state law that requires Arizonans to prove citizenship to register to vote and show identification at polling places. The order from the judge, Roslyn O. Silver of Federal District Court, dated Tuesday, rejected claims that the requirement imposed a poll tax. Judge Silver also said it did not violate federal election law to impose different identification standards for voters casting ballots at polling places and those casting early ballots. Parts of the suit to be decided at trial center on claims that the measure poses an undue burden on the constitutional right to vote and violates the federal Voting Rights Act.

A video camera lowered into a seventh hole in search of six miners trapped since Aug. 6 in a cave-in found only two and a half feet of clear space, a pile of rubble and mud seven feet deep, the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration said. The hole started plugging up with mud and rubble at a rate of five feet per hour, making it impossible for technicians to put a special robotic camera 1,856 feet into the mine to look for signs of the men, said Rich Kulczewski, an agency spokesman. The federal Labor Department said an independent review would be conducted into the agency’s handling of the search.

The Food and Drug Administration gave approval to a drug used to treat a rare condition that causes the body to produce too much growth hormone. The treatment, Somatuline Depot, will offer a new option for patients with acromegaly, which causes excess growth of the hands, feet and head. Ipsen SA, the Paris-based company that owns the drug in Europe, licensed American rights to the company Tercica, which is based in Brisbane, Calif., in November.

An Iraqi Christian who used migrant smugglers to enter the United States after escaping persecution in his home country has been granted political asylum and will be allowed to remain. The immigration judge, William Peterson, granted a request from the man, Aamr Bahnan Boles, in Harlingen on Wednesday. Mr. Boles escaped from Iraq and made his way through Mexico to the Texas border near Brownsville, where he was captured with two other young Iraqi men as they swam the Rio Grande in April 2006. They claimed asylum on grounds they were subjected to brutality and threats in Iraq because of their faith. Mr. Boles served six months in prison on a charge of illegal entry while the F.B.I. investigated his claim. In January, he was released and has been staying with a relative in Sterling Heights, Mich.

The Michigan House and Senate approved moving the state’s presidential nomination contests to Jan. 15, just days after national Democrats vowed to punish states that vote too early. Gov. Jennifer M. A disagreement among state Democratic leaders over whether to hold a primary or a caucus is complicating final action. The House vote was 67 to 34; the Senate’s was 36 to 0.

A woman accused of dragging her companion to his death after he tried to stop her from driving away from a party pleaded not guilty yesterday to a grand jury indictment charging her with manslaughter and drunken driving. The woman, Jesenia Vega, 27, who has been held in $100,000 cash bail, said through her lawyer that she was abused by Louis Wiederer, at a block party on July 21, when she tried to drive away. Mr. Wiederer, 26, who hung on to an open window of Ms. Vega’s car, fell under the car and was killed, the Suffolk County police said. The police said Mr. Wiederer was concerned that Ms. Vega had had too much to drink, but her lawyer said she was trying to flee from Mr. Wiederer.

A minor earthquake shook the Adirondack Mountains on Wednesday night. The magnitude 3.2 temblor happened just before midnight. Its epicenter was about eight miles northeast of Tupper Lake, according to the United States Geological Survey. “It sounded lke a sonic boom,” Bill Ghent, manager of the Saranac Inn Golf and Country Club, told The Adirondack Daily Enterprise. The police had no reports of injuries or damage, and most people reported hearing the rumble rather than feeling it. In the last six months, there have been several earthquakes in the Northeast with a magnitude of more than 3.

Although the owner of the Indian Point nuclear plant says its new siren system works, federal regulators said yesterday that the plant had missed its third deadline for installing the system and could face fines. The old system remains in place and would be used in case of an emergency. The sirens are intended to alert residents within 10 miles of the plant of a major problem. The plant owner, Entergy Nuclear, said two days before the Aug. 24 deadline that the new system was ready, but it had not been approved by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that approval, which could take 45 days or more, was needed to meet the deadline. Jim Steets, an Entergy spokesman, said the company believed approval from FEMA would happen as “we were putting the system into place.”.

A state trooper accused of failing to report that her neighbor had been abusing children has been placed in the state’s accelerated rehabilitation program by a Superior Court judge in Hartford. If the trooper, Mary Buckley, 61, completes nine months of probation, charges against her could be dismissed, The Hartford Courant reported. Trooper Buckley, who has been on administrative duty since her arrest in December 2005, is retiring from the state police tomorrow, her lawyer said. She has been a trooper for 27 years. Her former neighbor, Peter Waraksa, 45, of East Windsor, pleaded no contest to fourth-degree sexual assault in July and has been sentenced to five years in prison, court officials said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Former State Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., left, was returned to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday from the Oneida Correctional Facility in Rome, N.Y., for imposition of another sentence of one to three years in prison, prosecutors said. That sentence had been stayed while Mr. Norman appealed a lower court decision, but was imposed after the appeal was denied, prosecutors said. Mr. Norman, who is now sentenced to serve three to nine years, has been imprisoned on two other charges since June. He was convicted in February of extorting money from judicial candidates.

A $2 million lawsuit against the author Augusten Burroughs, by the family that sued him for defamation for his best-selling book “Running With Scissors,” has been settled, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Mr. Burroughs and the publisher, St. Martin’s Press, agreed to call the volume a “book” instead of “memoirs” in the author’s note, although the word memoir will still appear on the cover and elsewhere, and to change the acknowledgments in future editions to say that the Turcotte family’s memories of events he describes are “different from my own.” In addition future editions will express regret for “any unintentional harm” to them. But in a statement released yesterday by St. Martin’s, Mr. Burroughs declared his work “an entirely accurate memoir.” Howard Cooper, a lawyer for the family, said financial terms of the settlement were confidential. Mr. Burroughs lived with the Turcottes as a teenager, and though the book calls them “the Finches,” the lawsuit maintains that they are easily identified.

ONEIDA There's something about Oneida's music that seems as if it could go on forever. Maybe it's that dissonant organ, pounding a few chords over and over in long, throbbing noise-drones. Or maybe it's the vocals, chanted as if part of some ceremony from rock 'n' roll's tribal prehistory. It could be the drums, fast and strong and unrelenting. Whatever it is, Oneida has been bashing it out for 10 years now as the consummate Brooklyn avant-rock band, weird enough to play a single riff for 14 minutes, as it did on ''Sheets of Easter,'' from its 2002 double album, ''Each One Teach One'' (Jagjaguwar), yet enough of a meat-and-potatoes rock outfit to have clear stylistic connections to the MC5 and Led Zeppelin. Over the last decade it has been easy to take Oneida for granted, as the band -- above, from left, Hanoi Jane, Kid Millions and Fat Bobby -- has played countless club shows and parties, remaining a local favorite even as other Brooklyn groups like its onetime opening act the Yeah Yeah Yeahs have gone on to national prominence. But at P.S. 1 in Queens tomorrow Oneida makes an elder-statesman gesture by playing a 10th-anniversary show, supported by friends like Sightings, Ex-Models and Dirty Faces. May the weirdness go on and on. (Tomorrow at 3 p.m., P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, 718-784-2084, ps1.org; $10.) BEN SISARIO

LOW--Niels, M.D., The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital notes with deep sorrow the passing of our dear friend and colleague. Dr. Low joined the Medical Staff in 1956 and served as Chief of Pediatrics and Medical Director from 1966-1989. His knowledge and experience provided superb medical care to our children and left a lasting legacy of excellence. A warm, kind and compassionate person, Neils made a profound difference in the lives of all who knew him. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deep and sincere sympathies to his wife, Mary Margaret and his entire family. John L. Just over a week after Barnes & Noble said it would not carry copies of ''If I Did It,'' the book in which O. J. Simpsonhypothesizes about how he might have murdered Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman in 1994, the bookseller is reversing its decision. In a statement yesterday Mary Ellen Keating, a Barnes & Noble spokeswoman, said the company had initially responded to ''widespread customer outrage and disgust'' when it decided not to offer the book in its stores. But the company was selling it at bn.com, where advance orders propelled the book as high as No. 1 on its best-seller list. (Yesterday it had fallen to No. 17.) The company has ''concluded that enough customers have expressed interest in buying the book to warrant stocking it in our stores,'' Ms. Keating said. ''We do not intend to promote the book, but we will stock it in our stores because our customers are asking for it.'' Eric Kampmann, president of Beaufort Books, the publisher of ''If I Did It,'' said he had increased the first print run to 150,000 copies from 125,000.

FOR CHILDREN 'A CLEARING IN THE FOREST' (Tomorrow) Boys and girls are forever wandering into enchanted forests in fairy tales, but they don't expect to stumble onto one just off the bustling streets of Manhattan. Thanks to the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation and the Central Park Conservancy, they now have something that comes close. Called the Peter Jay Sharp Children's Glade, it has a natural amphitheater that will be the site of arts programs year round. Tomorrow ''A Clearing in the Forest,'' a storytelling series, will feature Dan Kitrosser in a presentation geared to Rosh Hashana, the approaching Jewish New Year: tales from Jewish folklore. From 1 to 2 p.m., entrance at 103rd Street and Central Park West, (212) 860-1370, centralparknyc.org/activities. Free.

Reacting swiftly to Lebanon's revocation of its ban on his performance piece, Rabih Mroue presented ''How Nancy Wished That Everything Was an April Fool's Joke'' twice yesterday at the Theater of the City in Beirut. ''Nancy'' presents an episodic history of Lebanon's civil war, using interwoven narratives by four fighters who belonged to -- and betrayed -- various militias. This month the Interior Ministry had banned the script, written by Mr. Mroue and Fadi Toufic, from being performed locally, citing concern that it would incite sectarian strife. The ban was appealed to the culture minister, Tarek Mitri, who said that he found no justification for the ban. On Monday it was reversed.

KAYAKING ON THE HUDSON As the enormous cruise ship barreled by, my companion went white. It's one thing to enjoy the sight of a ship from the safety of Riverside Park, quite another to be paddling in a one-person kayak in the same churning water as the behemoth. But the ship passed uneventfully, and we were soon laughing at our moment of panic, back to enjoying a rare chance to get out on the Hudson. Of all the free outdoor events that make summer in the city not just bearable but also a treat, the walk-up kayaking program run by the Downtown Boathouse may be the most quixotic.

DANCENOW/NYC FESTIVAL Early September is the calm before the live-performance storm in New York, and as if to remind audiences of the chaos that awaits them, the 13th annual DancenOw/NYC Festival returns with a weeklong run of more than 70 choreographers, from the aspiring to the established, in a flurry of sampler showings (left, Sara Joel and Kevin Gibbs, appearing on Sept. 9). This year the festival is honoring five troupes that have reached the 10-year mark; such longevity, along with baseball pitchers who can make it out of the sixth inning, is becoming an increasing rarity in these economically trying times. The troupes -- David Parker and the Bang Group, Brian Brooks Moving Company, nicholasleichterdance, Gina Gibney Dance and Young Dance Makers -- will each perform a dance from 1997, and a new work commissioned by the festival. DancenOw takes a grab-bag approach to programming, but some eye-catching names include the irrepressible portraitist Larry Keigwin, the Stephen Petronio Company alumna Jimena Paz and the Butoh-inspired Vangeline Theater, which, along with Ms. Paz and others, will perform site-specific gallery dances during the festival. And be on the lookout for dance films and video projects. (Tuesday through Thursday, and Sept. 6, at 7:30 p.m.; Sept. 8 and 9 at 2 p.m., with a free, informal showing of collaborative work on Sept. 10 at 6 p.m.; Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, 212-924-0077, dtw.org; $20 in advance, $25 at the door.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

A print depicting Osama bin Laden in a Christlike pose and a statue of the Virgin Mary covered in a burqa has ignited debate in Australia after they were showcased in a competition for religious works at the National Art School in Sydney, Reuters reported. ''The choice of such artwork is gratuitously offensive to the religious beliefs of many Australians,'' Prime Minister John Howard told The Daily Telegraph. The works -- ''Bearded Orientals: Making the Empire Cross'' by Priscilla Bracks and ''The Fourth Secret of Fatima'' by Luke Sullivan -- were among 500 competing for the $12,300 Blake Prize for Religious Art. It was won on Wednesday by the Aboriginal painter Shirley Purdie for ''Stations of the Cross,'' a recreation of stories told to her in childhood. The Rev.Rod Pattenden, a spokesman for the prize, defended the choice of the controversial works, saying the aim of the prize was to encourage discussion about spirituality in society, which was the goal of both artists.

Damien Hirst is selling his diamond-encrusted platinum skull, below, for $100 million to an investment group, Bloomberg News reported yesterday. The skull is studded with 8,601 diamonds, including a 52.40 carat stone valued at more than $8 million. Mr. Hirst's business manager, Frank Dunphy, said the buyers, who were not identified, did not receive a discount and would pay in cash. He would not specify the payment period but added that the sale would close in three or four weeks, and that the buyers would be required to exhibit the work for two or three years in museums around the world. The skull, which cost $23.6 million to make, according to the White Cube gallery in London, where it was exhibited, has been on the market at least since June 3. Art professionals said Mr. Hirst, 42, who made his name by pickling sharks, cows, sheep and the like, is likely to get 75 percent or more of the proceeds of a sale.

NEW YORK TUGBOAT RACE AND COMPETITION Tugboats are the tractors of the waterways, Capt. John Doswell said. And like tractors they are dependable, hard working and vital to their industry, though not exactly glamorous. But once a year tugboats have their day in the sun, when the Working Harbor Committee, of which Captain Doswell is the executive director, holds the New York Tugboat Race and Competition. ''They get to show off their stuff,'' he said.

George Strait and Brad Paisley, with five nominations each, led the field yesterday when the Country Music Association awards nominations were announced in Nashville, The Associated Press reported. Besides competing for entertainer and male vocalist of the year, Mr. Strait was nominated for musical event of the year, album of the year and single of the year. '25 YEARS LATER: WELCOME TO ART IN GENERAL' To celebrate its 25th anniversary, the scruffy, downtown, nonprofit art space Art in General is presenting a dozen newly commissioned installations by artists who have participated in its recent programs at the well-heeled Midtown gallery of UBS, one of the world's leading financial firms. It is an unorthodox partnership, though there is something immensely appealing about the idea of experimental art invading this sterile corporate environment. A handful of the artworks even poke fun at corporate culture and greed, including Ana Prvacki's mock money-laundering service (complete with a promotional video); the Dutch collective Bik Van der Pol's installation inspired by an out-of-print guidebook, ''How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found''; and Lee Walton's hiring of an actor to hang around the gallery's 51st Street entrance for an hour each day, pretending to be an office worker at lunch. Bleachers are provided nearby for viewers in the know. Several pieces invite audience participation, including Surasi Kusolwong's 2007 work ''Ping-Pong (New York Common Sense),'' above, a mirrored Ping-Pong table covered in kitsch figurines; Kianga Ford's white, cocoonlike structures for relaxing and listening to stories on headphones; or Chitra Ganesh and Mariam Ghani's library of chilling -- even sickening -- information on immigration issues, including detentions, deportations and legal battles. Occasionally an office worker stops, sits down and starts reading. At this point the exhibition begins to make sense, sort of: It is about introducing radical, experimental art to new audiences. (Through Nov. 9, UBS Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, between 51st and 52nd Streets, 212-713-2885, artingeneral.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

RUBIN--Doris. A favorite aunt, a courageous lady, a special friend. You will be in my thoughts forever. Barbara RUBIN--Doris Konheim, at the age of 95 passed away peacefully at her home on August 29th surrounded by her family. She lived a full and rich life and felt blessed to have experienced this wonderful adventure, which was her life, and to have enjoyed her personal relationships with numerous friends and an extensive family. Doris, the Quintessential New Yorker, took full advantage of the best that our city has to offer. She was a patron of the Arts, supporting many of New Yorks Cultural Centers. In 1989, with her beloved husband of 57 years, Harry Rubin, they founded the Harry and Doris Rubin Lecture Series, an educational endeavor within the American Art Department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Series will continue to be supported by the Rubin Foundation. Doris was one of the original founders of The Manhattan Guild, an organization that was over many decades supported the activities of then young Tel Hashomer Hospital in Israel, now known as the Chiam Sheba Medical Center. She was a loving mother to, Richard, Robert and the late Stephen; a cherished motherin-law to Gail, Polly and Lynne; an adored grandmother to Jeffrey, Michael, David, Joseph and Katherine; and an energetic and affectionate great-grandmother to Sydney, Laura, Rachael, Sasha, Eric and Jalen. Merrill, Jody and Donna Lewen and their families were also an important part of Doris' extended family. She relished being a devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. Friends are invited to meet the family at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street on Thursday evening August 30th from 7 to 9pm. Services to be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street on Friday, August 31st at 10am. In lieu of flowers, if you wish, a donation may be sent to the charity of your choice. Doris had a zest for life and a style that was uniquely her own. RUBIN--Doris. Avalued friend of many years, possessed a beauty, intelligence, generosity and grace. She was my inspiration and will be profoundly missed. Carolyn Minskoff RUBIN--Doris. Much love to our wonderful aunt Doris. We will cherish your devotion to all of us and remember you forever. Your nieces and nephews Alice and Michael Tannenbaum, Patricia Heffron, Nancy and Victor Greene, Anne and Robert Polansky, and your many great-nieces and nephews and your greatgreat-nieces and nephews.

Shahar Peer, seeded 18th, defeated No. 13 Nicole Vaidisova in a third-set tiebreaker, 6-4, 3-6, 7-6 (5), winning on her fourth match point when Vaidisova put a forehand into the net.
