Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, a Democrat, signed an executive order prohibiting most state employees from discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. The order requires agencies under the governor’s direct control to ensure they have programs to prevent harassment against gay men, lesbians, bisexuals and people who have had surgery for sex changes. It covers 25,000 of the 41,000 state employees.

The restaurant where a blaze killed two Boston firefighters was cited for greasy equipment and was overdue for an inspection. The Tai Ho Mandarin and Chinese Restaurant was cited for failing to clean ducts in 2005 and 2001, published reports said.

A Moroccan immigrant who was held for three years before his terrorism-related conviction was thrown out has filed a $9 million federal lawsuit against the prosecutor and two other figures in the case. The immigrant, Karim Koubriti, 28, argues in the suit that the former federal prosecutor, Richard G. Convertino, violated his civil rights. Mr. Convertino, left, was removed in 2003 after the Justice Department said he had withheld evidence that could have proved the innocence of Mr. Koubriti and three others who were accused of being in a “sleeper” terror cell in Detroit. Mr. Convertino was indicted last year on charges that he conspired to obstruct justice and lied to a federal judge in the case.

The state Supreme Court reversed lower court decisions and ruled that state restrictions on what unaccredited religious institutions can call themselves and their education training violated the First Amendment. Three religious organizations, including the Tyndale Theological Seminary in Fort Worth, waged the fight. The court said banning an institution like Tyndale from using the term “seminary” in its name violated the Constitution. Tyndale was cited in 1998 for violating a law that requires seminaries to be accredited and prevents unaccredited institutions from awarding degrees. The Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board fined it $173,000.

The Houston Independent School District suspended a police officer as it investigated his distribution of a “Ghetto Handbook” and the three-month lapse before top officials were informed of it. The booklet, subtitled “Wucha dun did now?” was given to 15 other officers at a meeting in May, said Terry Abbott, a spokesman for the district. A supervisor immediately collected the booklets, Mr. Abbott said, and ordered the officer to attend diversity training. District officials said they did not learn about the incident until someone complained to the district’s Equal Employment Opportunity Office last month.

(Starz) THE QUEEN (2006) Queen Elizabeth II and Tony Blair struggle with the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in this semibiographical drama directed by Stephen Frears from a screenplay by Peter Morgan (“Last King of Scotland”). Helen Mirren, above, won the best-actress Oscar for her portrayal of Queen Elizabeth in a performance that Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called “remarkable in its art and lack of sentimentalism.” James Cromwell plays Prince Philip as a dim bulb; Michael Sheen is the newly elected Mr. Blair; Helen McCrory bristles as his wife, Cherie; and Alex Jennings is “both sniveling and sly,” Ms. Dargis said, as Prince Charles.

LOW--Neils M.D. The Department of Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center mourns the death of Dr. Neils Low, pioneering and beloved pediatric neurologist at Babies Hospital and the Neurological Institute of New York. Dr. Low was an outstanding clinician, inspiring teacher, and friend to generations of students and residents. He was a doctor's doctor, and patients and their families loved him. All of us who knew him miss him greatly. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Mary Margaret, and to his children and grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Division of Pediatric Neurology, The Neurological Institute, Room 1406, 710 W. 168th St., New York, NY 10032. Timothy A. Pedley, M.D. Chairman, Department of Neurology Columbia University Medical Center

Countries once torn by civil war are seeking to revive tourism, hoping to replace images of violence with those of hospitality and adventure travel. The latest example is Rwanda, most closely identified in the minds of many Americans with the genocide that swept the country in 1994. The country's main attraction is still the mountain gorillas popularized in ''Gorillas in the Mist,'' the 1988 movie about the primatologist Dian Fossey. But now, aided by a newfound stability under Rwanda's first democratically elected president, the country's government, business leaders and entrepreneurs are trying to convey that Rwanda has more than primates to offer tourists.

HOCHWALD--Ronald Irwin, M.D., 72, died of brain cancer in the arms of his family Thursday, August 29th, 2007. Services Sunday September 2nd and Hendrix Hall, Nantucket. Donations honoring his memory may be made to Congregation Shirat Ha Yam.

LERNER--Marie Louise Power of New York, died suddenly on August 29, 2007 in New York. She was the beloved wife and best friend of M. Michael Lerner and the adoring mother of Michael Aloysius (Susie) and John Charles Lerner, all of New York. She is also survived by her brothers and sisters, John J. Power, Kathleen Power Sullivan, Sheila Power von Zumbusch, David Power, Suzanne Power and Eileen Power Beirne, and her aunts, Sister Margaret Coakley RSCJ and Dorothy Coakley. She will be missed by her family, many close cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. A Funeral Mass will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola (Park Avenue at 84th Street) on Saturday, September 1, 2007 at 10am. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Encore Community Services, 239 West 49th Street, New York, New York 10019-7493.

AT&T AND VERIZON WIN EXEMPTIONS AT&T and Verizon Communications can each merge their local and long-distance telephone operations with fewer government restrictions than some rivals wanted, the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday. In a order posted on its Web site, the F.C.C. exempted the two companies from price caps and other so-called dominant-carrier rules on long-distance service.

CARMEL--Ben Zion. Little Neck Jewish Center joins our neighbors, Temple Torah, in mourning the untimely passing of Cantor Ben Zion Carmel, who was to lead us all in Holiday worship. Our hearts ache with his bereaved fiancee, mother, and family. ''Into God's Sanctuary the singers enter first'' (Ps. 68). Joseph Prouser, Rabbi Julian Raber, Cantor Stephen Aronowitz, President

GROSS--Dr. Alfred. Born October 18, 1914 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He was a devoted husband of Claire Mollie Pines Gross who for 66 years he called ''Peanuts,'' his pet name for her. Formerly of Bayside, New York, he was a Lieutenant Commander at the Education Officers at Kings Point Maritime Academy. He was Professor Emeritus of NYU School of Business and Graduate School for 40 years where he chaired many departments and was a faculty advisor. He authored several published books written in English and Spanish including Salesmanship, Sales Promotion, Business Policy, and Selling Houses Successfully. He also wrote thousands of articles for many business magazines. He was a consultant for innumerable clients including, Bache, Penn. Furniture and Sun Oil. He was a member of Alpha Phi Sigma, Pi Sigma Epsilon and Who's Who in the East. In addition to his loving and devoted wife, Claire Mollie, survivors include several loving nieces and nephews. Private services were held.

DONIS--Ethel, nee Greenberg: two days before her 93rd birthday. Wife of the late Harry, mother of Stephan and Jeffrey, sister of Syril Appel and the late Robert Greene, mother-in-law of Roberta and Roseann, grandmother of Joshua, Katherine and Harry, great-grandmother, aunt, cousin, and friend. An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a rating downgrade of short-term notes issued by Cheyne Finance, a unit of Cheyne Capital Management of London, misstated the role that the unit's profits play for other investors. Profits from Cheyne Finance, which is known as a structured investment vehicle, are only used to bolster overall returns to investors in Cheyne Finance, not any other fund managed by Cheyne Capital.

An article in Business Day on Aug. 24 about political contributions by Silicon Valley executives referred incorrectly to contributions that Ron Paul, a presidential candidate, received from Google employees, and a correction in this space on Thursday misstated the amount of those contributions. Google employees gave the money before -- not after -- Mr. Paul visited the company on July 13, and the amount was $3,350, not $3,550.

WILLARD--Reverend Father William H. Peacefully, after a short illness, on June 8, 2007; son of the late Anson James Willard and Laura I. Willard. Survived by aunt Mary Dousett, special cousin Joanne Proctor, longtime special friend Linda A. Russell, and surrogate sons Eric B. Johnson and Stanley Obaji. Raised in Collingwood and Newmarket, Ontario, a graduate of York University, he attended seminary at Nashotah House, Wisconsin and was ordained Priest in 1979, serving parishes in Kingston, ON; Norristown, PA; Las Vegas, NV (Good Shepherd Campus); St. Jude's Ranch for Children; Westwood, NJ; and Hollis, NY. He was also an Associate of the Sisters of the Holy Nativity; Fond du Lac, WI. He was a founder of Essex County Child Abuse & Neglect Association, ON. Special thanks to Fr. John Mitchell, Wardens, parishioners of Grace Episcopal, Westwood for their kindness; to Fr. Brian Laffler, Fr. H. Gaylord Hitchcock Jr., the Rev. James Delaney and chaplains Francis Castello and Fr. Thomas Norton and medical staff at Pascack Valley Hospital and Hospice at Bergen Community Health Care. Private interment with his parents at All Saint's Cemetery, Collingwood, ON. Memorial Service on Saturday, September 22nd, 1:00pm at St. Thomas' Church, where Fr. Willard served as Acolyte, 383 Huron St., Toronto, Ontario M5S2G5, (416)979-2323. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations gratefully received by United Negro College Fund. (uncf.org) or Operation Eyesight Universal (operationeyesight.ca

Cappie Pondexter scored 9 of her 33 points in the final five minutes as the host Phoenix Mercury advanced to the W.N.B.A. finals with a 98-92 victory yesterday over the San Antonio Silver Stars.The Mercury, which has swept each of its best-of-three playoff series, will play beginning Wednesday against the Detroit Shock or the Indiana Fever. The Fever leads the series, 1-0.Penny Taylor added 23 points and Diana Taurasi had 18 for the Mercury.

The authorities in Wilmington, Del., pulled a body from the Delaware River yesterday, and there is a “strong likelihood” it is the missing father of Orlando Magic guard Jameer Nelson, the police said.Floyd Nelson, 57, who is an employee at a tugboat company and is known as Pete, was last seen Thursday working in a dry dock area in Chester, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. Two European entrants will be decided this month.

Daniele Bennati of Italy won the opening leg yesterday of the Vuelta a España, cycling’s most important race after the Tour de France and the Giro d’Italia.Bennati, a Lampre-Fondital rider, sprinted ahead of the pack to finish the 95-mile course in 3 hours 43 minutes 9 seconds in and around Vigo, a port city.

The Spanish club Racing Santander has signed Danny Szetela, a United States under-20 midfielder, from Major League Soccer’s Columbus Crew. The deal for Szetela, who has signed a two-year contract, was completed just before the transfer deadline Friday.

Simon Wakefield chipped in for birdie at the last hole to finish with a 73 and tie Fredrik Andersson for the third-round lead in the Johnnie Walker Championship yesterday in Gleneagles, Scotland.Andersson shot a seven-under 66 in a difficult wind on the Centenary Course to total nine-under 210 three hours before Wakefield finished his round.Mark Warren (73) was a stroke back. Lee Westwood (69), Alastair Forsyth (72) and Phillip Archer (73) were next at 212.Thomas Levet, who shared the second-round lead with Wakefield, was in the hunt until a double-bogey 7 at the 16th.Colin Montgomerie shot a 71 and was four strokes off the lead. Paul Casey, the defending champion, was another stroke back after a 73.

Wade Wilson, the Dallas Cowboys quarterbacks coach, was suspended for five games by the N.F.L. yesterday for buying and using performance-enhancing substances.Wilson, a former N.F.L. quarterback, said he took the drugs to try to improve the quality of his life after living with diabetes for more than 20 years.Greg Aiello, a league spokesman, said Wilson’s suspension and the suspension Friday of New England safety Rodney Harrison stemmed from an investigation by the Albany district attorney’s office. Authorities there have been looking into an Internet ring involving performance-enhancing drugs; the case allegedly involving athletes from a number of sports.Aiello said a third N.F.L. person involved in the investigation was Dr. Richard Ryzde, one of the Pittsburgh Steelers’ doctors. He had earlier been fired by the team.

The starting defensive end Lawrence Wilson broke his right leg midway through the second quarter of No. 11 Ohio State’s opener against visiting Youngstown State yesterday.Wilson, a 6-foot-6, 276-pound junior, grabbed the starting job last spring and was expected to be a force up front for the Buckeyes. A year ago he had 17 tackles, including five for negative yardage, and 3 sacks.Wilson was hurt with the Buckeyes leading 14-0.

Because of an editing error, the Samurai Shopper column last Sunday in T: Women’s Fashion magazine, about a fantasy dinner party, misspelled the surname of a collage artist (one of the imagined guests). She is Miriam Schapiro, not Shapiro. Also, an accompanying article misspelled the name of the blend of a Taylor Fladgate port. It is Douro, not Douto.

Mark Lilla (Aug. 19) is right to conclude his review of the intertwining of politics and religion by suggesting that instead of trying to make Muslims more like us, we must allow them to draw on the “theological resources within their own traditions” to “create a decent and workable political order.” Although he concedes that within our own tradition this kind of internal reformation was once possible, he believes that today it is not. Instead, we must rely entirely on “our own lucidity,” since religiously inspired hopes for a better world almost always generate violence. But the evidence from the French revolutionary terror to Hiroshima and the Gulag indicates that lucidity (reason?) can be at least as lethal a basis for political life; whereas biblically informed prophets like Bishop Desmond Tutu and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. can still inspire healthy, nonviolent change. The real challenge of Islam to Western intellectual discourse is for us to ask ourselves whether our unprecedented modern experiment of conducting political life with no transcendent values is really working out as well as once hoped, and if it is not, how can we draw on our own traditions, as we hope the Muslims draw on theirs, to craft a viable way to live together?.

The partners, attorneys and staff of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel LLP extend their condolences to their managing partner and friend, Paul Pearlman, and his family on the passing of his father, Harold Pearlman.

BENEDEK--Richard Charles, 77. Lifelong Upper West Side resident, our beloved ''Dick'' passed away on August 23, at Holy Cross Hospital in Ft. Lauderdale, FL, where he lived since 2002. Born and raised in NYC, Dick attended a military school, going on to serve at home for the Navy during the Korean War. His artistic talents led him to teaching art in New Rochelle for over 25 years before changing course in his mid1950s to obtain his Master's in Social Work from Fordham, finding his ultimate calling as a psychotherapist. He was friend and counselor to those who found trust, healing and acceptance under his care. He helped us find humor in the folly of human behavior, providing many the ability to forgive. May his friendship and guidance live on in our hearts. He is survived by a brother, two nieces, several cousins and a multitude of devoted friends. Memorial at The Church of St. Matthew & St. Timothy on 84th St. between Columbus and Central Park West on Sunday, September 9th at 2:30pm.

VAN EES--Evelyn B., age 93, on August 22, 2007 from a thoracic aneurysm. Native New Yorker, graduated from Hunter College Cum Laude in 1934. Independent but always devoted to her family and friends. Life long Yankee fan. Ave atque vale. Survived by her son, Alan Bory Van Ees.

CYRULI--Leonard, 83, of Hackensack, NJ, died August 27, 2007. A graduate of Hackensack High School, he served in the U.S. Navy during WWII with the Seabees in Guam from 1943-1946. Thereafter he attended Pace University in Manhattan. From 1959 he was affiliated with the Toomey Mortgage Company and later with Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company in Hackensack, NJ where he was Vice President. He later held similar positions with Safeco Title Insurance Company and with U.S. Life Title Insurance Company. In 1986, he co-founded Accusearch Title Services, Inc., a nationwide title insurance agency based in Hackensack, NJ, where he served as President until his death. He is survived by his beloved wife, Edith, cherished son, Robert and granddaughter, Ava, and his sister, Bernese Elkin. Donations may be made in his memory to Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, NJ.

WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30-8/30/03. Charlotte Dylan, our 1st great-grandchild honors your memory. Dearly beloved, missed more each day. You live forever in our hearts. Bernie WEISS--Doris T. In every way, every day, we miss you... Your family, Wendy and Judd, Samantha and Jonathan, Joshua and your great-granddaughter Charlotte

His Kind of Town Horton Foote may be 91, but to those of us who are older ourselves, he exemplifies that age is a state of mind (Alex Witchel, Aug. 19). He gives wings to the rest of us with his honesty, his work ethic still running on high and his love of, and appreciation for, life. May this wonderful man be part of our lives for years to come, and writing his heart out. He truly is one of a kind -- the best kind.

STEIN--Matilda Baran, 95, died in New York City August 18, fourteen years after her husband Monroe. An insatiable reader, she maintained her passionate commitment to politics and progressive issues throughout her life, passing her values to her children, Susan (David) and Michael (Maureen), and her grandchildren, Sarah, Jacob, Daniel, and Katie. She is remembered by her friends, family, and devoted caretakers as a truly ''yummy'' woman.

ADAMS--Susan Gernert, 51, of Chappaqua, NY, died at home on August 26, 2007. Devoted mother of Hannah and Molly Brock. Loving partner of Pope Brock. Beloved sister of Anne Campos. Daughter of the late Archibald Gernert and Judith Wilson. A graduate of Colby College, Susan was a national producer for ''Dateline NBC,'' which she joined in 1992. A four-time Emmy Award Winner, she also worked for ''Nightline'' and ''Primetime Live'' at ABC News, and covered the 1988 Olympics in Seoul. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 pm on Saturday, September 8 at the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua. HECTOR--Nancy Bean, born September 8, 1922, in Newington, Connecticut, died at home in New York on August 24, shortly before her birthday. She lived a full, exuberant life and returned to the city following the death of her beloved husband, Louis J. Hector, in November 2005, after 29 years in Miami. A journalist at Life Magazine and the NY Times Sunday Magazine, as well as the author of a children's biography of John F. Kennedy, she moved through her life generously and with unpretentious elegance. She faced her last years courageously, and she will be remembered as a person of integrity, the life of the party, a wise soul, a wonderful friend, a devoted member of the Cosmopolitan Club, Junior Fortnightly, and The Club--and also as a lifelong, outspoken, liberal Democrat. She also served as President of Planned Parenthood of Miami. Previously married to Theodore H. White and Charles Dewey Hilles, she is survived by her children-David F. White (Margaret) and Heyden White Rostow (Nicholas), both of New York, NY; her Hector step-children Denis (Joanna Lombard), of Coconut Grove, Fla., William, of Richmond, Va., Anne, of San Francisco, Ca., and Jay (Hilde Darre), also of New York; and seven grand-and step - grandchildren--Marga ret White, Theodore and Celia Rostow, and Dorothy Anne, William, Henry and Anna Hector. Memorial contributions may be made to The Brearley School. There will be a celebration of her life later this fall.

BULLITT--Anne Moen, 83, died August 18, 2007 in Dublin, Ireland, the only child of the late Louise Bryant and William Christian Bullitt, who served as Ambassador to the Soviet Union and France under President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Anne Bullitt lived for more than 40 years at Palmerstown House, Kill, County Kildare. She was the first woman breeder and trainer of thoroughbred horses in Ireland, where she was known and respected as the manager of Palmerstown Stud, the largest horse farm in Ireland. In her early years she was formerly married to Caspar Wistar Barton Townsend, Jr., Nicholas Duke Biddle, Roderic More O'Ferrall and Daniel B. Brewster. Her mother having died when she was eight, she was deeply devoted to her father, and was his constant companion and aide throughout his travels and foreign assignments in the 1930's. She treasured memories of meetings with President Roosevelt at Hyde Park and foreign leaders of that era. During one of her visits to Hyde Park when she was twelve, Roosevelt, expecting a delegation of local politicians, told her to hide behind the sofa in his study so that she could hear their conversation. Faithful to her lifelong wish she will be buried next to her father in Woodlands Cemetery, Philadelphia. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Holy Trinity, Rittenhouse Square, Philadelphia at 2:30pm on Wednesday, September 5, 2007. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Yale University, c/o Manuscripts and Archives, PO Box 208240, New Haven, CT 06520-8240, which holds collections of the voluminous papers of William C. Bullitt and Louise Bryant who, before her marriage to William C. Bullitt in 1923, was married to John Reed who wrote ''Ten Days That Shook the World'' while living in Moscow through the Bolshevik revolution.

THE NEWSLeona Helmsley, the billionaire and self-styled hotel queen, left $12 million in her will for the care of her 8-year-old dog, Trouble, a Maltese. BEHIND THE NEWS Mrs. Helmsley, who died on Aug. 20 at 87, was known as the ''Queen of Mean'' and became a symbol of 1980s greed and arrogance. She spent 18 months in prison for income tax evasion. Mrs. Helmsley left $10 million to her brother and $5 million each to two of four grandchildren. The other two got nothing, her will said, for ''reasons which are known to them.''

Her heart, humor, wisdom and generosity remain a lasting legacy for an international community of colleagues, students, clients and friends. Each week, as Matt Gross traveled across the United States, he asked online readers of his column to suggest places he should visit as he made his way west. Here is a sampling of what some readers had to say. When you head into South Carolina, you have to go to one of the best barbecue restaurants in the country. In the little town of Batesburg-Leesville, about 45 miles outside of Columbia. The place is Shealy's. They have mustard-based (local tradition) and vinegar-based (North Carolina) pork barbecue, wonderful fried chicken and wonderful Southern-style vegetables.

FELDMAN--Eva Krause Millenthal, age 96. Wife of the late S. Harry Feldman and the late Col. Benjamin Millenthal, beloved mother of Richard M. Feldman (Diana), Rochelle F. Levy (Robert), grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of 15. She died peacefully at Beaumont Retirement Community in Bryn Mawr, PA on August 29, 2007. Eva was born July 11, 1911 in Dresden, Germany and in 1933 she moved to New York where she lived out her life. During WWII she drove an ambulance for the Red Cross and for the past twenty-five years she has been a dedicated volunteer for the American Cancer Society. She leaves a legacy of three generations, all of whom will miss her forever. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to the American Cancer Society, 132 West 32nd St., NY, NY 10001.

DUNCAN--Angus McAlpine 48 year old banker of Rye, NY, died August 18 following a biking accident in Dutchess County, NY. At the time of his death Angus, an 18-year veteran of the mortgage-trading business, was a managing director of BNP Paribas, where he headed the firm's mortgage-backed proprietary trading activities. Prior to joining BNP Paribas, Angus was a director at Donaldson, Lufkin, Jenrette, and later, assumed charge of proprietary trading in mortgagebacked securities at Deutsche Bank. His interests took him far beyond his business. He delved into subjects as diverse as art, food and wine, history, mathematics, languages, and theater. He was fluent in Spanish and French, traveled abroad frequently, and appeared on the stage on numerous occasions at his theater club in Manhattan. An accomplished athlete, Angus participated in a wide array of sports ranging from squash to skiing to golf. He was a valued member of the Yale University varsity golf team, and in subsequent years, competed in numerous triathlons across the U.S. He was a great lover of the outdoors, enjoying hiking and biking with a passion. Perhaps most important of all, Angus loved people. His group of friends is vast and varied, and he shared unique and important relationships with each of them. He will be remembered for his boundless energy, his winning smile, and his extraordinary joie de vivre. Angus Duncan was a man who lived his life to the fullest. Born in Washington, D.C., to Nancy Young Duncan and the late R. Michael Duncan, Angus attended St. Alban's School in Washington and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH. He obtained a B.A. in Economics and Modern Languages from Yale University in 1981 and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School of Finance in 1985. Angus was the loving husband of Ivelisse (Vicky) Fernandez and the devoted father of their two boys, Colin and Bryce. He is also survived by his sister, Diana Boubin, of Denver, CO. A memorial service will be held Friday, September 7th, at 2:30pm at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York City. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in Angus' name to: The Natural History Museum of the Adirondacks, 45 Museum Dr., Tupper Lake, NY 12986 and to The Yale Child Study Center, P.O. Box 7611, New Haven, CT 06519-0611.

POWLESKE--Charles Robert, 79, lost his battle with stomach cancer on August 1 in New York City, just one month shy of his 80th birthday. He will be missed by all. Charlie, as he was known, was the President of the Business Council for International Understanding, Inc. (BCIU) from 1983 until his retirement in 1996. He joined BCIU in February 1960 just five years after its creation by President Eisenhower, and continued to advise and mentor the staff of the organization until the final days of his life. Born on September 1, 1927 on a farm in Mingo, Iowa, Charlie enlisted in the U.S. Navy upon his high school graduation, serving in the Pacific and in the post-war Philippines. He returned to the U.S. to study at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service and graduated from St. John's College in Annapolis, Maryland. Charlie is remembered as a consummate professional who loved his work and the people from around the world with whom he had contact. His unfailing kindness, gentleness and decency were his signature. He believed it was a special responsibility, and really an honor, to lead BCIU. This dedication and commitment was felt by the many leading U.S. Ambassadors and policymakers who received his support. BCIU's annual Opera Gala at Lincoln Center was inaugurated during his Presidency and its success and growth was a source of great satisfaction to him. Charlie was particularly enthusiastic about this year's October 12th Gala. We consider it to be a special tribute to Charlie's long and dedicated service to the principles of the BCIU. He is survived by his sister, Cleo Clausing; his nephew, Patrick Lee Hues and his wife; two nieces, Cathy Clausing and Colleen Clausing Bria and her husband and children. He is interred at Ashton Cemetery in Des Moines, Iowa. A ceremony to honor his life will be held at the Yale Club in New York City. Friends are welcome, and should call 212490-0460 for details.

COVEY--Shan Shan Covey began his employment with The Durst Organization on September 6, 1978, was born in Austin, Texas and served in the US Marine Corps. After finishing theatre studies at the University of Texas in Austin in 1967, he traveled and worked in the theatres around the country. He arrived in New York in 1972 to pursue his theatre interests where he directed several plays. While pursuing his theatre career, he was introduced to Douglas Durst and the Durst Portfolio. With his experience directing and designing sets he then began new endeavors working for The Durst Organization. Throughout 29 years as Director of Small Residential and Developmental Properties, Shan worked with Douglas and Jody Durst and 2nd, 3rd and 4th generation Durst family members. As the company developed, so did Shan's responsibilities and expertise. His loyalty and quiet determination to successfully accomplish his goals were unmatched. A man of great character and integrity he always extended equal energy and compassion to his colleagues and friends, even through his extended eight year battle with cancer. He lived his life with great dignity and pride and respected all who he came in contact with. Shan developed long-term meaningful relationships with co-workers, Durst family members, and friends and was consulted on many issues. Shan is survived by his sister Michael Covey Kittredge, brother James P. Covey, and beloved wife, French born, Sylvie Germain Covey. Nearly 30 years ago he and Sylvie met in one of the Durst properties where Sylvie resided and were married in 1984. Shan enjoyed many trips with Sylvie in the US and abroad. Worldly, surprisingly adventurous, Shan enjoyed charitable events in the industry and chats with colleagues about all sorts of issues especially his cowboy boots. The Durst Family and our organization not only remember and respect his achievements and dedication, but also the human qualities that distinguished him as a revered and loyal friend and mentor. Colleagues benefited greatly working with Shan and treasured his guidance and compassion. He will best be remembered as a man with spirit, kindness and joie de vivre. It has been our good fortune to know and work with Shan Covey. Shan made a difference in this world, and he will be deeply missed by all. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, September, 27, 2007 at 5:30pm; Westside Theatre; 407 W. 43rd St, bet 9th and 10th Aves. All are welcome.

What Happened in Norfolk? After reading Alan Berlow's article (Aug. 19) about the confessions that were made in the Norfolk rape-murder investigation, including the comments from the interviewed experts about false confessions (how they are typically elicited; state of mind of the confessor), it seems to me that the ability of the investigator to wield the threat of the death penalty dangerously skews the situation. I hope this can be one more piece of evidence as to why the death penalty should be abolished. Certainly a situation can be imagined in which giving a false confession is preferable to the thought of losing one's life. This story demonstrates that the mere legality of the death penalty can facilitate gross miscarriages of justice even when one is not sentenced to its punishment.

ON THE STEPS OF THE GIRONA CATHEDRAL, MAY 8, 2007 Claude Pasquini, 58, left, an ecological consultant from Rumelange, Luxemburg, with his partner, Christine Baillieux, 44, proprietor of an organic food store. ''I spent a week in Girona because it was my first time in Spain and it seemed to be a good place to stay between Barcelona and Figueres, where the Salvador Dalí museum is. Most of the time, we left Girona in the morning and would go to Barcelona to spend some time there, then the next day go to Figueres, and so on. When we sat on those steps, I tried to imagine Girona in the Middle Ages, how life could have been without cars, Internet, mobile phones. There was one Sunday there called ''Girona in Flowers''; all the museums were free, and among the narrow streets of the medieval town there were little private gardens with beautiful flower sculptures that were open to the public. The whole city was in flowers.'' As told to Austin Considine

MANDELSTAM--Charles Lawrence, 80, of Manhattan and North Salem, NY, died of leukemia on August 31, 2007. He was born July 6, 1927, in Brookline, MA. He was a student at the Mount Hermon School and later a member of its Board of Trustees. After serving in the U.S. Army at the end of WWII, he continued his education via the GI Bill. He was graduated magna cum laude from Harvard College in 1949, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, and Yale Law School in 1952, where he was Comment Editor of the Yale Law Journal. At Yale he met his wife of 50 years, Gloria Messinger Mandelstam (Yale Law School 1954), who for 12 years was the CEO of the American Society of Composers Authors and Publishers (ASCAP). He had a lifelong belief in the rule of the law. His first job was at the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Next he went to Kaye Scholer, then on for 36 years to the firm that became Dornbush, Mensch, Mandelstam & Schaeffer, of which he was a founder and leader. Finally, he moved to McLaughlin & Stern, where he worked until the last months of his life. He represented filmmakers Fred Wiseman and Michael Roemer; architects including Sam Brody, Lewis Davis, and Philip Johnson; psychoanalysts including Marianna Kris and Anna Freud; and authors including Betty Friedan, Gloria Emerson, and Jane Bryant Quinn. He also represented the Marilyn Monroe estate and the Rubin Museum of Art. He was an expert in complex trusts and estates and represented the Aaron Diamond Foundation and the Samuel Rubin Foundation. On behalf of American clients, he provided financial and strategic support to South African lawyers representing anti-apartheid activists. He sued the United States government on behalf of a number of prominent clients to compel production of FBI and CIA documents under the Freedom of Information Act. His interests were broad and diverse; he was always open to new experiences. An enthusiast of French wine and food, he organized in 1970 and led a group that bought a vineyard in Cote Rotie that became Domaine de Bonserine and produced awardwinning vintages. He was instrumental in establishing the North Salem Open Land Foundation, where he worked tirelessly to conserve the natural beauty of the historic rural town he adopted as his second home. An avid photographer, a lover of classical music, and a passionate collector of Mocha pottery, he became an accomplished folk artist in his seventies. A wonderfully devoted husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife; his daughter Emily Mandelstam and son-in-law Paul Engelmayer; his son Peter Mandelstam and daughter-in-law Dawn Drzal; and three grandchildren, Caroline and William Engelmayer and Andrew Mandelstam. He also leaves scores of loving and admiring friends. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 4th at 1:30 pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in his memory be sent to the North Salem Open Land Foundation, P.O. Box 176, North Salem, New York, 10560 or to the Hematology and Medical Oncology Research Fund -Dr. Eric Feldman, New YorkPresbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68 Street, New York, New York, 10065.

It is hard to imagine a tougher year to be a presidential candidate -- or at least, someone managing a presidential campaign. Never before has so much been up in the air so close to the first vote. Even as the campaigns spent the past few days planning for the unofficial kickoff that comes with Labor Day -- rallies, bus trips, house parties, speeches and the like -- they were struggling with what veteran aides described as the most unsettled landscape they can remember. By yesterday, all the major Democratic candidates said they would not campaign in states that move up their primaries in defiance of party rules -- Florida, and in coming days, possibly Michigan, a late-hour reminder that even the schedule of when states vote remains up in the air for both parties.

RUBIN--Doris Konheim, at the age of 95 passed away peacefully at her home on August 29th surrounded by her family. She lived a full and rich life and felt blessed to have experienced this wonderful adventure, which was her life, and to have enjoyed her personal relationships with numerous friends and an extensive family. Doris, the Quintessential New Yorker, took full advantage of the best that our city has to offer. She was a patron of the Arts, supporting many of New Yorks Cultural Centers. In 1989, with her beloved husband of 57 years, Harry Rubin, they founded the Harry and Doris Rubin Lecture Series, an educational endeavor within the American Art Department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Series will continue to be supported by the Rubin Foundation. Doris was one of the original founders of The Manhattan Guild, an organization that was over many decades supported the activities of then young Tel Hashomer Hospital in Israel, now known as the Chiam Sheba Medical Center. She was a loving mother to, Richard, Robert and the late Stephen; a cherished motherin-law to Gail, Polly and Lynne; an adored grandmother to Jeffrey, Michael, David, Joseph and Katherine; and an energetic and affectionate great-grandmother to Sydney, Laura, Rachael, Sasha, Eric and Jalen. Merrill, Jody and Donna Lewen and their families were also an important part of Doris' extended family. She relished being a devoted aunt to many nieces and nephews. RUBIN--Doris. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Doris Rubin, who was a generous Benefactor of the Museum for two decades. Passionate about American art, she was a spirited member of the William Cullen Bryant Fellows of The American Wing and founded, with her late husband, the annual Doris and Harry Rubin Lectures on American Art in 1988. Through the Rubin Foundation, this important forum for the presentation of new scholarly research in American art history will continue. We extend condolences to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chrman. Philippe deMontebello, Dir. Emily K. Rafferty, President RUBIN--Doris. New York lost another great lady in August. Doris Rubin was a true New Yorker who will be missed by many. Anthony Russo

So what did you manage to do this summer? Did you accomplish everything you set out to accomplish back around Memorial Day? Clean your garage? Build a campfire? Paint a wall? Take in a ballgame? Sleep under the stars? If your summer wish list remains unfinished, despair not. You're not alone, as the notes below show. They were gathered by Illegal Art, a collective of artists in New York, which used 6,000 Post-it notes to spell out the words ''To Do'' on windows and billboards across the city. Passers-by were then invited to write on the blank notes, to cover them with descriptions of tasks they hadn't gotten around to this summer. A few of the collected notes appear on today's page, all in their original handwriting -- a catalog of unfinished business, just waiting for fall.

Orange, the color of nasturtiums, is sprouting all over the city as the favorite shade of summer. The Chinese-lacquer color is vividly evident in Boston at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum's annual installation of 20-foot-long nasturtium vines, right, cascading from the third-floor balconies in the garden. At New York's spring galas, women were seen wearing nasturtium-colored evening dresses. One, top right, resembled the Greco-Roman relief at the Gardner. By June and July, the color had become the season's dominant shade on Fifth Avenue.

THE ECHO MAKER, by Richard Powers. (Picador, $15.) Powers's ninth novel, a National Book Award winner, is a brilliant exploration of memory and identity. On a remote Nebraska road, 27-year-old Mark Schluter has a near-fatal car accident. Left with a rare kind of amnesia, Mark cannot recall the emotional connections of his life and believes his sister Karin is an impostor. Stung by his rejection, Karin sends a desperate plea to Gerald Weber, an Oliver Sacks-like neurologist whose popular books have come under critical attack. Our reviewer, Colson Whitehead, said Powers's ''scientific discourses point to how the world works, but the struggles of his characters ... help us understand how we work.'' DEATH'S DOOR: Modern Dying and the Ways We Grieve, by Sandra M. Gilbert. (Norton, $17.95.) Since her husband's death in 1991, Gilbert has written a memoir on the medical misadventures that led to his death, edited an anthology of elegies and collected three volumes of her poems. Drawing on history, literature and contemporary culture -- from the poetry of Walt Whitman to 9/11 -- this book is a sprawling contemplation of mortality and mourning.
The idea of scaling back just seems so offensive to me when you think of the monumental nature of that tragedy.

Tomorrow's schedule should be noticed for what's not on it: the Venus Williams-Jelena Jankovic quarterfinal. The two are in the top half of the draw along with Justine Henin and Serena Williams, who are scheduled for Tuesday night. So conventionally both quarterfinals would be played the same calendar day. Instead, the United States Tennis Association moved Venus-Jelena to Wednesday night, before the Andy Roddick-Roger Federer quarterfinal (that is what they called it even though Federer is playing Lopez later tonight).

The debate should offer lots to chew over, with one big question: Will Mitt Romney directly take on Rudolph W. Giuliani, as he has been doing with increasing frequency on the campaign trail?

SIOUX CITY, Iowa - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton left a couple of things behind in New Hampshire this morning when she left for Iowa: Her vocal support for abortion rights and gay civil unions, both of which she touted in the Granite State but left out of her stump speech here today.

Previously, I wrote about the decline of American men's tennis. Today I'll show there is more to the story. Tennis around the world -- South America and Europe in particular -- is stronger and deeper on the men's side than ever before. In other words, it's not so much a decline in American men's tennis as it is a surge in the quality of tennis worldwide. And this, I believe, is not necessarily a bad thing.

(The "Michigan Who?" T-shirts are already flying off the shelves in Boone.)

A body pulled from the Delaware River was positively identified as the missing father of Orlando Magic guard Jameer Nelson. Floyd Nelson, known as Pete, a 57-year-old welder for a tugboat company, was last seen Thursday working in a dry dock area in Chester, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. The Delaware Medical Examiners office will provide the cause of death and how the body was identified once it finishes its investigation, the police said.

Nigeria and Germany won their quarterfinals at the FIFA Under-17 World Cup yesterday in South Korea, completing a semifinal lineup of four former finalists.Nigeria defeated Argentina, 2-0, to end South American participation in the tournament, while Germany dominated England, 4-1. The Detroit Shock, the defending W.N.B.A. champion, got 24 points from Deanna Nolan and evened the Eastern Conference finals at 1-1 with a 77-63 win over the visiting Indiana Fever yesterday.The Shock is 6-0 when facing elimination in the past two postseasons, and will look to make it 7-0 in the series finale at home tonight.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has filed suit to bar the public sale of two Oscars awarded to the silent film star Mary Pickford (1893-1979), The Associated Press reported. The academy is asserting its right to buy the two Pickford statuettes and one owned by her husband, Buddy Rogers (1904-99), for $10, under bylaws dating from 1950 and in accordance with agreements signed by Oscar winners. When Mr. Rogers died, all three Oscars went to his second wife, Beverly, who died in January, leaving them to her heirs, who are co-executors of her estate. Pickford, above, known as America’s Sweetheart, won the Academy Award for best actress for “Coquette” (1929) and was given an honorary Oscar in 1975. Mr. Rogers won the academy’s Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award in 1986. The academy said one heir asked it for $500,000 in July for one of the Oscars. David W. Quinto, a lawyer for the academy, said, “If the public believes that any multimillionaire can buy an Oscar, then it becomes cheapened.” A call to John Shevlin, a lawyer for the estate of Beverly Rogers, was not immediately returned.

Hundreds of Iranians, given a rare chance to hear live Western music, responded enthusiastically to a performance in Tehran last week by the 60-member Osnabrück Symphony Orchestra of Germany, The Associated Press reported. Its female musicians, above, wore headscarves in accordance with Iranian law. “It was wonderful,” said Sharokh Pourmaymin, a young musician, on Thursday, when the orchestra, led by Herman Baeumer, performed Beethoven’s “Leonore” Overture No. 3, Elgar’s Cello Concerto and Brahms’s Fourth Symphony. “I wish it could be repeated with other kinds of music, such as jazz, blues and rock.” Performances of Western music in Iran have been rare since the Islamic revolution in 1979, and in 2005 President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad banned state radio from playing it. Last week’s concerts received little press coverage, partly because of a three-day holiday when newspapers were not published. The concerts were part of an exchange that took the Tehran Symphony Orchestra to Osnabrück last year. Nader Mashayekhi, the Osnabrück conductor, said last week’s appearance was so successful that he would play host to a similar event next year.

Vaclav Havel withdraws play from Czech theater, Edinburgh festival honors New Yorker, TNT stands fast on “Law & Order” and more culture news.

Vaclav Havel, the former Czech president, has withdrawn his eagerly anticipated new drama from the National Theater in Prague after it refused to allow his wife to play the leading role, The Guardian of London reported. Mr. Havel, right, 70, who retired from the presidency four years ago, maintains that he wrote the play, “Odchazeni” (“Leaving”), for his wife, Dagmar Havlova, and said that if she could not star in it, he would take it to another theater. The play deals with the problems of a former high-ranking politician in surrendering the trappings of power. Although Mr. Havel’s stance has led to accusations that he is being highhanded, he said that he had promised his wife for years that they would collaborate onstage and that she inspired him to write the play. “She was present when I was writing it in the U.S. some months ago,” he said. Referring to the presidency, he said: “She lived alongside me. I wrote it for her. I imagined her being in it.” Ms. Havlova, who called the dispute “undignified and embarrassing,” has independently announced her withdrawal from the production. The National Theater said its policy is not to allow guest actors. The theater’s director, Ondrej Cerny, said, “The National Theater would still like to perform the newest Vaclav Havel drama, and we will try to open new talks.”.

A real “Law & Order” court proceeding may be on the docket in the not too distant future. Undeterred by federal equal time provisions, the cable channel TNT has decided to proceed with broadcasts of that crime drama even if Fred Thompson, who plays District Attorney Arthur Branch, announces, as expected, that he is seeking the presidency, The Associated Press reported. TNT plans to broadcast 23 episodes of the drama this week, although the impending announcement by Mr. Thompson, a Tennessee Republican, prompted NBC to decide to drop “Law & Order” reruns featuring him as of last Saturday. “TNT has no plans to alter its schedule,” said Shirley Powell, a spokeswoman. The equal time rules, requiring broadcasters to provide the same access to opponents when a candidate appears on a broadcast, were written decades ago, and it has never been clear whether the provisions apply to cable, which does not use public airwaves.

DiPASCA--Robert V., M.D. of Fort Salonga, L.I. on August 31, 2007. Beloved husband of Pegge and loving father of Donna (Mark) Eicher, Marcelle (Eric) Sjoman and Anita Coiscou. Cherished grandfather of Kevin Ryan, Mark Peter, Jaclyn, Christine and Stephen. Dear brother and brother-in-law of Vera and the late Gen. Edward S. Branigan, Virginia and the late Roger DiPasca. Dr. DiPasca was a Captain in the U.S. Public Health Service during WWII. He also served as an Assistant Deputy to the Suffolk County Commissioner of Health and had his medical practice in Levittown, L.I. Visiting Wednesday 2-5 and 79pm, Brueggemann Funeral Home 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, L.I. Funeral Mass Thursday 10am at St. Philip Neri R.C. Church, Northport, L.I. Memorials to Fordham University Alumni Association in Dr. DiPasca's name would be appreciated.

MANDELSTAM--Charles Lawrence, 80, of Manhattan and North Salem, NY, died of leukemia on August 31, 2007. He was born July 6, 1927, in Brookline, MA. He was a student at the Mount Hermon School and later a member of its Board of Trustees. After serving in the U.S. Army at the end of WWII, he continued his education via the GI Bill. He was graduated magna cum laude from Harvard College in 1949, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, and Yale Law School in 1952, where he was Comment Editor of the Yale Law Journal. At Yale he met his wife of 50 years, Gloria Messinger Mandelstam (Yale Law School 1954), who for 12 years was the CEO of the American Society of Composers Authors and Publishers (ASCAP). He had a lifelong belief in the rule of the law. His first job was at the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Next he went to Kaye Scholer, then on for 36 years to the firm that became Dornbush, Mensch, Mandelstam & Schaeffer, of which he was a founder and leader. Finally, he moved to McLaughlin & Stern, where he worked until the last months of his life. He represented filmmakers Fred Wiseman and Michael Roemer; architects including Sam Brody, Lewis Davis, and Philip Johnson; psychoanalysts including Marianna Kris and Anna Freud; and authors including Betty Friedan, Gloria Emerson, and Jane Bryant Quinn. He also represented the Marilyn Monroe estate and the Rubin Museum of Art. He was an expert in complex trusts and estates and represented the Aaron Diamond Foundation and the Samuel Rubin Foundation. On behalf of American clients, he provided financial and strategic support to South African lawyers representing anti-apartheid activists. He sued the United States government on behalf of a number of prominent clients to compel production of FBI and CIA documents under the Freedom of Information Act. His interests were broad and diverse; he was always open to new experiences. An enthusiast of French wine and food, he organized in 1970 and led a group that bought a vineyard in Cote Rotie that became Domaine de Bonserine and produced awardwinning vintages. He was instrumental in establishing the North Salem Open Land Foundation, where he worked tirelessly to conserve the natural beauty of the historic rural town he adopted as his second home. An avid photographer, a lover of classical music, and a passionate collector of Mocha pottery, he became an accomplished folk artist in his seventies. A wonderfully devoted husband, father, and grandfather, he is survived by his wife; his daughter Emily Mandelstam and son-in-law Paul Engelmayer; his son Peter Mandelstam and daughter-in-law Dawn Drzal; and three grandchildren, Caroline and William Engelmayer and Andrew Mandelstam. He also leaves scores of loving and admiring friends. Services will be held on Tuesday, September 4th at 1:30 pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in his memory be sent to the North Salem Open Land Foundation, P.O. Box 176, North Salem, New York, 10560 or to the Hematology and Medical Oncology Research Fund -Dr. Eric Feldman, New YorkPresbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68 Street, New York, New York, 10065. MANDELSTAM--Charles, The firm of Dornbush Schaeffer Strongin & Venaglia express their profound sorrow on the loss of their esteemed founding partner and colleague and express their heartfelt sympathy to his wife, their children and grandchildren.

HALDEN--Fred, loving husband of the late Ilse, beloved father of Peter and Judith, favorite-in-law of Lillian and Noel, devoted grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Mariel and BJ, brother of the late John Halden and Gerda Goldmann, also survived by many nieces and nephews as well as countless family members and friends who adored him. Born June 3, 1913, in Halberstadt, Germany, emigrated to the US in February 1936 to escape the Holocaust, carrying with him only a violin and a few architectural drawings. He married Ilse, his childhood sweetheart, September 8, 1938, in New York. Fred and Ilse, who passed away June 8, 2007, would have been married 69 years this week. Fred retired as an architect from Emery, Roth & Sons, the renowned NYC architectural firm, in 1986. Fred will be remembered for his amazing intellect -he did NY Times crossword puzzles in ink -his master of Scrabble, his keen interest in current events, his love of the outdoors, especially al fresco dining, and his eternal devotion to Ilse, the love of his long life. Contributions may be made to Mazon, the Jewish response to hunger. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY, on September 4th at 11am.

After the first set tie breaker, it was over. And while the scoreboard read, 7-6 (3), 6-1, the real score is Justine Henin 3, Serena Williams 0. When Williams dumped a forehand into the net, the top-seeded Henin won their third straight matchup in a Grand Slam quarterfinal this year. Henin, who will face the winner of tomorrow's Venus Williams-Jelena Jankovic match, had 30 winners against 22 errors, while Serena had only 17 winners but 28 errors. A more telling stat: Henin was 11 of 14 at the net, while the eighth-seeded Williams was 5 of 14. The first set lasted 61 minutes, the second, 36.

Mark Bittman shows how to make paella with a lot less.

Start emptying the stands. Novak Djokovic picked up the pace and routed No. 23 Juan Monaco in the fourth set to win their fourth-round match, 7-5, 7-6 (7), 6-7 (6), 6-1, Tuesday evening. The match lasted 3 hours 53 minutes and delayed the start of the highly anticipated Justine Henin-Serena Williams quarterfinal in the women's draw. Open officials must now clear Ashe Stadium of its day-session spectators before herding 23,000 night ticket-holders through the turnstiles. Officials just announced that the women will walk onto the court at 8:09 p.m.

The best laid plans of mice and men often go awry. The U.S.T.A. and USA Network had scheduled the quarterfinal between No. 1 Justine Henin and No. 8 Serena Williams to go on the air at 7 p.m., with the Open's much-anticipated match starting about 20 minutes later. But No. 3 Novak Djokovic and Juan Monaco are still on court. And it's not even close to being over. Monaco, a 23-year-old Argentinian seeded No. 23, survived the most unlikely wardrobe malfunction to save a match point and win a third-set tiebreaker, 8-6. Djokovic won the first two sets, 7-5, 7-6 (7).

Patrick McEnroe, the captain of the United States Davis Cup team, announced today that Andy Roddick and James Blake would play at Sweden in a semifinal later this month. Roddick and Blake, the top-ranked American players, will be playing on a fast hardcourt, similar to the Open's surface. While the United States and Sweden face off in one semifinal in Gothenburg, Sept. 21-23, Germany will head to Russia for the other.

It's official. Today Gov. Jennifer Granholm of Michigan signed a bill moving up the state's presidential primary to Jan. 15, 2008, saying that the earlier date would "lead to greater emphasis on issues that matter to all Americans."

Brian De Palma's factish concoction "Redacted," now thrilling Venice audiences with scenes of American atrocities in Iraq, may restore relevancy to the minister of "Scarface." But what Mr. De Palma may really inspire audiences to do is not to watch his patchwork film, but to make their own.

Instantly you feel that you've hit the restaurant when it isn't in full stride, and all of a sudden you think: maybe I did want the grouper.

Some are already looking ahead to a possible Nadal-Djokovic semifinal and the even more tantalizing prospect of either one battling the world's best player, who is unlikely to don his Darth Federer getup if he reaches the daytime final.

Before the start of the Labor Day weekend, I was making the rounds at designers' studios. Beautiful colors at Chris Benz, a practical sportswear scheme at Phillip Lim. At Ohne Titel, after looking at the pale minimalist knits and tailoring, I pushed the elevator button and out came a horde of models, like frat boys falling out of a phone booth. Narciso Rodriguez was in the middle of fittings when I stopped by his studio near Union Square. His partnership with Liz Claiborne is really beginning to make a difference. It means more workers and pattern makers in his sample room. It means having access to great fabrics and embroideries again. Two looks for his spring collection caught my eye: a sweet shirt dress in burnt orange silk with a kimono-like neckline and a short flaring skirt, and a slim gray pantsuit with a narrow-shoulder jacket that had a coy double effect at the hem. The shapes were new, the fit perfect. Oh, what a difference a little money makes. I know expectations are high for his show (on Sept. 9), and in reality we probably won't see the full weight of the Liz deal for at least another six months, but Rodriguez is certainly in a better position today.

Seminoles fans aren't happy this morning after last night's disappointing loss in Death Valley.While the focus was on Bobby and Tommy Bowden last night, Dave George of The Palm Beach Post couldn't help but think of Jeff Bowden during Clemson's 24-18 victory over Florida State.
There was no Labor Day rest for MetroPCS Communications and its advisers, who spent the holiday weekend cooking up a $5.1 billion deal.

European regulators have long argued that merging Suez and the state-owned Gaz de France would hinder efforts to open up the continent's energy markets. Now it seems like their concerns are proving true more than ever.

Though tradition holds that the Labor Day weekend marks the official start of the presidential campaign, that rule clearly doesn't apply to the 2008 election cycle. As the race heated up over months and months of campaigning ,we've heard quite a bit from the Democratic and Republican hopefuls who are vying for the White House. But, what about the voters?

After a federal judge ruled last Thursday that Bear Stearns cannot liquidate two of its troubled hedge funds in the Caribbean, in what The Deal calls a first for a Chapter 15 bankruptcy case, the investment bank faces a hard choice: go through a Chapter 7 or 11 bankruptcy filing, or decide it doesn't need a proceeding in the United States.

A bill that would affect much of the private equity industry by raising taxes on carried interest has a "good shot at passing in the House before year's end," The Washington Post reported Tuesday. But its prospects in the Senate are not as strong, the newspaper said.

For those who managed to enjoy an actual holiday on Labor Day, here's the the big news on the Democratic side of election '08: John Edwards snagged the endorsements of the United Steelworkers and United Mine Workers unions. Mike Allen at The Politico calls it a "surprise announcement" that "gives Edwards the largest bloc of formal labor support among the Democratic presidential candidates." Well, surprising or not, will it be enough to keep Edwards competitive?

Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers are likely to serve up some messy results when investment banks begin reporting earnings later this month, The Financial Times's Lex column wrote Monday. But the pain won't end there, Lex said.

J.C. Flowers, the private equity firm, is pursuing the 38 percent stake in WestLB held by the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia, Reuters reported Monday citing unnamed sources. NRW's government, which wants to sell the stake, has already spoken with J.C. Flowers, Reuters' sources said.
Justine Henin knocked off Serena Williams while Rafael Nadal was upset by David Ferrer to highlight day 9 at the U.S. Open.
Members of Congress return to Washington today and immediately get down to business, starting a month likely to be dominated by clashes over Iraq policy and federal spending.
Ten award-winning entries from The Dogan International Cartoon Competition, which celebrates the work of 1,200 artists from 90 countries.

Telkom South Africa may sell the rest of a mobile-phone venture, the nation's biggest, to the Vodafone Group and dispose of its fixed-line unit to the MTN Group. Telkom South Africa said in a statement that it was in talks with Vodafone and MTN over "mobile strategy."
The South African casino operator Gold Reef Resorts agreed to be acquired by a group including Ethos Private Equity and Goldman Sachs for 34 rand a share, or about 9.85 billion rand ($1.37 billion).

D.E. Shaw has more than halved its stake in the clothing retailer The Children's Place. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, D.E. Shaw shed hundreds of thousands of shares at the end of August, reducing its stake to about 4.1 percent from 9.7 percent.
General Electric has reportedly joined Goldman Sachs in a 4 billion pound ($8 billion) bid for Southern Water, which supplies about 1 million households in southeast England.
General Electric has agreed to buy a British oilfield services firm, Sondex, for 288.7 million pounds ($583.1 million) in cash, the two firms said on Monday.

Franklin Templeton Investments, which manages $621 billion in assets, has bought 25 percent of Dubai's Algebra Capital and wants to grow its business in Arab markets, it said on Tuesday. Franklin Templeton is a unit of Franklin Resources , the fourth-largest publicly traded fund manager in the United States.

Top money managers earn such huge incomes that even when their compensation is mixed with the much lower pay of clerks, secretaries and others, the average pay in investment banking is 10 times that of all private sector jobs, new government data shows.

Despite the recent gloom surrounding the credit markets, mergers and acquisitions may set a worldwide record of more than $3.57 trillion before this year ends. Bloomberg News said that bankers specializing in mergers and acquisitions need to drum up only $486 billion in transactions during the next four months to generate fee revenue of more than $11 billion for the first time.

Shares in Barclays topped the list of London gainers Monday, as investors eyed comments from the banking group's president that appeared to soothe recent worries about the amount of subprime exposure on the bank's books.

Grauman's Chinese Theatre, a Hollywood landmark that attracts millions of tourists each year to its outdoor courtyard where generations of movie stars left their hand and footprints, has been purchased by Hollywood's largest commercial landlord.
Nestle pushed its rapid expansion in the bottled water business forward on Tuesday by agreeing to take over a Swiss bottler, Henniez , in a deal valued at 155 million Swiss francs ($128.3 million).
Dailymotion, the French answer to YouTube, has raised $34 million in second round funding from a consortium of investors led by AGF Private Equity and Advent Venture Partners.

The chairman of Sainsbury's and Delta Two, the Qatar-backed fund considering a 10 billion pound ($20 billion) takeover of the supermarket chain, are likely to meet again this week as the two sides inch toward an agreement that would allow the potential bidder due-diligence access to Sainsbury's books, The Guardian reported.
The Nasdaq Stock Market has given potential bidders for its 31 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange until Friday to express their interest, according to media reports.
The Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli is considering buying Campbell Soup's Godiva Chocolatier brand, its chief executive told the Financial Times Deutschland newspaper.

As banks, private equity firms and hedge funds eye deals for leveraged loans amid the credit crunch, deal-seekers are also reportedly circling Canada's asset-backed commercial paper market, seeking to snap up securities on the cheap from distressed sellers.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange is making plans for an initial public offering. Wu Rong-I, who took over the chairmanship of the exchange two months ago, told FinanceAsia that work had started on consolidating the Taiwan exchange, The Gre Tai Securities Market, otherwise known as the OTC market; The Taiwan Depositary and Clearing Corporation; and the Taiwan Futures Exchange, into one corporate entity.
Google is apparently becoming a thorn in the side of venture capitalists.

HSBC said Monday that it has agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Korea Exchange Bank from the U.S. private equity firm Lone Star Funds for about $6.3 billion in cash as it attempts to increase its profile in South Korea.

IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the German bank that is being bailed out after being hurt by its investments in subprime loans in the United States, said Monday that it would post a loss of as much as 700 million euros, or about $950 million, this fiscal year.

Sony will sell about 332 billion yen ($2.9 billion) of shares in its insurance unit in Japan's biggest initial public offering this year, raising funds to invest in the consumer electronics and games divisions. The electronics maker will sell 725,000 shares, or 34.5 percent of Sony Financial Holdings, and the unit will offer 75,000 new shares, according to a statement Tuesday.

As predictions continue of job cuts at Wall Street banks and their international counterparts, The Financial Times reports that the tally of layoffs will come to about 10-15 percent of their staff across the board, as turmoil in the markets takes its toll on revenues.

The European Union's ambitions to open its energy sector to greater competition were dealt a fresh blow Monday after the French state-owned company Gaz de France announced that it would merge with the utility Suez to create one of the world's largest energy groups.

All summer, bankers have sweated on Wall Street. Instead of spending time at the golf course or at their summer houses, many found themselves in the office trying to make sense of the credit market shutdown that had left their companies responsible for the billions of dollars used to finance leveraged buyouts, yet facing uncertain prospects of getting investors to take some of the debt off their hands.

Private equity firms are setting records in the size of Asian buyout funds, adding to an existing pool of more than $35 billion that is waiting to be invested in deals in the region, according to industry participants and analysts.

Manfred Wennemer, the chief executive of the German auto parts maker Continental, which clinched an 11.4 billion euro ($15.5 billion) deal for Siemens VDO in late July, now faces the challenge of integrating a company almost as big as his own at a time when such transformational deals are out of favor. That is especially true in Germany, where DaimlerChrysler is in the process of becoming Daimler again.

ATLANTA, Sept. 3 (AP) — Maybe it was the heat. Perhaps it was a carry-over from a bad loss to the Florida Marlins. Whatever it was, Ryan Howard and Aaron Rowand could not make contact, and the Philadelphia Phillies lost again.

A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the limited television audience for Appalachian State’s college football upset of Michigan on the fledgling Big Ten Network referred incorrectly to the TV coverage of another game involving a Big Ten team. Michigan State’s victory against Alabama-Birmingham was on ESPN2, not the Big Ten Network.

The San Diego Journal article on Aug. 22 about the influx of Arizona residents into Southern California as summer guests referred incorrectly in some copies to one area near San Diego that is a popular destination. Coronado is a peninsula, not an island (although it is referred to colloquially as such).

Coronado is a peninsula, not an island (although it is referred to colloquially as such).
Police say a married man and woman organized the rape of young women and subsequent sold their babies to childless couples.
Parliamentary elections that will determine who will be prime minister got under way after being delayed by Hurricane Dean.
Police officers fired water cannons and rubber bullets at about 500 protesters in Soweto after crowds gathered in two neighborhoods to complain about municipal services.
A 25-year-old Vatican gendarme was found dead of a gunshot wound in a barracks bathroom, apparently a suicide, the Vatican said.

Svenska Cellulosa, Europe’s biggest tissue maker, named Jan Johansson chief executive, succeeding Jan Aastroem, who will step down in a surprise reshuffle of top management. Mr. Johansson, 52, is currently chief of the copper company Boliden. He will join Svenska Cellulosa, based in Stockholm and known as SCA, within three months, the company said. The finance chief, Lennart Persson, will be the acting chief in the meantime. During Mr. Aastroem’s five-year tenure, SCA’s shares gained 7.2 percent, trailing the 60 percent jump in Sweden’s OMX Index, as industry overcapacity weighed on tissue prices and earnings. Mr. Aastroem cut 3,600 jobs and closed 20 production lines to restore profitability. Boliden’s stock more than quadrupled during Mr. Johansson’s six years as chief. At SCA, Mr. Johansson has been given a mandate to expand in China and other emerging markets.

IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the bank that is being bailed out after investing in subprime loans, will post a loss of up to 700 million euros, or $954 million, for the fiscal year. The chief executive, Günther Bräunig, said during a conference call that the bank would curtail investments in international securities financed by commercial paper, a type of short-term business loan, and that it expected future earnings to be “significantly lower.” The bank had a profit of 179.6 million euros in the year that ended March 31. The government-owned KfW development bank and the German banking associations agreed to cover some losses at IKB after rising defaults on home loans hurt the value of mortgage-backed securities.

Telkom South Africa may sell the rest of a mobile-phone venture, the nation’s biggest, to Vodafone Group and dispose of its fixed-line unit to the MTN Group. Telkom South Africa said in a statement that it was in talks with Vodafone and MTN over “mobile strategy.” Telkom, which has a market value of about 103.4 billion rand ($14.4 billion), declined to give details. MTN and Vodafone confirmed the discussions in separate statements. The sales would effectively dismantle what was until last year a monopoly over fixed-line phone services in South Africa. They also would give the government an exit from its investment in Telkom. South Africa owns about 38 percent of the company.

The food giant H. J. Heinz, one of Zimbabwe’s first major foreign investors, sold its Zimbabwe interests to Cottco, a government-controlled cotton company. Cottco paid $6.8 million for Heinz’s 49 percent stake in Olivine Industries, a Zimbabwe company that makes fats, edible oils and soaps. The government previously shared ownership of Olivine with Heinz. Industry executives dismissed reports in the state media that called the Heinz deal the first in a much-publicized program by the government to take over white-controlled businesses. The executives said the deal was in negotiation months before plans were announced by President Robert G. Mugabe this year to force all businesses to yield 51 percent of their ownership to black Zimbabweans, a campaign the government calls “indigenization.” Heinz was one of the first major foreign investors after independence in 1980.

The South African casino operator Gold Reef Resorts agreed to be acquired by a group including Ethos Private Equity and Goldman Sachs for 34 rand a share, or about 9.85 billion rand ($1.37 billion). Gold Reef, which operates the Gold Reef City theme park and casino in Johannesburg and other casinos and hotels around the country, said after markets had closed that the deal implied an enterprise value of 11.6 billion rand. The company said Aug. 13 it was in exclusive talks with the buyout group, which also includes Gold Reef management and black investors, though Goldman Sachs’s involvement was not disclosed at the time. Goldman Sachs and Nedbank Corporate have agreed to provide financing for the deal.

Germany’s biggest industrial union, IG Metall, nominated Berthold Huber, 57, left, a top union deputy for four years, to take over as its leader later this year. The current leader, Jürgen Peters, has said he will not seek re-election in November when his term expires, the union said. IG Metall has 2.3 million members representing a broad range of workers in Germany’s key manufacturing sector. Earlier this year, it secured a pay increase of 4.1 percent this year and another 1.7 percent next year for manufacturing workers. It went into talks demanding a 6.5 percent raise.

HSBC Holdings, Europe’s biggest bank, agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Korea Exchange Bank for $6.3 billion as it attempts to bolster its presence in the fast-growing Asian market. The purchase of the stake from the United States private equity group Lone Star Funds would allow Lone Star, based in Dallas, to exit a controversial investment. HSBC, based in London, said that it did not intend to make an offer for the remainder of the Korean bank’s shares and that the bank would remain listed on the Korea Exchange. The acquisition would catapult HSBC past its foreign rivals Standard Chartered and Citigroup. Both have bested HSBC in the past in purchasing local banks during the post-Asian crisis turmoil. A local court in South Korea has been investigating allegations that Lone Star manipulated the stock price of the Korean bank’s credit card unit in 2003 so that the bank could take it over at a lower price.

Amid tributes to a Spanish player who died and to victims of the Greek wildfires, Sevilla routed host AEK Athens, 4-1, to reach the group stage of the European Champions League yesterday.The game originally was scheduled for last week but was postponed when Sevilla midfielder Antonio Puerta died Aug. 28 after collapsing during a game three days earlier. AEK had also requested a postponement because of wildfires in southern Greece that killed 65 people and caused a national state of emergency.

Paolo Bettini won the third stage of the Vuelta a España yesterday, and Óscar Freire held on to the overall leader’s gold jersey. Bettini held off a late surge from Freire, who was second with the same time of 4 hours 8 minutes 42 seconds.

Dirk Nowitzki had 35 points and 11 rebounds in Germany’s 83-78 overtime victory against the Czech Republic on the opening day of the European championships in Madrid. Pau Gasol scored 19 points as host Spain routed Portugal, 82-56, in Seville to begin its campaign to become the third country to win the European trophy while holding the world title. Greece, the defending champion, opened with a 76-66 win over Israel in Granada.

The Chinese men took a commanding lead in the world championships in Stuggart, Germany, as they finished with 374.275 points, a whopping 3.550 points ahead of Japan, the Olympic champion. The Chinese have a 12.1-point lead on Russia, a gap so big the Russians would need an extra routine to catch up.

Appalachian State’s 34-32 upset victory over Michigan on Saturday, which was seen only by viewers of the new Big Ten Network, will be replayed tonight on 13 Fox Sports Net affiliates around the country. In the New York area, the game will be seen on Fox Sports New York from 10:30 p.m. to 12:30 a.m., and will be augmented by an interview with Jerry Moore, the head coach of Appalachian State.

Deanna Nolan scored 20 of her franchise playoff-record 30 points in the first half to help the defending champion Detroit Shock advance to the W.N.B.A. finals with an 81-65 victory over the visiting Indiana Fever in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals. The Shock will face Phoenix starting tomorrow night as it goes for its third title in five years.

NEW AMERICAN TERMINAL American Airlines opened the final phase of its $1.3 billion terminal at Kennedy International Airport, which has 1.5 million square feet and a Customs and Immigration center capable of processing 1,600 arriving international passengers an hour, 400 more than the old terminal that was phased out. As part of American’s announced focus on attracting more business travelers, the terminal has two Admirals Club lounges and a new Flagship arrivals lounge, which is open to certain first-class passengers.
As my career has progressed, playing golf has evolved from being a good way to entertain clients to something of a savior.

8 P.M. (CMT) DALE They called him the Intimidator. And his No. 3 black Chevrolet was the car to beat. This two-hour documentary chronicles the life, on and off the track, of Dale Earnhardt, left, one of the most revered drivers in Nascar history. Paul Newman narrates this film, which uses archival race footage, never-before-seen home movies and interviews with family members, friends, fans and Mr. Earnhardt, who died in a crash on the last lap of the 2001 Daytona 500. In “Dale Pre-Show: His Greatest Comeback,” at 7, the country music stars Kix Brooks and Ronnie Dunn reminisce about Mr. Earnhardt and relive his dramatic victory at Talladega in 2000.
Women whose ovaries are removed before menopause may be at increased risk for dementia, a new study reports.
