For those who’d like to leaf peep while breaking a sweat, some prime mountain biking rides happen to be top spots for autumn’s colorful trees. One of the latest trails to earn an Epic Ride status, the highest designation from the International Mountain Bicycling Association, is the High Country Pathway in northern Michigan. The 80-mile route loops through groves of old-growth beech and maple trees in the Pigeon River Country State Forest, home to the largest elk herd east of the Mississippi. Riders may try to finish the route in a single day, stop to camp overnight, or find a mattress at one of the inns and lodges along the way. Short on time, or a bit less ambitious? Try the 14-mile Shingle Mill Pathway, a part of the High Country Pathway. Find trailheads east of Vanderbilt, Mich., and keep in mind that early elk-hunting season takes place Sept. 15-18.

After decades of renting props to movie and television stylists, Kuttner, a Manhattan company that opened shortly after World War II, originally as an antiques store, is shutting down. Its entire inventory of furniture, paintings, household accessories and dinnerware -- including silver and crystal -- will be auctioned at the shop on Sept. 18, with previews on Sept. 16 and 17. Merchandise includes an assortment of 19th-century American furniture, above, 17th- and 18th-century creamware, blue-and-white export ware and a large selection of Wedgwood drabware, prized by the likes of Martha Stewart. Bids may be made in advance at (203) 327-2227 or stamfordauctiongallery.com; there are no reserves. Kuttner is at 601 West 26th Street, (212) 242-7969. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

ZUK--Judith D. (Judy) The Trustees, Officers and staff of The Green-Wood Cemetery mourn the passing of Judy Zuk, a Trustee and good friend of the Cemetery since 1994. Judy's expertise in horticulture, environmental education, botanical research and plant conservation was a tremendous benefit to the Cemetery and its unique place in the history of the City of New York. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Judy's family. By Order of the Board of Trustees of The Green-Wood Cemetery ZUK--Judith. The Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of Judith Zuk. Judy was an inspiration to public gardeners throughout New York City and beyond. She enlivened an already fine, cherished botanical garden, introducing conservation and collaboration into all its programs, thus reaffirming the importance of gardens in American culture. Her passion for plants and gardening was matched by her warmth and caring for people. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and colleagues at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Wilson Nolen, Chairman of the Board Gregory Long, President

PETRIE--Bernard, in San Francisco, on August 26, 2007, just before his 82nd birthday. Son of the late Yetta Fridman and the late Milton Petrie, nationally known retailer and philanthropist. Bernard was a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point and the University of Michigan Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. After serving as an associate at major law firms in New York City and San Francisco, he served as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Northern District of California. Thereafter he practiced in his own law office for over forty-five years. He led an active social life, and his annual Bastille Day party was notable. He involved himself in many community activities. He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the San Francisco Symphony, as a member of the Board of Visitors of Stanford Law School, as a member of the California Judicial Nominees Evaluation Commission, and on several committees of the Bar Association of San Francisco. At the time of his death he was a member of the Committee of visitors of the University of Michigan Law School, and a Trustee of the New York University School of Law. He was a Fellow of the American Bar Association, and a member of the American Law Institute, and the State Bar of California. He was a past president of the Smith Kettlewell Eye Research Institute, and a life member of the California Tennis Club. He is survived by his half sister Patricia Hugenberg of Belvedere, and her son, Kurt, and by his half sister Marianne Miller of Greenwich, Connecticut, and her son, Matthew. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 4, 2007, at 4:00pm at the Presidio Officer's Club. petriememorial@yahoo.com Donations to the charity of your choice in honor of Bernard's memory are welcome.

Resident of Saltaire, Fire Island since 1968. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Thomas Circle Singers, www. thomascirclesingers.org, 202232-3354. A memorial service for family and friends is being planned.

Reveal, a device that creates the illusion of light coming through a window that isn't actually there, is the brainchild of Adam Frank, a Brooklyn designer. He calls it ''a way to use images to alter our perception of space and architecture,'' a complicated explanation for a simple idea: a small projector mounted on a wall or ceiling, casting an image that looks like the shadow of a mullioned window and a tree onto a nearby wall. Air blown through the projector ruffles dangling pieces of steel inside, making the tree appear to sway and compounding the trompe l'oeil effect. Reveal, below, which was produced in a limited run of 1,000, sells for $380. Information and orders: adamfrank.com. JULIE TARASKA

Mater, a new home accessories company in Copenhagen, is introducing its first collection tomorrow at the Maison et Objet design fair in Paris. Henrik Marstrand, Mater's founder, said it is ''about timeless, alluring design'' -- he hired Thomas Lykke, a former Wallpaper magazine editor, as a consulting creative director -- but the company has another agenda as well. Mr. Marstrand promises to improve the working conditions at the factories that make his products in China, Vietnam and India by developing new safety procedures, for example, and improvements for worker housing. Customers will be able to monitor the program's progress at the company's Web site, where reports from independent auditors will be posted twice a year. Mater's first collection of more than 20 products by European and American designers includes (from top) the High stool (about $1,100) by Space, a Danish design firm; Tod Bracher's InOut pitcher (about $120); and a wood bowl (about $500). The collection will be available in November. The first quality-of-life report, on the company's Chinese factory, will be posted late this month. Information: www.materdesign.com. ARIC CHEN

10 P.M. (Bravo) TIM GUNN'S GUIDE TO STYLE Watch out, Stacy London and Clinton Kelly. Mr. Gunn, the secret weapon of ''Project Runway,'' and his sidekick, the model Veronica Webb, left, are stepping onto your ''What Not to Wear'' turf in this new makeover series -- a gentler version of that TLC show. The premise is similar: a fashion failure is forced to make a nearly clean sweep of her closet by dividing its contents into tossers, menders, giveaways and just a few keepers. She is then taken shopping by Ms. Webb and Mr. Gunn, who culls advice from his book ''Tim Gunn: A Guide to Quality Taste and Style.'' In tonight's premiere he advises Rebecca Pennino of Hoboken, N.J. The worst part (or the best, given the outcome): opening up her lingerie drawer to Ms. Webb. 8 P.M. (NBC) N.F.L. WIESEN--Patricia Ann (nee Elfers), died in peace and with grace at home in Greenwich, CT on September 4, 2007 surrounded by family. She is survived by her devoted husband of 57 years, Donald G. Wiesen, her five daughters, Mary Patricia (Mara), Caitlin, Elizabeth, Anne, and Megan, seven grandchildren and her brother, William Elfers. Born August 30, 1929, Patricia attended Manhattanville College and graduated cum laude from Columbia University in 1952. She later received a Masters Degree in Counseling from the University of Bridgeport and volunteered her services at the Christian Counseling Center in Norwalk. Her other volunteer commitments included being a member of the NYC Commission to the United Nations, Vice-Chairman of the East Side International Community Center, member of the Board of Trustees of Greenwich Academy where her daughters attended school, and Representative to the Greenwich RTM. A Dame of the Order of Malta, Patricia served with her husband as the first co-hospitaller of the Order in Connecticut. Together they established school tutoring programs for the Dioceses of Bridgeport and a Eucharistic Ministry to hospitals in Connecticut. Patricia made 16 pilgrimages to Lourdes assisting the sick. She served as co-chair pilgrimage in 1992. Visiting hours are Friday, September 7 from 6-8pm at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. A funeral mass will be held Saturday, September 8 at 12:30 pm at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Shake-A-Leg, Inc., P.O. Box 1264, Newport, RI 02840.

IN a sport where stillness, patience and deftness count, having tools within arm's reach is a must. Yet fly fisherman have been wrestling with backpacks, dropping rods and wading back to shore for years, all in the name of performing simple tasks like tying on a new fly. No wonder so many anglers wax on about the one that got away. In an effort to streamline the gear and the sport, manufacturers have been retooling the traditional canvas fly-fishing vest, creating what are essentially wearable workstations. Following on the high-tech heels of other outdoor gear makers, they are incorporating breathable fabrics, waterproof zippers, rod holders, built-in backpacks and even hydration systems. David Ellerstein, the owner and head guide of Jackson Hole Anglers in Jackson, Wyo., field-tested five new models. JESSICA CASSITY

YESSELMAN--Esther, died at 94, in Boca Raton, Florida, September 5, 2007. Wife of the late Sam Yesselman, beloved mother of Robert and Jay, and her daughter-in-law Lynn Hinerman and granddaughters Blaine and Tessa. Her fierce devotion to her family will never be forgotten.

New photographs by Andy Freeberg take aim at the ''architecture of intimidation'' practiced in the galleries of Chelsea in Manhattan, as one gallery owner, James Danziger, put it. These luminous, comical and slyly trenchant studies of the front desks of big names (and desks) in the art world -- including (clockwise from top left) Andrea Rosen, Metro Pictures, Sonnabend and, behind Mr. Freeberg, Cheim & Read -- are on view in a show called ''Sentry'' at Mr. Danziger's own Chelsea gallery. The first photo was unstaged, Mr. Freeberg said recently. ''I was in Pace Wildenstein, this massive space with this massive desk,'' he said, ''and all you could see was the top of the head of the person sitting behind it. It seemed like the desks had gotten bigger since my last visit. I took the picture without them ever knowing I'd done it.''

BLITZER--Edward H. R., 91, died September 4 at home in NYC after a walk in Central Park. Husband of Nancy Mayers Blitzer; father of David (Judi), and Alfred (Beth), grandfather of Mark (Lauren), Julie and TJ. Memorial Service Sunday September 9 at 11am Cornell Club, 6 East 44th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Center for Defense Information, Central Park Conservancy, or the Nature Conservancy.

SCHABERG--Helen Margaret, nee Baenziger, 89, of Sparta, faithfully adored and beloved wife of Dr. Frank J. Schaberg for 67 years; devoted mother of Catherine, Frank, Helen, Nancy, John, and Paul; cherished motherin-law of Stanley, Monica, John, Michael, and Patti; much loved grandmother of 12 and great-grandmother of eight. Helen, known as ''Sunny'' since childhood her irrepressibly optimistic disposition and radiant smile, personified that name for the rest of her life. A 1939 graduate of Holy Name Hospital School of Nursing, she met her future husband Frank while he was an intern at that hospital, from where they began a lifelong devoted partnership. She was universally admired for her ability to manage their professional life, personnel life, and simultaneously raise six children in their Hackensack and Sparta homes. Her family always came first. She instilled in them her joy for living and appreciation for the arts and was a best friend, guardian and protector to her husband and children. She was able to tap into and nourish her spouses and each of her children's talents and never once allowed her unfaltering love to go unspoken or undemonstrated, a tradition she continued with her grandchildren. Her style and disarming wit belied a quiet strength, and unselfish dedication to others. Helen loved ballroom dancing, was a gracious hostess, and very accomplished at the piano, needlework, and cooking. When her physical ailments prevented her from pursuing some of these interests, she still thought only of others' comfort and enjoyment. She was always so much fun, and words cannot express how much we will miss her. Friends may call Thursday and Friday from 2-4, 7-9 pm at the Goble Funeral Home, 22 Main St., Sparta, NJ 07871. A funeral mass will be held on Saturday at 10am at Blessed Kateri Tekakwitha Church, 427 Stanhope Rd., Sparta. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in her memory to: Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Gift Processing Center, PO Box 96268, Washington, DC 20077-7487.

The Bergere two-seater sofa is an amalgam of people, places and styles. Designed by Autoban, an architectural and interiors company in Istanbul, it is manufactured by De La Espada, a company with factories in Spain and Portugal. Its style was inspired by a classic French armchair, the bergère, with a nod to the American wing chair, so it goes with many styles of furniture. It is available in walnut or oak, with wool or leather upholstery (in oak with wool it is $3,895, and in walnut with leather, above, $4,595), and can also be ordered as an armchair ($2,995 to $3,495). At De La Espada stores including the one at 33 Greene Street (Grand Street), (212) 625-1039; information: delaespada.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

RAU--Maryjane U., September 3, 2007. Born January 24th, 1920, Mountain Lakes, NJ. Deceased, Bellport, NY. Married in 1944 to Dr. R. Ronald Rau, Physicist, retired from Brookhaven National Laboratory. Masters degree from Stony Brook University; Teacher, English, at Dowling College, Oakdale, NY and in Beijing, China; Student, Union Theological Seminary, NYC. Organizer with Phyllis Vineyard, Planned Parenthood Clinic, Patchogue, NY; Volunteer with League of Women Voters. A lover of books, traveling, and the arts. Indomitable spirit leaves devoted husband, Ronnie, daughters Whitney Rau Kitts and Littie Elise Rau, son-in-law Rick Kitts, grandchildren Omni and Evan Kitts, nieces Anne Drapin and Bobbi Stonebridge, and full reign of the house to Bella. Commemorative gathering to be held at family's residence on September 29, 2007. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your favorite charity in honor of Maryjane. Family invites your memories via Guest Book online at Legacy.com.

In 1907, many of the world's best players met in Carlsbad, Czech Republic, to compete in one of the strongest tournaments organized to that point. The participants included Aron Nimzowitsch, author of "My System," the book articulating modern principals of the game; Karl Schlecter, who tied a match for the world championship against Emmanuel Lasker in 1910; Frank Marshall, U.S. champion 1909-36; and Mikhail Chigorin, the founder of the Soviet School of Chess, among others.

Because, apparently, regular polls don't give vague enough snapshots of Americans' political opinions, Gallup has now conducted a survey of attitudes on the presidential candidates using a "feeling thermometer" rating scale. "Only one -- Barack Obama -- stirs up warm feelings in a majority of Americans," the study found. "However, Rudy Giuliani, Hillary Clinton, John Edwards, and John McCain are all close to Obama in favorability. Clinton's image is the most polarized of this group: nearly as many Americans say she leaves them cold as say they feel warmly toward her."

The defending Super Bowl champions picked up where they left off on Thursday night, stumping Drew Brees, Reggie Bush and the New Orleans Saints.

All public schools in Paterson will be closed today after the fire department closed about half of thembecause of imminent fire hazards, affecting 30,000 students from kindergarten through high school. According to the fire department officials, 49 of the 52 Paterson public schools have fire code violations. Of the 49, 26 of them were deemed imminent hazards and closed by the Deputy Chief Michael Muccio yesterday. Violations were noted during summer inspections, but were not adequately addressed in time for the first day of school yesterday, a fire official said.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 6 (AP) — Brian Brohm threw for a career-high 401 yards and 5 touchdowns and Anthony Allen added a team-record 275 yards rushing and two scores as No. 8 Louisville avoided a major upset by holding off Middle Tennessee, 58-42, on Thursday night.
Thousands of job seekers showed up to fill positions as ushers, janitors, bartenders and cooks at the $300 million Prudential Center Arena scheduled to open next month.

An article yesterday about the Marine Corps’ formal reprimand of Maj. Gen. Richard A. Huck, Col. R. Gary Sokoloski and Col. Stephen W. Davis for their failure to investigate thoroughly the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians by a group of enlisted men in the town of Haditha two years ago misstated Colonel Sokoloski’s responsibilities at the time. He was General Huck’s chief of staff, not his legal adviser.

An article in Business Day on Monday about Microsoft’s efforts to let its Windows operating system connect more smoothly with an array of Internet services, misstated the name of the company’s open document format. It is Office Open XML, not Open Office XML.

A sports article on Aug. 27 about Hideki Okajima, an All-Star relief pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, misstated the nickname of a professional team he once played for in Japan, Hokkaido Nippon-Ham. It is the Fighters, not the Ham Fighters. (The error first appeared on Feb. 27 in an article about Okajima.).

An article on Saturday about a former homeless man, Arthur Pass, misidentified the outreach program that helped turn his life around, and referred incorrectly to James McCloskey, who counseled him. The program is the Street to Home Initiative — not the Common Ground Community, an umbrella group overseeing the home initiative. And Mr. McCloskey is the deputy director of the Street to Home Initiative, not the director of the umbrella group.

An article on July 19 about John Edwards’s tour of poverty-stricken areas of Appalachia included a debatable reference to Robert F. Kennedy, whom Mr. Edwards praised for his work on poverty issues. The statement that Mr. Kennedy had “appeared headed” for the Democratic presidential nomination after winning the California primary in 1968 was speculation, not established fact. A reader raised the point in an e-mail message the day the article appeared; this correction was delayed by debate about the error.

An article yesterday about the Marine Corps’ formal reprimand of Maj. Gen. Richard A. Huck, Col. R. Gary Sokoloski and Col. Stephen W. Davis for their failure to investigate thoroughly the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians by a group of enlisted men in the town of Haditha two years ago misstated Colonel Sokoloski’s responsibilities at the time. He was General Huck’s chief of staff, not his legal adviser.

The Jerusalem Journal article yesterday, about the pornographic pocket books with Nazi themes that were circulated in Israel in the 1960s, misquoted Na’ama Shik, a researcher at Yad Vashem, The Holocaust Martyrs’ and Heroes’ Remembrance Authority, regarding the pocket book “Doll’s House,” about a Jewish woman serving in a notorious brothel called Block 24 in Auschwitz. She said the book — not Block 24 — was fictional.
Six novels were nominated in London for the Man Booker Prize for Fiction. Since the long list was announced last month, Ian McEwan's “On Chesil Beach” has been the bookmakers’ favorite.

A 40-year-old man with a history of violent outbursts was charged with murder yesterday in the death of a former companion whose body was found in her SoHo apartment, the police said. The woman, identified by the police as Denise Deperrie, 36, was found on Wednesday in her apartment at 31 Crosby Street with puncture wounds in her chest. The man, Juan Rios, was described as a former companion of Ms. Deperrie. He was already facing charges of assault and criminal possession of a weapon in connection with an earlier attack on Ms. Deperrie and was forbidden to approach her under an order of protection, the authorities said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Mr. Rios checked into the psychiatric ward of a nearby hospital on Wednesday, and was arrested after he was discharged yesterday.
Doctors said Crown Prince Paras, 36, was in stable condition after suffering a severe heart attack.
Zimbabwe devalued its near-worthless currency again, moving to a rate of 30,000 Zimbabwe dollars to one American dollar, from the old rate of 250 per American dollar.
Heavy rain and strong winds lashed Tokyo today as a typhoon neared the capital after killing one person, injuring 35 and cutting power to tens of thousands of homes.
Interior Minister Michèle Alliot-Marie announced the creation of a special police unit for gang violence, in an attempt to halt a rise in clashes between youth gangs in the Paris region.
A $2 million survey released Thursday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg provided a trove of information on attitudes toward public middle and high schools.

TRENTON, Sept. 6 — In the ethically murky realm of New Jersey politics, where it is common practice for state lawmakers to collect multiple government paychecks, Assemblymen Alfred E. Steele and Mims Hackett Jr. are known as minor players who have refined their skills at working the system to find job opportunities for themselves and their relatives.
Gen. David H. Petraeus wants to keep heightened troop levels in Iraq well into next year, but could accept the pullback of one brigade in January, officials say.
A Royal Bank of Canada subsidiary, RBC Centura, said it had agreed to acquire the Alabama National BanCorporation in a $1.6 billion deal.
German manufacturing orders dropped the most in at least 16 years in July after a decline in sales of ships, trains and airplanes.
Dubai Aerospace Enterprises abandoned plans to buy control of Auckland International Airport, New Zealand’s largest airfield.
China ordered banks to put aside more money as reserves for the seventh time this year to cool lending and investment after inflation accelerated to a 10-year high.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,736 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Fred D. Thompson is trying to win over conservatives by positioning himself as the ideological and stylistic heir of Ronald Reagan.

Nassau County prosecutors said yesterday that a series of online stings this summer had resulted in the arrests of 21 men on charges ranging from attempted dissemination of indecent material to a minor to attempted rape. Kathleen Rice, the Nassau County district attorney, said that the suspects were charged after engaging in online conversations with police detectives posing as under-age girls. Six men showed up at arranged meetings and were arrested, she said. The suspects included a lawyer, an accountant and a former worker for the Transportation Security Administration, she said.

About 7,056 illegal guns were recovered in New York City last year, according to a report released yesterday by the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, an increase of 17 percent over 2005. The bureau also found that 85 percent of the illegal guns it could trace came from out of state, and that most of the recovered guns were older, suggesting that trafficking in new guns is down.

A member of the Gambino crime family who had been involved in an unsuccessful plot to kill Salvatore Gravano, the mob informant known as Sammy the Bull, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 30 years in prison in a separate case, prosecutors said. The man, Edward Garafola, 69, has been a “made” member of the crime family since the 1970s, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. He was sentenced yesterday for his 2004 guilty plea to murder and extortion for participating in the 1990 murder of his cousin Edward Garofalo, who was believed to be cooperating with law enforcement. Prosecutors said Mr. Garafola participated in a plot to kill Mr. Gravano in 1999 and 2000.

The Department of Parks and Recreation said yesterday that it would extend the temporary permit for the food vendors of Red Hook through Oct. 21, the traditional end of their season. A committee that represents the vendors, who sell Latino snacks each summer weekend in Red Hook Park, has had a series of temporary permits regularly renewed; the current permit was to expire tomorrow. In June, the Parks Department told the vendors that they would have to bid for the work, as vendors at other parks must. After an outcry, the city relented. The department said it still planned to request proposals for future vending, but added that it would consider “prior experience, longstanding community relations and the variety of cuisine offered.”.

Schools in the Pearl River School District were closed yesterday after a bomb threat, the authorities said. Two teams using bomb-sniffing dogs searched the grammar school, middle school and high school in this Rockland County hamlet yesterday and found no trace of explosives, said Sgt. Henry Reynolds of the Orangetown Police Department. Sergeant Reynolds said the threat was sent to district administrators in an e-mail message.

Camden County has agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle a lawsuit with people who were illegally strip-searched at the county jail between 2003 and 2005. A lawyer for the plaintiffs said that as many as 20,000 people might have been improperly searched and could be eligible for the money, which he said he expected to come to about $1,000 per person. The two original plaintiffs, who were arrested on minor charges, are entitled to $15,000 each. A spokesman for Camden County did not return a call seeking comment.

A city police officer pleaded guilty yesterday to sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child as his trial got under way in State Supreme Court. The officer, Robert Friedrich, 31, agreed to resign from the police force and register as a low-level sex offender, and Justice William Wetzel promised him a sentence of probation, probably six years. Officer Friedrich admitted sending sexually suggestive text messages to a 13-year-old girl and to kissing her with his tongue. His plea came moments before the girl and her mother were scheduled to take the witness stand on the first day of testimony. Prosecutors had shown the jury text messages from the officer indicating that he had instigated the relationship and that he knew she was, as he put it, “technically a minor.” Officer Friedrich, on the police force for six years, was assigned to the Manhattan South Task Force.

The Town of Rye has failed to comply with its own policies for the purchases of goods and services, and as a result, may have spent more than was necessary, according to a audit released this week by the state comptroller’s office. The report said, for instance, that the town paid $971,009 to eight vendors but had not issued requests for proposals, which are a standard practice. The document further stated that the town did not get written quotes for purchases totaling $110,493 from three vendors, and for four public works contracts totaling $294,017. The report, which examined the period from Jan. 1, 2005, to Sept. 30, 2006, said the town supervisor had not properly overseen the director of purchasing to ensure compliance with local rules and state laws. The supervisor, Robert A. Morabito, said, “I understand the concern of the comptroller’s office, but over the period they examined, there were hundreds of small jobs, 95 percent of which had written or verbal quotes from at least two or three vendors per job.”.
Makers of drugs and medical devices would be required to report publicly nearly all payments and gifts to doctors under legislation introduced Thursday in the Senate.
Senate Republicans suggested that the state inspector general, Kristine Hamann, faltered in her investigation of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration and lacked candor.

Iraq’s top anti-corruption official said that the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki had tried to limit his commission’s scope and to close cases by saying they fell outside his purview.
Human rights groups and a Republican member of Congress condemned President Bush’s acceptance of the invitation to the 2008 Games.
Idaho constituents says they are confused by the twists in the Senator Larry E. Craig case.

A year ago, Tatiana Hladyr of Ukraine led the women for 20 of the 26.2 miles in the New York City Marathon, and television announcers referred to her as a rabbit. She was not, and finished second to Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia. Yesterday, the New York Road Runners said Hladyr would join Prokopcuka in this year’s marathon Nov. 4. The latest challengers to Prokopcuka, who is seeking her third consecutive victory in New York, include Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, Constantina Tomescu-Dita of Romania and Elva Dryer, a two-time Olympian from Albuquerque.

A Honus Wagner baseball card has been sold for a record $2.8 million, a little more than six months after it was bought for a then-record $2.35 million. Referred to as the Mona Lisa of baseball cards, it is in the best condition of the few known T206 Wagner cards, released in 1909 by the American Tobacco Company. It was purchased by an unidentified private collector.

The American men answered their critics who said they were lucky to qualify for the Beijing Olympics by finishing fourth yesterday at the world gymnastics championships in Stuttgart, Germany. If not for two falls off the high bar, the United States would have been the bronze medalist. China breezed to its third consecutive title — and seventh in the past eight world championships — by an almost 5-point margin. Japan took the silver and Germany the bronze, 1.25 points ahead of the Americans.

The much-delayed return of the Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches has one more week to go. As expected, Rags to Riches, the first filly in 102 years to capture the Belmont States, will not run in tomorrow’s Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park, but she is set for the one-and-an-eighth-mile Gazelle Stakes a week later. Rags to Riches, a 3-year-old filly, has won all five of her starts this year, and the Gazelle would be a final prep before the Breeders’ Cup Distaff at Monmouth Park on Oct. 27.

An appeals court revived a lawsuit by two women who claim they were gang raped at a University of Colorado recruiting party in 2001, ruling there is evidence the alleged assaults were caused by the university’s failure to adequately supervise players. The ruling by the 10th United States Circuit Court of Appeals, which sends the case back to the trial court, said there was evidence the university had an official policy of showing high school recruits a “good time” and that it showed a “deliberate indifference” to any known sexual harassment.

Stan Lee beat Sam Farlow, 4 and 3, to win the U.S.G.A. Senior Amateur in Andover, Kan., five days after his 55th birthday, to become the tournament’s youngest champion. Lee, of Heber Springs, Ark., surpassed the previous record of 55 years 3 months 18 days, set by Bill Bosshard in 1991.
A wealthy Albany-area businessman may have violated New York lobbying laws when he provided flights on private aircraft to the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.
A proposal to double the tax rate of executives at private equity firms would have negligible impact on the returns received by pensioners, specialists told Congress Thursday.
After a series of recalls that have undermined public confidence, the nation’s largest toy makers are asking the government to impose mandatory testing standards.
Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton reached totally opposite conclusions from a report by an independent commission of military experts.
Fred D. Thompson emphasized a need to persevere with the war in Iraq and abide by “common-sense conservative beliefs.”
Syria’s air defenses repulsed Israeli warplanes that violated its airspace early Thursday, Syrian media reported.
The United States rugby team could return from the 2007 World Cup as the most successful in history even if it does not make it out of the first round.
A two-day taxi strike revealed a bitter dynamic in a deeply divided industry.
If all of the nation’s children are to get the education they deserve, Congress needs to strengthen the No Child Left Behind law.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 6 (AP) — West Virginia football Coach Rich Rodriguez has signed a contract extension through the 2013 season.
The world’s three leading news agencies suspended coverage Thursday of the Rugby World Cup in a dispute with the sport’s governing body over media restrictions.
The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is to begin publicly releasing data on infection and death rates at its 11 hospitals.
Military recruiters are frequently given free reign in New York City public schools and allowed into classes, according to a report released Thursday.

Christopher W. Adams, the first lawyer ever appointed to supervise the legal defense of poor people facing the death penalty in Georgia, announced last week that he was giving up on his “labor of love.”

The officials were charged with taking thousands of dollars in bribes in exchange for promising municipal business to undercover officers posing as insurance brokers.
Roger Federer says he never underestimates his opponents, but his respect for the competition may be the part of his game that frustrates his opponents the most.
A week of excessively high temperatures has ended in Southern California after causing more than 20 deaths and sporadic power failures.
A small clinic that handled the cases of thousands of 9/11 recovery and cleanup workers is coming under scrutiny.
Alnylam Pharmaceuticals and Isis Pharmaceuticals, expect to announce Friday an equally owned joint venture to develop drugs that work by blocking so-called micro-RNAs.
Citing new economic uncertainties, the European Central Bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 4 percent and reduced its forecast for growth in Europe this year.

The most provocative interpretation is that the upsurge was inadvertently caused by regulatory warnings about the safety of antidepressant drugs.
George Bubaris was charged on Thursday with second-degree manslaughter in the death of a homeless Guatemalan immigrant four months ago.
After a junior year slump sent him dropping in the draft, pitcher Ian Kennedy has exceeded expectations for the Yankees.

A federal judge’s ruling last week suspending a crackdown on employers who hire illegal immigrants could cause a major disruption in the processing of millions of routine retirement and disability claims.
Lehman Brothers Holdings and the National City Corporation said yesterday that they would lay off more than 2,000 workers as the banks scale back their struggling mortgage businesses.
Bids topped $10,000 yesterday on eBay for what an animal-rights group says are notes from Michael Vick’s speech apologizing for a dogfighting scandal.
Some local officials object to the new flight paths proposed in the agency’s plan to reduce delays at New York-area airports.
Both Virginia Tech and Louisiana State, whose football teams play Saturday in a marquee matchup, have recently turned to athletics for comfort after suffering major tragedies.
The fashion designer Isabel Toledo, charged with reanimating the venerable but floundering Anne Klein brand, has drawn raves at Bryant Park.
Rupert Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of the News Corporation media conglomerate, received compensation valued at $24.3 million in the fiscal year ended June 30.
James E. Press has been lured away from Toyota to serve as Chrysler’s co-president as the company continues its transformation.
With the hiss of an espresso machine and a note in Russian explaining the meaning of tall, grande and venti, Starbucks opened its first coffee shop in Russia.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 57.88 points, or 0.44 percent, as investors were more optimistic about the chances of cuts in interest rates.
Six samples collected from a three-story house and a barn in Danbury, Conn., tested positive for anthrax, and more samples were gathered on Thursday for additional testing.

United Healthcare settled complaints about its past claims practices on Thursday, agreeing to pay $12 million in fines to 36 states and the District of Columbia.
Bill Frist, the former Senate majority leader, will lead a drive by the charity Save the Children that aims to win more federal money for children’s health in the developing world.
Hyundai Motor America is introducing a $150 million advertising campaign meant to improve the image of the Hyundai brand.
The Giants start a new season with a rookie snapper and a new kicker, but holder Jeff Feagles provides a fleeting sanctuary of reliability in the placekicking game.
The luxury-home builder Hovnanian Enterprises reported its fourth consecutive quarterly loss on Thursday, citing continuing problems of credit availability and high inventory.
Mr. Jackson was a civil rights activist and one of 21 Communist Party members who were indicted in 1951, for, among other things, teaching classes on violent revolution.
Health officials reported that the rate of suicide in Americans ages 10 to 24 increased 8 percent from 2003 to 2004, the largest jump in more than 15 years.
Wrigley Field was rocking in anticipation of a Cubs victory yesterday. Then Andre Ethier tuned out the noise, silenced the crowd and sent the Los Angeles Dodgers to a stunning victory.
The group is the latest of several large transfers to Saudi Arabia since May 2006 that have reduced the population of Saudi detainees.
The New Jersey decision is a legal victory for Merck, which faces nearly 27,000 individual lawsuits from people claiming the drug Vioxx harmed them.
Stephon Marbury has drawn mockery this summer with a series of odd television appearances and curious statements.
The move puts more pressure on the company to close its subprime mortgage unit and shed other divisions not tied to the core tax business.
Worker productivity rebounded in the April-June quarter, growing at the fastest pace in nearly two years, while wage pressures eased, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

The rate of home loans in foreclosure rose to a record level in the second quarter of 2007 as more homeowners in California, Florida and other states could not refinance their adjustable-rate mortgages.
No 15 Rutgers showed that it does not have to rely on the run last week, which bodes well for the rest of the season.

For sheer Italianate tenorial beauty, Luciano Pavarotti was hard to top.

The back-to-school shopping season was not a disaster, but the respectable, if lackluster performance of retailers may have been driven by discounts that obscure troubles ahead.

Jack Romanos will be succeeded by Carolyn Reidy, currently president of the company’s adult publishing group.

9 P.M. (CBS) FASHION ROCKS They go together like a horse and carriage — or, more to the point, like skintight leather and Mick Jagger. JENKINS--Rhoda Barney, born 1920, NYC, died August 25, 2007, Greenwich, CT. Father Morgan Barney, MIT naval architect and mother Nora Stanton Barney, Cornell graduate and America's first female civil engineer. A fourth generation feminist, Ms. Jenkins was the great-granddaughter of Elizabeth Cady Stanton, who fought for women's equality. Ms. Jenkins was a fount of history who inspired a generation of Women's Studies scholars. She earned an architectural degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1941. During WWII, she designed floating dry docks and High Mowing School. Licensed in Connecticut and New York, she designed churches and residences. A tireless member of NOW, she campaigned for equal rights and supported the Women's Rights National Historical Park. Predeceased by her husband Frederick, Ms Jenkins is survived by her children, Morgan Jenkins and Coline Jenkins. Services are 1pm, September 8, Quaker Meeting, Purchase, NY.

WIESEN--Patricia Ann (nee Elfers), died in peace and with grace at home in Greenwich, CT on September 4th, 2007 surrounded by family. She is survived by her devoted husband of 57 years, Donald G. Wiesen, her five daughters, Mary Patricia (Mara) Wiesen (Justin Clifford), Caitlin Wiesen (Jacques Antin), Elizabeth Wiesen (Skip Delano), Anne Wiesen (John Seitz), and Megan Dowley (Mark Dowley), seven grandchildren and her brother, William Elfers. Born August 30th, 1929, Patricia attended Manhattanville College and graduated cum laude from Columbia University in 1952. She later received a Master's Degree in Counseling from the University of Bridgeport and volunteered her services at the Christian Counseling Center in Norwalk. Her other volunteer commitments included being a member of the NYC Commission to the United Nations, Vice-Chairman of the East Side International Community Center, member of the Board of Trustees of Greenwich Academy where her daughters attended school, and Representative to the Greenwich RTM. A Dame of the Order of Malta, Patricia served with her husband as the first co-hospitaller of the Order in Connecticut. Together they established school tutoring programs for the Dioceses of Bridgeport and a Eucharistic Ministry to hospitals in Connecticut. Patricia made 16 pilgrimages to Lourdes assisting the sick. She served as co-chair pilgrimage in 1992. Visiting hours are Friday, September 7 from 6-8pm at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home 31 Arch Street Greenwich, CT. A funeral mass will be held Saturday, September 8 at 12:30 pm at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Shake-A-Leg, Inc., P.O. Box 1264, Newport, RI 02840.

NASHVILLE SYMPHONY NAMES MUSIC DIRECTOR The ambitious Nashville Symphony has a new home, a series of recent recordings and now, finally, a music director. The orchestra said that Giancarlo Guerrero, a Costa Rican born in Nicaragua, would take up the post in the 2009-10 season and be given a five-year contract. The orchestra has been semi-leaderless since the death of its longtime music director, Kenneth Schermerhorn, in 2005, although Leonard Slatkin has been acting as musical adviser. Mr. Slatkin will stay on through the 2008-9 season, when Mr. Guerrero will conduct 10 weeks before moving up to his full 14-week season, the orchestra said. Mr. Guerrero, 38, is music director of the Eugene Symphony in Oregon and has recently appeared as a guest conductor with the Cleveland Orchestra, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Los Angeles Symphony at Hollywood Bowl and others. He was also associate conductor of the Minnesota Orchestra from 1999 to 2004. DANIEL J. WAKIN

GLASSLANDS GALLERY OPENING, MONSTER ISLAND BLOCK PARTY Any recent visitor to Williamsburg can see that this once-industrial Brooklyn neighborhood is gentrifying rapidly. Condo towers are springing up on nearly every block, no matter how far from the L (or even G) train. But some residents want to remind New Yorkers that there is still artistic fun to be had in the 'Burg. This weekend two of the biggest spaces will hold parties with music, art, video installations, dancing, cheap beer and many, many grilled tofu pups. ''We want to show off the fact that there's a lot of underground spaces in Williamsburg that are happening and continue to happen, and that there are a lot of artists who are into community,'' said Rachel Nelson, an organizer of the Monster Island Block Party tomorrow. Ms. Nelson's gallery, Secret Project Robot, is in the 9,000-square-foot facility known as Monster Island, which also houses music and dance studios and a screen-printing shop.

'CELIA: THE LIFE AND MUSIC OF CELIA CRUZ' When Carmen Rivera and Cándido Tirado were first approached about writing a musical on Celia Cruz, the queen of salsa, they quickly realized that they had two problems: how to dramatize what by showbiz biopic standards was a normal life, and how to fashion a story that could hold up to the music. Fittingly, this husband-and-wife team saw the solution in marriage: Ms. Cruz's 41-year union with Pedro Knight, a trumpeter who almost always accompanied her onstage. ''They met on the day she auditioned for the same band he was in,'' said Ms. Rivera, whose work includes ''La Gringa,'' coming to Repertorio Español in the fall. The show, in previews at New World Stages, opens with an ill Mr. Knight recalling his wife, including her 15 years of stardom in Cuba and their escape after the rise of Castro. In the title role, Xiomara Laugart Sánchez (above), opposite Modesto Lacen as her husband, interprets Ms. Cruz's best-known songs.

FOOTNOTE The producer Scott Rudin has obtained film rights to the 1934 Robert Graves novel ''I, Claudius,'' about the plots and counterplots surrounding the fourth emperor of Rome, Reuters reported. The novel was the basis of a 1937 film and a 1976 BBC mini-series that starred Derek Jacobi, Sian Phillips and John Hurt.

An article on Monday about a financial gift from Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey to Rocco Riccio, a former state employee who is the brother-in-law of a former companion of the governor, misstated the amount he gave. It was $10,000, not $15,000. (Nancy Dunlap, Mr. Corzine's personal business manager, donated $5,000.) The article also referred incorrectly to the current business relationship between the governor and his former chief of staff, Tom Shea, who Mr. Riccio said had asked him to resign from the Human Services Department after he was accused of looking up the tax returns of political enemies. Mr. Shea is a consultant to Mr. Corzine, a position paid for personally by the governor; he did not stop working for Mr. Corzine when he left the chief of staff's job last Friday.

What's the art style of the moment? Roberta Smith says it's something called the ''Providence look'' --''a shifting, often impacted ratio of psychedelic, Op Art, wall-to-wall collage, thrift-store finds, craft, pop, counterculture and sci-fi references.'' Tomorrow, one of its foremost -- and youngest -- practitioners, Ryan Trecartin, opens his solo debut at the Elizabeth Dee gallery. In one short film, the artist and a cast of dozens take on po-mo issues like cloning and virtual identities. The set is recreated in one part of the gallery; the film screens in another (and in a one-time-only showing at the Anthology Film Archives at midnight). Come meet the artist before we move on to the Portland peek. Art in Review, by Roberta Smith

BRITNEY SPEARS TO APPEAR AT MTV'S VIDEO AWARDS Britney Spears will be the opening act at the MTV Video Music Awards on Sunday night, MTV announced yesterday. Ms. Spears will perform ''Gimme More,'' the first single from her coming album, at the event in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Spears, who has drawn more attention lately with her late-night partying and erratic behavior than with her music, is a veteran of the awards show. She performed ''I'm a Slave 4 U'' with a seven-foot albino python around her neck in 2001. Two years later, she and Madonnajoined in an open-mouth kiss -- in the show's first act. Ms. Spears's new album is due for release Nov. 13 from Jive Records.

THE BIG DRAW Never underestimate the ingenuity of children. One day they're tying their shoelaces; the next they're tying buses together. Knitting and knotting links between these parked vehicles with shoelaces, yarn and rope is one of the unusual activities in the Big Draw, a day when crowds will take up pencils (and brushes and sponges and even crochet hooks) to create public artworks in Lower Manhattan. Originating in Britain, the Big Draw was first held in New York last year (above), and like that other import, Harry Potter, it attracted fans of all ages. Tomorrow the format will be the same -- participants will work with professional artists at several locations -- but the mediums and the methods have expanded.

CAST PHOTO REVEALS 'PRISON BREAK' ABSENCE When a television show has accumulated as large a body count as ''Prison Break'' has over its first two seasons, any hint that a character might be facing doom is likely to be noticed by fans. So last month, when Fox started rolling out publicity for the third season, chatter grew on television Web sites about the fate of Dr. Sara Tancredi, the character played by Sarah Wayne Callies (above, in character), who is missing from the group photos of the cast being distributed by the network. Dr. Tancredi, a former addict, is the prison physician who helped the show's protagonists, Michael Scofield (Wentworth Miller), and his brother, Lincoln Burrows (Dominic Purcell), escape in the first season and stay on the lam in the second. (Stop reading here if you do not want to know her fate.) Ms. Callies revealed she was pregnant at the end of last season, with the baby due in August. The third season of ''Prison Break'' was to start shooting by then, so the producers used a body double for her in the first few episodes. Todd Adair, a Fox spokesman, explained that a double was used because the timeline progressed only a couple of months over the first two seasons and there was no way to incorporate Ms. Callies's pregnancy into the story line. Mr. Adair declined to comment about whether Ms. Callies might reappear, and a spokeswoman for the actress did not return phone calls to comment, but a person involved in the show confirmed that Ms. Callies has decided not to return after giving birth. EDWARD WYATT

PETRIE--Bernard, in San Francisco, on August 26, 2007, just before his 82nd birthday. Son of the late Yetta Fridman and the late Milton Petrie, nationally known retailer and philanthropist. Bernard was a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point and the University of Michigan Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. After serving as an associate at major law firms in New York City and San Francisco, he served as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Northern District of California. Thereafter he practiced in his own law office for over forty-five years. He led an active social life, and his annual Bastille Day party was notable. He involved himself in many community activities. He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the San Francisco Symphony, as a member of the Board of Visitors of Stanford Law School, as a member of the California Judicial Nominees Evaluation Commission, and on several committees of the Bar Association of San Francisco. At the time of his death he was a member of the Committee of visitors of the University of Michigan Law School, and a Trustee of the New York University School of Law. He was a Fellow of the American Bar Association, and a member of the American Law Institute, and the State Bar of California. He was a past president of the Smith Kettlewell Eye Research Institute, and a life member of the California Tennis Club. He is survived by his half sister Patricia Hugenberg of Belvedere, and her son, Kurt, and by his half sister Marianne Miller of Greenwich, Connecticut, and her son, Matthew. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 4, 2007, at 4:00pm at the Presidio Officer's Club. petriememorial@yahoo.com Donations to the charity of your choice in honor of Bernard's memory are welcome. 'KOHEI YOSHIYUKI: THE PARK' It is hard to characterize this unusual exhibition of black-and-white photographs from the 1970s by the Japanese photographer Kohei Yoshiyuki. Basically they are snapshots, taken in Tokyo parks at night using a 35-millimeter camera, infrared film and flash to document the people gathered for amorous trysts, as well as -- and this is the bizarre part -- the hordes of spectators hiding in the bushes who watched, and sometimes even participated in, the action. The three dozen images at Yossi Milo Gallery in Chelsea show more or less equal numbers of heterosexual and homosexual couplings, but they are not simply about sex or even the social strictures of Japanese society at a time when loving couples were forced into the park. They are about the guilty, if electric, pleasure of voyeurism, which drew people to these lonely locales all those years ago and draws us to Mr. Yoshiyuki's photographs, which by and large are not terribly well composed or printed. Several pictures are slightly out of focus, and at times movement blurs the figures. But somehow it all adds to the allure, giving them a grainy realism. We delight in the naughty, clandestine quality of the imagery, viewed in safety from another time and place. But the experience is no less engrossing. (Through Oct. 20, Yossi Milo Gallery, 525 West 25th Street, 212-414-0370, www.yossimilo.com.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

'SESSUE HAYAKAWA: EAST AND WEST, WHEN THE TWAIN MET' The American silent film industry wasn't a particularly hospitable place for Asian and black actors, who were cast mostly in supporting roles or as villains. The taboo, of course, was interracial sex (''Birth of a Nation,'' anyone?) and even interracial sex appeal. All the more remarkable, then, was the singular career of Sessue Hayakawa, the subject of this series at the Museum of Modern Art, which affords an extremely rare opportunity to see 16 Hayakawa films: 14 silents and two talkies (including ''The Bridge Over the River Kwai,'' from 1957, for which he received an Oscar nomination). Broodingly handsome, with an athlete's physique and agility, Hayakawa, born in Chiba, Japan, wasn't always the romantic lead. He played his share of bad guys and also his share of non-Japanese. In this series alone he is an Indian rebel leader, an Arab donkey tender, an American Indian, a Chinese Tong warrior and, in ''The Cheat'' (above), the 1915 film that made him a star, a Burmese ivory trader. Directed by Cecil B. DeMille and beautifully photographed by Alvin Wyckoff, ''The Cheat'' chugs right along, a model of streamlined silent storytelling. It has its racist elements, suggesting that the ivory trader's civilized veneer -- his spiffy suits and suave ladykiller manners -- hides a sadistic depravity: In the most eye-popping, sensationalist scene he burns a brand onto the white heroine's back. But it also shows off Hayakawa's intensity and skill as an actor.

CHARLOTTE GAINSBOURG HOSPITALIZED The French actress Charlotte Gainsbourg (below), daughter of the singer Serge Gainsbourg (who died in 1991) and the actress Jane Birkin, underwent surgery for a brain hemorrhage in Paris on Wednesday night, Agence France-Press reported. Friends said Ms. Gainsbourg, 36, whose films include ''The Golden Door,'' ''The Science of Sleep'' and ''21 Grams,'' had been suffering from headaches for several weeks after a water-skiing accident in the United States. She was in Venice this week for the world premiere of ''I'm Not There,'' Todd Haynes's biographical film about Bob Dylan.

A Scottsdale, Ariz., jury found Tampa Bay tight end Jerramy Stevens guilty of driving under the influence of alcohol. Stevens, a former Seattle top pick, was arrested in March after the police stopped his car in downtown Scottsdale. Seattle let him become a free agent shortly afterward. Stevens faces a jail sentence of at least 30 days for “extreme” intoxication, a blood alcohol content of .15 percent or higher. The legal limit in Arizona is .08 percent; Stevens’ measured .20 percent. Coach Jon Gruden said he expected Stevens to play Sunday.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Microsoft’s efforts to win approval for its Office Open XML format as an international standard misidentified the developer of the rival OpenDocument Format. It was developed by the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards, known as Oasis, not by a consortium led by I.B.M. (I.B.M. is a sponsor of Oasis, a global organization.) The article also referred imprecisely to the nature of the Office Open XML format. It is an open format, meaning that it can be used by any program that supports it; it is not open source, which means that the source code is publicly available for modification.

An article yesterday about President Bush’s decision to attend the 2008 summer Olympics in Beijing, despite opposition by human rights advocates, referred incorrectly to the American presence at the 1936 Olympics in Hitler’s Germany. President Franklin D. Roosevelt did not attend. (The 1936 circumstances were raised on Thursday by Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California, who likened Mr. Bush’s situation to the one faced by Roosevelt. But Mr. Rohrabacher did not say in his statement that Roosevelt attended the games in Germany.).

More than 200 items from the mansion once owned by the Giants’ Michael Strahan and his wife will be auctioned Sept. 14 at the Morristown, N.J., Armory. Strahan and his wife, Jean, went through a bitter public divorce that included allegations of physical abuse. Jean Strahan said in May that she was putting the mansion, valued at $3.6 million in 2006, on the market.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the uncertain future of Holly Hill, the Westchester County estate of the late Brooke Astor, referred incorrectly to the view looking west from the outdoor pool. In the distance is the Hudson River and Rockland County, not the cliffs of New Jersey.

A report in the Metro Briefing column on Aug. 29, about a motion to dismiss a federal lawsuit claiming that the State of New Jersey is pressuring a Methodist group to allow civil union ceremonies for gay couples at a boardwalk pavilion the group owns in Ocean Grove, referred incorrectly to the state’s argument for dismissal. It says the federal courts are not the proper jurisdiction for the lawsuit; it is not arguing that a state investigation into discrimination complaints from gay couples who sought to use the pavilion should be resolved first.

An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about the office real estate market in San Francisco referred incorrectly to an island visible in San Francisco Bay from One Market Plaza, a high-priced building offering spectacular views. It is Angel Island, which is off the Tiburon peninsula in Marin County; there is no Tiburon Island.

An article yesterday previewing the visit of Pope Benedict XVI to Austria misspelled the surname of a professor at the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in Rome who commented on the visit. He is The Rev. John Paul Wauck, not Wauk.

Diego Maradona and his 1986 World Cup-winning Argentina teammates have agreed to an unofficial rematch with their England counterparts. Two dozen people, including a professional female boxer, were charged yesterday in an undercover investigation of two New York gyms suspected of peddling steroids and other drugs to aspiring boxers, body builders and other clients. Cindy Serrano, 25, who fights under the nickname Checkmate, was awaiting arraignment on charges of criminal sale of a controlled substance. She was ordered held on $10,000 bail. Serrano’s husband, Jordan Maldonado, 41, a manager and trainer at Envy Us Gym, also was facing charges and was ordered held without bail. A lawyer representing the couple did not immediately return a phone message. Maldonado’s gym and the other location, Powerhouse Gym, were padlocked under court orders.

Shawn Johnson, a 15-year-old girl from Iowa, won the all-around title at the World Championships in Stuttgart, Germany, and set herself up as the woman to beat next year at the Beijing Olympics. Johnson scored 61.875 points to defeat Steliana Nistor of Romania by 1.25.

Nascar reached an agreement with AT&T that will allow the company to sponsor Jeff Burton’s car through 2008. The agreement ends months of legal wrangling involving AT&T, Nascar and Sprint Nextel. AT&T sued Nascar over its refusal to allow it to replace Cingular as the primary sponsor of the Richard Childress Racing car after the telecommunications companies merged. Nascar prohibited the name change because of its exclusivity agreement with the series sponsor Sprint Nextel.

Argentina upset the host nation France, 17-12, in the opening game of the World Cup. The French now face a talented Ireland squad and the possibility of being the first host nation to fail to make the quarterfinals.

An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Thursday, about earnings projections for Kraft Foods and Tyson Foods, incorrectly attributed a statement that Kraft’s profit margin would narrow this year. Maria Bello and Maggie Gyllenhaal play their wives. The film is “from the first frame to last, almost unbearably moving,” A. O. Thom Browne, the men's designer whose twisted take on American classics is sold at Brooks Brothers, may be the anti-Ralph Lauren. It should be said at the outset that Mr. Browne's spring collection, which includes seersucker and Madras suits with codpieces and shirt sleeves long enough to tie together and make into a skipping rope, is not for individuals easily sidetracked by the question, ''But is it wearable?'' This is fashion, a separate universe. Codpieces have historically interested men who like to make statements, from rock stars to Black Panthers. (Remember the ''Cleaver sleeve?'')

O'CONNOR--David M., on September 5 at the age of 60 years. Life-long resident of Franklin Square, New York. He was born August 29, 1947 to David and Mary (Fitzmaurice) O'Connor. Devoted husband to Pat O'Connor (Bottini), for 21 years. He is forever, the proud father of Mary Alice and David. Dave served in the US Air Force during the Vietnam War. He worked for The New York Times for 35 years. For more than 35 years, he was a Volunteer Fireman in Franklin Square. Dave was a member of the Knights of Columbus, the Ancient Order of Hibernians, and the VFW. Funeral services will be held Saturday September 8th and Sunday September 9th, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Franklin Funeral Home, 42 New Hyde Park Road, Franklin Square, NY. Funeral Mass 10am at St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City. Burial at Calverton Cemetery. Dave's family has requested that donations be made in his memory to: The David M. O'Connor Memorial Fund, 1066 Van Burer Avenue, Franklin Square, NY 11010. Donations will be made to the East River Fire Dept., Hospice and Dave's other favorite charities.

SHARE--Harold. September 6, 2007, of Fort Lee, NJ. Loving husband of Sally for 48 years, proud father of son Robert and daughter Vicki Fleiss and father-in-law of Michael Fleiss and Lisa Brown. Devoted grandfather of Rachel, Rebecca, and Daniel Fleiss and David and Emily Share. A CPA, he began his career working for a major accounting firm before spending nearly 25 years in the retail industry. Harold retired in 1988 as Senior Vice President -Control and Operations for Stern's Department Stores. As active in retirement as he was in his first career, he was the Founder and CEO of The Research Distribution Group, a company that distributes corporate Annual Reports to university libraries. Since its inception, he served as Chairman of the Federated - Allied (Depart ment Stores) Retirees Association, where he was responsible for improving benefits and overseeing the management of the Medical Benefits Plan and Trust. He was an active participant in the Colony Co-op Association in Fort Lee, NJ, serving on the Board of Directors and on the Finance Committee. Your family, friends, associates and present and former Board members and Trustees will miss your guidance, trusted advice, support and love. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am on Sunday, September 9, 2007 at the Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel at W150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International, 120 Wall St., NY, NY 10005 or the Cancer Research and Treatment Fund, 74 East 79th Street, 5B, New York, NY 10021.

Chad offered to assist the United Nations in its move to bring about a broadly based peace conference next month between Sudan and rebel leaders from Darfur. Idriss Déby, Chad's president, told the visiting secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, that he would offer leaders of the fragmented rebel movement in neighboring Sudan the opportunity to meet in Chad beforehand to help them ''smooth over the rough edges'' prior to the peace negotiations. Those negotiations, under the auspices of the United Nations and the African Union, were announced by Mr. Ban in Khartoum on Thursday and are scheduled to begin Oct. 27 in Tripoli, Libya. Mr. Ban welcomed the offer.

An article yesterday about Gen. David H. Petraeus's views on troop levels in Iraq gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a spokesman for General Petraeus, the top American commander in Iraq. The spokesman is Lt. Col. Joseph Yoswa, not Yoswell.

SCHULTZ--Harvey W. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York mourn the loss of one of our dear friends and leaders. Harvey served as a member of the CSS Board of Directors from 1991 through 2006, mostly recently as our Chairman, from 2004 to 2006. His deep knowledge of the issues and concerns of poor New Yorkers and longtime support of CSS helped to guide our organization in new directions; we remain inspired by his caring and thoughtful leadership. Our deepest sympathy goes to his family. Janet W. Thompson, Board Chair David R. Jones, Esq., President & CEO Steven L. Krause, Executive Vice President & COO Community Service Society

HART--Joan. The partners and staff of Labaton Sucharow LLP express their deepest sympathies to their partner, Barbara J. Hart, on the passing of her mother, Joan Hart. We extend our condolences to her husband, children and grandchildren. Labaton Sucharow LLP

PETRIE--Bernard, in San Francisco, on August 26, 2007, just before his 82nd birthday. Son of the late Yetta Fridman and the late Milton Petrie, nationally known retailer and philanthropist. Bernard was a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point and the University of Michigan Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. After serving as an associate at major law firms in New York City and San Francisco, he served as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Northern District of California. Thereafter he practiced in his own law office for over forty-five years. He led an active social life, and his annual Bastille Day party was notable. He involved himself in many community activities. He served as a member of the Board of Governors of the San Francisco Symphony, as a member of the Board of Visitors of Stanford Law School, as a member of the California Judicial Nominees Evaluation Commission, and on several committees of the Bar Association of San Francisco. At the time of his death he was a member of the Committee of visitors of the University of Michigan Law School, and a Trustee of the New York University School of Law. He was a Fellow of the American Bar Association, and a member of the American Law Institute, and the State Bar of California. He was a past president of the Smith Kettlewell Eye Research Institute, and a life member of the California Tennis Club. He is survived by his half sister Patricia Hugenberg of Belvedere, and her son, Kurt, and by his half sister Marianne Miller of Greenwich, Connecticut, and her son, Matthew. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 4, 2007, at 4:00pm at the Presidio Officer's Club. petriememorial@yahoo.com Donations to the charity of your choice in honor of Bernard's memory are welcome. PETRIE--Bernard. The Directors of the Carroll and Milton Petrie Foundation, Inc. express their profound sadness at the death of the Foundation's President, Bernard Petrie. Bernard led the Foundation with distinction throughout its history and his contributions to the Foundation's activities were significant. His presence will be sorely missed.
POWELL--Maxwell M. Daddy, theres still a big hole in my heart. Missing you every day. Love, Susan

Grandchildren; Randi Andosca, Steven Ratinetz, Stacy Ratinetz, Adam Ritchin, and Mark Ritchin. Great-grandchildren; Melissa, Michael, Stephanie, Juliet, and Sarah. KELL--Yetta ''The Great Lady'' September 8th marks 21 years that she passed away, but her wisdom and kindness has never been forgotten by all who knew her. ''Rest in peace mom'' Your children, Joseph Kell and Ethel Kell-Davis

HOOD--Samuel Leighton. Born to Clarence and Janie Hood in Jackson, Mississippi in 1943. The family moved east, eventually settling in Florida where Sam played football on a scholarship from Florida State. In 1962 he moved to Manhattan with his father to manage The Gaslight (1962-1965) a popular folk club in Greenwich Village, producing performers such as Len Chandler, Tom Paxton, Bob Dylan, Bill Cosby, Flip Wilson, Phil Ochs, Carolyn Hester, Dave Van Ronk, John Sebastian, Buffy Ste. Marie, Kris Kristofferson, James Taylor and countless others. In 1965, Sam married folk singer Alix Dobkin and moved to South Miami to open the Gaslight South. Sam brought folk luminaries to Coconut Grove and produced concerts at the Miami Colosseum for Bob Dylan and John Sebastian's the Lovin' Spoonful. After returning north in 1969, he operated the clubs Village Gaslight, The Elephant in Woodstock, and Max's Kansas City. He worked for Columbia records, managed bands like Fotomaker and produced several rock albums. His beloved daughter Adrian was born in 1970. Sam moved to Woodstock in the mid-1970's and spent 18 years as a top salesman for Pitney Bowes. Woodstock citizens knew him as a generous and loyal friend who worked quietly as a benefactor and philanthropist. He died of cancer at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, NY on September 3, 2007. He is survived by his wife, Judy Upjohn, stepson Gryphon Rower-Upjohn, daughter Adrian Leighton Hood, her husband Christopher Lofaro and sons Lucca Ray and Marlin (Marly) Leighton Lofaro, stepson Max Glazer, brothers John Bell Hood and Eugene Hood, sisters Lynn Hood and Robin Hood Leach, and 10 nieces and nephews. A memorial celebration of Sam's life will be held on Sunday, September 9th, at the Bearsville Theater just outside Woodstock. Donations in his name can be made to Family of Woodstock, 39 John Street, Kingston, NY 12401, www.familyofwoodstock.org.

KAPLAN--Hon. Louis I., For well-over a quarter century, we have borrowed upon the largesse of New York's Judiciary in drawing to Daytop's side the quiet voice but Solomonic guidance of our beloved Judge Louis Kaplan, and the graciousness of his beloved Beatrice. We acknowledge our profound indebtedness over the years, and in so doing, we offer our prayerful sympathies to the Kaplan Family on this great loss! (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President KAPLAN--Hon. Louis I. Our hearts cry out in profound sorrow at the loss of our beloved friend for over 50 years. The world is diminished and its light darkened by the passing of Judge Kaplan. He generously gave us his wisdom and insight, and never waivered in his resolve to live a rich and productive life. Our heartfelt condolences to his wonderful wife, Bea, and his children and grandchildren. We love him and will miss him always. Shelby and Bill Modell and the entire Modell family KAPLAN--Honorable Louis I., The Board of Governors of The New York Cardiac Center acknowledge with sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague and Board member. Judge Kaplan provided wise counsel and support in our efforts to improve the well-being of all through research and education. We send our sincere condolences to his wife, Bea and family.

In the past two decades, there has been a South American rain forest worth of newsprint written about Joe Paterno's possible retirement. There has been talk of succession plans and exit strategies since well before some of his current players were born. This week, Joe's wife, Sue, offered the first known proposed family plan for Joe to retire.

The Roundabout Theater Company said it would produce ''The 39 Steps,'' a comical stage version of the 1935 Hitchcock thriller and a London hit. ''Steps'' was originally to be a commercial transfer, but because of problems finding a theater, Roundabout agreed to present it at the American Airlines Theater on West 42nd Street in Manhattan, in association with Bob Boyett and other producers. Previews begin on Dec. 28, with an opening date set for Jan. 10. In other Roundabout news, Doug Hughes (''Doubt'') has been appointed resident director at the company, which means that he will be an artistic adviser for both the Roundabout in general and for specific productions.

DELTA RAISES FARES Delta Air Lines, the third-largest carrier in the United States, raised fares on most domestic round trips by $10, citing higher costs. Other airlines did not immediately join in the move. Delta's increase follows a 10 percent rise in the price of jet fuel for immediate delivery in New York Harbor in the last month. Southwest Airlines raised round-trip fares as much as $20 on Aug. 31, prompting higher charges by seven other carriers including Delta. ''Fare increases reflect increased costs and fuel plays a big role in our business,'' said Betsy Talton, a spokeswoman for Delta, based in Atlanta. Fuel and labor are the top two expenses for airlines. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

An after dinner thought on Monza. Actually, no, part of the thought began to develop this morning when I took the photos of the front wings of the Ferrari and the McLaren in front of those teams' respective garages. If McLaren is supposed to have stolen all this data and re-created its car in according to the Ferrari, then why are the cars so phenomenally different aerodynamically upon close inspection? My photos of the front wings are very bad, one not even being in focus. But I hope it is enough to see the massive difference between the two, the result of the millions of dollars the teams put into aerodynamic design and wind tunnel work, etc.

After 120 minutes of scoreless soccer, Nigeria defeated Spain in penalty kicks to win its third U-17 World Cup (though before 1991, it was a U-16 competition). Spain failed to convert any of its first three penalty kicks in the shootout, missing the first and seeing Oladele Ajiboye save the next two. The young Golden Eaglets from Africa scored their first three kicks making the last two unnecessary.

A pregnant woman stabbed another pregnant woman to death at a Long Island homeless shelter where both women were staying with their children, the Suffolk County police said.

Fernando Alonso is not letting his team’s involvement in a spying scandal distract him from trying to win a third straight Formula One title. Alonso clinched the pole position yesterday in qualifying for today’s Italian Grand Prix in Monza. Alonso won his second pole of the season with a time of 1 minute 21.997 seconds on the 3.6-mile circuit.He drives for McLaren, which has been accused of obtaining confidential technical data about Ferrari’s cars. The World Motor Sport Council will hold a hearing on the spying case Thursday after the world governing body, known as FIA, said new evidence had emerged.

Chicago Sky guard Armintie Price was named the W.N.B.A. rookie of the year yesterday, and Dan Hughes of the San Antonio Silver Stars was honored as the league’s top coach.Price, who was drafted third over all, out of Mississippi, started all 34 games and finished third among first-year players in scoring (7.9 points a game) and assists (2.9 a game).Price received 30 votes. Minnesota Lynx guard Lindsey Harding was runner-up with 12 votes, and Los Angeles Sparks guard Sidney Spencer had 10.Hughes, whose Silver Stars won seven more games in 2007 than the year before, becomes the second coach in league history to be named coach of the year award more than once, joining the former Houston Comets Coach Van Chancellor, who won from 1997-1999.

England stayed in contention for a spot in the 2008 European Championship by beating Israel, 3-0, yesterday in a qualifying match at Wembley Stadium.Shaun Wright-Phillips, Michael Owen and Micah Richards each scored for England, which had been in fourth place in Group E before the match.Wright-Phillips scored his first competitive international goal in the 20th minute. Owen made it 2-0 in the 49th minute, swiveling on the edge of the penalty box and scoring with a half volley.Richards, a defender, scored his first international goal in the 66th minute.
The bombing was the first against Shiites in Baghdad since last week, when the cleric Moktada al-Sadr ordered his militia to halt all attacks.

Tony Parker scored 23 points for France in its 78-66 victory over Germany yesterday at the European Championship in Madrid. Dirk Nowitzki had 28 points for Germany, which must win its final two Group F matches to guarantee a place in the elimination round.Also in Group F, Lithuania and Slovenia remained unbeaten and reached the quarterfinals, which begin Thursday. Lithuania edged Italy, 79-74, and Slovenia defeated Turkey, 66-51.

Nastia Liukin was unable to defend her world title in the uneven bars yesterday in Stuttgart, Germany, but her silver medal put her one medal away from joining Shannon Miller as the most decorated American gymnast in world championship history.Liukin now has eight world medals; she can tie Miller’s record today in the balance beam finals.The gold medalists in the five individual events yesterday were Ksenia Semenova of Russia (uneven bars); Diego Hypolito of Brazil (men’s floor exercise); and China’s Chen Yibing (still rings), Xiao Qin (pommel horse) and Cheng Fei (women’s vault).

I was fascinated by the quest of John Seo, who runs a hedge fund, to understand and price catastrophic risk (Michael Lewis, Aug. 26). The article has made plain an arcane corner of the financial markets. But as a multiple insurance policy holder and a longtime cynic of the insurance industry, I am left wondering if and how Seo’s work will affect not the asset-management side (risk management), but the policy-services side (payout policies) of the insurance industry. That is, will the appropriate pricing and spreading of catastrophic risk eliminate the policyholder’s ultimate fear — that the insurance company refuses to pay out on what seemed to be a legitimate and insured loss, making us all wonder what was the purpose of paying all of those premiums along the way?.

QWhat are a renter's rights when seeking to cancel a lease before the end of the term? Though there are no provisions in my lease allowing for liquidated damages, my landlord wants two months' rent for allowing me to break the lease. This seems excessive. A Neither a landlord nor a tenant can break a lease unless the right to do so is spelled out in the lease or is granted by some statute or regulation, said Lucas A. Ferrara, a Manhattan lawyer and an adjunct professor at New York Law School.
