ROSS--Arthur. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with sorrow the passing of Arthur Ross. His life was distinguished by a profound concern for the greater good of all humanity. His wisdom was matched by his compassion, and the confluence of those qualities caused the world to rise in admiration. His legacy as a humanitarian and an American will forever remain a blessing in the hearts of those who knew him and in his multifold contributions. With his family and loved ones we share the grief of his passing. Dr. David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary ROSS--Arthur. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Arthur Ross, whose commitment to the Jewish community has been deeply felt. The Ross family's longstanding generosity helped enable us to aid those in need and build a strong Jewish community. We extend our deepest sympathies to Arthur's wife, Janet; to his brother, Chester; to his children, Alfred, Beverly, and Clifford; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. ROSS--Arthur. The Central Park Conservancy's Board of Trustees, Women's Committee, and staff deeply mourn the loss of Arthur Ross. Arthur served as a Trustee since the Conservancy's founding in 1980. His visionary and outstanding support is evident in the beauty and grandeur of Central Park's Arthur Ross Pinetum, which he established in 1971 and endowed years later. Arthur provided sustaining annual support for many Conservancy programs, as well as funded the restoration of the Mall's Wisteria Pergola, Conservatory Garden's Vanderbilt Gates, and Ladies' Pavilion at Hernshead. We send heartfelt condolences to his wife, Janet, his children, Clifford, Alfred, and Beverly, and the entire Ross family. The Board of Trustees and Women's Committee, Central Park Conservancy A. J. C. Smith, Chairman Nancy Paduano, President of the Women's Committee Douglas Blonsky, President Adrian Benepe, Commissioner New York City Dept. of Parks and Recreation ROSS--Arthur. The Board, artists and staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of former Board member and enthusiastic advocate, Arthur Ross. For over 22 years Arthur, devotedly civic-minded, extraordinarily generous and passionate in his convictions about what best served the people of New York, believed in the theater as a civilizing force and a keystone of the city's claim to cultural eminence. Best of all, Arthur deeply enjoyed our plays and musicals almost always, never hesitating to share a contrary opinion. We will miss him dearly and extend our sympathy to Janet, Clifford and Betsy, Beverly, Alfred and Jane and his beloved grandchildren Caroline and Adrian. John B. Beinecke, Chairman Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman Emeritus Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer ROSS--Arthur. The Board of the United Nations Association of the USA on behalf of the staff and the members of our organization mourn the loss of our dear friend and Vice Chairman, Arthur Ross. This is a devastating loss for all who care about the United Nations and peace in the world. Arthur's energy and optimism about that world body was virtually unmatched. His generosity in the last two decades to institutions such as UNA-USA and the World Federation of UNAs was unprecedented. He believed deeply in the need to build and support a stronger United Nations. Arthur was always looking ahead, trying to build a better, more sane and more beautiful future for the world, for New York, for his friends and for his family. His benefaction of UNA-USA and his lively attention to all aspects of the world around him were trade marks of this brilliant man. Arthur's success in business was a reflection of that same intense intellectual engagement that enabled him to be such a creative and valued philanthropist. We honor the legacy he has left for New York, for the UN, and for the world. William McDonough, Thomas R. Pickering, John C. Whitehead and William H. Luers. ROSS--Arthur. The University of Pennsylvania mourns the death of Arthur Ross-Wharton alumnus, honorary degree recipient, and former member of Penn's School of Design Overseers. His many contributions to the University include the creation of the Arthur Ross Gallery: a vibrant legacy and a center for art and culture that is a campus treasure. We extend heartfelt condolences from the entire Penn community to his wife Janet and his children. James Riepe, Chair, Board of Trustees Amy Gutmann, President ROSS--Arthur. All New Yorkers have lost a pillar and benefactor of almost incomparable magnitude. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our neighbor and dear friend, Arthur Ross, an esteemed and active member of our co-operative for nearly four decades. We send our condolences to Janet, his children and the extended Ross family. The 19 E. 72nd St. Corporation, Cary A. Koplin, President ROSS--Arthur. The Jewish Home and Hospital Lifecare System is profoundly saddened by the loss of our Life Trustee, longtime friend and very generous supporter, Arthur Ross. For nearly a quarter of a century Arthur's leadership skills, generosity and commitment to those we serve have been invaluable assets. His tenure on the Board of Trustees for 20 years, prior to becoming a Life Trustee, provided incredibly insightful and inspirational guidance. Among his many long-lasting contributions, the nursing administration offices in the Friedman Pavilion were named for Arthur and Gloria Ross and his establishment in 1979 of the Arthur Ross Diagnostic Center Fund. He will be sorely missed by all who had the good fortune to know him both professionally and personally. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Janet C. Ross, his children and his entire family. Gene D. Resnick, M.D., Chair of the Systems Board of Trustees Audrey S. Weiner, DSW, MPH, President and CEO ROSS--Arthur. The Madison Square Boys & Girls Club mourns the passing of Arthur Ross, a wise and gentle man who generously supported the mission of our Club to save the lives and kindle the hopes and aspirations of boys and girls in New York City who live and have lived at risk in the less fortunate neighborhoods of Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. Victor F. Ganzi, Co-Chairman of the Board William G. Parrett, Co-Chairman of the Board Edmund J. Blake Jr., Co-Chairman of the Board Myles D. Gillespie, President Joseph Patuleia, Executive Director ROSS--Arthur. The Directors, Staff and Students of Boys & Girls Harbor are deeply saddened by the passing of our longtime friend Arthur Ross. Arthur was an extraordinarily generous benefactor and supporter of The Harbor's practice of educating innercity children to be their best. Arthur thought and acted globally and through his legacy our International Education programs now flourish. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Janet and the entire Ross family. Stephen J. Dannhauser, Chairman, Board of Directors Anthony 'Tony' Drexel Duke, Founder and President Hans E. Hageman, Executive Director Boys & Girls Harbor ROSS--Arthur. The Board, staff, and friends of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of Arthur Ross, longtime friend and esteemed Board Member since 1982, who served with distinction in leading roles, including the Executive and Horticulture Committees. Arthur's love and extensive knowledge of trees, especially conifers, was exemplified in his introduction and advocacy of his wonderful new elm, first propagated by Arthur at the Botanical Garden, to replace elms devastated by Dutch elm disease. Arthur's foresight, loyalty, and generosity have been essential to the Gardens renaissance over two decades. The vision and philanthropy of Arthur and his wife, Janet, resulted in new plantings, innovative horticulture, and educational interpretation at the Garden's historic Arthur and Janet Ross Conifer Arboretum, whose 250 mature conifers are one of the most impressive collections of pines, firs, and spruces in the world. He also made possible the Arthur and Janet Ross Gallery and Lecture Hall, providing a state-ofthe-art venue for exhibitions, lectures, symposia, performances, professional meetings, and community gatherings. Arthur's philanthropy in the arts, environment, and green spaces has enhanced the landscape of New York City and enriched the lives of its citizens. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Janet and their entire family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman of the Board Thomas J. Hubbard, Chairman of the Board Emeritus Gregory Long, President The New York Botanical Garden ROSS--Arthur. With deep love and sadness, Greenhaven Associates mourns the passing of Arthur Ross. Arthur was one of the most brilliant and successful investors of his era. His intellectual and creative approach to equity investing was an inspiration to us all. His passion for excellence carried over into philanthropy, where his generosity, caring, and ideas helped make this world a better place. There are very few Arthur Rosses. He will be deeply missed at Greenhaven Associates and by the many others whose lives he touched and bettered. Edgar Wachenheim III, Chairman and CEO ROSS--Arthur. On September 10, 2007. The directors, officers and staff of Central National-Gottesman Inc. sadly mourn the loss of our Vice Chairman and extend their deepest condolences to his family. Arthur was an officer of Central National-Gottesman Inc. for nearly 70 years and a director for more than 40 years. He served as its Vice Chairman since 1974. He astutely managed the company's investments for 40 years from 1938 to 1978. Arthur was a dedicated and inspiring counselor and leader for our entire organization. We will greatly miss his warmth and humor, keen intelligence, and superb business insight. Kenneth L.Wallach, Chairman and CEO Central National-Gottesman ROSS--Arthur. The Institute of Classical Architecture & Classical America mourns the loss of our co-founder and Honorary Chairman, Arthur Ross. We extend our condolences to his wife, Janet, his children, and all those in his family who survive him. His decades of generosity and public service have blazed the Institute's national educational trail and we acknowledge it with abiding pride and gratitude. Simply put, our success and determination are his legacy. At the nadir of New York's civic and cultural expectations a generation ago, Mr. Ross foresaw future promise and set in motion an array of good works across the city to that hopeful end. The ICA & CA was among them and his expectations were our blueprint. All here pledge to sustain his charge. The Board of Directors, Staff, Faculty, Students, Members and Friends Anne Fairfax, Chair Paul Gunther, President ROSS--Arthur, 96, the son of Adolf and Estelle, died peacefully on September 10, 2007, at his home in East Hampton. He is survived by his wife Janet, sons Alfred and Clifford, daughter Beverly, grandchildren Adrian and Caroline, and his brother, Chester. A brother, Joseph, predeceased him. The interment will be private. A memorial service will be held in the Autumn in New York City. ROSS--Arthur. Arthur Ross: truly one of the most creative and generous philanthropists of our times. An optimist, a lover of nature's beauty, his integrity gave light to everything he did. When he received the Four Freedoms Medal, we noted that he had raised the standards and strengthened the mission of every enterprise in which he was involved. We honor his extraordinary life which has sustained and enhanced the Roosevelt legacy. His light has touched the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in many ways and we are stronger for his love and support. Ambassador William J. vanden Heuvel, Founder and Chair Emeritus Anna Eleanor Roosevelt, Co-Chair, Board of Directors Richard E. French, Jr., Co-Chair, Board of Directors Christopher N. Breiseth, President & CEO Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute ROSS--Arthur. The Trustees, Fellows, and Staff of the American Academy in Rome mourn the loss of Arthur Ross, our beloved trustee, advisor and benefactor. An incomparable friend, he will be remembered for his convictions, perfectionism, gallantry, and financial acumen. He and Janet have played a crucial roll in the revitalization of the Academy, and our rebuilt Library will be named for them in November on his 97th birthday. We will ever consider ourselves privileged to count Arthur as a member of the Academy family. We honor his commitment to artists and scholars, and to excellence in every endeavor, a quality he exemplified through his long and distinguished life. ROSS--Arthur. The Citizens Committee for New York City salutes Arthur Ross for a lifetime of generosity that continues to benefit all New Yorkers whose lives and neighborhoods have been permanently enriched by his love of art, learning and -in the very heart of the city -nature itself. Osborn Elliott, Founding Chairman Henry Cornell, Chairman Peter H. Kostmayer, President ROSS--Arthur. Richard C. Holbrooke, Vishakha N. Desai and the Asia Society family express profound sorrow at the loss of our dear friend, visionary mentor and Honorary Life Trustee Arthur Ross. Arthur's tireless energy, unique insights, and boundless passion for Asia and USAsia relations have been at the center of shaping our institution into what we are today. We will miss him deeply. We pledge to carry on his legacy of building closer relations and mutual understanding between Asians and Americans through our work which he helped advance, most recently by establishing the Asia Society Center on US-China Relations. Our love and heartfelt condolences to Janet and the Ross family. ROSS--Arthur. The entire Barnard College community is deeply saddened by the death of our long-serving trustee Arthur Ross. Arthur was a generous patron of the College and took an active role in the beautification of our campus, including the renovation of The Arthur Ross Greenhouse, a state-of-theart teaching and research facility for the biological sciences. Sincere condolences are offered to his beloved wife Janet, and his entire family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President ROSS--Arthur. The Trustees and staff of the American Museum of Natural History are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime Trustee, benefactor, guiding force, and friend, Arthur Ross -a great New Yorker, an engaged citizen of the world, and a man of the utmost intelligence, integrity, and generosity. An active and involved Trustee of the Museum for 28 years, Arthur was devoted to science, culture, education, and to beautifying New York for the benefit and pleasure of all. His impact is evident throughout the City and, in our Museum, in the cutting-edge Arthur Ross Hall of Meteorites, the magnificent outdoor Arthur Ross Plaza, and in his longstanding support for our exhibition program. It is with the greatest of admiration, affection, and gratitude that we will remember him-for his excellent taste and elegant style, his keen wit and unerringly wise counsel, but even more, for his persevering focus on making our Museum and our City better, more effective, and more beautiful, today and for generations to come. Arthur always reached for the stars and emboldened us to do so as well-an irreplaceable gift for which he will be not only missed, but cherished. We send our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Janet, his partner in all endeavors, his children Alfred, Clifford, and Beverly, and to the entire Ross family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President ROSS--Arthur. New York City has been touched in so many ways by Arthur Ross. His spirit, energy and generosity enhanced our parks and open spaces, and gave a special poetry to urban settings. Although a citizen of the world, Arthur was foremost a New Yorker and a great neighbor in our city. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Janet and his loving family. The Trustees and Staff of the Municipal Art Society

GIROLAMO--Rita F. New York Medical College mourns the passing of one of its most ardent supporters and esteemed colleagues, Rita F. Girolamo, M.D., emeritus professor of radiology. A graduate of the medical school class of 1951, she was a gifted physician, teacher and administrator who served on the faculty for 30 years until her retirement in 1996. She devoted her time and talents to the Alumni Association, serving as president and receiving the Medal of Honor. In 1987 she was awarded the college's Distinguished Service Medal. Her legacy will long be remembered through the Rita F. Girolamo, M.D., Award, given annually to students pursuing a career in radiology. We will miss her professionalism, insight and dedication, and we extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M. D. President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M. D., Provost and Dean, School of Medicine

HASEN--Burt, on September 7th, 2007. It is with great sadness that the School of Visual Arts announces the death of artist, distinguished faculty member and dear friend Burt Hasen. Born in 1921 in New York City, he taught at the School of Visual Arts from 1954-2000. He was best known for his encyclopedic knowledge of the history of art, which he used to teach drawing and painting in the traditional ways of the great masters. A one-time resident of Paris, Hasen painted and studied at the Academie de la Grande Chaumiere from 1948-1950. Upon returning to the U.S., he began teaching at SVA and showing work at the Brooklyn Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, among many other institutions. During his career, Hasen was the recipient of awards from the New York Foundation for the Arts, the Pollock-Krasner Foundation and the National Academy of Design. He died after a long illness, and is survived by his wife, Mary, stepson Herb, and his brother Harvey. Our condolences go to the entire Hasen family.

Britons and the Irish can still down a pint of beer, walk a mile and eat a pound of bananas after the European Union ruled that the countries could retain measurements dating from the Middle Ages. Under a previous Union plan, Britain and Ireland would have been required to adopt the metric system and phase out imperial measurements by 2009. But after a vociferous antimetric campaign by British skeptics and London's tabloid press, Union officials relented.

Hot on the heels of receiving the top prize at the Venice Film Festival for his erotic thriller ''Lust, Caution,'' the Taiwanese director Ang Lee has snipped about 30 minutes from the film to pave the way for it to be seen on the Chinese mainland, Agence France-Presse reported. The official Xinhua news agency said Mr. Lee had been told by Chinese authorities to cut steamy scenes. ''Authorities told me that there was no film rating system on the mainland, so they let me cut it,'' he said. ''Children are able to watch it on the mainland.'' In the United States, ''Lust, Caution'' has been given an NC-17 rating, meaning that no children will be admitted.

OPEC TO RAISE PRODUCTION OPEC sought to regain its authority over volatile oil markets, agreeing to increase production by 500,000 barrels a day, but prices still rose to a record.

The director John McTiernan, below, whose films include ''Die Hard'' and the 1999 remake of ''The Thomas Crown Affair,'' filed a motion to withdraw his guilty plea to making ''knowingly false'' statements to an F.B.I. agent about Anthony Pellicano, the private investigator he said he hired to wiretap a business associate, The Associated Press reported. On Monday, when Mr. McTiernan was to have been sentenced, his lawyers filed a motion to withdraw the plea, saying that it was based on inadequate legal representation at the time. ''He should never have been charged with a criminal offense,'' said Milton Grimes, one of Mr. McTiernan's lawyers. He is to return to federal court in Los Angeles on Sept. 24 to hear the judge's ruling on the motion. Mr. Pellicano has pleaded not guilty to charges in a 111-count criminal indictment accusing him of tapping phones and bribing the police to gather information on celebrities and others.

DePAOLA--Joseph, 97, passed away Friday September 7, 2007. He was the President and Owner of DIC Concrete Corp. He was known and respected by his peers for his innovational contributions to the construction industry. He developed re-designing of structural steel buildings into reinforced concrete and created the two day cycle for concrete placement. His system is still utilized by major concrete construction companies and provides economic benefits to building owners and contractors. Some of the numerous projects he has completed include Lefrak City, Co-op City, the Pan Am building, now known as the Met Life building, 101 Park Ave, Trump Towers and the World Trade Center. He has built over 35,000 international housing units using his reinforced concrete system. He is lovingly known as the father of reinforced concrete or Mr. Concrete. He was the recipient of numerous awards, the Concrete Industry Board presented him with Leader of Industry Award and the Concrete Industry Foundation presented him the Humanitarium Fellow Medal and the Apprentice Scholarship program was established in his name. He died at home in Boca Raton, Florida surrounded by his family. He is the loving son of Leonardo DePaolo and Palmina Guarduclo and was married to Anna (Mahler) DePaola for 63 years. He is survived by his four children, Dennis DePaola of Yonkers, Donald DePaola of New York City, Joanne DePaola of Mahopac, Kathleen DePaola of San Francisco; adored grandfather of 12; cherished great-grandfather of 18. Funeral mass was Monday, 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Putnam Womans Resource Center, 935 South Lake Blvd, Mahopac, NY 10541, SFPRG Low Income Psychotherapy Service, 10 Funston Ave, The Presidio, San Francisco, CA 94129, Joseph DePaola Apprentice Scholarship Program, Concrete Board, 520 5th Ave, NY, NY 10036

While at Taillevent in Paris last spring, I tried an unfamiliar cheese with a rust-colored rind. It was Échourgnac (pronounced AY-shore-nyak), soaked in walnut eau-de-vie. This supple, delicate cow's-milk cheese had the fragrance and flavor of walnuts. Steven Jenkins, the cheesemonger at Fairway, had not heard of it, but eventually got some. It comes from the Abbey of Échourgnac, in the Dordogne region, and like many abbey cheeses, it has a washed rind. Such cheeses are often strong and funky, but this is neither. I like it with fresh walnuts and tawny port. The cheese, about 10 ounces, is $13.99 at Fairway.

Rates of infection with the human immunodeficiency virus have risen substantially among New York men younger than 30, indicating a shift in the age of the population most vulnerable now to contracting H.I.V. and AIDS, city health officials said yesterday. Over six years starting in 2001, new diagnoses in men who have sex with men and who are under the age of 30 increased by 33 percent, officials said, while the rate for men over 30 decreased by 22 percent. The number of H.I.V. cases among men in the under-30 group increased to 499 in 2006, from 374 in 2001. The group with the fastest-growing rate of H.I.V. infection comprised males between the ages of 13 and 19, for which H.I.V. diagnoses doubled from 2001 to 2006, according to preliminary data from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

Ratings for CBS's ''Evening News With Katie Couric'' fell to a new low last week, a period when Ms. Couric, right, traveled to the Middle East and delivered an interview with President Bush on the ground in Iraq. Nielsen Media Research reported that CBS's newscast drew an average of 5.46 million viewers, a significant decline from the 10.16 million viewers who tuned in exactly a year ago for the week in which Ms. Couric made her debut as anchor. ABC's ''World News With Charles Gibson'' once again earned the title of No. 1 newscast, one week after falling behind NBC's ''Nightly News With Brian Williams'' while Mr. Gibson was on vacation. ABC's margin of victory was slim, however, with 7.81 million viewers, compared with 7.78 million for NBC.

MONTI--Joseph. While his entire family and countless individuals who were touched by his warmhearted generosity mourn Sunday's passing of Joseph Monti, we take solace in knowing that he and his beloved wife Tita leave behind a legacy that will last for generations. Joseph Monti was born in Manhattan, New York, the youngest son of immigrant parents, Domenico and Caroline Pisani Monti. A graduate of the Julliard School of Music, Mr. Monti pursued a career in opera. As a promising young tenor, he appeared on Broadway with many noted entertainers and recorded for Columbia records. In 1943, he met the beautiful Titania Scandalis, a concert pianist and gifted soprano. They were married in 1944. After a successful career in the entertainment industry, Mr. Monti formed the JCJ Restaurant Corporation, followed by the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, New York. This was the beginning of a passionate 54-year career in the restaurant, hospitality and real estate industry. In 1972, the Monti's founded the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation in memory of their 16-year old son Don, who died of Leukemia in June of that year. Completely underwritten by the Monti's, the Foundation established the Don Monti Division of Medical Oncology/Hematology at North Shore University Hospital, the largest cancer care, research and education network on Long Island. In 2006, the Foundation formed an alliance with Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and established the Tita Monti Cancer Research Laboratory. Mr. Monti served as a trustee of the North Shore--Long Island Jewish Health System for more than 30 years and was a member of the Tilles Center Council of Overseers. He was also a Director of the Boy Scouts of America, The Dante Foundation and The Columbus Citizens Foundation. In addition, he was a Knight of the American Sovereign Military Order of the Knights of Malta and a sponsor of the International Committee of Boys Town of Italy. Mr. Monti holds an honorary Doctorate Degree from Long Island University in recognition of his contribution to cancer care, research and philanthropy. A longtime resident of Sands Point, Mr. Monti is survived by his two loving children, Caroline Monti Saladino and Richard Monti; son-in-law Arthur Saladino; 10 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. Calling hours will be held at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY, from 7 to 9 pm on Wednesday, and 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 pm on Thursday. A funeral mass will be held at 10 am on Friday at St. Mary's Church, 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, One Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. MONTI--Joseph. Virtuoso in the art of living, Joseph Monti created institutions that brought a new sense of elegance and culture to Long Island, as our honorary degree citation noted. Mr. Monti and his beloved wife, the late Tita Monti, were great and generous friends of Long Island University, establishing the Don Monti Endowed Memorial Scholarship to assist generations of students they never knew. In addition, they were longtime supporters of the University's Tilles Center for the Performing Arts. A valued member of the Tilles Center Council of Overseers, Mr. Monti will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to his many friends. Edward Travaglianti Chairman, Board of Trustees Long Island University David Steinberg President Long Island University

Visitors to Battery Park have a new place for a nosh as they take in the view or wait for a ferry to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. A kiosk, Picnick, sells sandwiches ($6.95 to $9.95), salads ($7.95 to $10.95), desserts ($1.95 to $3.95) and drinks ($1.95 to $5.95). Two chefs are behind it: Will Goldfarb, formerly of Room 4 Dessert, and Kevin Pomplun, formerly of Thor. Both have tamed their creative impulses, though the tuna served with roasted peppers on ciabatta is imported from Italy and the pork, with coleslaw on a roll, is a heritage breed.

Rémy Julienne, the former motocross champion, stuntman and stunt coordinator whose high-speed automobile chase scenes have enlivened half a dozen James Bond films and countless others, was given a suspended 18-month jail sentence and fined $18,000 yesterday for his role in the death of a cameraman during the filming of the French action comedy ''Taxi 2'' in Paris in 1999, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Julienne, 77, was found guilty of involuntary homicide and causing bodily harm to Alain Dutarte, 41, who died of severe head injuries after he was struck by a car fitted with foils to make it airborne as it sped out of a tunnel. The car sailed past its mark, a pile of cardboard, and hit Dutarte.

Dave Eggers, the author of the autobiographical best seller ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,'' among other books, has been chosen to receive the $250,000 Heinz Award for Arts and Humanities. At 37, he is the youngest recipient of one of the five annual Heinz prizes, given in five categories. This year's other honorees include Bernard Amadei and Susan Seacrest (the environment), Dr. David L. Heymann (the human condition), Dr. Donald M. Berwick (public policy) and Hugh Herr (technology, the economy and employment). Mr. Eggers was cited for using his commercial success as a springboard into philanthropy, advocacy and education, including the establishment of 826 Valencia, a writing laboratory for children that has expanded from his home in San Francisco to Ann Arbor, Mich.; Chicago; Los Angeles; New York; and Seattle, and soon to Boston. The 13th annual awards will be presented at a private ceremony on Oct. 22 in Pittsburgh.

Sherry-Lehmann, a bastion of Bordeaux on Madison Avenue and 61st Street for 59 years, has moved nearby, to Park Avenue. The new location offers a sweeping gold-trimmed show window; inside, there is more space for display. Michael Aaron, the store's chairman, is especially proud of the racks holding 20 imperials, each equivalent to eight bottles (impress your friends with the 2004 Château Beychevelle for $495), and 26 double magnums of Bordeaux. The dark wood, Old World décor of the former store has been maintained but in a lighter fashion. Ceiling beams are hung with wine memorabilia, antiques and vinous bric-a-brac. A touch-screen computer allows customers to troll the inventory; only some of the more than 7,000 bottles the store carries are on display, with the rest kept in climate-controlled conditions on the lower level. A second floor area will become the venue for wine tastings and classes next year.

Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

The Turkish police found a van packed with explosive chemicals in a parking lot in central Ankara, said Kemal Onal, the city's top official. The van was found by dogs that were part of security on the sixth anniversary of the terrorist attacks on the United States, he said. His office said the 40 bags of chemicals ''matched'' material found in recent raids on PKK, the Kurdish rebel group.

Kevin Gover, a member of the Pawnee Tribe of Oklahoma and a professor at the Sandra Day O'Connor College of Law at Arizona State University in Tempe, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian. Announced yesterday, the appointment by Cristián Samper, acting secretary of the Smithsonian, was the recommendation of a search committee. Mr. Gover, 52, who serves on the faculty of the university's Indian Legal Program, was the assistant secretary for Indian Affairs in the Interior Department from 1997 to 2000. On Dec. 2 he will succeed W. Richard West Jr., the museum's founding director, who is retiring after 17 years. Established by Congress in 1989, the museum comprises the National Museum of the American Indian on the National Mall in Washington, the George Gustav Heye Center in Lower Manhattan and the American Indian Cultural Resources Center in Suitland, Md.

A six-story building in Harlem was evacuated last night after city inspectors determined that it might be unstable, the Buildings Department said. A complaint about tremors in the building, at 305 West 150th Street, was made to the Fire Department about 4 p.m. The Buildings Department vacated 28 occupied apartments. On Aug. 10, the department issued a work permit to remove the interior partitions and plumbing fixtures in all apartments at the site, but on Aug. 30, the department issued a stop work order for work beyond the approved plans and excessive debris. Building inspectors issued a violation to the contractor for the conditions at the site.
