The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Arthur Ross, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council for 15 years. A true Renaissance man in his reverence for and delight in nature, art, and science, Arthur was deeply committed to advancing research and education. He brought keen intelligence, astute judgment, and a vigorous passion for science to his service as a member of the Council Executive Committee since 1998. Appreciating the importance of basic research, he endowed the Arthur and Janet Ross Professorship in neuroscience research to address Alzheimer's disease. With his wife, Janet, also a member of the Council, he provided leadership and support to the University's Women & Science program. Friend, advisor, and benefactor, Arthur Ross was an enlightened partner in the struggle against human disease. A philanthropist of generosity and distinction, his commitment to the greater community exemplified The Rockefeller University motto: pro bono humani generis. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Janet, his children and grandchildren, and to the entire Ross family. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. ''Dr. Johnson's Doorknob and Other Significant Parts of Great Men's Houses,'' by Liz Workman (Rizzoli; $25), is a curious little artifact of a book, with photographs of the skirting boards, ashtrays, doorknobs and other domestic objects found in the homes of George Washington, Washington Irving, Sigmund Freud, F.D.R. (see his chair, far left) and Winston Churchill (and his, left). The randomness of the objects (desks are included, but so are banisters and soup tureens) points out the weirdness inherent in mythmaking and the creating of shrines. ''Through most of the houses in this book stalk invisible wives, who can claim nothing,'' Germaine Greer writes in her introduction, clearly irritated by the book's organizing principles. ''Winston Churchill is thought to have pervaded Chartwell, so that every bibelot is where it is by his express command. In fact it was Clementine who ran Chartwell as a living breathing house full of visitors and children and animals, and I wouldn't mind betting that Winston could never find anything without asking her first where it was.''

Before creating Urban Picnic, above, a table setting intended to be used without a table, Kelly Simpson, a product designer at Dansk, interviewed friends and co-workers about their eating habits. She found a preponderance of couch eaters, and also many who sat on the floor in front of the television and used the coffee table as a dining table. (Those with real dining tables, she said, ''had them turned always toward the TV.'') Ms. Simpson is a confirmed couch eater herself. Though there is a kitchen table in her apartment, she rarely uses it. ''I like to put a pillow on my knees and the tray on top of that,'' she said. She also likes to use the bowl, top left, by itself for cereal. At five inches, it fits in the palm of her hand. (The vessel just below the bowl is a bud vase; salt and pepper shakers sit on the opposite corner of the 18 1/2-by-9 1/4 inch tray.) Urban Picnic is $40 at dansk.com. PENELOPE GREEN

ORSBURN--Thomasine, age 85, passed away on Wednesday, September 5, 2007, at Casa Dorinda in Montecito, California. Born in Bronxville, New York, she was the daughter of the late Frank and Julia Wadelton. She graduated from Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, New York. She moved to California after World War II with her husband, Warren and settled in Pasadena where she raised her three children, participated in community service and ran her two clothing stores on Lake Avenue in Pasadena. She and Warren spent their retirement years at their home in the foothills of Santa Barbara County, near Carpinteria, California until his death in 2005. She enjoyed cooking, gardening and music and was a member of the Womens Auxiliary of the Music Academy of the West. Most of all she enjoyed being surrounded by family and friends. Thomasine was a joy to be around and will truly be missed. She was preceded in death by her beloved Warren and daughter, Julie. She is survived by her sons, Peter and his wife Lily, Rob and his wife Nelle, her granddaughters Holly and Emily, and her brother George Wadelton and his wife Marjorie. Memorial donations may be made to the Music Academy of the West Coast in Santa Barbara, California.

EcoSmart Fire, an Australian company that makes ''green'' fireplaces, recently introduced the Vision, a freestanding, see-through unit with a flueless burner (no chimney required), which uses environmentally friendly ethanol. The Domus Design Collection, one of the Vision's American distributors, sells it in a standard white or black frame ($6,125), as well as in custom colors. And in an ultramodern take on the hearth, Domus has incorporated EcoSmart's flueless burners into some of its cabinets and credenzas, like the Studimo ($18,230) and the Cube ($20,575), as well as custom-made one-of-a-kind pieces, like the one below (prices vary). Domus Design Collection, 181 Madison Avenue (34th Street), (212) 685-0800 or ddcnyc.com. STEPHEN MILIOTI

An article last Thursday about people who use Ikea furniture in imaginative ways included incorrect references to the Internet in a quotation from Shoshana Berger, the editor in chief of ReadyMade magazine, who attributed the magazine's success to the mind-set of a generation that came of age in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Although Ms. Berger noted that this generation had used self-authoring tools ''like editing their own movies and photos on their computers, blogging, creating their own Web sites,'' most of these features were not in use in the 1980s, and they only came into being as the Internet evolved during the 1990s.

CLARK--Terry. The New York State Health Foundation staff and Board express profound sorrow at the passing of Terry Clark, beloved wife of President and Chief Executive Officer Jim Knickman, and mother of Annie Knickman. Terry was a wise, beautiful person. She will be deeply missed by all those whose lives she touched. We extend our deepest sympathies to Jim, Annie, and all other members of the Knickman and Clark families. CLARK--Terry, 57. Distinguished educational re searcher and president, Education Resources Group of Princeton, NJ. Former Director of Research, NYC school system; former research scientist at NYU; active volunteer for Princeton Public Schools. Survived by husband James Knickman, president of the NYS Health Foundation, and daughter Annie Knickman, student at Harvard College. Viewing September 14, 6-9pm and September 15, 9-10:30am, Kimble Funeral Home, Princeton. Memorial service Saturday, September 15, 2007, 11am, Princeton University Chapel. Memorial contributions: Cancer Institute of New Jersey, New Brunswick.

Thanks to last year's celebratory book from Pointed Leaf Press and a splashy retrospective exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, the American decorator Dorothy Draper (1889-1969) is the design world's latest inspirational blast from the past. So it stands to reason that an auction devoted to her furniture would be a highly anticipated event. A total of 173 lots of Draper and Draper-related furniture and accessories from the attics of the Greenbrier resort in West Virginia will be sold on Sept. 29 at the Potomack Company, a new auction house in Alexandria, Va. Draper redecorated the 6,500-acre West Virginia resort, top near right and bottom far right, in 1948, and it recently underwent a $50 million renovation by Carleton Varney, the owner of Dorothy Draper & Company.
HDTV Recordings Need More Room

SCHULMAN--Burton Jack, 81, of New York City, died on September 11, 2007. Beloved husband of Gloria Schulman (nee Gottlieb) for over 60 years; father of Alan Schulman of Rancho Santa Fe, CA, and Jill Schulman of Los Angeles, CA. Much loved grandfather of Alex Amini and Gillian, Sabrina, Hope and Hanna Schulman. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th St. on Sunday, September 16 at 11:15am. In gratitude for the compassionate care given by Dr. Werner Doyle, the family requests that, in lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to NYU-FACES, 724 Second Ave LL, New York 10016 (www.med.nyu.edu/faces). SCHULMAN--Burton. Con gregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Burton Schulman. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Michael W. Schwartz, President

Two sales offer the chance to redecorate for fall. From Sept. 20 to 26, Property, a contemporary furniture store in SoHo, will offer 20 percent off new orders, and will sell floor models for 30 to 70 percent off. The adjustable Upper sofa, above, will be $4,200 (it was $6,900); 14 Wooster Street (Canal Street), (917) 237-0123 or propertyfurniture.com. This month, Richard's Interior Design will sell in-stock fabrics for 50 percent off and special-order fabrics for 15 percent off. Furniture, like the French-country-style mahogany armoire, left, will be 30 percent off ($10,489, from $14,985); 1390 Lexington Avenue (92nd Street), (212) 831-8645. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

GALLUP--Kingsley H. Died peacefully at her home in Princeton, NJ on Saturday, September 8, age 70, from complications related to breast cancer. She is survived by her husband, George, children Alison and George of Knoxville, TN, and Kingsley and granddaughter, Daisy, from Durango, CO. She is also survived by her mother, Kingsley K. Hubby, of Old Black Point, CT, brothers Nicholas Hubby of Ogunquit, ME, Frank B. Hubby of Savannah, GA, and sister, Alison Hoversten of Vail and Denver, CO. Kingsley, also called ''Kinny'', attended Miss Fine's School, Princeton, NJ, The Lennox School, NYC and Bennett College, Millbrook, NY. Kinny was a talented figure skater in her youth and was the Senior Lady Champion of the Princeton Skating Club. She served a term as the President of the Board of Trustees of the Mercer Council on Alcoholism. Over the last 20 years, she and her husband, George, facilitated small bible study groups at their home and spoke at numerous churches around the country on this form of ministry. She played a major role with George in developing and managing the George H. Gallup International Institute, a non-profit organization, founded in 1988. The Institute was created by the Gallup family in honor of George's father, Dr. George Gallup, founder of The Gallup Poll. The mission of the Institute is to ''discover, test, and implement new ideas for society''. A person of great charm, grace and beauty, Kinny's priorities were God, family, and friends. Faced with a deadly illness eight years ago, she made the decision to be a witness to the power of the Lord in her life. She spent her remaining years in heartfelt service to others. A memorial service will be held at the University of Princeton Chapel on Friday, September 21 at 10:00am. Donations may be given to the Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania, Development Office, 3535 Market Street, Suite 730, Philadelphia, PA. 19104; to the Trinity School for Ministry, 311 Eleventh Street, Ambridge, PA. 15003; or to the Battle Against Hunger, St. Matthew's Church, 300 South Main Street, Pennington, NJ 08534.

Following is the second and final set of of answers from Graham Hodges, professor of history at Colgate University and author of “Taxi! A Social History of the New York City Cabdriver” (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007). Mr. Hodges took questions from City Room readers this week. A first set of answers was posted on Wednesday.

The 15.5-ton Willamette Meteorite, discovered in Oregon in 1902, is the largest meteorite ever found in the United States and the sixth largest in the world. It is also again the source of debate, involving American Indian religious traditions, the pending auction of a 28-pound chunk that was sliced off six years ago, and the collectors’ market for rocks that fall from the sky.

The Little Red Lighthouse has a fresh coat of paint, and the Parks Department is celebrating on Saturday with a reading by Dr. Ruth Westheimer.The lighthouse, on the banks of the Hudson River near the George Washington Bridge, has gotten new panes for its lantern and general repairs, as well as the fresh coat of bright red paint, thanks to a $45,000 gift to the city from the paint manufacturer Benjamin Moore. That “face lift,” as the Parks Department called it, will be celebrated from noon to 5 p.m. on Saturday at the 15th annual Little Red Lighthouse Festival under the bridge at Fort Washington Park.
What we’re reading on the local blogs…

The 80th annual Feast of San Gennaro, an 11-day event that has become the city’s largest and best-known street festival, began on Thursday and continues through Sept. 23. The event brings thousands of visitors to Little Italy for food, festivities, and religious ceremonies, but its history also underscores the extent to which the once-vibrant immigrant community of Italians in Lower Manhattan has thinned.The highlight of the event is scheduled for 6 p.m. on Wednesday, with a Mass and candlelight procession as a statue of the saint, the patron saint of Naples, is carried from its permanent home, the Most Precious Blood Church on Mulberry Street.

Updated, Sept. 15 | The authorities closed off the lower level of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Friday afternoon, after a worker fell 100 to 150 feet to the ground from the Brooklyn approach to the bridge around 1:40 p.m. The authorities said the man went into traumatic cardiac arrest and died.A city official said the man on the lower level of the bridge, on a temporary walkway that had been built for construction work, fell after a Jersey barrier came loose and crashed onto the walkway. The worker was identified Manuel Pereira, 48, of 137 Sullivan Street in Greenwich Village.

For those following the travails of former State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, the full State Ethics Commission file, detailing its investigation into Mr. Hevesi’s use of state employees to chauffeur his wife, has been obtained by The Times from the State Archives. In December, Mr. Hevesi pleaded guilty to a felony and resigned in the wake of the allegations.The Ethics Commission file, which includes transcripts of depositions of about a dozen witnesses, fills out details of the case known by many as Chauffeurgate. But is unrelated to the current investigations of pay-to-play allegations at the state’s $154 billion pension fund during Mr. Hevesi’s tenure, except for the fact that several key figures being looked at by investigators are the same, including Mr. Hevesi and his chief of staff, Jack Chartier.

Updated, 9:43 p.m. | The police have confirmed that a horse was killed this afternoon near Central Park — the latest bad news for the horse-drawn carriage industry, which was the subject of a highly critical audit by the city comptroller’s office earlier this month.According to a preliminary police account, calls about the horse started coming in at 4:49 p.m., with people reporting that a horse had been involved in an accident around 50 Central Park South, near the Avenue of the Americas.

With its zig-zagging facade straight out of the Kennedy administration and its ghosts of eggs-over-easy, the Market Diner, on 11th Avenue and 43rd Street, is for lease in a land of new high rises.

If the Giants know whether Eli Manning will play Sunday against the Packers, they have done a masterful job of hiding it. Manning threw some balls about 20 or 30 yards while warming up for practice on Friday, giving his sore shoulder more of a workout than it has had all week. The Giants, to use Coach Tom Coughlin's word of the week, were "encouraged," but Coughlin said he still does not know if Manning will be well enough to play on Sunday.

There has been very little time for ruminating on the quality of life in the new paddock at Spa-Francorchamps in the past couple of days, but hopefully, over the next couple of days tensions will die out somewhat. CHENGDU, CHINA -- The U.S. fans may be in short supply in Chengdu, but they are making a statement a fashion statement. This colorful bunch, made up mostly of family and friends of the team, greeted the U.S. subs with a roaring chorus of USA! USA! USA!, when they took the field before match. And that was the last they were heard from. They were seriously outnumbered by the Chinese and North Koreans who elected to root for Sweden today.

With several major brokerage firms set to report quarterly earnings next week, Wall Street is nervous. Merrill Lynch didn't help matters with its cryptic Friday-morning announcement hinting at credit-related writedowns. Merrill's stock was down 2 percent in early trading.

We'll begin today with words of wisdom from two much-maligned coaches, Ron Zook and Greg Robinson. As the Chicago Tribune's Terry Bannon reports, neither has made many converts in their short tenures at Illinois and Syracuse, respectively. Robinson says 0-2 Syracuse is in "a state of growth," while Zook describes Illinois as "a little baby learning to walk and then jog." Geez guys, not exactly Gipper-esque speeches. What happens when you get into the conference schedule, teething? The loser of tomorrow's game between the Illini and the Orange will have plenty of explaining to do about the state of their program.
More than two years after Terri Schiavo died and more than 15 after she was (by most accounts) last known to be conscious, the issues raised by her case continue to make headlines.
Cadbury Schweppes turned down a bid for its North American drinks business from a private equity group that included Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, according to news reports Friday.
Viacom's Sumner Redstone is said to constantly regret not bidding for MySpace, the social networking behemoth that archrival Rupert Murdoch of the News Corporation scooped up two years ago.
The building at 165 University Avenue here has been so good to the Amidi family that Saeed Amidi says it is blessed with good karma. There are some high-technology entrepreneurs who would agree.

Barclays shareholders approved the company's 61 billion euro ($84.7 billion) bid for Dutch bank ABN Amro on Friday, but the move may have been largely symbolic. Many large investors were expecting the takeover battle for ABN, which is moving into the home stretch, to be won by a rival bidding group, including Royal Bank of Scotland and Fortis, that plans to carve ABN into pieces.

The Beatles insisted that money can't buy you love. Apparently it can do a lot of other things, like lure top-flight talent from one high-profile, well-paying job to another high-profile, better-paying job. On Wednesday, Harvard announced that Mohamed A. El-Erian, the head of its $35 billion endowment, would return to the Pacific Investment Management Company after a year and a half in Cambridge.

HSBC has signed a deal to buy 10 percent of Vietnam Insurance, a move that seems to hav only increased the ire of an activist shareholder who is calling for a review of the bank's operations. HSBC Insurance said that it had purchased the stake from Vietnamese firm, known as BaoViet, for 4,121 billion Vietnamese dollars ($254 million).

Some investors in two bankrupt Bear Stearns hedge funds are now claiming that the bank soft-pedaled the risks of investing in the funds, according to BusinessWeek.

With all the new engine technology on display at the Frankfurt motor show, I needed a break from the bustling press conferences to get back to my automotive roots. Mercedes-Benz brought several replicas of Karl Benz's original Motorwagen to the Frankfurt show.

The United States had another nervous start in the Women's World Cup, and has not really played with the full assurance of a tournament favorite. But its defense remained impenetrable against Sweden on Friday and Abby Wambach continued to show why she is the world's most imposing forward.

KKR Financial said yesterday it would sell seven of its private equity investments to two institutional investors, a month after the company said it faced financing disruptions from troubles in the mortgage and commercial paper markets.
EXCO Partners, which was recently formed by oil and gas producer EXCO Resources, filed with U.S. regulators on Thursday to raise up to $1.725 billion in an initial public offering of common units.
Alcoa, the world's second-largest aluminum company, should consider bidding as much as $9 billion for venture partner Alumina to increase profit margins, according to Merrill Lynch analysts

The managing director of cosmetics group Clarins told Reuters on Friday that there were no talks underway with larger rival L'Oreal. But he added that his company was discussing several possible small acquisition targets.
Campbell Soup, the world's largest soup maker, is seeking $1 billion to $1.5 billion for its Godiva chocolate division, Bloomberg News reported.

The fate of a pending $1.1 billion leveraged buyout of Reddy Ice Holdings is in jeopardy after Morgan Stanley said it had the leag right to pull its debt financing commitment for the deal. The maker of packaged ice agreed to be bought by hedge fund GSO Capital Partners in July for $1.1 billion, with Morgan Stanley providing $775 million of debt financing for the buyout.

More than two years after James and Charles Dolan launched their first offer to buy out Cablevision Systems, the company they founded, shareholders will finally get to have their say on the deal. Cablevision has set an Oct. 24 shareholder vote for the $22 billion buyout by the Dolans, the company said in a proxy statement filed Thursday.
Fortress Investment Group is taking Seacastle public only a few months after forming it to buy marine container rental company Interpool for $2.4 billion.

Federal regulators charged 69 accounting firms and partners on Thursday with violating a landmark 2002 antifraud law by auditing public companies without registering with the board that supervises the accounting industry.

The Bank of England on Thursday made its biggest concession yet to banks caught in the credit crisis, giving them greater flexibility on how much cash they can borrow, without penalty, to manage daily cash flow. Britain's central bank, which has taken mostly a hands-off approach to the crisis engulfing world credit markets, allowed banks to raise their reserves by 4.4 billion pounds (about $8.9 billion).
Countrywide Financial said Thursday that it had lined up $12 billion of financing, easing fears that the nation's mortgage lender was facing a crippling cash shortage.

The group whose $10 million prize spurred privately financed rocketeers to send a small piloted craft to the cusp of space in 2004 has issued a new challenge: an unmanned moon shot. With the audacious new contest comes a much bigger prize: up to $25 million, paid for by Google, the ubiquitous Internet company.

Despite the chill in the buyout markets, Blackstone Group is still hiring. The firm said Thursday that Vikrant Sawhney, previously a banker at Deutsche Bank, would join Blackstone as a managing director in its private equity group.

Bank of America sold 230 billion yen ($2 billion) of global bonds on Friday, joining a handful of major banks that have sought to raise cash in Japan's stable credit markets, Reuters reported Friday citing unnamed sources.

The UnitedHealth Group, trying to fend off another investigation into the company's backdating of stock options, asked the Minnesota Appeals Court on Thursday to block an inquiry by the state's attorney general.

Yes, that was a green dot on the back of Eli Manning's helmet on Sunday night. And Tony Romo's. And the same for dozens of other N.F.L. players. The dot marks the helmet as being equipped with a radio transmitter, allowing the player wearing it to communicate to coaches on the sideline or up in the press box. The N.F.L. puts the stickers on before every game. Rules allow only one dotted helmet on the field at a time; usually it's the quarterback's.

“Nashville” rips off “The Hills,” and that’s fine: there’s enough happy dust in the “Hills” magical-reality formula to dose Fox, MTV and any other channel that needs to feel good again.

All four games in Round 1 of the world championship tournament in Mexico City ended in relatively short draws, but not because the games lacked possibilities. Instead, the players seemed to be feeling each other out and acclimating themselves. Clearly, everyone was worried about falling behind by pushing too hard and making a misstep. Between Billy Bob Thornton’s wry performance and Tami Reiker’s nuanced photography, you half-expect “Mr. Woodcock” to deliver more than formulaic laughs.
Somewhere around its midpoint, “Across the Universe” captured my heart, and I realized that falling in love with a movie is like falling in love with another person.
Toots Shor’s name hasn’t lighted up a New York sign for more than 30 years, but thanks to Kristi Jacobson, his granddaughter, it will now grace movie marquees.
“Great World of Sound” observes a sadder, tawdrier side of the self-deluding dream of fame.

In “December Boys,” Daniel Radcliffe takes a holiday from Harry Potter.  Too bad his destination is this treacly coming-of-age tale.
Every other Sunday, in the fields and playgrounds of suburban Baltimore, a medieval fantasy world materializes. That world is the subject of “Darkon.”
“The Brave One,” though well cast and smoothly directed, is just as crude and ugly as you want it to be.
In “Angels in the Dust,” Louise Hogarth reveals a heart-wrenching facet of the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic by turning the camera on a group of innocent children in South Africa.
“Ira & Abby” is a hard-working comedy of lust, therapy and Manhattan angst that deserves an A for ambition, if not achievement.
In his long-awaited memoir, Alan Greenspan says he was mystified at the Republicans’ abandonment of their party’s small government principles.

Police investigators in Las Vegas questioned the former football star today in connection with a break-in of a casino hotel room, according to news reports.
Benazir Bhutto, an exiled former prime minister, will return to Pakistan on Oct. 18, her party said today.
The Mayo Clinic today called for every individual to have basic universal insurance as a step toward gradually replacing the current employer-based system.
A third day of tremors left people here skittish today after Wednesday’s massive earthquake left a death toll throughout the region of at least 13.
A Chinese research assistant for The Times served three years in prison on a conviction that sparked outrage.
Northern Rock’s need for emergency funding represents a broadening of the effects of the global financial crisis.
Viktor A. Zubkov, President Vladimir V. Putin’s little-known choice for prime minister, was confirmed by Parliament today.

Nineteen members of the Lehigh University swim team were charged with underage drinking after the police broke up a party. The police heard loud music coming from a house late Wednesday night and found kegs, bottles of liquor and a beer pong table when they went inside, authorities said. One student was rushed to the hospital after a breath test showed that her blood-alcohol content was 0.31 percent, or nearly four times the legal limit for driving.

The Buffalo Bills placed the starting cornerback Jason Webster on injured reserve. Webster’s season is over after he broke his forearm in the second half of Buffalo’s 15-14 season-opening loss to Denver last Sunday. It is not clear how he was hurt, but it is the latest blow to an already injury-depleted defense as the team prepares to play at Pittsburgh on Sunday.
Steve Slaton ran for 137 yards and 3 touchdowns, while Noel Devine amassed 125 yards on his first three carries for West Virginia.
Cappie Pondexter scored a game-high 26 points, including a driving bank shot with 21 seconds to play to force a deciding fifth game in the W.N.B.A. finals.

A 33-year-old woman was stabbed to death yesterday in her Newark home, the police said. The woman, Jeanine Darby, was found stabbed multiple times in her torso at 84 North Munn Avenue at 8:38 a.m., the police said. She was taken to University Hospital, where she later died. Investigators said last night that they were seeking a 16-year-old boy, who had had previous disputes with the victim. No arrests had been made.
The case is the first the S.E.C. has brought for violations of a requirement that accounting companies that audit public firms register with Public Company Accounting Oversight Board.
The Yankees will face the Red Sox at Fenway Park on Friday leading Detroit by three and a half games in the wild-card race but trailing Boston by five and a half in the American League East.

An article on Tuesday about a case before the New York State Court of Appeals in which prosecutors are arguing that the lone man on the state’s death row, John B. Taylor, should face execution, despite a 2004 ruling by the court that effectively invalidated the state’s death penalty law, referred imprecisely to Steven W. Fisher, the trial judge in the case, who told the Taylor jury that he would “almost certainly” impose consecutive terms totaling more than a century if the decision were left to him. Judge Fisher’s comments, made in 2002, were part of his instructions to the jury after it convicted Mr. Taylor of murder; the judge was not in fact “mindful of the court’s” 2004 ruling at the time.

A sports article on Sunday about Oregon’s 39-7 victory over Michigan referred incorrectly in some copies to the receiver who caught a 61-yard touchdown pass for Oregon. It was Derrick Jones, not Walter Thurmond. (Both players wear No. 6, but Thurmond plays defense.).

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Aug. 28, about the shortage of donor organs, referred incorrectly to organ donation in Europe, and a correction in this space on Wednesday gave contradictory information on how the issue is handled there. Europe does not have a uniform policy on donations; not all countries there consider a person a potential donor unless he expressly declares he does not want to be one. (Some countries require explicit consent for donation and others presume consent but allow a person to opt out of being a donor.).

An article yesterday about President Vladimir V. Putin’s surprise choice of Viktor A. Zubkov, a relatively low-profile financial regulator, to be the next prime minister of Russia, referred imprecisely to the subsequent actions of Dmitri A. Medvedev, a first deputy prime minister, who had been considered a favorite candidate for prime minister. Although Mr. Medvedev made no public announcements, he did indeed make a public appearance — with Mr. Putin, at a conference.

An article on Tuesday about beacons used on planes like the one flown by the missing adventurer Steve Fossett misstated part of the name of such a device, known as an E.L.T. It is an emergency locator transmitter, not an electronic locator transmitter.

An article on Tuesday about the political consequences faced by Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, after deporting a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, as he tried to return from exile misstated the amount of money in American dollars involved in a money laundering case in which Mr. Sharif has been charged. The amount is about $21 million, not “about $31.5 million.” (Indian rupees were used instead of Pakistani rupees in converting 1.273 billion rupees to dollars.).

An article yesterday about President Vladimir V. Putin’s surprise choice of Viktor A. Zubkov, a relatively low-profile financial regulator, to be the next prime minister of Russia, referred imprecisely to the subsequent actions of Dmitri A. Medvedev, a first deputy prime minister, who had been considered a favorite candidate for prime minister. Although Mr. Medvedev made no public announcements, he did indeed make a public appearance — with Mr. Putin, at a conference.

An obituary on Sept. 3 about Alfred H. Peet, an early marketer of gourmet coffee in the United States, referred incorrectly to his early history in the coffee business. At the age of 18, before World War II, he moved to London to work for a coffee and tea company; the company was not Lipton’s Tea, for which he worked after World War II.

An article in Business Day yesterday about homeowners who face steep prepayment penalties on their mortgages gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a Seattle lawyer who commented on the complexity of mortgage contracts. She is Melissa A. Huelsman, not Helmsman. The article also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the given name of a homeowner who says he cannot afford to refinance his house because of a $9,000 prepayment penalty. He is Timm Larson, not Tim.

A film review on Wednesday about “Forever,” a documentary set mainly in the Père-Lachaise cemetery in Paris, erroneously included Maria Callas among those buried there. While her ashes were placed there after her death in 1977, and there is a memorial to her in the cemetery, the ashes were later stolen and after being recovered were scattered over the Aegean Sea.

A sports article in some copies on Wednesday about optimism surrounding the Columbia football team referred incorrectly to the program’s history. Columbia has finished over .500 twice since 1971, not once. (In addition to a 5-4-1 campaign in 1994, the Lions had a winning season in 1996, when they went 8-2.) Also, the article misstated the location of the Columbia-Fordham game scheduled for tomorrow. It will be at Fordham, not Columbia.
President Bush’s address again raises the question of what America’s mission in Iraq really is.
If Eli Manning, who sustained a strained right shoulder against the Dallas Cowboys, is not cleared to play, Jared Lorenzen will step in.

Prosecutors decided not to file marijuana possession charges against Indiana Pacers forward Shawne Williams after his arrest this week, but the team suspended him for the first three games of the regular season for poor judgment. The Marion County prosecutor’s office said the police found marijuana in the vehicle Williams was driving, but prosecutors believed they could not prove the drugs belonged to him.

Meb Keflezighi and Alan Culpepper have entered the United States Olympic team trials that will be held Nov. 3 in Central Park. Dan Browne will also try for a spot on the American squad for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, USA Track and Field and the New York Road Runners said yesterday. Keflezighi won a silver medal in the marathon at the 2004 Athens Games, and Culpepper finished 12th. Browne competed in the 10,000 meters and the marathon in Athens.

Tyrell Gatewood, a senior safety at Texas, was released from jail after his arrest on drug charges, the fifth arrest of a Longhorns player since June. Gatewood, 22, was charged with two counts of possession of a dangerous drug.

Commissioner Roger Goodell visited the injured Bills tight end Kevin Everett, who sustained a severe spinal cord injury. Goodell flew to Buffalo from New York and spent 90 minutes with Everett and his mother, Patricia Dugas, in the player’s room at Millard Fillmore Gates Hospital, a hospital spokesman said.

The Dallas Cowboys wrested the title of the N.F.L.’s most valuable franchise from the Redskins, knocking Washington off the top of the list for the first time in eight years, according to Forbes magazine’s survey. Thanks to a new $1 billion stadium set to open in 2009, the Cowboys’ value increased by 28 percent to $1.5 billion. With their climb from third, Dallas passed the Redskins ($1.467 billion) and New England ($1.199 billion). Both New York teams had big jumps because of a planned stadium that they will share. The Giants moved to 8th from 15th with a 9 percent increase to $974 million. The Jets went to 10th from 19th with a 10 percent increase to $967 million.
In its plan to withdraw five combat brigades by next summer, the White House was careful not to be pinned down on just how many soldiers would remain.
It’s a disgraceful decision for the new law school of the University of California, Irvine, to rescind its offer of deanship to Erwin Chemerinsky because of his political views.
Congress should reform the ailing unemployment compensation program if the job market weakens further and more Americans may need to turn to it.

A dispute over whether a 20-foot inflatable rat can be kept out of a New Jersey town is headed to State Supreme Court, New Jersey’s highest. A three-judge appeals panel ruled yesterday that Lawrence Township could ban the big black rat, which a union local wanted to display during a protest in 2005. But the litigants can appeal automatically to the Supreme Court because of one judge’s partial dissent. The event, at Gold’s Gym in Lawrence, was staged by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers to protest low wages paid to electricians by an out-of-area contractor. Wayne DeAngelo, the senior union official on the site, was fined for violating an ordinance preventing the display of banners, streamers and inflatable signs. The appeals panel affirmed Mr. DeAngelo’s conviction yesterday. However, Judge Jack Sabatino of the Appellate Division of State Superior Court wrote that the ban might be unfair because it exempted signs for grand openings.

A soldier from Washington Heights who was killed while serving with the Army’s Second Infantry Division in Iraq is to receive citizenship posthumously on Monday, immigration officials said in a statement yesterday. The soldier, Cpl. Juan Alcántara, 22, left, was one of four soldiers killed in an explosion as they searched a house in Baquba on Aug. 6. Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Harlem Democrat, will speak at a ceremony at the City University Great Hall in Manhattan and present a certificate to Corporal Alcántara’s family. The corporal was born in the Dominican Republic and grew up in Washington Heights, Mr. Rangel’s office said.

A new casino planned by the Revel Entertainment Group, featuring two hotel towers with 3,800 rooms, would be Atlantic City’s tallest building. The company filed plans last week with the state and the city. The project, which is scheduled for completion by 2011, is expected to be built on 20 acres just north of the Showboat casino and would include more than 1,000 feet of Boardwalk frontage. The casino is expected to cost about $2 billion, the company said.

The pool-equipped barge that attracted thousands of swimmers to the Brooklyn Bridge Park this summer might be headed to Barretto Point Park in the Bronx next year, officials said yesterday. The barge, which drew about 50,000 visitors this year, left its mooring in Brooklyn yesterday and headed to dry dock in Bayonne, N.J., where it will spend the winter. Ann L. Buttenwieser, the head of the Neptune Foundation, which owns the barge, said she was working with the city’s Parks and Recreation Department to station the barge in the Bronx next year. The parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, said the department supported the plan and was working to secure approvals.

An audit released this week by the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, criticizes the financial management of a program in which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority periodically runs excursions with vintage subway cars, called the Nostalgia Train. The trips raise money for the New York Transit Museum, an arm of the authority based in a decommissioned subway station in Brooklyn Heights. Mr. DiNapoli’s audit, released on Wednesday, found that the authority did not adequately keep track of the money it raised. It also said repairs to the trains were paid for by New York City Transit, meaning that subway riders and taxpayers were subsidizing the rides. The comptroller’s office recommended that the authority’s board “evaluate the appropriateness of this fund-raising arrangement.” The authority noted that the Transit Museum was not expected to turn a profit.

Credits earned at New Jersey’s county colleges must be accepted at the state’s colleges and universities under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. Jon S. Corzine. The law is meant to help students with an associate’s degree from the state’s 19 county colleges transfer credits toward a degree from a four-year institution. The new program begins with the 2008-9 academic year.

Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino will eliminate smoking on its casino floor, officials said yesterday, bringing to six the number of Atlantic City casinos that will ban smoking where patrons gamble. All 11 Atlantic City casinos must tell the state by tomorrow how they intend to comply with a partial smoking ban enacted by the Atlantic City Council in February mandating that at least 75 percent of the space on the casino’s floor be smoke-free. Trump Plaza is among the six casinos that have chosen to create nongambling smokers’ lounges.
Once again, it is clear that President Bush refuses to recognize the truth of his failure in Iraq and envisions a military commitment that has no end.
Coach Bill Belichick was fined $500,000 and the Patriots were ordered to forfeit a draft pick and pay $250,000.

The mother of a 3-year-old girl who became known as Precious Doe after her remains were found in a Kansas City Park in 2001 pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the girl’s death. The woman, Michelle Johnson, 32, of Muskogee, Okla., also pleaded guilty to child endangerment, abandoning a corpse and tampering with evidence. As part of a plea deal, Ms. Johnson will testify against her husband, Harrell Johnson, who is charged with first-degree murder in the death of the girl, who was identified in 2005 as Erica Michelle Marie Green.

The former head of an oil field service company said in federal court that he bribed three Alaska legislators, including the son of a senator who is under federal investigation. The man, Bill Allen, 70, the former chief executive of the VECO Corporation, testified in the corruption trial of former Speaker Pete Kott of the state House. Mr. Allen is awaiting sentencing on bribery charges. He said he bribed Mr. Kott; the former State Senate president, Ben Stevens; and former Representative Vic Kohring. Mr. Stevens, the son of United States Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, is under federal investigation but has not been charged. “Mr. Stevens has consistently said he’s not engaged in any of the illegal activity that is alleged by Mr. Allen,” John Wolfe, Mr. Stevens’s lawyer, said.

A judge spared a man who was to be executed today in a double murder, after the Dallas County prosecutor’s office discovered evidence they believe had been withheld from the man’s lawyers. A second polygraph given to a co-defendant of the man, Joseph Lave, came to light in the last few days and reflects on the credibility of the co-defendant, said Mike Ware, of the district attorney’s conviction integrity unit. Mr. Lave was one of three robbers involved in the 1992 deaths of two teenagers in Richardson. Prosecutors say lawyers no longer with the office misled the court by saying the evidence did not exist.

Philadelphia’s police chief, acknowledging that the police alone cannot quell a run of deadly violence, has called on 10,000 men to patrol the streets to reduce crime. The chief, Sylvester Johnson, says black men, in particular, have a duty to protect vulnerable residents. He wants volunteers to work three hours a day for at least 90 days. “We are definitely encouraging black men to be involved in it,” he said. But he said he would not turn away men of other races. “We have to put the tourniquet where we’re bleeding at this point,” he said. The men would not make arrests but would emphasize conflict resolution.

Two advocacy groups asked a court to stop the Texas Youth Commission from permitting the use of pepper spray to subdue unruly juvenile prisoners before other forms of restraint. The lawsuit was filed on behalf of three 15-year-old incarcerated youths with mental disabilities who say they have been sprayed or threatened with spray. Commission officials issued a directive last month allowing the use of pepper spray before other forceful restraints, arguing that it would reduce injuries to staff members and inmates. Critics say the use has since skyrocketed in commission lockups. The suit comes as a task force, formed by the commission, criticized the expanded use of pepper spray, as first reported by The Austin American-Statesman.

A man who grew up on the tree-lined blocks of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, and returned regularly despite having moved away, was fatally shot on the steps of a brownstone yesterday morning after being chased by a gunman down one of those blocks.
The New Yorkers who frequent pawnshops often want something simple: quick cash to help get by.
New Jersey voters will not have a printed record of their electronic votes in the state’s presidential primary next February, Attorney General Anne Milgram said.
Roger Clemens, 45, wants to be part of the playoff push. His last start, on Sept. 3, was cut short after four innings because of an inflamed elbow.
Rudolph W. Giuliani said that The New York Times and an antiwar group had engaged in character assassination against Gen. David H. Petraeus, the American commander in Iraq.
The departure from Harvard this week of Mohamed A. El-Erian highlights the difficulties that universities face in retaining endowment chiefs.
Over the years, one building in Palo Alto, Calif., has been home to some of Silicon Valley’s most successful start-ups.
ABC News is beginning a second investigation into five years of reports that relied on information from a consultant who faked interviews for a French journal.
The state comptroller has instituted new policies regarding the disclosure of the use of intermediaries by investment firms who do business with the New York State pension fund.
There are signs that consumers are beginning to be more cautious as a result of the turmoil in the credit markets.
The choice may signal the union’s willingness to bargain on a health care trust as the current contract with automakers is set to expire Friday night.
Tim Clark tied the East Lake Golf Club record Thursday with an eight-under-par 62 in the first round of the P.G.A. Tour playoffs.
Now that Gen. David H. Petraeus’s presentation on the Iraq war has come and gone, Republicans’ talking points on the war have seemed only to toughen.
Another earthquake shook the coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra on Thursday, but the area escaped a major tsunami like the one that devastated the region in 2004.
Mr. Spira is credited with helping standardize modern camera equipment and making it accessible to amateurs.
The four officers were shot in Cutler Bay, a suburb about 20 miles southwest of downtown Miami, after they pulled over the suspect, who opened fire with an assault rifle.
Private lawyers for two top aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer said they would not fight subpoenas issued by the State Ethics Commission earlier this week.
Greg Oden, the top pick in this year’s N.B.A. draft, will likely miss his first season after surgery on his knee Thursday.
KKR Financial Holdings said Thursday that it would sell seven of its private equity investments to two institutional investors.
ESPN’s decision to relieve Joe Theismann with Ron Jaworski on “Monday Night Football” looks like a smart audible.
A state-approved educational video that discusses a same-sex couple has sparked debate in New Jersey.
A judge ordered the bond for Norman Hsu after authorities told the court that Mr. Hsu might have been involved in another multimillion-dollar fraud investigation.
A pipe bomb, a rifle, ammunition and antigovernment literature were found during a raid on the bedroom of a Garden City man accused of aiding two fugitive tax resisters.
An initiative, known as Healthy San Francisco, is the first effort by a locality to guarantee care to all of its uninsured.
The higher crude prices could put a new drag on the economy at a time when it seems to be weakening.
Two lawyers representing George J. Mitchell, who is leading Major League Baseball’s investigation of performance-enhancing drug use, met with officials from the district attorney’s office in Albany.
The Bank of England eased restrictions on how much cash banks can borrow to manage daily cash flow, allowing greater flexibility as the banks grapple with the credit crisis.

The prosecution’s star witness in the trial of the fundamentalist Mormon polygamist leader Warren S. Jeffs testified that she was taught to either obey church leaders without question or face dire consequences.
Prime Minister Bertie Ahern told an anticorruption tribunal he did nothing wrong in accepting tens of thousands of pounds in the early 1990s when he was finance minister and deputy premier.

The Hamas government in the Gaza Strip called on Palestinian militants to stop firing rockets and mortar bombs at border crossings with Israel that are used to bring in food and aid, especially during Ramadan.
The General Assembly overwhelmingly passed a declaration on the human rights of the world’s indigenous people, but Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States voted no.

The Canadian police have arrested a suspect in connection with three Austrians linked to Al Qaeda who were detained in Vienna on Wednesday. Said Namouh, 35, was arrested in Maskinonge, Quebec, on Wednesday, and charged with plotting to cause explosions in a foreign country.

Former Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, a suspect in a smear campaign against Nicolas Sarkozy before he was elected president, accused the president of a conflict of interest in the case. Mr. Sarkozy is the plaintiff and, by virtue of his office, oversees the Magistrates Council and the Justice Ministry. “Does that not mean that he is judge and participant and does that astonish anyone in a country governed by the rule of law?” Mr. Villepin said in a statement. Mr. Sarkozy has not commented on the case.
The Pacific island state of Tuvalu begged the rest of the world to do more to combat global warming before it sank beneath the ocean.
A licensing dispute over cellphone ring tones between the estate of Bob Marley, the Universal Music Group, and Verizon Wireless took an ugly turn on Thursday.
The Dow Jones industrial average close up 133 points on Thursday, boosted by signs that the credit markets may be thawing.

In a decision that somehow managed to bring together karaoke, laser tag, exotic dancers and rabbinical consultations, a federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a lower court had erred in saying the College of Staten Island could not deny official recognition to a Jewish fraternity simply because all of its members were male.
Nair, like other depilatory makers, is expanding its product offerings and beginning to market to younger customers.
Verizon Wireless has sued the F.C.C., seeking to overturn auction rules requiring the buyers of some airwaves to make their networks compatible with any device.
The Shul Band, a folk rock octet, describes itself as “Jerry Garcia in Jerusalem.”
Five and a half months into Daisuke Matsuzaka’s hyped first season with the Boston Red Sox, he has deteriorated into a pitching punching bag.
As the Rangers gathered for their first official day of training camp, questions lingered about whether this talented team can develop championship chemistry.
If history is a barometer as to whether or not the Mets will win their division, the team is essentially on a lounge chair with a frosty drink within reach.
President Bush opted for higher troop levels than some of his senior military advisers wanted.
The day before their match with China, Denmark team officials found two men with video cameras sitting behind a two-way mirror in the room where the team was about to hold a strategy meeting.

Steve Trachsel earned his first victory with the Cubs since being acquired from Baltimore on Aug. 31 and Chicago hit four home runs last night to regain the National League Central lead by beating the host Houston Astros, 6-2.
Terry Ryan resigned Thursday as general manager of the Minnesota Twins, effective at the end of the season.

The UnitedHealth Group, trying to fend off another investigation into the company’s backdating of stock options, asked the Minnesota Appeals Court on Thursday to block an inquiry by the state’s attorney general.
Of all the titillating details in the Patriots spy story, the biggest mystery is why they did such a poor job of disguising their alleged surveillance practices.
Funds that invest in “sin stocks” — companies involved with drinking and gambling, for example — have earned better returns this year than funds striving to be socially responsible.
The punishment for McLaren Mercedes was by far the harshest in the 57-year history of Formula One racing.
Experts are questioning a study’s linking a 2004 increase in the suicide rate for children and adolescents to a warning by drug regulators about the use of antidepressants in minors.
Lisa Dennison, the museum director who startled the art world by abruptly resigning from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, is now trying her hand at auctioning.
The board of the union, representing employees at The Wall Street Journal and other Dow Jones properties, is set to meet on Friday to endorse the deal and set a date for a vote by the membership.
The increase was smaller than expected, suggesting resilience in the labor markets.
Tuareg rebels fighting government troops in Mali’s far northern desert have fired on an American military plane that was delivering food to a Malian Army garrison.
A blast Thursday evening, apparently set off by a suicide bomber, tore through the dining hall of a military installation.
For the first time in his career,  Martin Truex, the lesser-known teammate of Dale Earnhardt Jr., has earned a spot in the 10-race Chase for the Nextel Cup playoff.
Fires that tore through forests and farmland in August have affected elections in Greece, pitting candidates in what appears to be one of the toughest races in memory.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was hospitalized on Thursday morning, and the governing Liberal Democratic Party pushed back the date to choose his successor.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,768 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., struggling like other home builders, is offering six-figure discounts on some of its properties this weekend as it tries to draw interest in a slumping market.
The contest calls for entrants to land a rover on the moon that will be able to travel at least 550 yards and send high-resolution video, still images and other data back home.
Two Colombian politicians were charged in the killing in 2003 of a journalist who had reported on ties between government officials and illegal paramilitaries.
San Francisco is gambling that it can provide universal and sensibly managed care to the uninsured for about the amount being spent on their treatment now.
Aleksandr Y. Pichushkin is charged with 49 counts of murder, part of what the authorities describe as a macabre and sustained scheme to kill one person for every square on a chessboard.
By taking the side of pro-lifers for democratic, but not devout, motives, a President Giuliani could shake up the nearly 35-year-old debate over Roe v. Wade.
Comings and goings in the banking indurstry.
The home of the president, Congress, central bank and government ministries might be in La Paz, but residents of Sucre, Bolivia, insist that their city is the real capital.
NATALIE FRANK.
But a new analysis in a British journal includes some less clear-cut findings that may spell trouble for Boston Scientific.
Ms. Parker will star alongside Kathleen Chalfant in the Playwrights Horizons production of Sarah Ruhl’s new play, “Dead Man’s Cell Phone.”
Vanished child case delays film premiere, London Film Festival to open in October, a rush for Led Zeppelin seats and more culture news.
Roberta Maxwell is so magnificent as an aged sculptor in “The Shape of Metal” that it’s easy to see why she would have been drawn to this ramshackle work.
A high-profile sheik who collaborated with the U.S. military in the fight against jihadist militants was killed in a bomb attack.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The East Village has been dragged up-market, but isn’t going without a fight.
This intermittently funny but meandering comedy by Danny Hoch squanders much of its considerable potential.
Deloss Brown’s new comedy comes out of the Restoration stage world of rakes and cuckolds and sexual misalliances.
The Grey Art Gallery offers a spirited display of Latin American abstraction. Working through its riches is both humbling and thrilling; you encounter your ignorance and have a chance to rectify it.

The show, which weaves like a DNA strand through the Metropolitan Museum’s Chinese galleries,  has the casual logic of a household photo album, with evidence of shared habits, tastes and temperaments, and of rapport between generations.
President Vladimir V. Putin’s little-known choice to be prime minister suggested on Thursday that he might consider running for president next year.
Ian McKellen — in Trevor Nunn’s otherwise spotty interpretation of “King Lear,” which runs in repertory with Chekhov’s “Seagull” — wears old age as a coat of many, infinitely mutating colors.
Charles Burnett’s “My Brother’s Wedding” has a sense of place and personality that is marvelous and rare.
The Mettawee River Theater Company’s adaptation of Aristophanes’ comedy demonstrates a kind of fundamental good health: it gets the job done.
Jeff Koons’s “Blue Diamond,” will be offered for sale on Nov. 13 at Christie’s auction of postwar and contemporary art, with an estimate of around $12 million.
The company revised its 2007 sales forecast lower for a third time this year because of price reductions and reduced orders.
As the writer delves into his wretched childhood, his operation seems less like a turning point than an overcharged symbolic event. In a curious way, this only makes the story more intriguing.

10 P.M. (Sundance) 40 SHADES OF BLUE (2005) A long-suffering Russian woman living in Memphis with a maniacal record producer eases her pain by having an affair with his adult son. Rip Torn, Dina Korzun and Darren Burrows star in this country-and-blues-tinged drama by Ira Sachs, which won the top prize at the Sundance Film Festival in 2005. (Above, Mr. Torn and Paprika Steen.) “The songs distill pain, desire and betrayal into something humorous and joyful,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, “an alchemy that is sadly beyond the reach of the Memphis residents who populate this beautiful, melancholy film.”.
Selected dance listings by critics of The New York Times.
FOR CHILDREN.
JAZZ.
Selected art listings by critics of The New York Times.
AROUND TOWN.
CLASSICAL.
POP.
MOVIES.
Selective listings from theater critics of The New York Times.
In the auction world almost nothing is more intriguing than fresh, unknown collections. Sotheby’s has found a new route to them this fall: outsourcing the sale’s expert.
Poor starts by Notre Dame and Michigan, who play Saturday in Ann Arbor, raise the question: Can the two  programs contend for championships without lowering academic standards?
Pissarro emerges from this exhibition  at the Jewish Museum as an artist whose subtly anti-authoritarian stance propelled painting into the next century.
A Bush administration program has not focused enough on the impact of warming on humans, the panel said.
President Bush argued that his plan to begin gradually withdrawing some troops from Iraq was a “return on success” that could be squandered by deeper and speedier reductions.
President Bush argued that his plan to begin gradually withdrawing some troops from Iraq was a “return on success” that could be squandered by deeper and speedier reductions.
Corporate pessimism seems to be growing. Would a Fed rate cut help?
N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell should have come down harder on the Patriots, given how he has leveled players like Pacman Jones, Tank Williams and Michael Vick.
Rutgers fans in the student section are said to have profanely and drunkenly serenaded Navy’s players during a 41-24 Rutgers victory.
How Doctors Without Borders dealt with pain management is an example of how hard it is to get painkillers to many of the world’s poor.
Inevitably, the first question patients ask about morphine is: But isn’t it addictive?
Next week’s meeting of the Fed’s policy makers is likely to focus on how much to cut rates and may mark a defining moment for the Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman.

Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, said yesterday that it had lined up $12 billion of financing to help weather a housing slowdown that it expects to lead to widespread layoffs.
Neighbors in Hell’s Kitchen are wondering who will rent the corner lot that used to be home to the Market Diner.
The reality is that from the beginning, the politicians have not even tried to articulate their own reflections on the meaning of that terrible day in 2001.
The Congress is moving to revamp electoral laws to rein in negative campaigns and to keep businesses and individuals from trying to influence elections.
A couple of New York producers have plans to bring a concert version of “Jerry Springer: The Opera” to, of all places, Carnegie Hall.
The normally sleepy Joyce SoHo kick-started its effort to revitalize itself by presenting the American premiere of Jeremy Wade’s “... and pulled out their hair.”
Not far from East Coast cities, Cherry Springs State Park is so dark you can see for light-years.

HOFHEIMER--Joseph . Died suddenly September 10th at the age of 83 in White Plains, NY. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 58 years Natalie (nee Doernberg), survived by his children, Judy Wiesen (Larry), Jean Bennett, Joanne Egerman (Paul), Jim Hofheimer (Teresa), Josie Funchess (Jerry) and by his 12 adoring grandchildren, Eric, David, Jeff, Rachel, Michael, Sarah, Mark, Ben, Matthew, Andrew, Scott and Myron. Also survived by his sister and brother-in-law Babette and Walter Sonneborn, and Natalie's brother and sister Dudley Doernberg and Margery Bruno. He was predeceased by his brother Hank and his parents Henry and Hannah Hofheimer. Joseph cherished his relationship with his many nieces, nephews, and their children. He was a man who loved life and loved his family. He was a visionary who gave tirelessly to the community and served on the boards of the White Plains Hospital, Blythedale Children's Hospital, SUNY Purchase and Mt. Holyoke Art Museum. He also served on the boards of the Scarsdale Board of Education, Hospital for Joint Diseases, UJA, Human Rights Watch, The Fund for Free Expression, Jewish Community Center of White Plains, Barnard College, and the STEP program. The Scarsdale Foundation honored him with the Scarsdale Bowl in 1986. A graduate of Cornell University, Joseph served in the army in the Second World War. Upon his discharge he worked for and subsequently became the president and owner of Richard Bauer and Co. until he was 79. He was a lifelong Democrat, an avid reader and gardener, and loved to play tennis and swim. Everyone whose life he touched came away enriched and he left the world brighter because of his vision, idealism and his huge heart. Services will be held at 10:30am Wednesday at Kol Ami Synagogue in White Plains, 252 Soundview Avenue. The family will receive friends at his home, 39 Oxford Rd. in Scarsdale, Wednesday from 2-5, Friday from 1-5 and Saturday from 6-9. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Joseph Hofheimer Fund at White Plains Hospital, Davis Ave. at E. Post Rd., White Plains, NY 10601 or Blythedale Children's Hospital, 95 Bradhurst Ave, Valhalla, NY 10595. HOFHEIMER--Joseph. The entire Barnard College community is deeply saddened by the death of our long-serving trustee, Joseph Hofheimer. Joseph and his late wife Natalie generously supported the Hannah Falk Hofheimer 1909 & Henry Hofheimer Scholarship Fund, and the Blanche Heyman Doernberg 1905 Scholarship Fund in memory of their parents. Sincere condolences are offered to his entire family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President

EARTHA KITTIt is not entirely far-fetched to imagine Eartha Kitt as the opening act of MTV's Video Music Awards. Imagine her Catwoman from the television series ''Batman'' growling ''I Want to Be Evil,'' one of her signature songs from the early 1950s, at last Sunday's awards, instead of a glassy-eyed Britney Spears sloppily lip-synching her latest single, ''Gimme More,'' while executing a few feeble bumps and grinds. Ms. Kitt doesn't need to lip-sync, nor is there anything feeble about her. A complete show business professional, this eternal sex kitten, who turned 80 last January, is in trimmer condition right now than Ms. Spears apparently is. And believe it or not, she is still smolderingly sexy. Ms. Kitt knows how to make a single shoulder shrug or raised eyebrow convey more erotic provocation than most performers less than half her age. And when she locks eyes with a man at ringside and begins to purr and play the gold digger, she emits a dangerous electric charge. It's all in fun, of course. Or is it?

PHILLIPS--Allyn , 80, of West Beach, South Australia, formerly of New Rochelle, NY, died peacefully at his home on September 8. Allyn was born in New York City on April 25, 1927. A graduate of Queens College. He was a distinguished English teacher for over two decades at Mamaroneck (NY) High School, retiring in 1988. He leaves his loving wife Marnie of West Beach; his sons Paul of Coronado, California; John of Seattle, Washington; David of Pipersville, Pennsylvania; their wives and seven grandchildren. He is also survived by his sisters Dorothy of Laguna Beach; Margie of San Francisco; and Richard of Palos Verdes -all in California. To know Allyn was to appreciate his love for the active life and the natural world. His passions included sailing, biking, hiking, camping, birding, cross-country skiing, and tennis. His zest for these activities will keep his memory alive.

NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' earned Wednesday night's top ratings among adults 18 to 49, but CBS still managed to finish No. 1 on the night over all with its lineup of crime drama repeats and ''Power of 10.'' Even as NBC's stand-up comedy competition, whose final round will be broadcast next week, fared well in the 18-to-49 demographic, it drew just 6.5 million total viewers at 9 p.m., considerably behind CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' rerun in the hour (8.1 million), Nielsen reported. CBS also easily led the 8 and 10 p.m. hours with ''Power of 10'' (7.8 million) and ''CSI: NY'' (8.9 million), respectively. NBC ended the night in second place. ABC and Fox, both largely broadcasting repeats, finished about even in third. ABC's ''Nascar in Primetime'' drew just 2.7 million viewers at 10 in its fifth and final episode.

'PASO DOBLE' Collaborative ventures between artists in different places usually mean that each works separately, and that the pieces are put together late in the creative process. ''Paso Doble,'' a performance event by the Hungarian-born choreographer Josef Nadj and the Catalan artist Miquel Barceló, which opens the St. Ann's Warehouse season tonight, is a rare example of another kind of collaboration. On a stage covered in red clay, Mr. Nadj (at painting, above) and Mr. Barceló (in foreground) punch their way through an initially pristine white wall, then -- using pickaxes and shovels, sculpturing tools and their bare hands -- they carve, dig and shape the clay into a landscape of forms that are quickly erased and replaced. Mr. Barceló bangs the floor until a pool of water appears. Mr. Nadj, a tall man with the face of a tragic clown, sets a soft clay pot on top of his head and lets it slowly melt over his face. At the end they are covered in rusty clay and white dust, almost indistinguishable from their material. As they work, they are performers, choreographers, sculptors and artists all at once. And they are also part of the artwork itself, their bodies mutable elements in its changing topography.

Foxy Brown's next issue will be an album, not a baby. Although the rapper's defense lawyers said in court last month that she was three months pregnant, her manager, ChazWilliams, issued a statement on Wednesday saying, ''And to the pregnancy rumors, this is the official statement: She is not pregnant.'' Mr. Williams and Koch Records also announced that Ms. Brown, above, whose real name is Inga Marchand, would release the album ''Brooklyn's Don Diva'' on Nov. 20, while serving a one-year jail sentence. Last Friday Ms. Brown was sentenced for violating probation arising from a fight with two manicurists in a nail salon in New York three years ago. ''This is just a temporary situation,'' she said in a statement. ''I made my bed and have no problem lying in it. My will is steady. What doesn't kill me will only make me stronger.''

FESTIVAL OF NEW TRUMPET MUSIC The horns are not just plentiful but purposeful during the Festival of New Trumpet Music, which begins its fifth year of programming tomorrow night. Founded and directed by Dave Douglas, a jazz trumpeter rightly celebrated for his imaginative rigor, it presents a host of independent-minded artists in a range of club and concert settings. A kickoff concert at the Center for Improvisational Music in Brooklyn will benefit a handful of musician-run educational programs in the city. And its roster of performers neatly encapsulates the festival's broad-minded ethos: Cecil Bridgewater, Ralph Alessi, Taylor Ho Bynum and Roy Campbell Jr. all bring different perspectives as trumpeters and improvisers, as does Mr. Douglas, above, who will also perform. Of course those artists have something in common besides their choice of instrument. By definition, the Festival of New Trumpet Music prizes a spirit of innovation; that ''new'' in the title is no accident. It's a mandate that should resonate with anyone who has observed the prolific Mr. Douglas over the last dozen years. Within the next week alone, he will introduce two new compositions as part of the festival: ''Blue Latitudes,'' at the Manhattan School of Music on Sunday, and ''Inspiration,'' a collaborative effort with his fellow trumpeter Jeremy Pelt, at Jazz Standard on Thursday. And judging by precedent, Mr. Douglas will be present for most of the other events.

WITTEN--Robert C . The Dunewood community notes with sorrow the loss of our longtime good neighbor and dear friend, and extends our deepest sympathy to his wife Greta and to his children, Judy, Andy and Betsy. WITTEN--Robert C., died September 11th, 2007, three days short of his 88th birthday. He leaves behind his wife and best friend Greta Walker, children Andrew, Betsy, and Judith, stepson David, their partners Kevin, Dana, and Charlotte, four grandchildren, and a bounty of friends. He was lucky to have married happily twice, and was predeceased by Barbara Yager Witten on September 15th, 1987. Bob was a consummate New Yorker; he moved from NJ in 1937 to attend Columbia College and stayed here taking advantage of everything the City could offer: opera, theater, and summers on Fire Island playing tennis and chasing away the deer. He was also a great traveler, something that grew from his years as an officer in the Navy aboard the USS Greene during WWII. Bob had a sharp mind, great humor, and integrity. He built his company on hard work and his handshake. He was proud that people trusted and relied on him, and so were we. A private ceremony will be held. Contributions in his honor may be made to: Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute, Box 1070, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, NYC, NY 10029.

The British release and London Film Festival screening of Ben Affleck's first full-length feature as a director, ''Gone Baby Gone,'' have been scrubbed because of its parallels to the case of Madeleine McCann, the British 4-year-old who vanished in Portugal in May, the BBC reported. The film, starring Mr. Affleck's brother Casey Affleck and Morgan Freeman, follows two Boston private detectives helping a police investigation of a missing child, played by Madeline O'Brien, who bears a close resemblance to the missing girl. In a statement explaining their decision to postpone the British release, scheduled for Dec. 28, Buena Vista International, the distributor, and Miramax, its subsidiary, said they were ''sensitive to the depth of feeling surrounding the disappearance of Madeleine McCann.'' Sandra Hebron, artistic director of the London Film Festival, where the movie was to have been shown on Oct. 26, said she supported the decision to withdraw the film, filmed last year and based on a 1998 Dennis Lehane novel of the same title. Speaking at the recent Deauville Film Festival, Ben Affleck said he was ''acutely aware of the situation'' regarding Madeleine McCann and called the release of the film ''just a commercial matter, whereas this is a matter of life and death.'' He added, ''We don't want to release the movie if it is going to touch a nerve or inflame anybody's sensitivities.'' A district attorney in Portugal is deciding whether to charge Kate and Gerry McCann, Madeleine's parents, in the case. They were cited as suspects last week.

DECISION TIME AT THE FED When policy makers at the Federal Reserve meet to set interest rates on Tuesday, their debate is likely to be less about whether to reduce rates than about how much. The meeting is also likely to be a defining moment for Ben S. Bernanke, who has not had to wrestle with a major economic upheaval since he took over as Fed chairman in February 2006. [C1.]

BABCOCK--Edward Dennison Jr . The officers and Associates of Cotterell, Mitchell and Fifer (CM&F Group) mourn the September 7th passing of our former Vice President, mentor and friend. He was a gentleman of the Old School who, from the time he came to Cotterell from Colgate after World War II until his retirement some 40 years later, always and in every way comported himself with aplomb, dignity and forbearance. He was a master of the arcane aspects of Commercial Insurance and Surety and lent his expertise to numerous clients as well as mentoring new professionals when they entered the field. ''Denny'' was a steadfast friend and supporter of this firm. Despite being a WWII hero, having earned a Bronze Star during the conflict, he was humble and circumspect about his accomplishments and service to his nation. Beloved Husband of the late Molly, he would always generate a smile and twinkle when recounting their partnership as curling enthusiasts or their treasured Julys at Groton-Long-Point in the Bosom of their wonderful extended family. Denny is mourned and will be remembered as an icon of another more stable and optimistic time. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his surviving three sons, their wives and children. Richard J. J. Sullivan, Jr. President & CEO The CM&F Group, Inc

ROSS--Arthur . The Noyac Golf Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Arthur Ross, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife, Janet, and to the entire Ross family. Ted Ronick, President Alan Jacobs, Secretary ROSS--Arthur. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend, Arthur Ross, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council for 15 years. A true Renaissance man in his reverence for and delight in nature, art, and science, Arthur was deeply committed to advancing research and education. He brought keen intelligence, astute judgment, and a vigorous passion for science to his service as a member of the Council Executive Committee since 1998. Appreciating the importance of basic research, he endowed the Arthur and Janet Ross Professorship in neuroscience research to address Alzheimer's disease. With his wife, Janet, also a member of the Council, he provided leadership and support to the University's Women & Science program. Friend, advisor, and benefactor, Arthur Ross was an enlightened partner in the struggle against human disease. A philanthropist of generosity and distinction, his commitment to the greater community exemplified The Rockefeller University motto: pro bono humani generis. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Janet, his children and grandchildren, and to the entire Ross family. Russell L. Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and Council Chair Members of the Council Executive Committee Paul Nurse, President Charles D. Gilbert, Arthur and Janet Ross Professor ROSS--Arthur. The Board of Directors, physicians, and researchers of The Macula Foundation mourn the loss of Arthur Ross. Arthur was a generous benefactor of the Foundation's research and educational efforts in the specialty of retinal and macular diseases. We will miss his generous and humble demeanor and his enthusiastic passion for our research. We will not forget him, nor will the many patients with macular disease who are the true beneficiaries of his generosity. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Janet and the entire Ross family. Lawrence A. Yannuzzi, M.D., President The Macula Foundation, Inc.

MAD. SQ. ART 2007: 'AROUND THE PARK' There is a meticulous absurdity to William Wegman's ''Around the Park,'' a temporary video installation adjacent to Shake Shack, the popular food kiosk in Madison Square Park. Showing simultaneously on four outdoor television monitors, the video, above, follows two lovely silver-gray Weimaraners, Penny and Bobbin, as they enjoy a day in the park. But this isn't a dog walk -- far from it. Mr. Wegman has dressed the dogs to look like people and then filmed them lounging about on benches, reading books, interacting with each other on the lawn, eating burgers and fries at the kiosk, and even driving around collecting trash. It is a cross between the 1974 television series ''Planet of the Apes'' and ''Saturday Night Live.'' It is also a carefully contrived stunt, with the dogs propped up on stools as hidden actors hold them in place. These actors also provide the dogs with surrogate hands with which to hold food, books and other items. Still, it took Mr. Wegman many days of shooting to get the approximately seven-minute-long footage showing here; the dogs were incredibly skittish and kept darting off whenever they saw a squirrel. (Through Oct. 28, Madison Square Park, 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, 212-538-4689, madisonsquarepark.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO
