Humberto Leon of opening ceremony brings his brand of downtown cool to L.A. 1. Los Angeles just got an injection of New York style, thanks to Humberto Leon and his business partner Carol Lim, whose clever concept store, Opening Ceremony, bowed on Manhattan's Howard Street in 2002. Their West Coast outpost, behind an unmarked door at 451 North La Cienega Boulevard, offers an unpredictable mix of fashion, furniture, art and media. ''We sell superclassic items as well as totally wild ones,'' Leon says. ''You'll find perfectly tailored suits right next to custom Ping-Pong tables that have fluorescent California state flags on them.''

Decades after he designed the cover for the breakthrough New Order album ''Power, Corruption and Lies'' (left ), Peter Saville remains the biggest rock star in British graphic design. Raf Simons dedicated an entire fashion show to Saville's Factory Records archive in 2003, and a year later Saville's hometown of Manchester appointed him its creative director. ''Estate'' (JRP Ringier) is the first major publication of his oeuvre, which spans the worlds of music, fashion, art and advertising. A companion to the recent retrospective at the Migros Museum in Zurich, the tome will also include essays and recollections from friends and colleagues like the photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, making it required viewing for Mancunians and design groupies alike.

WHEN President Bush announced plans late last month to help borrowers who were struggling to keep up with their adjustable-rate mortgages, local housing advocates and lenders waited eagerly for details of exactly how the initiative would work. Now that the Federal Housing Administration has disclosed those details, the jury is still out. ''I think there's a subset of borrowers this will help,'' said Brian J. Chapelle, a partner in Potomac Partners in Washington, a consulting firm to the mortgage industry. ''Whether it's the 240,000 people the Bush administration said it would help, we'll have to see.''

The Corduroy Appreciation Club Inspired by established organizations like Rotary International, the Brooklyn corduroy enthusiast (you heard that right) Miles Rohan founded the Corduroy Appreciation Club in 2005. Members must wear at least two items of corduroy to assemblies, where surreal motions receive yea or nay votes and cries of ''Hail the wale!'' often break out. (The club's official mascot is the humpback whale, for its homonymic appeal and corduroy-like ventral ridges.) Official functions occur on dates that resemble corduroy, like 1/11 and 11/11; a membership card and pin are available online for $11.11. www.corduroyclub.com.
Yorktown, Sept. 8.

JETS' SECONDARY VS. STEVE McNAIR OR KYLE BOLLER Like the Ravens, the Jets have to prepare for two quarterbacks with distinctly different styles: Steve McNair, who sustained a groin injury Monday night in a loss to Cincinnati, and Kyle Boller, above, a fifth-year pro who threw two touchdown passes and no interceptions in his only start against the Jets, in 2004. Contrasting the two, Jets safety Kerry Rhodes said that McNair ''is going to hang in the pocket.'' ''He's not the old McNair where he'd take off early,'' Rhodes said. ''He's going to sit there and try to read coverages and pretty much be a pocket passer. Kyle Boller is younger. If he doesn't see things right away, he's going to try to get out of there and make something happen.'' The Jets cannot afford a repeat of what happened in their season opener, when 12 of Tom Brady's 22 completions for the Patriots were for gains of 10 yards or more.

LIGHTMAN--H. Allen, 81, husband of Irma, father of Timothy, Chip and Stacey, grandfather to Jordan, Matthew and Nicholas, son of Gertrude and Abraham, brother of Alyce, passed away September 9, 2007. He was president of Irma Shorell Inc., the prestigious skin care company he founded with his wife. He served proudly in WWII as a member of the 87th Infantry Division, fighting in the historic Battle of the Bulge and was a recipient of The Purple Heart. He attended Cambridge and was a proud graduate of the University of Miami Business School. He, not coincidentally, was a vocal and enthusiastic supporter of the Miami Hurricanes. Family request that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his name to the Alzheimer's Association.

PARISH--Elizabeth Myers, 94, of Naples, FL, died peacefully on September 1. Zib, as she was better known, was born April 24, 1913, in St. Paul, MN, the daughter of Paul N. Myers and Reine H. Myers. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) INSIDE THE LIVING BODY For anyone who has ever wondered what's going on in there, this one's for you. Using high-definition film footage taken by endoscopic cameras, this two-hour special traverses the mouth, throat, heart, lungs, digestive tract, blood vessels, brain and reproductive organs to show saliva spurting in the mouth, food dropping into the stomach from the esophagus, yellow fat lining the abdomen and an egg getting ready to erupt from an ovary. The show also combines computer-generated images with powerful scientific technology to depict processes like nerve signals traveling through synapses in the brain, and eardrums vibrating against the ossicle bones (above, an ear canal). More than 200 experts in 45 fields of medicine from 54 institutions explain it all in, um, human terms. 8 P.M. (Fox) THE 59TH PRIMETIME EMMY AWARDS Ryan Seacrest is host of this year's ceremony honoring excellence in television programming, broadcast live from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Presenters include Steve Carell, Kyle Chandler, the cast of ''Entourage,'' Kelsey Grammer, Patricia Heaton, Katherine Heigl, Hayden Panettiere, Jimmy Smits, Jon Stewart, Kiefer Sutherland and Kate Walsh. Tony Bennett and Christina Aguilera will trip the light fantastic in their duet, ''Steppin' Out With My Baby,'' choreographed by Rob Marshall and John DeLuca. The Broadway cast of ''Jersey Boys'' will pay musical tribute to ''The Sopranos.'' And the ceremony even goes green: A solar-panel canopy will be installed over the red carpet grandstands, supposedly reducing the carbon footprint of the Emmys. Pre-ceremony shows include E!'s ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' at 4, and ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6, and Fox's ''Countdown to the Emmys'' at 7. E! will also show ''Live 2007 Primetime Emmy Awards Post Show'' at 11.

MATHIAS KIWANUKA VS. GREEN BAY'S TIGHT ENDS If Jared Lorenzen makes his first start at quarterback for the Giants, in place of the sore-shouldered Eli Manning, he is the game's key. The Packers will blitz him mercilessly, knowing that Lorenzen is slow-footed and inexperienced. But the other intriguing matchup features Kiwanuka, who struggled in pass coverage -- as the Giants expected and feared -- in his first game since moving to linebacker from defensive end during the off-season. Last week, the Cowboys and quarterback Tony Romo found open spaces down the middle of the field with midrange passes. Six of those passes went to tight end Jason Witten, for 116 yards and a touchdown. Kiwanuka's play was suspect enough that, in the wake of a knee injury to defensive end Osi Umenyiora, the Giants considered moving Kiwanuka back to end this week. The Packers have a three-time Pro Bowl tight end in Bubba Franks, now a backup to Donald Lee. The two combined for 6 catches and 44 yards in a victory over the Eagles last Sunday.

Authorial confusion has been around forever. At some point, no doubt, the Greek lyric poet Simonides of Ceos was approached at a party by someone claiming to absolutely adore his verse on the nature of women. An uneasy silence ensued, perhaps a polite smile, before the writer explained that the man must be thinking of Semonides of Amorgos. Keeping authors straight these days is even tougher, so we've put together a handy if incomplete guide. Some of these literary hotshots have obvious differences; others you probably never realized were two separate people. Shrink this down, glue it to the back of your cocktail napkin and avoid all sorts of humiliating mix-ups.

If trends aren't your thing, invest in fashion that's (hand-) built to last. We break down the luxury labor costs. Berluti's bespoke shoes can cost up to $90,000, which makes the $4,500 starter model a bargain, considering that each pair takes 80 hours to fabricate. Cost per hour: $56.25. There are two individually cut, hand-sewn layers of fabric in Thom Browne's cotton piqué and lace coat. It will set you back $12,000, but it set back the seamstresses 240 hours. Cost per hour: $50.

SHOPPING IN A VINTAGE CLOTHING STORE, APRIL 23, 2007 Stacy Jordan, 21, an acting student in New York, originally from Honolulu: ''I was studying in Florence, and I met my dear friend in Paris. Another friend who was studying there at the time took us to this old hair salon turned vintage store. My friend and I went crazy; we love secondhand shopping. The photo makes me laugh, because it is clear to me that I am posing for the camera. I was conscious of the other people while the photo was being taken, which made me a bit self-conscious. I love posing, but I remember feeling like I looked silly and like I wasn't sure what to do.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

There's no shortage of snooze aids out there, but most of them don't take into account how we wake up. Enter Zyken's NightCove, a sleep-rhythm alarm clock that caresses you awake. This futuristic box creates light combinations of varying color, wavelength and intensity. A dusklike amber glow darkens at bedtime; short pulses of white and blue light gradually awaken you come morning. The device also features an array of original sounds, as well as a connection to an MP3 player on the off chance that you need to be roused by a 30-piece orchestra. About $2,500; go to www.zyken.com.

GALLUP--Kingsley H. Died peacefully at her home in Princeton, NJ on Saturday, September 8, age 70, from complications related to breast cancer. She is survived by her husband, George, children Alison and George of Knoxville, TN, and Kingsley and granddaughter, Daisy, from Durango, CO. She is also survived by her mother, Kingsley K. Hubby, of Old Black Point, CT, brothers Nicholas Hubby of Ogunquit, ME, Frank B. Hubby of Savannah, GA, and sister, Alison Hoversten of Vail and Denver, CO. Kingsley, also called ''Kinny'', attended Miss Fine's School, Princeton, NJ, The Lennox School, NYC and Bennett College, Millbrook, NY. Kinny was a talented figure skater in her youth and was the Senior Lady Champion of the Princeton Skating Club. She served a term as the President of the Board of Trustees of the Mercer Council on Alcoholism. Over the last 20 years, she and her husband, George, facilitated small bible study groups at their home and spoke at numerous churches around the country on this form of ministry. She played a major role with George in developing and managing the George H. Gallup International Institute, a non-profit organization, founded in 1988. The Institute was created by the Gallup family in honor of George's father, Dr. George Gallup, founder of The Gallup Poll. The mission of the Institute is to ''discover, test, and implement new ideas for society''. A person of great charm, grace and beauty, Kinny's priorities were God, family, and friends. Faced with a deadly illness eight years ago, she made the decision to be a witness to the power of the Lord in her life. She spent her remaining years in heartfelt service to others. A memorial service will be held at the University of Princeton Chapel on Friday, September 21 at 10:00am. Donations may be given to the Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania, Development Office, 3535 Market Street, Suite 730, Philadelphia, PA. 19104; to the Trinity School for Ministry, 311 Eleventh Street, Ambridge, PA. 15003; or to the Battle Against Hunger, St. Matthew's Church, 300 South Main Street, Pennington, NJ 08534.

Fresh from the Paris haute couture: designers' most spectacular flights of fantasy, grounded by a street-smart attitude.

1. The Australian ex-pro surfer Mic Eaton started Material Boy by altering the surf gear sent to him by sponsors. Recently, his aesthetic has evolved into psychedelic animation -- oversize vests and MC Hammer pants come in cornea-burning prints. At Seven New York and Surface to Air in Paris. 2. A highlight of Tokyo fashion week, Attachment hits New York this fall. The designer (and Issey Miyake alum) Kazuyuki Kumagai loves moody Japanese minimalism, with an emphasis on fabric innovation -- he's been known to make his own thread. At Atelier New York.

Designers have lost it at the movies. Junya Watanabe's black leather jackets could have been worn by the Terminator-turned-Governator (albeit in extra-large); Dolce & Gabbana's tux-and-spacesuit combos belonged on the set of the James Bond classic ''Moonraker.'' David Bowie's ''The Man Who Fell to Earth'' landed three decades later on the Louis Vuitton runway, in slicked-back spray-paint-orange hair. Alexander McQueen sent out a legion of android businessmen with Max Headroom hairdos, while John Galliano's futuristic ninja-meets-samurai fantasy featured woolly oil-stained warriors reminiscent of Mad Max. Even Dsquared's pumped-up gym jocks came out wielding baseball bats, chains and flak jackets -- dead ringers for Snake Plissken, the lead character in John Carpenter's epic dystopia ''Escape From New York.'' The eye patch is up to you.

GROSSMAN--Earle H. Died Wednesday September 12th. Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Born in Brooklyn, April 30th, 1923. He was president of the B'nai Brith Masonic Lodge District 1. He was also president of the Seawane Country Club in Hewlett Harbor, NY. The world has last one of the good guys. We express our deepest sympathies and share in your sorrow. We only hope that we can be there for you, Joan, and your family the way Earle was there for our family. Judy Walker The Feinstein Family The Karson Family

The News Three out of four workers drove to their jobs by themselves in 2006, according to another finding by the Census Bureau. Behind the News Only about 11 percent shared a ride and just 5 percent took public transportation. Commutes averaged 25 minutes, though New Yorkers spent an average of 31 minutes getting to work while folks in North Dakota made it in 15 minutes. Despite computers, fax machines, personal digital assistants and good old cellphones, just 4 percent worked at home.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has preached a doctrine of fiscal responsibility, but he has been presiding over one of the greatest expansions of city government since the John V. Lindsay administration, fueled by an extraordinary surge in real estate revenues, Diane Cardwell reports in a front-page article. The Times reviewed city data going back to 1980 and found that the city budget, adjusted for inflation, has grown by 23 percent, to $60 billion, since Mr. Bloomberg took office in 2002, compared with 8 percent during Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s eight years; 4 percent under Mayor David N. Dinkins’s four years; and 19 percent during the last two terms of Mayor Edward I. Koch.About 75 percent of the growth under Mr. Bloomberg has been driven by expenses that are difficult to control, like employee health care costs and benefits, pension payments and Medicaid. Even so, Mr. Bloomberg has increased spending on controllable expenses, like parks, information technology and schools. The number of city workers has declined by about 1 percent since Mr. Bloomberg took office, but he has been increasing the staff of late. Mr. Bloomberg’s aides argued that their approach has been restrained and that the mayor’s investment in services has helped the city thrive.

The demise of the independent bookstore is a lament often heard among New Yorkers — and the lament has gotten louder over the past year or so.Last year, Coliseum Books, which opened at 57th Street and Broadway in 1974 and moved to West 42nd Street in 2002, filed for bankruptcy protection, then closed its doors for good. The same month that Coliseum Books closed, Murder Ink, a mystery bookstore on the Upper West Side, announced that it, too, was shutting down, a victim of high rents. The store’s owner, Jay Pearsall, wrote an elegy about the store’s demise.

About 94 percent of the more than 3,300 restaurants inspected between July 1 and Sept. 1 had switched to spreads and oils free of artificial trans fat, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced today. The first phase of the city’s two-step ban on trans fats took effect on July 1, but there has been a three-month grace period for restaurants to comply. On Oct. 1, the grace period ends and restaurants caught using trans fats will be subject to fines starting at $200.

Taking the subway or bus is already one of the greener things you can do, according to environmental advocates and experts on climate change. But whether the Metropolitan Transportation Authority does enough to minimize harmful effects on the environment is a different question. Today, the M.T.A. announced the creation of a Sustainability Commission to develop an environmental master plan for the agency by the next Earth Day — April 22, 2008.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg held a news conference under the Brooklyn Bridge today to call on Congress to pass a bill that would allow the Justice Department to block gun sales to people who appear on the federal government’s terrorist watch lists.The bill, sponsored by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Representative Peter T. King, Republican from Long Island, has the support of the Justice Department. But gun control of any kind remains a touchy issue in Washington, where many of the new Democrats in Congress last year were elected on pro-gun stances. Michael Luo of The Times described the bill when it was proposed in April.
What we’re reading on the local blogs…

Assemblyman James F. Brennan, Democrat of Brooklyn, has teamed up with an expert on energy regulation to argue that New Yorkers have paid a high price for the state’s decision to deregulate New York’s wholesale electricity market beginning in late 1999 and early 2000.Gov. George E. Pataki led the deregulation push, in which most of the state utilities, including Consolidated Edison, sold their power plants to independent companies, then brought power on unregulated wholesale markets. But instead of lower prices, New Yorkers have faced increases far larger than consumers in states that kept their power industries regulated, according to a study by Marilyn Showalter of Power in the Public Interest, which oppose energy deregulation. The new figures may provide momentum to members of the Legislature who are interested in re-regulating the power markets in New York.

Last week, it seemed odd that news about the ever-decreasing options of Iraqi refugees came from United Nations officials in Syria, where stricter visa rules commenced, and not Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker, who had the remainder of the limelight absorbed by General David Petraeus in Washington. The forty-five senators asking questions during hearings focused on troop cuts and progress on the military and political tracks.
Steph Jespersen, the director of advertising acceptability,  is answering questions Sept. 17-21.
On Monday, debt investors are expected to flock to New York's Pierre Hotel to find out more about the first sale of loans related to First Data's buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

The thing about having eight months off between college football seasons is that there's enough time for hype to be mistaken for reality, for people to think that teams that look good on paper will look great on the field.
Evercore Partners doesn't seem to be letting the credit crunch get in the way of its hiring plans.

Young British fashion has become infectious. In addition to Christopher Kane and Marios Schwab, who had a brilliant show this morning, there are new talents like Louise Gray, Danielle Scutt and Louise Goldin. I arrived in London early yesterday, parked my bags in South Ken, and took a taxi ($36) to Bloomsbury Square, where Topshop has a sponsored venue. I thought Goldin's knit minidresses and tunics, in swirling patterns, were amazing (she's 27 years old), and the shapes were just right for spring. Todd Lynn's pantsuits were needle-thin and elegant. This morning Schwab sent out dresses that attempted to duplicate body imagery in their blurry digitalized prints and wire-enhanced drapes and folds. Everything seems directed to the young and new here. What's a socialite?

Utah's stunning 44-6 rout of U.C.L.A. was the biggest surprise of the weekend. As Lya Wodraska of the Salt Lake Tribune reports, the Utes are hoping to use the upset victory as a springboard for success.
David Ortiz had just popped out off Mariano Rivera with the bases loaded to allow the Yankees to hustle out of Fenway Park with a 4-3 victory over the Red Sox on Sunday night.
The Boston Globe
Policy speeches on health care, economic and labor issues will dominate the campaign trail today, especially on the Democratic side.

After much speculation that conservative hero and liberal bete noir Ted Olson would be tabbed to replace Alberto Gonzales as attorney general, it seems the Bush administration has chosen a nominee with a far lower profile: Michael B. Mukasey, a former federal judge from New York who has presided over several high-profile terrorism trials.
Twenty words from Alan Greenspan's memoir of a career that ended at the top of the Federal Reserve streaked across the Web on Saturday like the bullet that preceded the smoking gun:
A list of winners for the 2007 Emmy Awards.

The shoe retailer Finish Line, which is taking a closer look at its decision to acquire Genesco, the shoe and hat retailer, said on Friday that the bank providing the funds for the purchase is also taking another look.

European acquirers nearly doubled their spending on North American technology companies in the first half of 2007, a boon for investment bankers that advise on trans-Atlantic transactions, The 451 Group reported.

Chris Albrecht, the former chief executive of HBO who helped develop hits like "The Sopranos" and "Sex and the City," is planning to join IMG, the talent agency that has been quietly building an international broadcasting business, as the head of its global media unit, The New York Times reported.

One of the most influential business books ever written is a 1,200-page novel published 50 years ago, on Oct. 12, 1957. It is still drawing readers; it ranks 388th on Amazon.com's best-seller list. ("Winning," by John F. Welch Jr., at a breezy 384 pages, is No. 1,431.)
After spending last week listening to President Bush and General David Petraeus, members of the Senate now get their say on Iraq as the war debate returns to the floor beginning today.
ABN Amro's board said Sunday that it would not recommend either of the two takeover offers it had received, leaving the outcome in shareholders' hands.
Lehman Brothers on Tuesday will be the first of four big investment banks to report quarterly earnings this week, and its results are expected to get heavy scrutiny on Wall Street.
Major League Baseball's regular season is winding down. But the auction of the Chicago Cubs is just heating up.
Goldman Sachs's Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund lost 1.8 percent in the first week of September, extending the slide that led to last month's $3 billion cash injection.

In a stinging rebuke to the world's largest software maker, the second-highest European court rejected Monday a request by Microsoft to overturn a 2004 European Commission antitrust ruling that the company had abused its dominance in computer operating systems.
Soho China, the largest developer in Beijing's central business district, plans to raise as much as 12.9 billion ($1.65 billion) Hong Kong dollars in an initial share sale, Bloomberg News reported.
The planned initial public offering of Virgin Radio by its owner, SMG, is unlikely to proceed this year, Dow Jones Newswires reported.

It is not a good sign that the private equity giant Blackstone now expects to get debt funding only for deals less than $1 billion - a far cry from the mega-leveraged buyouts of recent years. That was just one of the points a Bank of America research analyst, Michael Hecht, highlights in a report from a meeting with the buyout firm's president Tony James.
Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, sold just over $20.5 million in company stock last week, according to regulatory filings.
Online currency trading site Oanda, which has effectively become the E*Trade for currency speculators and traders, hopes to expand by moving up the food chain in the banking world.
It seems Carl C. Icahn has found a new project.

The moribund private equity market stirred a bit last week as Kohlberg Kravis Roberts dredged up some buyers for loans to finance its $22 billion purchase of Alliance Boots, a British drugstore chain. But lingering investor wariness toward private equity maestros and their deals is far from the only problem facing the buyout business, according to The New York Times' Gretchen Morgenson.

Professionals associated with the alleged phony hedge fund A.R. Capital - including lawyers, accountants and the brokers that cleared its trades - are all in the legal crosshairs of victims of the fraud, The New York Post reported.

Depositors of a big British mortgage lender, Northern Rock, rushed to withdraw money on Friday after the bank, unable to raise financing because of the tight credit market, turned to the Bank of England for an emergency loan.

The troubled Canadian drug maker Biovail Pharmaceuticals brought back a law firm it recently fired to help it fend off charges that it improperly used documents in a legal battle it's waging against hedge funds and Wall Street analysts.
Magazines and newspapers across the country are building up their Web offerings in health and fitness as their specialized advertising dollars and readers migrate online at a particularly rapid pace.

The world's top cellphone maker, Nokia, said Monday it had agreed to buy Enpocket, a privately held mobile advertising firm based in Boston, but did not disclose financial details. Enpocket has 120 employess.
The SCO Group, the software maker that sued International Business Machines for copyright infringement, filed for bankruptcy Friday, 10 days after conceding that much of the case should be dropped.
CapitalSource confirmed Friday that a fund affiliated with Madison Dearborn Partners has acquired about 2.8 million CapitalSource shares through an open-market purchase.
Yahoo, looking to attract visitors and advertisers to its online news pages, purchased BuzzTracker, a site that ranks stories based on their popularity among bloggers.

Deutsche Telekom's mobile phone division, T-Mobile USA, has agreed to buy SunCom Wireless for about $1.6 billion, the companies said on Monday. Deutsche Telekom said it would also take on SunCom debt of almost $800 million and it saw synergies from the transaction of about $1 billion.
Leap Wireless International, the prepaid cellphone service provider, said Sunday that its board had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from MetroPCS.

The opening scenes of this new show give proof of intelligence, and the series might yet display that intelligence more effectively.

Alex, an African gray parrot with extraordinary cognitive and linguistic skills, died last week. He is survived by his trainer - Irene Pepperberg, a prominent comparative psychologist - and a scientific community divided over whether creatures other than human are more than automatons, enjoying some kind of inner life.

Levon Aronian of Armenia beat Peter Leko of Hungary in Round 4 to even his record at 2 and 2 at the world championship tournament, while Viswanathan Anand of India and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia drew their games and remained tied for first with 2.5 points each. More information about the tournament and the players can be found at the official Web site of the championship.

The Supreme Court today started hearing a case against the plans of Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to get re-elected while still in military uniform.

Plants reopened as scheduled, and a number of local unions told their workers to hold off on strike preparations until there was word from Detroit on the negotiations.

An article on Saturday about the funeral of a Sunni Arab tribal leader who had organized tribes to work closely with the American military in Anbar Province and who had been assassinated included an erroneous name in the list of those who attended the funeral. Brig. Gen. John R. Allen, the deputy Marine commander in western Iraq, was out of the country and was not present.

An article on Saturday about the funeral of a Sunni Arab tribal leader who had organized tribes to work closely with the American military in Anbar Province and who had been assassinated included an erroneous name in the list of those who attended the funeral. Brig. Gen. John R. Allen, the deputy Marine commander in western Iraq, was out of the country and was not present.
Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut said that a computer backup tape stolen in June contained sensitive financial data for nearly all Connecticut state agencies.

Kimi Raikkonen won the Belgian Grand Prix for the third consecutive time, beating his Ferrari teammate Felipe Massa yesterday in Spa-Francorchamps in the first race since Formula One’s spy scandal. The world champion Fernando Alonso took third ahead of his McLaren teammate Lewis Hamilton after an opening corner duel, reducing Hamilton’s lead in the drivers’ standings to 2 points with three races left.

Pittsburgh point guard Levance Fields was arrested early yesterday outside a nightclub after the authorities said he tried to grab an off-duty police officer’s weapon and was subdued with a stun gun. Fields was arraigned yesterday afternoon on charges of aggravated assault, disarming a law enforcement officer, disorderly conduct and public drunkenness and released pending a Sept. 24 hearing.

Jon Robert Holden scored with two seconds remaining in Madrid to lift Russia over Spain, 60-59, in the European Championship final. Holden stripped the ball from the Spanish center Pau Gasol, then pump-faked before his jump shot bounced high and in for the victory. Gasol’s jumper at the buzzer rattled out as time expired. Andrei Kirilenko, the tournament’s most valuable player, had 17 points as the Russians earned their first European title since they won as the Soviet Union 22 years ago. Holden, who has dual American and Russian citizenship, played for Bucknell from 1994-98.

Dominating the singles matches the way they always have, the Americans celebrated one of the most coveted wins in women’s golf yesterday, a 16-12 decision against Europe in the Solheim Cup in Halmstad, Sweden. Led by Morgan Pressel’s upset over Annika Sorenstam and Stacy Prammanasudh’s surprising win over Suzann Pettersen, the Americans went 8-3-1 in singles. They captured the Solheim Cup on foreign soil for only the second time.

George Hincapie took the individual title and his Discovery Channel team finished second, in its final United States event before disbanding, in the six-day Tour of Missouri. Ivan Dominguez of Toyota-United took his second stage of the tour in a mass sprint, finishing in 2 hours 37 minutes 13 seconds.

Lindsay Davenport won her first singles title after almost a year’s absence from the Tour, defeating Daniela Hantuchova, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, to capture the Bali Open in Nusa Dua, Indonesia. Davenport, 31, was playing her first singles tournament since having a baby in June. She eliminated some strong opponents en route to the title: second-seeded Hantuchova, top-seeded Jelena Jankovic and fifth-seeded Eleni Daniilidou.

The pole-vaulter Yelena Isinbayeva of Russia and the 400-meter runner Sanya Richards of the United States shared the $1 million jackpot when they won their events yesterday in Berlin at the season’s final Golden League meet. Isinbayeva cleared 15 feet 9 ¾ inches. Richards won in 49.27 seconds, the fastest time this year.

Samuel Sánchez of Spain won the 15th stage of the Vuelta a España in Granada, and Denis Menchov maintained his overall lead with a ninth-place finish. Sánchez, of Euskatel-Euskadi, won the 125.1-mile leg in 4 hours 45 minutes 59 seconds. Menchov was 41 seconds slower but kept the gold jersey with an overall time of 62:32:27.
A bill that would provide health insurance to four million children sets the stage for a battle with President Bush.
The president will nominate Michael B. Mukasey, a former federal judge from New York, as attorney general, according to people familiar with the decision.
“The Sopranos” won the Emmy for best drama series in its final season, while NBC’s “30 Rock” won for best comedy.
A tribute to Beverly Sills brought together her many worlds, roles and celebrity friends.
After white parents complained about school crowding, authorities drew up a rezoning plan. The results: almost all of the students required to move this fall were black.
The Justice Department inappropriately put pressure on a former state representative to consider pleading guilty in a corruption case, said his lawyer.
The Jets lost the game but may have found, in quarterback Kellen Clemens and receiver Jerricho Cotchery, the next coming of Chad Pennington and Laveranues Coles.
Tiger Woods won the Tour Championship, his seventh victory of the year, which also clinched the first FedEx Cup, the PGA Tour’s first playoff system.
Six Democratic presidential candidates sought to win over thousands of undecided voters who flocked to Senator Tom Harkin’s annual steak fry.
Landlords at a growing number of apartment buildings are finding it lucrative to replace long-term tenants with a transient clientele of tourists and other short-timers.

The Military Commissions Act created a separate, substandard and clearly unconstitutional system of trial and punishment for foreigners. This week Congress has a chance to begin fixing that grievous mistake.
In a speech on Monday, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will argue that U.S. foreign policy must embrace both realism and idealism.

Jason Elam, left, kicked a 23-yard field goal in overtime to give the Broncos a 23-20 victory against the Raiders. He also kicked a field goal on the final play to give Denver a victory in its opener.
The main union representing employees at The Wall Street Journal and the newspaper’s parent have reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract.
In their final meeting of the regular season, Curt Schilling outlasted Roger Clemens but couldn’t beat Derek Jeter, who drove a splitter over the Green Monster for the winning run.
Clint Bowyer started from the pole and led 222 of the 300 laps at New Hampshire International Speedway, in the first race of the Chase. Bowyer won by 6.469 seconds over Jeff Gordon.

Jim Thome’s 500th home run was a game-winner. He hit a two-run shot in the bottom of the ninth inning yesterday to give the Chicago White Sox a 9-7 victory against the Los Angeles Angels, becoming the 23rd player — and third this season — to reach 500 home runs.
State inspectors will be fanning out across Connecticut to check for safety violations on large commercial trucks in response to a crash on Avon Mountain.

Penny Taylor scored 30 points Sunday and the Mercury cruised to a victory against the defending champion Detroit Shock in the fifth and deciding game of the W.N.B.A. finals.
Derek Anderson threw five touchdown passes and Jamal Lewis rushed for 215 yards to lead the Browns over the Bengals. Cincinnati’s Carson Palmer tossed a career-high six TDs in the loss.

Nick Saban needed three games to get Alabama back in the top 25. The Crimson Tide jumped into the Associated Press poll at No. 16, its first time in the rankings since the final poll of the 2005 season.

“The Brave One” tops the weekend movie box office, “Eastern Promises” wins the top prize at the Toronto International Film Festival and more culture news.
“The Brave One,” starring Jodie Foster as an urban vigilante, outgunned the western “3:10 to Yuma” to end its one-weekend reign as North American box-office champion.
“Eastern Promises,” the David Cronenberg thriller, won the top prize, the Cadillac People’s Choice Award, at the Toronto International Film Festival.

Paddington Bear, the duffle-coated, marmalade-loving hero of children’s books by the British author Michael Bond, is headed for Hollywood, Reuters reported.
The Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its musicians have reached agreement on a new contract, The Chicago Tribune reported yesterday.
Both Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, and Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors have everything on the line in negotiations that continued Sunday.
Top lawyers for Microsoft and the European Commission are to learn whether the company has persuaded the court to overturn a record $690 million fine and antitrust ruling.

FED ACTION EXPECTED The Federal Open Market Committee is widely expected to lower the federal funds rate, either by a quarter point or a half point (Tuesday). Investors and economists will also parse the language of the Fed’s statement for clues about future moves.
Chris Albrecht plans to join the talent agency, which has been quietly building an international broadcasting business, as head of its global media unit.
The Mets made six errors, gave up 11 walks and hit one batter Sunday in a loss to Philadelphia that left the second-place Phillies three and a half games behind the Mets in the N.L. East.
The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News have been encouraged to be creative in their use of advertising, but the papers’ neighbors objected to one such promotion involving an inflatable honeybee.
Tonight 10 motorcycle stunt riders wearing sunglasses will ride for seven minutes on 288 panels of painted plywood covering the drill hall floor of the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Chan Marshall, who performs as Cat Power, sang a skittish set. Is it more appealing to hear that a product is selling at a 50 percent discount or to hear that it has been marked down twice, first by 25 percent and then by a further 33 percent? The two options come out to the same result, of course. But a paper in the Journal of Consumer Research reports that consumers tend to prefer the second option, since they often proceed by the flawed arithmetical process of adding the two sale percentages together to get 58 percent.
Weeks before Halloween, marketers, retailers and media companies are busily painting the town orange in order to satisfy consumers who are already in the mood.

8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK Just when you thought it couldn’t get any worse, it has — and the gang’s all here. This new season finds the tables turned as Michael (Wentworth Miller) lands in a security-free zone, if you don’t count the lone tower guard with a punchy trigger finger, among the worst of the bad in a Panama prison. Now it’s up to Lincoln (Dominic Purcell, above) to break him out. Michael has company, though, in his fellow inmates, including Agent Mahone (William Fichtner), who still has the killer instinct, even without his pills. T-Bag (Robert Knepper) has already ingratiated himself to Lechero (Robert Wisdom), the lord of these flies. And Bellick (Wade Williams) finds himself on latrine duty, clothed in only a diaper and a plastic bag. He’s hungry too. Thank heavens for that nice man behind the wall who keeps offering him morsels of something that tastes like chicken.
The Sloan Center for Internet Retailing is turning to a new approach to make its annual forecast for online holiday sales: ask everybody.
The New York Post is introducing Page Six Magazine as a Sunday insert. The title refers to The Post’s gossip page, but the magazine will be broader than its namesake.
Musiq Soulchild  has survived by redoubling his commitment to the adult-oriented (no, that’s not a euphemism) R&B that made him a star.
The American Contract Bridge League organizes three North American Championships a year. The English Bridge Union, in contrast, restricts itself to one major tournament, held each August in Brighton.
A new documentary sets Toots Shor’s rise and long, sad decline against the backdrop of 20th-century American social history.
Recently catapulted from relative obscurity to the shortlist for this year’s Man Booker Prize, Lloyd Jones’s “Mister Pip” is an improbably palatable visit to a pedagogue’s paradise.

The first day for homework is up to the teachers.

LANE--Alvin S. , died on Thursday September 13 in New York, age 89. Husband for 58 years of Terese Lyons Lane of Hanover, NH, and father of Mary Jo Lane Harris of Charlottesville, VA, and Judith Lane Mattson of Oakham, MA, father-in-law of Mark Mattson and Robert Harris. He and his wife were collectors of major modern sculpture and sculptors drawings which he has donated to the Chazen Art Museum of University of Wisconsin. Among the artists represented are Louise Nevelson, David Smith, Alexander Calder, Christo Arp and Claes Oldenburg. He was a partner in the law firm of Wien Lane & Klein for over 40 years. There will be a memorial service at the New York Harvard Club on Thursday September 20 at 5pm. Interment will be at Martha's Vineyard.

HEILBRUNN--Harriet . The Board of Directors, volunteers, and staff of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation wish to extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Heilbrunn family. The passing of Mrs. Harriet Heilbrunn is mourned by all, as we have lost a beloved and committed supporter of diabetes research. The generous contributions of Mrs. Heilbrunn and her late husband, Mr. Robert H. Heilbrunn, have undoubtedly helped in our mission to accelerate the pace of science leading to a cure for type 1 diabetes. Their steadfast support and devotion to JDRF will forever remain in our memories, and continue in their honor through the Heilbrunn Research Endowment Fund. Mrs. Heilbrunn's passion and hopes of finding a cure for diabetes will be remembered by all, and live on in those whose lives she has touched, and those who will benefit in the future from her efforts. The JDRF Family

The Firewall: R.I.P. For the last couple of years, William R. Cheswick, an AT&T Labs researcher, has been experimenting with ''Internet skinny-dipping.'' That is his colorful phrase for Internet computing without firewalls. It has worked pretty well so far, he said, and the solutions include encryption by users (which he terms end-to-end encryption) and the use of virtual-machine software to put programs in what he calls a secure sandbox.

DUER--Lucille St. Peter , actress and play write, 83, widow of W. Richard Duer, died September 14, 2007 at Oconee Memorial Hospital after a long illness. A native of Springfield, Massachusetts and a graduate of Fordham University spending most of her adult life in the heart of Manhattan, New York. Drawn to the city by her love of acting, Ms. Duer was highly respected for her skills in speech, voice, and acting. She taught at Stella Adler Theater, School of New York City, C.W. Post College, Columbia University, American Academy of Dramatic Arts, Speech Rehab Institute, and National Academy of Ballet and Theatre Arts, public speaking at Brandeis University, Screen Actors Guild, United Jewish Appeal, working with executive Vice Chairman for 10 years. Ms. Duer has preformed over 60 off Broadway and Broadway shows; Hallmark Hall of Fame, As the World Turns, The Defender, and Eye on New York. She was a member of the National Poet Society and the Screen Actors Guild. Surviving are three stepdaughters, Celeste Malott of California, Camille Greenwald of St. Louis, MO, and Monica Pennington of Beufort, SC; a stepson, Jeffrey Duer of Ohio; a brother, Robert St. Peter of Florida; a sister, Carole King of Taylors, SC; eight grandchildren, Samantha and Jamie Greenwald, Audrey and Trevor Duer, Vanessa and Austin Duer, Max Allman, and Alexa Mallott; and several nieces and nephews. Ms. Duer was predeceased by her parents, Edward J. St. Peter, Sr. and Adriana Andries St. Peter, two brothers, Edward St. Peter and Albert St. Peter, and three sisters, Jeanette Spagnuolo, Dorothy Harlambakis, and Alyce Stebbins. Funeral services will be held 10:00am Wednesday, September 19, 2007 at St. Michael's Cathedral in Springfield, Massachusetts. Burial will be in Gates of Heaven Cemetery. Visitation will be held 4:00-7:00 pm Tuesday, September 18, 2007 at Curran-Jones Funeral Home in West Springfield, Massachusetts. A memorial service will be held 4:00-7:00 pm Saturday, September 29, 2007 at 50 East Tenth Street, Apt. 2E between Broadway and University Street, New York, New York. The families are at their respective homes. Memorials may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 301 University Ridge, Suite 5000, Greenville, SC 29601. Online condolences may be made at www.thewoodmortuary.com.

HANLEY-COLLINS--Sharon Marie . The family and friends of Sharon Hanley Collins mourn her September 15 passing in East Northport, NY. As a daughter, sister, mother, wife and friend, Sharon brought a light and love to each life she touched. As one of the seven children of Jane and Charles Hanley, nurturing came naturally to Sharon. Her schooling at the School of the Holy Child (Holy Child Academy), set the stage for her life. There she met some of her closest friends, with whom she would travel the world as an adult. Before life took her to California, Sharon worked at Town & Country magazine. And upon her return to New York, she joined the family business, Thomas C. Wilson, Inc. as Secretary of the Board. Sharon's dedication her alma mater brought her back to the School of the Holy Child, where she earned the friendship and respect of her fellow board members. On November 21, 1998, Sharon wed Paul Gerard Collins, her supportive and loving husband, at Nassau Country Club. And on July 12, 2003, Sharon realized a lifelong dream of becoming a mother to Grace Marie Collins. It is with a heavy heart that her family and friends say goodbye. Her passing leaves a great void in the lives of all those she touched. Sharon's wake will be held at the Oyster Bay Funeral Home, Oyster Bay, Monday, September 17, 516-922-7442. Her funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, September 18, at 10 am at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Brookville NY, 516935-1880. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Sharon Hanley Collins Scholarship Fund at the Holy Child Academy, Old Westbury, NY, 516-626-9300.

SIMON--Joyce Shanock , passed away on Wednesday, September 12, 2007. Her family and friends grieve her death and mourn her loss. Loving wife for over 50 years to Seymour, loving mother to her sons, Robert and Michael, her daughters-in-law, Nicole and Debra, and her grandchildren, Joel, Benjamin, Chloe and Jeremy. She was a teacher, a travel agent, a passionate lover of books, glass art, music and the New York Knicks. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 23rd at 3pm at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name may be sent to Hospice Care Network, Woodbury, NY or any charity celebrating life and caring. When Joyce died, it was not her love that perished, and so say we all.

There is a primary election today in New York City, but most New Yorkers barely seem aware of it. At two polling places in Brooklyn, the poll workers easily outnumbered the number of actual voters. At Public School 139 in Flatbush, there were 97 votes cast by noon, said Ronald Holmes, a voting coordinator at the site. At the Brookdale Senior Citizens Center in Midwood, 45 votes were cast by noon, said Annete T. Benvenuto, a voting coordinator.At the senior center, the biggest commotion was about whether poll workers were allowed to eat their lunches at the tables immediately in front of the voting machines. Senior citizens, some using wheelchairs and walkers, passed through the collection of voting machines on route to a dining room, which was only accessible through the polling place.

Staten Island is home to one of the largest populations of Liberians outside Africa, many of them survivors of 14 years of civil war. Starting next month, Liberia’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission will collect testimony on Staten Island. In a front-page article, Ellen Barry recounts some of the experiences of war and violence that the Liberians have experienced, explains the process by which testimony will be gathered and examines the painfulness of memory.

Nearly 60 percent of New York voters who have read or heard about the so-called Troopergate scandal believe that Gov. Eliot Spitzer needs to be more forthright about what he knows, while 70 percent believe that the governor should publicly testify under oath about everything he knows about the matter, according to a new poll released today.The poll, by the Siena Research Institute in Loudonville, N.Y., suggests that the damage from a report by the attorney general’s office, which found that aides to Governor Spitzer had improperly used the State Police to try to gather damaging information on State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, is lasting.

Between 1996 and 2003, 225 New York City bicyclists were killed and nearly 3,500 were injured by cars. A new advertising campaign being started today aims to make New Yorkers more conscious of bike safety, with fairly striking — and surreal — images of bike lanes veering off the road and onto the wall or onto the hood of a car.

"I was born in 1953. It's only in retrospect that the political and economic environment of my youth stands revealed as a paradise lost, an exceptional episode in our nation's history."

Hola amigos! Greetings from the great state of Virginia. It has been a couple of months since my last post and during that time I have been on a couple of trips and even attended my 10-year high school reunion in St. Petersburg, Fla. It was nice to see some of the people that I have not seen since graduation. I received a very warm welcome from everyone. As it turns out, I am the only one who had a really good reason for having plastic surgery! But in all seriousness, I was very touched to receive a plaque from my class thanking me for my service and sacrifice to our country. They even had it engraved in Braille so that I can read it.

A long day of shows, a memorial to Isabella Blow, and the opening tonight of "The Golden Age of Couture" at the Victoria and Albert Museum. I left the V & A, staying only for cocktails and a chat, as Prince was arriving with his couture-coordinated entourage of young women. Daphne Guinness, her black-and-white hair swept up with feathers, had invited him, and she waited with Philip Treacy by the door. It was a small, very glamorous, mostly English crowd tonight, and somehow the clothes and the attitude reflected curator Claire Wilcox's wonderful exhibition. The show deals with the links between London tailoring and Paris dressmaking in the years 1947 to 1957, and of course there is a lot of Dior and Balenciaga. You see as well how thoroughly dedicated English society was to fashion.

For all those wondering whether Mitt Romney can break through among Christian conservatives, add this data point: he was the only candidate who received zero votes in a straw poll after last night's Values Voters Debate, an event he and the other leading Republican contenders decided to skip.

Goal celebrations are often over the top in soccer. Perhaps because goals are rare in a game that has traditionally placed a premium on scoring. Or perhaps it is a natural continuation of the game's artistry -- only because the ball found the back of the net does not mean the goal scorer is finished dancing, diving or flipping around the field. In some cases, it gives players an opportunity to show some love, express a political position, sell a product or show off.

Schaller, an associate professor of political science at the University of Maryland at Baltimore County (and, depending on which region you'd place the Old Line State, perhaps a white Southern male himself) with unrestrained glee, at Salon.
Facebook said on Monday its backers have created an unusual $10 million fund to dole out grants to start-ups with ideas for innovative applications for the social-networking site.

Lehman Brothers, kicking off a series of earnings reports this week from major Wall Street firms, said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell from a year ago, but not as much as many analysts had feared. The better-than-expected results were a potentially positive note at a time when investment banks' profits are being scrutinized for weakness amid the credit market's downturn.
Standard Chartered of Britain agreed to buy the banking unit of American Express for about $860 million.

A multibillion buyout of PHH, a vehicle fleet manager and residential mortgage lender, led by General Electric Credit and the Blackstone Group, appears to be on the brink of collapse because J.P. Morgan Chase and Lehman Brothers are threatening to scale back drastically part of the debt package for a portion of the two-stage takeover, PHH disclosed Monday.

On Tuesday, as the Federal Reserve's policy making board meets, the commercial paper market -- the market for short-term loans backed by mortgages, credit card debt and business loans -- which has started to loosen after almost coming to a stand-still, will be a factor that Fed governors will consider as they decide on a rate cut.
Goldman Sachs said an industry-wide private placement market is the best solution after it set up a proprietary platform and rival banks established a competing system.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division should establish written procedures and criteria for reviewing and approving new investigations, the Government Accountability Office said in a report published Monday.
Michael Eisner said Monday night he would not raise his $385 million offer for sports card icon Topps even if shareholders reject the deal Tuesday.

The United States Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., said Monday that turmoil in the world's financial markets could continue for some time. But he cautioned against the hasty introduction of regulations that could stymie innovation and slow economic growth.

Panicky customers of Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, have withdrawn 2 billion pounds ($4 billion), since the bank acknowledged Friday that it could no longer raise money because of the credit squeeze that has constrained global markets after a meltdown in the market for subprime loans in the United States.

Click "read more" to follow the play-by-play commentary of the US-Nigeria game, the final Group B match of the opening round, LIVE, as it is played at the Hongkou Football Stadium in Shanghai. Jeff Z. Klein narrates the action.
Defense contractor ITT said Monday it is buying EDO, an aerospace and defense company, for about $1.19 billion in cash to broaden its presence in other markets.

Candover, the British private equity firm, said on Monday it was withdrawing its 1.5 billion euro ($2.07 billion) offer for Stork, the Dutch industrial company, but that a new offer was still possible.
Sentinel Management Group, which filed for bankruptcy last month only days after freezing client withdrawals, has about $2 billion in assets, according to a filing in its Chapter 11 case.

For the oil giant PetroChina, a share listing in Shanghai will raise money for a new pipeline and refinery, among other projects. For coal miner China Shenhua Energy, it means cash for possible mine acquisitions abroad.
Idearc, operator of an online telephone directory, said Monday that it had agreed to buy Switchboard.com and other online properties from InfoSpace for $225 million.
Merrill Lynch said Monday it would cut jobs at its First Franklin Financial unit, a mortgage lender it acquired last December.
Despite already reaching profitability, a human resources software maker, Cornerstone OnDemand plans to grow aggressively with $32 million in new funding from venture investors.

Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp plans on Tuesday to announce it has taken a majority stake in the game developer GarageGames.com to anchor a soon-to-be launched gaming site, InstantAction, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Edgar Bronfman Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Warner Music Group, said Monday that the company has acquired a 70 percent stake in Taisuke, an artist services company in Japan, The Deal.com reported.
Newfield Exploration has agreed to sell all its holdings in the North Sea for $486 million to Centrica, which owns British Gas, the Houston company announced Monday.

The securities lawyer William S. Lerach is expected to plead guilty Tuesday to a criminal conspiracy charge in connection with a class-action scheme involving his former firm, now known as Milberg Weiss, according to The New York Times.
A bankruptcy court has given Bally Total Fitness permission to move ahead with a reorganization plan that will make the hedge fund Harbinger Capital Partners the new owner of the chain.

Yahoo said Monday that it was buying Zimbra, a start-up that provides Web-based e-mail to businesses and institutions, as it seeks to extend the reach of its popular e-mail service and better compete with Google.

NovaStar, a troubled subprime mortgage lender that has drastically scaled back its business, said Monday that it was giving up its status as a real estate investment trust because it could not afford the $157 million dividend it would have to pay to maintain the status.

Paetec Holding said Monday that it would buy the privately held McLeodUSA, which manages high-capacity fiber networks, for $492 million in stock, to compete with Verizon and AT&T in the business market for phone and data service.
Two fired executives of Penn Traffic, a regional grocer, have been charged with fraud, federal regulators said Monday.

Aired Friday night: The big story last night, President Bush addressed the nation with a speech about Iraq. Yeah. The speech aired on all three networks, and was secretly videotaped by the New England Patriots.
With the collapse of mortgage lender Northern Rock making headlines, two new reports aren't helping the mood of skittish U.K. housing investors.
Aired Friday night on "Jay Leno"
Senator Barack Obama may be relieved to hear that "Obama Girl" has a new crush.

Today, Indiana running back Bryan Payton visits The Quad to discuss how the Hoosiers have dealt with the death of their coach, Terry Hoeppner, who passed away in June after an 18-month fight with brain tumors.
The online brokerage lowered its full-year forecast, sending shares plummeting 8.5 percent in extended trading.
Women have suffered acute horrors — as the documentary “Lumo,” to be shown on PBS, quietly details — a consequence not only of the lawlessness that has plagued Congo.
A look at Achamore House, an estate on the island of Gigha, Scotland.
Properties on the market in Colorado, South Carolina and California.
The search for the millionaire adventurer Steve Fossett, who has been missing in Nevada for two weeks, was scaled back on Monday.
TAMPA - There's been a relatively recent trend in college football of jettisoning head coaches who have brought success to some of college football's, ahem, more remote programs.

Mike Shanahan has spent more than 20 years in the N.F.L., and Lane Kiffin less than one, so it shouldn't be a surprise that Shanahan, 55, has a few more tricks in his bag than his 32-year-old counterpart. It was Shanahan who called the timeout that erased Sebastian Janikowski's apparent winning field goal in overtime Sunday.
“The Age of Rembrandt” brings together the Metropolitan Museum’s entire 17th-century Dutch painting collection.

LAS VEGAS, Sept. 18 — Five new charges, including two for kidnapping with a deadly weapon, were added today to the six already lodged against O.J. Simpson in connection with what the Las Vegas police say was an armed robbery of sports memorabilia from a casino’s hotel room last week.
Other things being equal, a firstborn son may be the worst choice to run your family business, some experts say.
Of the estimated 7,000 languages spoken in the world today, linguists say, nearly half are in danger of extinction and are likely to disappear in this century.
The director of the Pentagon’s missile defense program said that a Soviet-era early warning system is incapable of replacing an antimissile tracking radar proposed for the Czech Republic.
Drivers who commute between New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are wasting more time and money sitting in traffic, according to a new study.
The Dow gained 2.5 percent after the Fed’s forceful move, which was intended to limit the damage from the disorder in the housing and credit markets.
The new architecture, code-named Nehalem, will use as many as eight processing cores, and offer better graphics and memory control processing.
Steve Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said the iPhone would become available to British consumers in November in an exclusive arrangement with O2.
A top House Democrat said that the State Department inspector general interfered with investigations into fraud and abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Top American officials in Iraq were setting out their vision for the U.S. troop presence to the British prime minister.
The future of remaining cases has been left in doubt as 14 more families have settled their suits against the airlines.
David Robertson is to lead the Lucerne Festival’s orchestra in two of its three concerts at the hall next month instead of an ailing Claudio Abbado.
Gen. Pervez Musharraf plans to run for another term but resign his military post if he is re-elected as president.
But a rise in vehicle and prescription drug prices pushed the rate of core producer inflation — excluding food and energy — up 0.2 percent for the month, a slight acceleration from July.
The announcement follows the banning of Blackwater USA, an American contractor, after  a shooting that left eight Iraqis dead.
The Yankees gained ground on the Red Sox in the A.L. East and extended their lead in the wild-card race to three and a half games over the Tigers.

Demetrius Jones, the Notre Dame quarterback who lost the starting position after a poor performance in the season opener, expects to play next season at Northern Illinois after his decision to transfer.Jones told The South Bend Tribune that he was stung by Coach Charlie Weis’s comments that the freshman Jimmy Clausen had been the team’s top quarterback but was not named the opening game starter because he was recovering from surgery to remove a bone spur from his throwing elbow.
Canada’s Conservative government captured a seat in a generally separatist region of Quebec during one of three special elections on Monday.
The game unraveled in the sixth inning when errors on consecutive plays and a mental gaffe by Jorge Sosa turned a 5-4 Washington lead into a 9-4 advantage.
Under a plea deal,  William S. Lerach may face up to two years in prison.

Because of an editing error, the article on Sunday referred incorrectly to a defendant in a terrorism case that came before Mr. Mukasey in 2003, when he was a federal judge. The defendant, Jose Padilla, became known as the “dirty bomber” — not the “shoe bomber” — after he was accused of plotting to detonate a radioactive “dirty bomb.” (Richard C. Reid was the so-called shoe bomber because he hid explosives in his sneakers on a flight to Miami from Paris.).
The Weekend Explorer column on Friday, about the East Village, misidentified the timing of the closing of Public School 64, on East Ninth Street. It closed in 1977, not in the 1960s.
The diagram with the chess column on Sunday, about the United States Chess League, was missing a piece. A Black bishop should have been at b7.

An article in some copies of Business Day on Saturday about negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors misstated the amount of pay autoworkers will receive if they strike. It is $200 per week, not per day.

An article on Sunday and a front-page article yesterday about Michael B. Mukasey, President Bush’s choice to become attorney general, misstated the circumstances under which Mr. Mukasey and Rudolph W. Giuliani worked together in the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. It was in the early 1970s, when both men were assistant United States attorneys; it was not during Mr. Giuliani’s subsequent tenure as the United States attorney.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about efforts by the Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center to compete nationally for patients misspelled the surname of the physician in charge of quality improvement at the hospital. She is Dr. Uma R. Kotagal, not Kotogal.
A television review yesterday about “K-Ville,” which had its premiere on Fox last night, critiqued the wrong episode. It was about next week’s show, not last night’s premiere.

An essay in Science Times on June 26, about a potential shift in the scientific approach to understanding evolution, misstated the source of a statement about the development of a complex eye through selection. And a correction in this space on Wednesday misstated the number of years it takes for the eye to develop. The statement came from analytical studies; it was not shown in computer simulations. The eye develops over a few hundred thousand years — not a few hundred.
A Dubai-based private investment company will create a center at M.I.T. to help students from developing countries hone their skills and meet mentors and financiers.

All the sheep on a farm in southern England will be slaughtered after blood tests suggested they had contracted foot and mouth disease, the British Agriculture Ministry said. The sheep are on a farm within the protection zone west of London that was set up last week, when a new outbreak of the disease was discovered and hundreds of pigs and cattle were slaughtered.
Ernest Koroma, an opposition leader, was sworn in as Sierra Leone’s president, hours after election officials declared him the winner of a tense runoff.

The Colombian police said they had dismantled the private army of Carlos Mario Jiménez, a paramilitary warlord who is awaiting extradition to the United States, by arresting 147 people believed to be protecting a major cocaine smuggling ring. Gen. Orlando Páez, who carried out the weekend raid on three jungle camps where the arrests took place, said the armed group was under the command of Mr. Jiménez, who is being held on a navy frigate off Colombia’s Atlantic coast while awaiting extradition.

Beijing church leaders will ordain Bishop Joseph Li Shan this week, a senior religious official said, filling an influential post that had been closely watched to gauge whether the government would consult with the Vatican on church appointments. He was approved by China’s 59-member Conference of Bishops on Aug. 28 and an ordination ceremony will be held Friday, said Liu Bainian, vice chairman of the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association. He said there had been no contact between China and the Vatican about the appointment “because the two sides have no diplomatic relations.” But the Vatican-affiliated AsiaNews agency cited Chinese Catholic sources as saying the bishop had received papal approval, while adding that other sources said they were not aware of it. Efforts to reach the Vatican spokesman in Rome were not successful.

Myanmar and Venezuela have “failed demonstrably” to do enough to fight illegal drugs for a third straight year, the United States said, but waived sanctions on Venezuela to maintain American aid for democracy programs. The 20 states identified as major illicit drug transit and drug producing countries in the annual presidential report to Congress were unchanged from 2006, but the administration said allies Afghanistan and Colombia had made progress. The report listed Afghanistan, the Bahamas, Bolivia, Brazil, Myanmar, Colombia, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Haiti, India, Jamaica, Laos, Mexico, Nigeria, Pakistan, Panama, Paraguay, Peru and Venezuela as major drug transit or major illicit drug-producing countries.
President Karolos Papoulias asked Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis to form a government, after the governing conservative New Democracy Party won close weekend elections.

Secretary General Ban Ki-moon warned that a recent surge of fighting in the Darfur region of Sudan could hurt next month’s political negotiations on ending the four-year conflict. Mr. Ban said he was “alarmed” that attacks were reported after the Sudanese government said in a joint communiqué during his visit to Sudan this month that it was committed “to a full cessation of hostilities in Darfur” in the run-up to talks, which are expected to begin Oct. 27 in Libya.

Barry Callebaut, a Swiss candy maker, agreed to sell its Brach’s Candy unit after weaker-than-forecast growth in the United States market for private-label confections. Callebaut, based in Zurich, sold Brach’s to Farley’s & Sathers Candy, a private company based in Round Lake, Minn. In 2003, Callebaut acquired Brach’s for $1 plus $16 million in assumed debt.

Exceptional growth in China and India prompted the Asian Development Bank to raise its forecast for economic growth in developing Asia this year to a collective 8.3 percent from 7.6 percent. The lender, based in Manila, also raised its forecast for 2008 to 8.2 percent from 7.7 percent, but warned that the region could face pitfalls, including volatile oil prices and the impact of credit market strains on the United States economy, an important export market. “This reassessment stems from the exceptionally strong performance of Asia’s giants: the People’s Republic of China and India,” said Ifzal Ali, the bank’s chief economist, who added that “the headline numbers for 2007 have also been lifted by faster-than-expected growth in Indonesia and the Philippines.”.

Nokia, the world’s largest maker of mobile phones, agreed to buy a marketing company, Enpocket, to gain technology for placing advertisements through text messages and e-mail. Nokia, based in Espoo, Finland, did not disclose terms of the deal. Enpocket, a closely held company, is based in Boston and was founded in 2001, Nokia said. It has offices in London, Mumbai and Singapore and has about 120 employees. The acquisition of Enpocket is expected to help speed Nokia’s push into the mobile advertising market. Enpocket can deliver personalized ads through text and video messages as well as via the Internet on mobile devices, according to its Web site.

The T-Mobile USA unit of Deutsche Telekom said it would buy a smaller rival, SunCom Wireless Holdings, for $1.6 billion to expand its network and cut costs. T-Mobile USA will take on SunCom debt of almost $800 million and pay SunCom shareholders $27 a share, a 22.7 percent premium to SunCom’s closing price Friday. SunCom, founded in 1999, operates in the southeastern United States and in the Caribbean; it posted second-quarter revenue of $242.5 million. The acquisition will expand T-Mobile’s network coverage in North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Georgia, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands, the companies said.

A top European Union court banned the Dutch chemical company Akzo Nobel from keeping communications between executives and in-house lawyers confidential. Akzo and several lawyers’ organizations were seeking to keep documents seized by European Union investigators during a raid of Akzo’s offices in 2003 from being used as evidence in an investigation into possible price fixing in markets for coatings and plastics. The Court of First Instance, the European Union’s second-highest court, rejected Akzo’s arguments on the ground that in-house lawyers were not independent advisers but loyal to their companies. Tim van der Zanden, a spokesman for Akzo, said the company was deciding whether to appeal the case to the union’s highest tribunal, the European Court of Justice.
